site_title: Hong Kong bans non-resident arrivals from 13 more countries due to Omicron
summary: Hong Kong has banned non-residents from entering the city from four African countries (Angola, Ethiopia, Nigeria, and Zambia) and plans to expand the ban to travelers from Australia, Canada, Israel, and six European countries due to Omicron fears. Non-residents from these countries will face quarantine requirements. Vaccinated residents returning from these countries will have to do three weeks of hotel quarantine. The ban follows similar restrictions imposed by countries around the world amid the Omicron surge.

site_title: ComfortDelGro in second JV with Engie to provide renewable, solar energy
summary: ComfortDelGro Engineering, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro, has entered into a second joint venture with Engie South East Asia to develop and manage solar energy solutions. The JV aims to electrify ComfortDelGro's vehicle fleet with renewable power and offer fast charging solutions using renewable energy assets. The company plans to install rooftop solar panels at three buildings, powering them and its automotive workshops, and offering solutions to its customers and business partners. This venture is part of ComfortDelGro's pledge to deploy 60,000 EV charging points in Singapore under the Singapore Green Plan 2030.

images.alt_text: Through JV company ComfortDelGro Engie Solar, both sides intend to electrify ComfortDelGro's fleet of vehicles with renewable power and offer fast charging solutions to drivers and public electric vehicle (EV) users through renewable energy assets.

site_title: Spacetech startup SpeQtral secures US$8.3m in funding round led by Temasek unit
summary: Spacetech startup SpeQtral has secured US$8.3 million in funding from Temasek's Xora Innovation, its early-stage deep science investment platform. The funds will be used to expand the company's presence, establish partnerships, and develop its terrestrial and satellite-based systems. SpeQtral's Quantum Key Distribution technology enables "computationally uncrackable" encryption keys, which will be used to secure data networks globally. The company aims to deliver tamper-proof encryption keys, addressing present and future threats brought on by advances in computing.

site_title: Omicron poses near-term risks to Asia as it comes amidst stretched supply chains, inflation
summary: The emergence of Omicron poses near-term risks to Asia's growth, but economists believe the downside risk may be limited due to high vaccination rates. Countries with lower vaccination rates, higher dependence on tourism, and lower fiscal and monetary policy support are more likely to be affected. The economic impact will vary across the region, with China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan maintaining a Covid-zero strategy, while Australia, Japan, and Singapore may face pressures on hospitals and intensive care units. Asia's GDP growth is expected to hold at 1.9% quarter-on-quarter growth for the three months to December, but risks may rise in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with further losses
summary: Hong Kong shares continued their downward trend on November 30, 2021, as concerns over the Omicron Covid strain impacted the global economic recovery. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.29% to 23,782.86, while China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose 0.23% and 0.35% respectively. The losses followed a broader global market decline, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Fauci says can't predict if Omicron will become dominant variant in US
summary: US top infectious disease official Anthony Fauci stated that it's uncertain if the Omicron Covid-19 variant will become the dominant variant in the US. He also reiterated that the US is unlikely to impose further travel restrictions.

site_title: Keppel Reit to acquire Grade A office building in Sydney for A$327.7m
summary: Keppel Reit has agreed to acquire a Grade A office building in Sydney, Australia for A$327.7 million (S$322.2 million). The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of 2021, with practical completion in mid-2023. The property, Blue & William, will increase Keppel Reit's assets under management to S$9 billion and its freehold assets to 32.6% of its portfolio. The investment is expected to enhance Keppel Reit's overall portfolio returns with an initial net property income yield of 4.5%.

site_title: Westpac to likely pay A$113m for charging dead people, other breaches
summary: Westpac Banking Corp is expected to pay A$113 million for alleged compliance failures, including charging financial advice fees to thousands of dead customers. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) alleged the bank charged over A$10 million in fees to more than 11,000 deceased people and distributed duplicate insurance policies to over 7,000 clients. The bank will remediate about A$80 million to customers and urgently improve its systems and culture to prevent similar breaches.

site_title: ByteDance backs Dubai startup building logistics chain to China: sources
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, has invested $10 million in Dubai-based startup iMile Delivery LLC as part of its $40 million Series A financing round, valuing iMile at $350 million. The investment aims to support iMile's plans to expand services into banking and telecommunications, and hire more engineers in China. The move is part of ByteDance's strategy to spur growth through its global products, including TikTok, which is increasingly acting as an online marketplace.

site_title: Travel sector sees recovery slip from grasp amid new coronavirus scare
summary: Airlines scramble to limit the impact of the new Omicron coronavirus variant on their networks, as multiple countries impose travel curbs to slow its spread. The latest outbreak deals a blow to the industry's fragile recovery, with analysts expecting the recovery to be pushed back by a year. Shares in airlines performed better on Monday following a sharp sell-off on the discovery of the variant, but concerns remain about future bookings, with some travelers canceling or delaying trips amid new requirements for arrivals to isolate.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as traders edge back after rout
summary: Asian markets mostly recovered on Tuesday, following a two-day sell-off fueled by concerns over the Omicron variant, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Sydney leading gains. However, Hong Kong was dragged down by tech sector selling and casinos continued to fall. Despite the uncertainty, major drug firms are working on a jab specific to Omicron, and China's factory activity picked up more than expected. The World Health Organization warns that Omicron poses a "very high" risk globally, while the Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell expressed concerns about the virus's impact on supply chains and inflation.

images.alt_text: Asian investors began edging back into the market on Tuesday after a two-day sell-off fuelled by fears about the impact of Omicron on the global recovery.

site_title: Australia's current account surplus hits record A$23.9b in Q3
summary: Australia's current account surplus reached a record A$23.9 billion in the third quarter, driven by high commodity export prices and strong shipments. This provides a welcome economic cushion amidst coronavirus lockdowns at home. The surplus added 1.0 percentage points to gross domestic product (GDP), helping to counter domestic demand hit during the quarter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.07 points, or 0.27%, to 1,514.64 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 572.53 million lots worth RM305.33 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 281 to 171.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence eases in November
summary: New Zealand business confidence eased in November, with a net 16.4% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, down from 13.4% in October. The number of respondents expecting their own businesses to grow also decreased to 15.0% from 21.7% last month, reflecting ongoing cost and inflation pressures.

site_title: Singapore shares regain footing at Tuesday's open, tracking global rise; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rebounded on Tuesday, tracking the global rise, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.1% or 4.13 points to 3,124.71. Investors appear less worried after vaccine makers Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson indicated a potential formula for the new coronavirus strain, limiting its impact.

site_title: SingPost's accelerated investment in FMH leaves little room for missteps: S&P
summary: S&P Global Ratings has warned that Singapore Post's (SingPost) accelerated investment in Freight Management Holdings (FMH) may constrain its issuer credit rating, currently BBB+ with a stable outlook. The investment, valued at S$112 million, will increase SingPost's leverage temporarily. If operational weaknesses occur, it could impact the credit rating, despite the company's efforts to maintain its stable outlook.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS expects Singapore banks to benefit from rate-hike cycle, maintains 'buy' on UOB, OCBC
summary: DBS Group Research maintains "buy" ratings on UOB and OCBC, expecting Singapore banks to benefit from the rate-hike cycle. DBS economists predict 2-4 Fed rate hikes in 2022, which could lead to higher net interest margins and earnings. The banks' strong capital levels and high earnings visibility also support their valuations. However, key risks include a slower-than-expected economic recovery and higher credit costs. DBS analyst Lim Rui Wen expects a potential writeback of provisions and higher dividends in FY2022.

site_title: Temasek-backed mRNA vaccine developer Abogen raises US$300m from investors including SoftBank
summary: Chinese mRNA technology firm Suzhou Abogen Biosciences has raised US$300 million from investors including SoftBank's Vision Fund and 5Y Capital to support the development of its potential Covid-19 shot and other drug candidates. This capital raise follows an August funding round that brought in US$720 million. The funds will be used to improve its mRNA platform with technologies such as artificial intelligence.

site_title: Australia on alert after first probable Omicron community case
summary: Australia is on high alert after a probable Omicron community case was confirmed, with a fully vaccinated international traveller likely infectious in the community. The traveller visited a busy shopping centre in Sydney while infected, prompting authorities to track close contacts and locations visited. All passengers on the traveller's flight have been asked to self-isolate for 14 days. If confirmed, it will be Australia's sixth Omicron case, with the country's national cabinet meeting to review measures to limit the variant's spread.

images.alt_text: Australian authorities said on Tuesday that an international traveller who was most likely infected with the Omicron variant has spent time in the community as officials rushed to track the person's close contacts and locations visited.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound, gain 1% as investors absorb Omicron shock
summary: Australian shares rose 1% on Tuesday, recovering from sharp losses due to concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its best day since early October, driven by gains in heavyweight banking stocks and miners. Despite a third consecutive monthly loss, the benchmark index rebounded as local currency recovered from Omicron fears. Tech stocks also climbed, tracking a rebound on Wall Street.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday, extending US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending US gains, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 1.12% or 318.09 points at 28,602.01. The Omicron variant of the coronavirus continues to cast a shadow, but investors are buoyed by a rebound on Wall Street.

site_title: Gold flat as cautious investors gauge Omicron virus impact
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at US$1,785.13 per ounce on Tuesday, as cautious investors assessed the impact of the Omicron coronavirus variant on the global economy. The World Health Organization warned of high infection surges, while a South African expert said existing vaccines should be effective against severe disease. The US Federal Reserve Chair, Jerome Powell, also expressed concerns about the new strain, citing potential price rises. Meanwhile, platinum and palladium rose 0.4% each, while silver remained steady.

site_title: China's factory activity edges up in November as power shortage eases
summary: China's manufacturing activity edged up to 50.1 in November, surpassing the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction, driven by easing power shortages and declining raw material costs. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) was better than expected, but analysts caution that factory activity may drop again in December as the government restricts output in high-polluting sectors. China's non-manufacturing PMI dropped slightly to 52.3, and analysts predict a slowing growth amid the approaching Christmas season and the approaching Winter Olympics.

site_title: APRW marks 25th anniversary by venturing into emerging sectors
summary: Singapore-based PR agency APRW marks its 25th anniversary by expanding into emerging sectors, including gaming and e-sports, fintech, and blockchain. The agency has worked with clients such as One Esports, MatchMove, and FOMO pay, and has established an office in Jakarta. APRW has diversified its portfolio and shifted its focus from local consumer-driven work to regional and global projects. The agency has also joined the Blockchain Association Singapore and has partnered with IPREX, a global communications network. With over 40 staff and 6 independent teams, APRW aims to continue its growth and expansion in the coming years.

site_title: US FTC orders Walmart, Amazon to provide information in supply chain probe
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has ordered Walmart, Amazon, and several major food suppliers to provide detailed information about supply chain disruptions, which may be causing higher prices for consumers. The investigation aims to determine if supply chain problems led to bottlenecks, anti-competitive practices, or higher prices. The study will examine the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on supply chains and the potential for large retailers to use their size to disadvantage smaller competitors. The FTC is seeking information from 10 companies within 45 days.

site_title: South Korea's Oct factory output shrinks most since May 2020 on auto chip shortage
summary: South Korea's factory output in October shrank 3.0% seasonally, its largest decline since May 2020, due to global chip shortages affecting car production. The annual growth rate rebounded to 4.5%, surpassing forecasts of 3.0% growth. The decline follows a 1.1% drop in September. The chip shortage continues to weigh on the country's industrial output, with auto production being severely impacted.

site_title: Japan's Oct output rises for first time in 4 months as supply snags ease
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 1.1% in October for the first time in four months, driven by easing supply constraints for automakers. This marks a smaller increase than market expectations and highlights lingering global supply chain disruptions. Auto production rebounded in October, with manufacturers expecting a 9.0% gain in November and a 2.1% gain in December. Japan's jobless rate fell to 2.7% in October, and the economy is expected to rebound in the current quarter due to a rise in consumption.

site_title: Cryptocurrency Omicron in frenzy over Covid-19 variant
summary: Cryptocurrency Omicron surged in value after the World Health Organization named the latest Covid-19 variant "Omicron". The virtual unit jumped to nearly US$700, then fell to US$152, before rebounding to around US$350. Created in early November, Omicron was designed to conserve purchasing power independently of market volatility. This is not the first cryptocurrency to benefit from real-world notoriety, as the Squid coin's value also skyrocketed before collapsing.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Yangzijiang, IHH Healthcare, BRC Asia, No Signboard
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks on Nov 30, 2021, include Keppel Reit acquiring a Sydney office building for A$327.7 million, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding proposing a spin-off for its investment segment, IHH Healthcare reporting a 77% year-on-year jump in third-quarter net profit, BRC Asia posting a 131% full-year net profit increase, and No Signboard Holdings reporting a narrower net loss. Trading halt was called for Manulife US Reit due to plans to acquire US properties and raise funds through a private placement.

site_title: UK services industry sees record cost inflation: CBI
summary: The UK services industry experienced record cost inflation, with costs rising at the fastest rate in over 20 years, according to a CBI survey. The survey showed a record 50% of businesses plan to raise prices and 25% expect pay increases of 3% or more. This comes as consumer price inflation reached a 10-year high of 4.2% in October. The Bank of England may raise interest rates, which could reduce pressure on businesses to pass on costs and workers to ask for higher pay, but may not address the underlying global surge in energy prices and supply chain difficulties.

site_title: Failure to deal with debt limit would 'eviscerate' US economic recovery: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that failure to raise the US debt limit would "eviscerate" the country's economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. She expressed confidence in strong economic growth but urged Congress to pass a $1.75 trillion social and climate spending bill to address the "childcare crisis" and support parents returning to work.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Powell warns Omicron poses risks to US economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warned that the Omicron variant of Covid-19 could slow the US economy and labour market recovery, and heighten inflation uncertainty. Powell also acknowledged that factors driving US inflation will persist into next year. His comments, made in Senate testimony, indicate growing concern about the economy's inflation outlook.

images.alt_text: The Omicron variant of Covid-19 could slow the recovery of the US economy and labour market, and heighten uncertainty regarding inflation, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said in testimony released on Monday.

site_title: Tesla's Musk highlights 'supply chain nightmare' in tweet
summary: Elon Musk highlighted the challenges of supply chain problems in Tesla's production of the Cybertruck, despite the company avoiding major hits from the global auto industry crisis. In a tweet, Musk stated that the supply chain has been a "nightmare" and promised an updated product roadmap on the next earnings call. Despite initial preorders for the futuristic electric pickup truck, Musk had previously indicated that production would begin next year and reach volume production in 2023. Tesla shares rose 5% following the tweet.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc chief Elon Musk on Monday pointed to the challenges stemming from supply chain problems on Cybertruck's production, even though the company has so far avoided a major hit from the crisis that has plagued the global auto industry.

site_title: Lego offers staff bonus after bumper year
summary: Lego, the world's largest toymaker, announced it will offer its 20,000 employees three extra days of holiday and a special bonus after a year of record revenues. The company reported a net profit of over 6.3 billion Danish kronor (S$1.3 billion) and revenues shot up 46% to 23 billion kronor in the first half of 2021. The bonus will be paid in April 2022, recognizing the hard work of Lego's colleagues during an "extraordinary year."

site_title: Manulife US Reit to acquire properties in Arizona and Oregon for US$201.6m; proposes private placement to raise US$80m
summary: Manulife US Reit is acquiring three properties in Arizona and Oregon for US$201.6 million, marking its pivot to high-growth tech and healthcare tenants. The acquisitions will increase exposure to these sectors, with a focus on Phoenix and Portland, and are expected to drive returns through accretive acquisitions. The Reit will also issue US$80 million through a private placement to fund the acquisition. Post-acquisition, the portfolio occupancy is expected to increase to 91.3%, and weighted average lease expiry will rise to 5.2 years, driving a 4.4% distribution per unit accretion.

images.alt_text: Diablo Technology Park is a 5-building collaborative office campus made up of flex-office buildings, while Park Place comprises 2 class A office buildings.

site_title: Messi claims Ballon d'Or for seventh time
summary: Lionel Messi won the Ballon d'Or for a record-extending seventh time at a ceremony in Paris, marking his first major international title with Argentina's Copa America victory in July. Messi scored 38 goals in 48 games for Barcelona last season and has played 11 games for Paris Saint-Germain, scoring four goals. He has now won the award twice more than his rival Cristiano Ronaldo, who finished sixth in the voting. Robert Lewandowski finished second, and Jorginho was third.

site_title: Never say die for nightlife industry as new entrants brave restrictions
summary: New nightlife venues in Singapore are defying restrictions by opening despite challenging times. Vertigo 26, Stay Gold Flamingo, and Honcho, set to open in December, are creating buzz in the local bar scene. The venues, which include a music-centric bar, a coffee bar with a cocktail twist, and a multi-concept venue with a social space, rooftop bar, and izakaya, are confident that crowds will eventually return as Singapore moves into an endemic Covid situation. Despite restrictions, these new entrants believe that now is the best time to open and are adapting to the new landscape.

images.alt_text: Wayne Liu (left), also known as DJ KoFlow, and fintech entrepreneur Amos Poh plan to open Honcho - a S$1 million three-concept F&B venue spread over 3 floors - at Ann Siang Hill in December 2021.
Stay Gold Flamingo founders Jerrold Khoo (right) and Bai Jiawei.

site_title: 1,103 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore on Monday; ICU rate falls to 51.2%
summary: Singapore reported 1,103 new Covid-19 cases on Monday, with the weekly infection growth rate at 0.69, consistent with Sunday's figure. The ICU utilisation rate fell to 51.2%, down from 57.4% on Sunday. Nine people aged 58-91 died of Covid-19 complications, bringing the total fatalities to 710. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 263,486, with 85% of the population vaccinated or partially vaccinated.

site_title: Thai finance minister says 2021 exports expected to grow 17%, most in 12 years
summary: Thai finance minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith expects 2021 exports to grow 17% this year, the highest rate in 12 years. Gross domestic product is forecast to grow around 4% next year, supported by 1 trillion baht of government infrastructure. The Bank of Thailand plans to keep interest rates low for next year to maintain financial conditions. However, the tourism sector remains a risk due to the new Omicron variant and fragile households with credit card debt.

site_title: Biden says Omicron 'not a cause for panic' as G-7 urges action
summary: US President Joe Biden downplays Omicron as a cause for panic, while G-7 health ministers urge urgent action to combat the rapidly spreading Covid-19 variant. Many countries, including Australia and Japan, have imposed fresh travel restrictions or closed their borders. The World Health Organization warns that the overall risk from Omicron is "very high" and that a major surge could put pressure on health systems and cause more deaths. Despite this, Biden says the US is in a good position to control Omicron's spread, and pharmaceutical companies are working on versions of their Covid-19 vaccines targeting the variant.

site_title: Tim Hortons China to open coffee shops in Metro's China stores
summary: Tim Hortons China has partnered with Metro China to open 7 compact coffee shops, called Tims Go, in 4 cities, expanding its store footprint to over 335 stores in 20 cities. The company aims to go public next year and expects its stores in China to reach 2,700 by 2026. China is the fastest-growing coffee market in the world, with per capita consumption at 5% as of last year, offering "tremendous room" for growth, according to Tims China chairman Peter Yu.

site_title: Oil pares gains, but ends higher after Friday slump
summary: Oil prices ended the session higher after a slump on Friday, with Brent crude settling at $73.44 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude at $69.95 a barrel. The gains came despite fears of a weaker demand due to the Omicron coronavirus variant, with analysts citing a potential overblown reaction. OPEC+ officials also expressed confidence in the market, with the Saudi energy minister stating he was not worried about the variant.

site_title: SBF Foundation inks MOU to spearhead migrant initiative
summary: The SBF Foundation, a social impact arm of the Singapore Business Federation, signed a Memorandum of Understanding with several organizations to launch Project MigrantWell, a migrant worker welfare initiative. The project aims to support the health and wellbeing of migrant workers, with a charity, welfare fund, and medical centre to be established. The medical centre will serve approximately 57,000 workers, and the fund will support niche care programs. The initiative was signed by SBF Foundation chairman Hsieh Fu Hua and Ministry of Manpower officials, with Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam as the guest-of-honour.

site_title: Not that '70s inflation - perhaps more like the 1960s
summary: The US is experiencing moderate inflation, reaching a 6.2% rise in consumer prices in October, the highest since 1991. Unlike the stagflation of the 1970s, the economy has recovered strongly from the pandemic, with a low unemployment rate and rising wages. The issue lies in supply constraints, including port bottlenecks and chip shortages, rather than insufficient demand. Monetary policy cannot ease these constraints, but they are expected to improve over the next year. Experts caution that moderate inflation may eventually build into expectations, but it is unlikely to repeat the mistakes of the 1970s, and policymakers are taking steps to address the issue.

site_title: Blended finance lures funds to developing world
summary: A group of world's biggest asset owners is proposing a significant escalation of joint public-private financing ventures to help developing countries transition to clean energy and combat climate change. The proposal, led by the Net Zero Asset Owner Alliance, aims to scale up blended finance models, which combine public and private money, to entice more private investors. The alliance estimates that developing countries need over $1 trillion annually to support the transition to clean energy, and the proposed model could represent a significant enticement for investors, particularly in regions with high levels of junk-rated debt.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia aim to expand land VTL to general travellers from mid-December
summary: Singapore and Malaysia plan to expand their Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme to include general travelers from mid-December, allowing 1,440 citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders to have quarantine-free entry. Discussions are underway to pilot a sea VTL, enabling port calls by Singapore cruise ships to Malaysian ports. The goal remains to have more open borders between the two nations, despite the Omicron variant.

site_title: Europe: Shares regain ground after selloff fuelled by Omicron variant
summary: European shares rose 0.7% on Monday, recovering from a 3.7% slump on Friday due to concerns over the Omicron variant. Travel and leisure stocks, including Wizz Air and Ryanair, surged between 1% and 5.5% after fears of renewed restrictions. Financial stocks added 1.7%, while energy and basic material stocks also rose. Investors bet the Bank of England may rethink monetary policy tightening next month, citing mild symptoms of the variant. The European Central Bank argued the euro zone's economy has learned to cope with successive pandemic waves, despite record-high German consumer price inflation.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound from Omicron-induced plunge
summary: US stocks rebounded on Monday, regaining some losses from the previous day after the Omicron variant sparked concerns about the global economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 1.3% and 1.9% respectively. Investors expressed optimism over the potential impact of vaccines and therapeutics on the variant, with Pfizer and Johnson & Johnson working on a formula targeted at the new strain.

site_title: BRC Asia posts full-year net profit of S$47m
summary: BRC Asia reported a full-year net profit of S$47 million, a 131% increase from last year, driven by improved sales volume and higher steel prices. The company proposed a final dividend of 4 cents per share and a special dividend of 4 cents per share, totaling 12 cents per share, representing 61% of earnings.

site_title: Singapore private homes aren't as pricey as they seem
summary: Singapore's private home prices, up 8% in Q3 2021, may not be as unaffordable as thought. With household income growing faster than home prices, and low borrowing costs, there's no froth in the market. Median household income has more than doubled since 2000, and with improvements in condo efficiency, smaller household sizes, and lower interest rates, private home ownership remains accessible to mobile young Singaporeans. However, buyers face higher transaction costs, including Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), which may impact affordability, particularly for those buying outside prime central areas.

site_title: Nissan unveils 2 trillion yen electric vehicle strategy
summary: Nissan Motor plans to invest 2 trillion yen (S$24 billion) over five years to electrify its lineup, introducing 23 new models by 2030, including 15 electric vehicles. The company aims for more than half of its sales to be electrified by then. As an early entrant into the EV market, Nissan seeks to use its know-how to drive growth, with the Leaf remaining one of the world's top-selling EVs despite Tesla's recent sales gains.

site_title: ASEM summit signals new European focus on Asia
summary: The Asia-Europe/ASEM summit, held in Phnom Penh, marked a significant shift in European focus towards Asia, with 53 partners, including 21 Asian countries and 30 European nations, attending the 2-day event. The summit aimed to drive economic and political competitive advantage, with the two regions collectively representing 60% of global GDP, population, and trade. European leaders, including President Charles Michel and President Ursula von der Leyen, emphasized mutual respect and equality in cooperation with Asian nations, signaling a new era of engagement between the two regions.

site_title: Wage recovery to put more stress on rising consumer costs
summary: Singapore's inflation is expected to rise in 2022 due to rising wages, despite external forces remaining the main driver of price increases. Wages are picking up, with private-sector firms projecting an average pay increase of 3.5% in 2022. Labour-market watchers attribute this to the pandemic-related border closures, which have led to a shortage of foreign workers and increased demand for local workers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and economists also note that rising imported and labour costs will support a steady increase in core inflation.

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo reassures firms after court rules against investment law
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has reassured investors that his government will ensure legal certainty and continuity guarantees amid concerns following a court ruling against a job creation law. The Constitutional Court ruled that the law's formation had procedural flaws, citing it as a potential game-changer for foreign investment in Indonesia. Widodo's assurance aims to alleviate investor jitters, following the ruling last week. The government will now focus on implementing the law while addressing the court's concerns.

site_title: US dollar wobbles on Omicron shock moves
summary: The US dollar experienced a mixed day in European trading on Monday, reversing some of Friday's losses after the Omicron variant of Covid-19 prompted a sell-off in financial markets. The dollar strengthened initially before dipping, while the euro fell and the yen steadied. Markets calmed as investors took a more balanced view, waiting for clearer information on the variant's impact. The US dollar index remained unchanged, and the euro-dollar 1-month volatility hit its highest since December 2020.

site_title: Encanto leads subdued North American box office over Thanksgiving weekend
summary: Disney's animated film "Encanto" earned an estimated $40.3 million over the Thanksgiving weekend, falling short of forecasts despite critical acclaim. The underwhelming box office performance is attributed to cautious consumer behavior, with total North American ticket sales reaching $142 million for the holiday weekend. This marks a significant decline from 2019's $262.3 million, with many parents hesitant to bring kids to cinemas and older film lovers opting for TV viewing instead.

site_title: Omicron threatens oil demand recovery, already hit by Europe's rising Covid cases
summary: The Omicron coronavirus variant is threatening oil demand recovery, with refiners' margins in Asia and Europe hitting a 5-month low due to travel restrictions and concerns over the variant's impact on oil demand. Oil prices plummeted 10% on November 26, their largest daily drop since April 2020, but have since recovered some losses. Analysts expect oil demand to grow 5.5 million barrels per day to 96.3 million bpd in 2021, but the new variant's impact is uncertain, potentially derailing the global economic recovery.

site_title: As world shuts borders to stop Omicron, Japan offers a cautionary tale
summary: Japan has closed its borders to travelers from everywhere in response to the emergence of the Omicron variant, joining other countries in taking drastic measures to stop the virus' spread. This move is a repeat of Japan's earlier pandemic response, which included barring tourists since the pandemic's early stages. The country's decision is seen as a cautionary tale for other nations, highlighting the potential risks and limitations of border closures in controlling the virus' spread.

site_title: Fauci says new US restrictions amid Omicron unlikely
summary: US infectious disease official Dr. Anthony Fauci said new restrictions amid the Omicron Covid-19 variant are unlikely, citing the effectiveness of vaccines as a top tool to blunt its impact. The US has implemented a travel ban on eight southern African countries to slow transmission, but Fauci stated no further curbs are imminent. Fauci and other health officials anticipate the variant's arrival and urge Americans to get vaccinated and receive booster shots. National Institutes of Health Director Dr. Francis Collins expressed optimism that vaccines will work against Omicron, citing previous success against other variants.

site_title: Robo adviser Endowus raises S$35m from new and current investors
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based robo-advisory firm, has raised S$35 million in a new funding round, bringing its total fund-raising to S$67 million. The investment is led by EDBI and Prosus Ventures, with new investors including Z Holdings and Wee Teng Wen. The firm's assets under advice have surpassed S$1.5 billion, and it plans to expand its services, technology, and staff, with a goal of doubling its headcount by end-2022.

site_title: Rise of Omicron variant underscores need to address vaccine inequity
summary: The emergence of the Omicron variant of Covid-19 has prompted governments to take cautionary measures, including travel curbs and mask mandates. The World Health Organization has urged restrictions to be scientifically based, but also warned that no one is safe from Covid-19 until everyone is safe. The variant's increased transmissibility highlights the need to address global vaccine inequity, which will continue to prolong the pandemic if not addressed. Under-vaccinated populations serve as reservoirs for new variants, emphasizing the need for expanded vaccine access worldwide.

site_title: Will rising home prices raise the risk of fresh cooling measures?
summary: Singapore's private residential market is expected to end the year on a high note, with rising home prices potentially raising the risk of policy measures to cool the market. Analysts warn that the perceived possibility of cooling measures could negatively impact the share prices of property developers with exposure to the private residential market. However, others suggest that policy measures could be calibrated or take different forms, such as wealth taxes, to mitigate their impact. The market's resilience has been driven by factors like low interest rates, liquidity, and demand for larger homes, but the en bloc market and potential interest rate hikes could pose challenges in the near term.

site_title: BP plans green hydrogen base in UK amid energy transition
summary: BP plans to build a green hydrogen facility in north-east England, starting production by 2025, as part of its strategy to transition towards cleaner energy sources. The 60 megawatts of green hydrogen expected to be produced will boost to 500MW by 2030, with the UK government providing support for the project. The facility will also become the UK's first hydrogen transport hub, with BP considering green hydrogen production at refineries in Germany, Spain, and the Netherlands.

images.alt_text: BP plans to build a green hydrogen facility in north-east England that could start producing the gas by 2025, part of a massive project to help the oil major transition towards cleaner sources of energy.

site_title: IReit Global bags new tenant for office space in Germany
summary: IReit Global has secured a 5-year lease from a German federal municipal association for 5 floors of office space in its Munster Campus building in Germany, increasing occupancy to 95.7%. The association, which employs 18,000 people, will take over the space after the existing tenant vacates in March 2022. The new lease extends the weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of Munster Campus to 4.9 years, improving IReit's portfolio WALE to 4.2 years.

site_title: Australia overhauls bank capital rules to withstand stress
summary: Australia's prudential regulator has overhauled its bank capital requirement rules, allowing major banks to set their own benchmarks starting in 2023. The new guidelines aim to ensure the institutions can withstand stress during economic downturns. Banks must maintain tier one capital ratios above 11%, slightly higher than the current threshold. The regulator expects banks to operate without raising new funds, as they are already well-capitalized. The changes follow four years of regulatory efforts to align with Basel III standards.

site_title: European energy prices jump with impending cold days expected to boost demand
summary: European energy prices surged due to forecasted colder temperatures, expected to boost heating demand. Benchmark Dutch natural gas and German power prices rose 9.7% and 11% respectively, while carbon futures hit a record. The cold blast is expected to ease throughout the week, but tight gas supplies and low inventories may drive prices higher if winter is particularly cold, prompting potential extraordinary measures to calm markets.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: London's Heathrow is considering increasing fees for its £10 billion upgrade project, amid rising costs. Indonesia has detained an employee of Trafigura in a US$17 billion graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, has been named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' citing slowing earnings growth in H2. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Supply chain chaos sparks fried chicken shortage at Japan stores
summary: A shortage of fried chicken in Japan's convenience stores, including 7-Eleven and FamilyMart, has been caused by plant closures in Thailand due to a spike in coronavirus cases. The closures have disrupted supply chains, leading to low inventory levels and delayed restocking. As a result, popular convenience store fried chicken, including Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC), is in short supply, particularly around Christmas. The shortage has sparked frustration among consumers, who are accustomed to buying fried chicken as a holiday tradition. The situation is expected to continue until Thailand's chicken production resumes.

site_title: Yuan rises to one-week high on corporate demand and as Omicron jitters ease
summary: China's yuan rose to a one-week high against the US dollar on corporate demand and easing Omicron concerns. The People's Bank of China set a midpoint rate of 6.3872 per US dollar, the highest since November 19. Experts say the Omicron variant won't have a major impact on China due to strict virus containment measures. The onshore yuan is set for a fourth straight monthly gain in November, driven by strong corporate demand and China's strict virus measures.

site_title: Singapore economy still on track to grow, despite Omicron risk
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3-5% in 2022, despite the potential impact of the Omicron Covid-19 variant, according to economists. The country's steady growth and high vaccination rates are expected to mitigate the risks, but a return to strict containment measures could slow down growth. Economists warn that Omicron's impact on international border reopenings and the aviation and hospitality industries could be significant, but the overall growth outlook remains positive.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend fall on Covid-19 variant fears
summary: Australian shares fell 0.54% to 7,239.7 on Monday, the second straight session, amid concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. The country reported its first cases of the variant, potentially more contagious than previous strains, putting reopening plans in jeopardy. The mining and tech sectors led a partial recovery, while financial and travel stocks bore the brunt of the selling.

site_title: Singapore and UK sign MOUs on digital trade and identities as well as cybersecurity
summary: Singapore and the UK have signed three memoranda of understanding (MOUs) to strengthen digital connectivity and cooperation, including facilitating digital trade, digital identities, and cybersecurity. The agreements aim to make digital transactions easier, safer, and cheaper for businesses, and support the growth of digital delivery of cross-border services between the two countries. The partnerships are expected to bring economic and societal benefits to both nations, and set a global benchmark for high-standards digital cooperation.

site_title: Challenges to sustainable financing in Singapore can be mitigated: Indranee
summary: Singapore is taking measures to mitigate challenges to sustainable financing, said Minister Indranee Rajah. The country is working with industry and international partners to develop credible disclosures, harnessing technology to enhance access to trusted climate-related data. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is partnering with the industry to develop interoperable platforms for green finance, while the Singapore Exchange is setting up road maps for mandatory climate-related financial disclosures. Singapore aims to issue S$19 billion worth of public-sector green projects and has issued its own sovereign green bonds.

site_title: Banking sector must prioritise building its sustainability talent pool
summary: The banking sector in Singapore must prioritize building its sustainability talent pool to address the growing need for green finance. Despite Singapore's strong global sustainable finance credentials, the industry faces a significant skills deficit, with 40% of institutional investors in Asia held back on ESG-based investing due to a lack of expertise. To address this, banks must develop and prioritize the right skills, including business and ESG acumen, and soft skills such as agility, communication, and empathy. They must also widen their recruitment horizons and collaborate with schools and universities to develop a greater understanding of the sustainability industry.

site_title: China's Xi pledges additional 1 billion vaccine doses to Africa
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged to donate an additional 1 billion vaccine doses to Africa, including 600 million doses donated and the rest jointly produced with African countries. This move comes as the continent grapples with the emergence of the new and potentially more transmissible Omicron variant. Xi also announced a $10 billion credit line for African financial institutions, $10 billion in trade financing, and $10 billion in special drawing rights from the International Monetary Fund to support African nations' economic recovery.

site_title: No Signboard narrows full-year loss to S$6.4m, revenue down 42%
summary: No Signboard, a Singaporean seafood restaurant operator, reported a net loss of S$6.4 million for FY2021, narrowing from S$9.8 million the previous year. Revenue declined 42% to S$7.9 million due to the prolonged pandemic and travel restrictions. The group's topline has been impacted since February 2020, with assets declining to S$11.8 million and liabilities increasing to S$9.6 million. No Signboard aims to preserve cash, keep operating costs low, and explore opportunities to strengthen its competitive edge and expand its business.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q3 net profit up 77% to RM550m
summary: IHH Healthcare's third-quarter net profit surged 77% to RM550 million, driven by a steady return of patients to hospitals and continued Covid-19 support services. Revenue and Ebitda increased 26% and 32% respectively, with key markets in Malaysia, Singapore, India, and Greater China showing improved performance. The company expects revenues from Covid-19 services to decrease and staff costs to rise as it strengthens its clinical talent and expands into new revenue streams.

site_title: Dorsey steps down as Twitter CEO, replaced by Parag Agrawal
summary: Jack Dorsey is stepping down as Twitter CEO, effective immediately, and will be replaced by Parag Agrawal, the company's chief technology officer. Dorsey cited his trust in Agrawal, who has led transformational work over the past 10 years, as the reason for his departure. Dorsey will remain on Twitter's board until his term expires in 2022.

site_title: Is property tax ready for the future economy?
summary: Singapore's property tax system, dating back to the 19th century, needs to be updated to reflect the digital age. The current system incentivizes investment in machinery for old industrial economies, but not those for the modern economy. The Victorian-era language used in the law disadvantages investments in cutting-edge technologies, such as cold chain and sterile environment technologies, and sustainable energy technologies. Updating the property tax system to encourage investments in deep technologies and sustainable properties is necessary to support Singapore's future economy and address climate change and demographic challenges.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares weighed down by Omicron fears
summary: Tokyo stocks ended down 1.63% on Monday, Nov 29, amid concerns over the new Omicron Covid variant, prompting Japan to strengthen border controls. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 467.70 points to 28,283.92. The broader Topix index slipped 1.84% to 1,948.48.

site_title: SIA pilots, crew on flight with Omicron cases under self-isolation
summary: Two passengers on a Singapore Airlines flight from South Africa to Australia have been confirmed to have the Omicron Covid-19 variant. Six passengers currently on a 10-day Stay-Home Notice are being tested, and one pilot and crew member will self-isolate and get tested. The Omicron variant has been classified as a "variant of concern" by the World Health Organisation, with five confirmed cases in Australia. Contact tracing is ongoing for airport staff who may have come into contact with the infected individuals.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open after Omicron-driven rout
summary: Wall Street's main indexes rose at the open on Monday, driven by investors seeking to capitalize on the recent virus-driven losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.34%, 0.74%, and 1.47% respectively. Twitter shares surged as reports indicated Chief Jack Dorsey's expected departure. The market's rally comes despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China sends warplanes near Taiwan after US lawmaker's visit
summary: China sent 27 warplanes, including 8 fighter jets, near Taiwan after a US lawmaker visited the island, defying a Chinese demand to abandon the trip. This is the largest sortie by China in over seven weeks, with a Y-20 aerial refuelling tanker also spotted. The deployment comes amid increased tensions between China and the US, with Lithuania expected to open a representative office in Taiwan next year. The Taiwanese government has avoided a formal declaration of independence, but China has ramped up pressure on the island, citing separatist activities.

site_title: From petroleum to cappuccinos, Thailand's PTT has bold Cafe Amazon plans
summary: Thailand's majority state-owned energy giant PTT plans to expand its international Cafe Amazon outlets to 1,000 by 2025, tripling its current global presence. The retail arm of PTT, PTT Oil and Retail Business, aims to become a global brand, with a focus on Southeast Asia and countries with high growth potential. Cafe Amazon, launched in 2002, has contributed 15% of PTTOR's operating profit in 2019 and 2020, and the company targets total Cafe Amazon sales of US$1 billion by 2025. This expansion is part of PTT's effort to diversify out of the high-carbon petroleum sector.

site_title: Omicron clouds recovery of aviation, tourism sectors
summary: The emergence of the Omicron coronavirus variant has cast a cloud over the recovery of the aviation and tourism sectors. Analysts predict a negative impact on international travel restrictions, potentially leading to tightened quarantine measures and delayed reopening of borders. The World Health Organisation's designation of Omicron as a "variant of concern" raises concerns about its transmissibility and vaccine efficacy. Experts warn that the Omicron variant could push back the recovery timeline by 6-9 months, weighing on the aviation sector and potentially scarring the industry's recovery.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip downgrades ThaiBev to 'accumulate' on slower recovery expectations
summary: Phillip Securities has downgraded its call on Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) from "buy" to "accumulate" with a revised target price of S$0.765, citing slower-than-expected post-lockdown recovery. Analyst Paul Chew attributed the downgrade to ThaiBev's lower-than-expected spirits volume in FY2021 and fragile consumer sentiment. However, CGS-CIMB has raised its target price to S$0.91, maintaining a "high-conviction 'add' call".

site_title: Migrant workers' healthcare: Bosses can soon buy primary care plans to cover medical costs
summary: Singapore companies can soon buy primary care plans for migrant workers, covering medical costs such as examinations, consultations, treatments, and screenings. The plans, costing S$108 to S$145 per worker per year, will be offered by four healthcare providers and can be paid in monthly instalments. Migrant workers will also pay a S$5 co-payment for each visit and S$2 for telemedicine sessions. The system, expected to be implemented in the second quarter of next year, aims to deliver healthcare in six geographical sectors, each with at least 40,000 migrant workers.

site_title: Singapore adds to its gold pile for the first time in decades
summary: Singapore has added 26.3 tons of gold to its reserves for the first time in decades, a 20% increase, according to data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The purchases, valued at around $1.5 billion at today's prices, took place in May and June. The move was not widely publicized to avoid influencing foreign-exchange markets and potentially affecting the city-state's exchange rate. The central bank's decision to expand its gold holdings comes after a period of relatively stable economic conditions.

site_title: India parliament votes to scrap farm reform laws after Modi U-turn
summary: India's parliament voted to scrap agricultural reform laws that sparked a year-long protest by farmers, following a surprise U-turn by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The laws, which aimed to deregulate farm produce markets, were seen as a threat to farmers' livelihoods. The repeal comes ahead of key elections for Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party, and farmers have vowed to continue fighting for further concessions, including minimum prices for crops and compensation for those who died during protests. The reversal is seen as a tactical move to avoid electoral losses.

site_title: LHN full-year net profit up 16.9% to S$28.9m
summary: LHN Limited's net profit rose 16.9% to S$28.9 million for the full-year ended Sept 30, 2021, driven by improved profitability in its space optimisation, facilities management, and logistics services businesses. The company also proposed a final dividend of 1 Singapore cent for FY2021. Despite a 9.9% slip in revenue, the group expects revenue contributions from its newly-acquired industrial joint venture properties and fully operational co-living properties in FY2022. However, the company anticipates headwinds in the path to recovery from Covid-19 due to global supply chain disruptions and rising costs.

site_title: Yangzijiang proposes spin-off and listing of investment unit to focus on asset management, direct investments
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has proposed a spin-off and listing of its investment segment to focus on asset management and direct investments. The proposed separation aims to create two independently run companies, allowing for sharpened operational focus and strategic flexibility. The spin-off is expected to be completed within 6-12 months and will realign investment portfolios towards growth-oriented investments, expanding the global footprint and diversifying the business. This move is seen as a strategic move to accelerate growth and create two well-capitalized, investment-grade companies.

site_title: BTS 'emotional beyond words' to play in front of fans again
summary: BTS, a K-Pop sensation, performed their first in-person concerts since the Covid-19 pandemic at SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles, playing four "Permission to Dance on Stage" concerts. The concerts, held on November 27 and 28, marked the group's return to live performances after a two-year hiatus. BTS member RM expressed his emotional response to being on stage again, citing the emotional impact of seeing fans and a filled stadium. The concerts come after the group won top awards at the American Music Awards, further solidifying their global popularity.

site_title: WHO urges countries to prepare for Omicron's 'very high' global risk
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged countries to prepare for the "very high" global risk of Omicron, a heavily mutated coronavirus variant, as it spreads internationally and poses severe consequences in some areas. No Omicron-linked deaths have been reported, but further research is needed to assess its potential to escape vaccine protection. The WHO has called for accelerated vaccination of high-priority groups and plans to maintain health services, while also launching negotiations on an international agreement to prevent future pandemics.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend losses amid Omicron fears; STI falls 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% to 3,120.58 amid Omicron fears, extending losses. The decline follows a similar trend in Asia, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi also falling. Aviation counters, including Singapore Airlines and SATS, were hit hard, closing down 2.8% and 2% respectively. Analysts predict the aviation sector will remain negative if Omicron becomes the dominant variant, citing restricted international travel.

site_title: Green hydrogen can cost less than 'grey' alternative, says EU's von der Leyen
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen stated that green hydrogen, produced with renewable energy, can already be cheaper than its carbon-emitting "grey" alternative due to high natural gas prices. Green hydrogen could cost less than 1.8 euros per kilogram by 2030, according to von der Leyen, who aims to make this goal a target for the EU bloc. This shift could enable green hydrogen to be used in heavy industry to cut greenhouse-gas emissions.

site_title: London: FTSE 100 rises after Friday's rout
summary: London's FTSE 100 rose 1.1% on Monday, recovering from its worst session in over a year due to concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant. Oil majors BP and Royal Dutch Shell gained 3.1% and 2.5% respectively, as crude prices jumped back from their lowest in over a year. BT Group surged 9% after reports of a potential takeover offer. The FTSE 100's gain came despite Amigo Holdings slumping 29% due to court proceedings over its rescue plan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.65 points to 1,510.57. Volume reached 6.127 billion lots worth RM5.195 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 790 to 351.

site_title: Deutsche Bank strengthens South-east Asia team with 3 key appointments
summary: Deutsche Bank has strengthened its South-east Asia team with three key appointments: Felicia Tan as director and team leader, Edmund Tee as vice-president, and Dita Darmawan as director. Tan and Tee are based in Singapore and report to Urs Brudermann, while Darmawan reports to Ingrid Widjaja. The appointments aim to further strengthen client support in the region, following Deutsche Bank's expansion strategy in South-east Asia.

site_title: Bright spots among Singapore-listed F&B stocks despite potential tightened Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore-listed food and beverage (F&B) stocks have seen bright spots despite potential tightened Covid-19 measures due to the emergence of the Omicron variant. Analysts point to F&B operators with a strong presence in heartland areas. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has hinted that Singapore may roll back easing of safety measures to tackle the disease. The industry remains positive about reopening plans, with some analysts expecting earnings growth to slow in the second half of the year.

site_title: Virgil Abloh, fashion's most powerful Black exec, dies at 41
summary: Virgil Abloh, a renowned Black fashion executive and designer, has died at 41 after battling cardiac angiosarcoma, a rare and aggressive form of cancer. Abloh was the head of menswear design at Louis Vuitton and founder of the influential streetwear brand Off-White. His death sent shockwaves through the fashion world, with tributes pouring in from celebrities and fashion designers. Abloh's influence extended beyond fashion, with collaborations with artists, athletes, and brands, and he was remembered for his innovative designs and his ability to break down barriers in the industry.

site_title: World economy will still face credit stress, price pressures, Covid-19 risks in 2022: Fitch Solutions
summary: The world economy will face significant downside risks in 2022, including credit stress from China's property sector, price pressures, and new Covid-19 variants, according to a Fitch Solutions report. Despite initial anticipation of a slowdown, the property sector's credit stress could lead to a sharper economic downturn than expected. Fitch Solutions warns that the risks are not to be underestimated, particularly with large sections of the global population unvaccinated against Covid-19.

images.alt_text: Credit stress from China's property sector could spread to the wider economy and result in a "sharper" economic slowdown than the world is currently anticipating, Fitch Solutions Macro Research said in its report.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close at a more than one-year low
summary: Hong Kong shares closed at a one-year low on Monday, falling 1.0% to 23,852.24, amid concerns over the Omicron variant and Meituan's weaker forecast following its largest quarterly loss in three years. The Hang Seng index also reached its lowest since October 2020.

site_title: China not inviting Western politicians who threaten boycott of Beijing Winter Games: media reports
summary: China will not invite Western politicians who threaten a diplomatic boycott of the Beijing Winter Olympics, according to state media. The country has not invited US politicians and will limit foreign guests due to COVID-19 risks. US President Joe Biden and Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson have hinted at a possible boycott. Russian President Vladimir Putin is the only major country leader invited to attend. China has repeatedly condemned calls for a boycott, calling them "malicious hype".

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Asian markets remained bearish on Monday, extending losses due to Omicron uncertainties. Singapore and Malaysia plan to expand their Vaccinated Travel Lane scheme to include general travelers from mid-December. Digital Core Reit aims to raise US$977 million in a Singapore IPO. ComfortDelGro entered a joint venture to start a logistics business in China. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.4% amid Omicron fears, closing at 3,120.58.

images.alt_text: Asean equity markets remained bearish on Monday as the spectre of new Covid-19 variant Omicron continued to weigh on sentiment.

site_title: New Zealand to ease Covid-19 measures this week despite Omicron threat: PM
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced plans to ease Covid-19 measures despite the Omicron variant posing a health threat. The country will move into a "living with the virus" system from Friday, allowing for more relaxed border controls. Auckland will start at red, requiring face masks and limiting gatherings. Ardern emphasized the need for caution due to the global situation, but acknowledged that a lot of evidence is still needed to understand the impact of Omicron. New Zealand will keep borders closed to most international travelers for five more months.

site_title: ABB partners Solar Philippines on 63.3 MW solar plant project
summary: ABB partners with Solar Philippines on a 63.3 MW solar plant project in Batangas, Philippines, making it one of the largest solar farms on the island. The plant provides electricity to 413,000 people in six municipalities. ABB provided the core Electrical Balance of Plant equipment, reducing on-site installation time and costs. The project is supported by the Philippine government's Feed-In Tariff scheme, and it is expected to contribute to the country's goal of increasing renewable energy usage. The partnership aims to shape a more sustainable future for the Philippines.

site_title: Britain to unveil new booster guidance as Omicron variant spreads
summary: Britain is set to unveil new guidance on extending Covid-19 booster shots to under-40s amid the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has restricted travel to southern Africa, tightened testing rules, and made mask-wearing compulsory. The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation is reviewing boosters for under-40s, with a decision expected soon. Even if vaccines prove less effective against Omicron, ministers aim to offer better protection and reduce hospitalizations and deaths.

site_title: Moderna surges after it announces that Omicron vaccine will be ready early 2022
summary: Moderna's shares surged 11% in pre-market trading after announcing an early 2022 release for its Omicron vaccine. The company mobilized hundreds of workers to work on the vaccine, which is ideally suited for adapting to new variants. CEO Stephane Bancel stated the vaccine's efficacy against Omicron is currently unknown, and shipping may take months. Rivals Pfizer and BioNTech are also testing their vaccines against the variant. Moderna's mRNA technology positions the company for future revenues, with analysts predicting years of future revenue potential.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks mark lowest close in nearly 2 months on Omicron worries
summary: South Korean shares closed at their lowest in nearly two months on Monday, November 29, due to worries about the Omicron coronavirus variant and its potential impact on the global economy. The benchmark KOSPI fell 27.12 points, or 0.92%, to 2,909.32. Despite no variant cases reported in South Korea, the spread of the new variant globally raised concerns, particularly about the country's strong run of exports growth.

site_title: Vietnam's Nov exports up 18.5% y-o-y; trade surplus at US$100m
summary: Vietnam's exports in November likely rose 18.5% to US$29.9 billion, while imports increased 20.8% to US$29.8 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of US$100 million. This is the 11th consecutive month of a trade surplus for Vietnam. For the first 11 months of 2021, exports rose 17.5% and imports by 27.5%, also resulting in a trade surplus of US$220 million.

site_title: Asian markets remain jittery, extend losses over Omicron uncertainties
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, November 29, due to concerns over the Omicron Covid-19 variant. Singapore's key index fell 1.4%, while Malaysia and East Asian markets also dropped. The World Health Organization declared Omicron a variant of concern on Friday, November 26.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital initiates 'buy' on ST Group Food with S$0.26 target price
summary: SAC Capital has initiated a "buy" call on ST Group Food Industries, a Catalist-listed food and beverage operator, with a target price of S$0.26. Analyst Peggy Mak believes the group's strong brand portfolio and plans to expand outlets in Australia, driven by easy-to-prepare food concepts and a central kitchen, will benefit from the country's rapid re-opening. Mak projects a net addition of 15 outlets per year and 70-80% sales growth per outlet in FY2022 and FY2023, with upside risk if the recovery turns out stronger.

site_title: SLNG, Linde in tie-up for carbon dioxide liquefaction, storage facility
summary: SLNG and Linde Gas Singapore have signed a memorandum of understanding for a carbon dioxide (CO2) liquefaction and storage facility on Jurong Island. The project, if feasible, will be the first in Singapore and the region, utilizing cold energy from SLNG's operations to liquefy CO2, which will be stored in tanks onsite and transported for end use. The facility aims to reduce CO2 emissions and support Singapore's decarbonisation plans, with a potential future expansion to handle CO2 from more sources.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near two-month low on Omicron variant concerns
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.36% to a near two-month low on Monday, amid concerns over the Omicron variant, with two cases confirmed in the country. This extends losses to a second straight day, sparking a broad sell-off, particularly among banks and travel stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit 7,180.3, its lowest level since October 1.

site_title: Gold ticks higher as Omicron virus variant woes boost appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,793.72 per ounce, boosted by concerns over the impact of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The Omicron variant's possible vaccine resistance and global spread of new cases led to travel restrictions and supported gold's safe-haven appeal. US Federal Reserve President Raphael Bostic expressed hope for the US economy's momentum, while European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated the euro zone is better equipped to face economic impact. Physical gold demand increased in major Asian hubs due to a retreat in prices.

site_title: SGX-listed glovemakers rally amid worries over Omicron variant
summary: Gloves makers on the Singapore Exchange surged amid concerns over the new, potentially more infectious Omicron Covid-19 variant. Shares of Medtecs International, Riverstone Holdings, Aspen (Group) Holdings, UG Healthcare, and Top Glove rose by 25%, 14.8%, 18%, 27.7%, and 21%, respectively, in morning trading. The rally followed global vaccine roll-outs and economic reopenings, which had previously pulled back glove maker share prices.

site_title: Digital Core Reit aims to raise almost US$1b in Singapore IPO
summary: Digital Core Reit aims to raise nearly US$1 billion in a Singapore IPO, offering 13.4 million units to retail investors at US$0.88 each. The trust will also issue 267 million units to international investors. The offering includes a placement tranche and a public offer. The IPO will provide a total gross proceeds of US$977 million.

site_title: China's Nov factory activity likely contracted at a slower pace: Reuters poll
summary: China's factory activity likely contracted at a slower pace in November, with the official manufacturing PMI expected to rise to 49.6, according to a Reuters poll. The easing of power cuts and a post-holiday production uptick contributed to the shallower contraction, but factors such as high raw material prices and supply shortages continue to hamper the economy. Analysts expect a further slowdown in fourth-quarter GDP growth, with China's central bank likely to move cautiously on loosening monetary policy to bolster the economy.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia reopen land border amid worries over the Omicron variant
summary: Singapore and Malaysia reopened their land border on Monday after nearly two years, allowing vaccinated travelers to cross. The move comes amid concerns over the Omicron variant, with travelers required to test negative for Covid-19 before departure and undergo an on-arrival test. The border was closed in March 2020, leaving tens of thousands stranded, and up to 1,440 travelers can cross daily without quarantine. Vaccinated air travel lanes also started on Monday, with Singapore having vaccinated 85% of its population and Malaysia 80%.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia aim to expand land VTL to general travellers from mid-Dec
summary: Singapore and Malaysia aim to expand the land Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme to include general travelers from mid-December, allowing up to 1,440 people per day to travel quarantine-free between the two countries. The expansion is contingent on the public health situation, particularly the new Omicron variant. Additionally, discussions are underway to pilot a sea VTL for port calls between Singapore cruise ships and Malaysian ports.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong meets Malaysia PM Ismail Sabri Yaakob during the launch of the land Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) between Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Inflation reached its peak in November: ECB board member
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) board member Isabel Schnabel stated that inflation peaked in November, contrary to raising interest rates, as price increases are expected to slow down gradually next year. Schnabel believes inflation will trend back towards 2% due to supply bottlenecks and energy price growth leveling off. She also mentioned that if inflation permanently exceeds 2%, the ECB would react, but there are no indications of this at present.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida says foreign visitors to be barred entry from Nov 30
summary: Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced that the country will bar all new foreign arrivals starting from November 30, due to the Omicron Covid variant. This measure comes after a brief relaxation of strict entry rules earlier this month. Japan has recorded over 18,300 coronavirus deaths and 76.5% of its population is fully vaccinated, but the government aims to avoid tough lockdowns.

site_title: Australia Q3 inventories to drag on GDP, company profits rise
summary: Australian firms reduced inventories by 1.9% in Q3, potentially dragging on economic growth. Despite this, company profits rose 4.0% due to government subsidies amid coronavirus lockdowns. The wages bill fell 0.8% due to stay-at-home orders in major cities. These findings may impact Australia's GDP, which was expected to fall sharply due to lockdowns.

site_title: Philippines suspends decision to allow vaccinated tourists entry
summary: The Philippines has suspended plans to allow fully vaccinated tourists to enter the country from December 1, citing concerns over the Omicron variant. The decision comes as the country launches a three-day vaccination drive targeting nine million people aged 12 and above. The suspension affects tourists from seven European countries, in addition to earlier bans from several African nations. The move is a major blow to the country's tourism industry, which accounts for nearly 13% of the country's GDP.

site_title: China's Twitter-like Weibo plans US$547m Hong Kong listing
summary: Weibo, a Chinese microblogging platform, plans to raise up to $547 million in a Hong Kong listing, amid rising tensions with the US. The move is seen as a hedge against being removed from US exchanges and accessing a closer investor base. This is the latest China tech company to list in Hong Kong, following Alibaba's initial public offerings over the past two years.

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo reassures firms after court rules against investment law
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has reassured investors after the Constitutional Court ruled against a controversial job creation law, citing procedural flaws. The law, passed last year, aimed to reduce red tape and streamline business permitting. Despite the ruling, which calls for amendments within two years, Widodo assured investors that their investments will remain safe and secure. The government will guarantee the security and certainty of investment in Indonesia, and operations of the Indonesia Investment Authority will remain unchanged. Foreign investors, including a $10 billion pledge from the UAE, have pledged billions of investment.

site_title: Macau casino stocks tumble after junket boss arrest
summary: Macau casino stocks plummeted after the arrest of Alvin Chau, head of Suncity Group, who confessed to running illegal betting activities overseas. Chau was taken in for questioning after a two-year investigation by Macau police. Suncity suspended trading in its shares, and other major casino operators saw their share prices dive, with Wynn down 10%, SJM, Sands, and MGM tumbling more than 7%. The arrests are part of a crackdown against the sector, with plans announced to increase government regulation and criminalize underground banking.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks sank at open on Monday, Nov 29, 2021, extending a global sell-off fueled by fears over the new Omicron variant. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.71%, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.99%. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.10%. The declines were part of a broader market downturn.

images.alt_text: Shares in Hong Kong and mainland China opened with more losses Monday (Nov 29) morning to extend a sell-off across world markets fuelled by fears about the new Omicron variant.

site_title: ComfortDelGro in JV to start construction logistics business in China
summary: ComfortDelGro has entered a joint venture with Guangzhou Xinhongqiang Concrete Company in China to start a logistics business delivering concrete. The company will hold a 60% stake in Guangxi ComfortDelGro Logistics, with an initial start-up capital of 12 million yuan (S$2.5 million). The venture aims to purchase a fleet of up to 35 trucks by the end of 2022 to deliver concrete in southern China's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region.

site_title: Evergrande shares fall after chairman cuts stake; Fantasia suspends trading
summary: Evergrande shares fell as much as 4.8% on Nov 29 after its chairman, Hui Ka Yan, cut his stake to raise about US$344 million. The company's electric vehicle unit also dropped 5% amid capital-raising efforts. Evergrande faces over US$300 billion in liabilities and has been scrambling to raise capital, with Chinese authorities urging Hui to use his personal wealth to pay bondholders. The company missed a US$82.5 million coupon payment on Nov 6, with a 30-day grace period ending on Dec 6.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Monday on Omicron fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to concerns over the potentially more transmissible Omicron variant. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.30% to 28,376.95, and the Topix index dropped 1.43% to 1,956.66. This comes as countries strengthen border control efforts amid fears of the new variant.

site_title: Nissan plans 50% electric vehicle sales by 2030
summary: Nissan aims to achieve 50% of its global sales as electric or hybrid vehicles by 2030, with plans to launch 23 new models, including 15 electric vehicles, over the next five years. The move is part of the company's effort to achieve carbon neutrality across its products by 2050. Nissan will invest $24 billion over the next five years to speed up electrification, with the goal of launching electric vehicles with its proprietary batteries by 2028. This targets 75% of European sales as electric vehicles by 2026.

site_title: Barbados to become a republic, replacing British queen
summary: Barbados is set to become a republic, replacing its head of state, Queen Elizabeth II, with Governor General Sandra Mason. Ceremonies will take place on Monday and Tuesday, marking a new era for the Caribbean island. However, the transition has sparked debate about Britain's centuries-long influence, including slavery and colonialism, and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on tourism. Some critics argue that the celebrations are not the right time, given the country's economic turmoil and high unemployment rate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.69 points or 0.64% to 1,502.53. Volume was 276.37 million lots worth RM164.62 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 510 to 72.

site_title: Oil recoups losses from Friday, focusing on Omicron spread, Iran talks
summary: Oil prices rose Monday, recouping losses from Friday's decline of about $10 a barrel, as investors sought bargains amid concerns over the Omicron coronavirus variant and Iran nuclear deal negotiations. Brent crude futures rose 4.2% to $75.77 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 4.8% to $71.42 a barrel.
