The Omicron variant's spread and potential impact on global demand and supply have raised uncertainty, with Opec+ meetings postponed to assess its impact.

site_title: Yoma Strategic returns to profitability to hit US$216,000 net profit for H2
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-based company, has reported a net profit of US$216,000 for the second half of 2021, reversing a loss of US$44.6 million a year ago. Revenue declined 18% to US$43.4 million, mainly due to lower land development segment revenue. The company expects growth in its Wave Money business and strong performance in its real estate business, with plans to acquire a 51% stake in Wave Money from Telenor.

site_title: Trans-China Automotive founder boosts stake
summary: Trans-China Automotive Holdings executive chairman and CEO Francis Tjia Han Joe increased his stake in the company after acquiring 5.5 million shares at 26.5 cents per share. The acquisition increased his deemed interest in the vehicle dealership group from 75.6% to 76.54%. This follows his founder role in the company since its establishment in 2009.

site_title: Should Singapore millennials (and Gen Z) buy or rent their homes?
summary: Singapore millennials and Gen Z face a dilemma: whether to buy or rent their homes. Experts argue that the traditional view that home ownership brings capital gains may not be applicable, as sustained property price appreciation is not guaranteed. The decision should consider non-financial factors like location flexibility, job mobility, and lifestyle choices. A holistic approach is necessary, and the benefits and burdens of home ownership at the individual level should be weighed. Ultimately, the financial balance may not tilt towards buying, and non-tax strengths may prevail. A review of home ownership's impact on the social compact is also needed.

site_title: In crisis, there is an opportunity: A new era of HR is emerging
summary: A new era of human capital management is emerging as the COVID-19 pandemic accelerates changes in the workplace, including climate change, diversity, equity, and inclusion, and remote working on mental health. HR professionals are being forced to redefine their role, providing strategic guidance to leaders and developing strategies to attract, assess, and support employees. To thrive, organizations must prioritize employee wellbeing, demonstrate purpose, and incorporate sustainable practices. HR leaders must drive change by deploying new skills, resources, and innovative approaches, such as upskilling and reskilling, and embracing hybrid work models that prioritize employee experience and engagement.

site_title: Supply chain chaos sparks fried chicken shortage at Japan stores
summary: Supply chain disruptions in Thailand due to a spike in coronavirus cases have led to a shortage of chicken in Japan, affecting the availability of fried chicken at convenience stores like 7-Eleven and FamilyMart. Sales of Kentucky Fried Chicken are expected to be 10 times busier than usual on Christmas Eve. Despite efforts to source from domestic chicken farms, 7-Eleven has suspended fried chicken sales in some areas and FamilyMart has warned of a shortage. The shortage may continue until Thailand's chicken production returns to normal.

site_title: On a mission to revolutionise the custom PC market, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore is set to sign its first carbon credits transfer agreement with an ASEAN country by the end of 2025, aiming to boost its efforts in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement will enable the country to purchase carbon credits from other countries, helping to offset its own emissions. This move is part of Singapore's strategy to become a carbon-neutral city-state by 2050. The agreement with the first ASEAN country is seen as a significant step towards achieving this goal and will help Singapore meet its climate change mitigation targets. Details of the country are not disclosed.

site_title: IReit Global bags new tenant for office space in Germany property
summary: IReit Global has secured a 5-year lease from a German federal municipal association for 5 floors of office space in its Munster Campus building in Germany, increasing the overall occupancy rate to 95.7% and boosting the weighted average lease expiry (WALE) to 4.9 years.

images.alt_text: The new lease will increase the overall occupancy rate of Munster Campus to 95.7 per cent from 64 per cent, if the existing tenant GMG were to vacate in April 2022 without a new lease.

site_title: Pandemic-themed art emerges tops again
summary: The UOB Painting of the Year awards has announced its top winners, with Malaysia's Saiful Razman taking the overall prize for his minimalist work "Walk In Silence, Don't Walk Away In Silence." The painting reflects humanity's struggle to stay safe in a pandemic-affected world. In Singapore, Keane Tan won the Established Artist category for "A Dramatic Cinematic for Our Century," depicting the Merlion engulfed by crashing waves. The competition also recognized emerging artists, including Brian Ko, who won the Most Promising Artist of the Year Award for his abstract representation of sustainable solutions.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday's open, tracking global losses; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.8% on Monday, tracking global losses after the discovery of the Omicron coronavirus variant. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that Singapore may roll back eased safety measures. Local stocks were impacted, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 1.5%, 1%, and 0.5%, respectively. The Straits Times Index ended at 3,140.67.

site_title: Canada confirms first Covid Omicron infections
summary: Canada has confirmed its first cases of the Omicron Covid-19 variant, in two individuals who recently traveled to Nigeria. Both patients are in isolation as public health authorities investigate possible contacts. The World Health Organization has listed Omicron as a "variant of concern," prompting travel restrictions and precautions worldwide. It's unclear when Omicron's transmissibility, severity, or vaccine implications will be known, with monitoring and testing continuing in Canada.

site_title: Amazon executive says Omicron's impact on holiday spending uncertain
summary: Amazon executive Dave Clark expressed uncertainty about the impact of Omicron on holiday spending, saying it's too early to predict. Despite supply chain disruptions and travel restrictions, Clark is optimistic about the ability of scientists and pharmaceutical companies to respond to the new variant. Consumers are pressing ahead with their holiday plans, with shoppers focusing on apparel and home decor, and Clark attributes this to a desire to reconnect after pandemic restrictions.

images.alt_text: A senior Amazon.com Inc executive said it remains too early to predict how the Omicron coronavirus variant will impact consumer spending during the holiday season but suggested that shoppers will press ahead for now.

site_title: Pandemic to cost global tourism US$2t in 2021: UN
summary: The global tourism sector is expected to lose $2 trillion in 2021 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, with international tourist arrivals forecast to decline 70-75% compared to 2019. The sector's recovery is considered "fragile" and "slow," with uneven vaccination rates and new Covid-19 variants impacting the recovery. The World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) warns that the situation remains unpredictable, and tourism experts urge nations to harmonize their virus protocols to boost travel confidence.

images.alt_text: The coronavirus pandemic will cost the global tourism sector US$2 trillion in lost revenue in 2021, the UN's tourism body said Monday, calling the sector's recovery "fragile" and "slow".

site_title: ECB's Lagarde says euro zone in better shape facing new Covid-19 wave, Omicron variant
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that the euro zone is better equipped to face the economic impact of a new wave of Covid-19 infections or the Omicron variant. The euro zone has learned from past crises and has implemented measures to respond to the new risks. Despite concerns about the economic recovery in 2022, Lagarde expressed confidence in the euro zone's ability to respond to potential risks, citing the importance of vaccination in preventing the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: The euro zone is better equipped to face the economic impact of a new wave of Covid-19 infections or the Omicron variant, European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said.

site_title: China's developers face US$1.3b in December bond payments
summary: China's developers face nearly $1.3 billion in bond payments in December, with $2 billion in November, despite no reported defaults. Investor scrutiny persists over principal and interest payments amid a cash crunch in the real estate industry. China Evergrande Group and Kaisa Group Holdings, two major dollar-bond issuers, have grace periods ending by mid-December on $170.9 million of coupons. Yields on riskier notes surged to a record 24.6% in November but remain too high for most builders to refinance.

site_title: UK calls urgent meeting of G-7 health ministers
summary: The UK, currently chair of the G-7, has called for an emergency meeting of health ministers to discuss the Covid-19 Omicron variant, after several European countries reported cases. Britain, Germany, Italy, and the Netherlands have announced cases, despite most European countries shutting down flights from southern Africa. The meeting, set for November 29, aims to address the developments and potential spread of the variant.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, ThaiBev, Singtel, StarHub, China Everbright, Asian Healthcare Specialists
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings posted a net profit of US$216,000 for the second half year ending Sep 30, 2021, reversing a loss of US$44.6 million a year ago. Thai Beverage Public Company reported a net profit of 24.6 billion baht (S$1 billion) for the full fiscal year 2021, 8.3% higher than the previous year. Shares of Yoma and ThaiBev closed down 1.5% and 2.8% respectively on Friday.

site_title: US braces for Omicron ahead of southern Africa travel ban
summary: The US is preparing for the Omicron Covid-19 variant, which has been detected in southern Africa and has spread to several countries. The US government has imposed a travel ban on most foreign nationals from southern Africa, starting Monday, in an effort to buy time to assess the new risk. US health officials, including Dr. Anthony Fauci, are urging Americans to prepare for the variant and to get vaccinated and boosted. The variant's transmissibility and severity are still unknown, and officials are monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: Time for a revamp of the annual report
summary: Industry players are pushing companies to rethink their annual reports, citing their complexity and lack of usefulness for investors. Only 23% of Straits Times Index companies published a website version of their annual report, with most lacking interactive charts and search functionality. Companies may consider a multi-channel approach, with designs suitable for both websites and PDFs. Integrated reporting, combining annual, sustainability, and financial reports, is also seen as a solution, with several companies already adopting this format. Efforts are underway to improve disclosures for material information, including standalone sustainability reports and an ESG data portal.

site_title: New virus pain upends global policy bets to offer relief to euro
summary: A new strain of the coronavirus variant may provide relief to the euro, as fears of renewed travel curbs spread globally, potentially slowing interest-rate hikes from global policymakers. This shift in market sentiment has led to a surge in the euro, breaking above US$1.13, and may derail a popular trade betting on a weaker euro. Analysts now expect a slower pace of interest-rate hikes, and some predict a weaker euro by year's end, while others remain cautious.

site_title: Algos and options turn a tumble into a crash on oil's Black Friday
summary: Global oil markets experienced a sharp decline on Black Friday, with West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude plummeting 13% and 12% respectively. The sell-off was driven by concerns over the Omicron variant of Covid-19, which sparked fears of widespread lockdowns and travel bans. The market's volatility was exacerbated by technical factors, including anaemic post-holiday volumes and algorithmic trading. Despite some recovery by the close, the day remains the seventh worst one-day drop in London's Brent futures history, with prices expected to recover quickly once the US market returns to normal.

site_title: Growing old in high style
summary: Luxury assisted-living homes have emerged in cities like New York, catering to affluent retirees with upmarket tastes. The Watermark at Brooklyn Heights and Inspir Carnegie Hill are examples of these high-end facilities, offering amenities like indoor swimming pools, gourmet dining, and cultural programs. Monthly fees range from $8,295 to $29,750, significantly higher than the median cost of assisted living in the US. These luxury residences promote a lifestyle rather than just basic living needs, aiming to engage residents rather than simply entertaining them. They appeal to the "silver tsunami" of aging baby boomers seeking a luxurious and culturally active lifestyle.

site_title: Is the Omicron sell-off a buying opportunity?
summary: The Omicron variant of the coronavirus has prompted a global sell-off in markets, with travel restrictions and concerns about its economic impact weighing on investors. The World Health Organization (WHO) has designated Omicron as a variant of concern, and it is the 15th letter of the Greek alphabet, following Delta, the fourth letter. The sell-off is a reminder that Covid-19 will continue to impact the economy and market for a long time, making it a potential buying opportunity for investors.

site_title: Holiday season, supply chain issues bolstering demand for warehousing
summary: Demand for warehousing and storage space in Singapore is expected to increase during the holiday season, driven by pandemic-linked shipping delays and construction delays for homes. Firms in industries such as e-commerce, FMCG, and healthcare are stocking up on extra goods, while some businesses are keeping extra stock on hand to avoid supply chain snags. Operators such as YCH Group, J&T Express, and Extra Space Asia are anticipating a 30% increase in revenue this year, with occupancy rates for warehouses reaching a 5-year high of 90.1%.

site_title: Real Estate Indonesia chief wants VAT waiver on new homes extended for another year
summary: Real Estate Indonesia's secretary-general, Amran Lukman, is urging the Indonesian government to extend the temporary VAT waiver on new home sales for another year, citing its positive impact on boosting consumer confidence and encouraging home purchases. The waiver, initially set to expire in December, has seen over 149,000 residential units sold in November, a 2.85% increase compared to 2020. A one-year extension could cost the government an additional 10 trillion rupiah, but is seen as necessary to support the economy's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Bitcoin offers no refuge from Covid market rout
summary: Bitcoin plummeted almost 8% to around $54,350 on November 26, its worst day in over two months, amidst a global market rout triggered by a potentially dangerous coronavirus variant. The drop contradicts the argument that Bitcoin can serve as a hedge against turmoil in traditional markets, with experts saying it behaves like a risk asset. The correlation between Bitcoin and the S&P 500 has increased, making it less effective as a hedge against volatility. The cryptocurrency's role as an inflation hedge remains uncertain, with its recent price drop fueled by market concerns rather than inflation fears.

site_title: PCR tests detect Omicron, studies under way for other tests: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed that PCR tests can detect Omicron, a Covid-19 variant of concern, but studies are underway to determine its impact on other test types. The WHO declared Omicron a variant of concern, citing its high infectiousness and potential for severe disease, although symptoms appear to be similar to other variants. Research is ongoing to assess the variant's impact on vaccines and treatments, with WHO urging caution and coordination with global researchers.

images.alt_text: While PCR tests can detect infection with Omicron, studies are looking to whether the Covid-19 variant of concern has any impact on other test types, the WHO said on Sunday.

site_title: Yen and Swiss franc gain as Covid variant dents risk appetite
summary: A coronavirus variant potentially resistant to current vaccines led to investors seeking safer assets, causing the Japanese yen and Swiss franc to gain. The yen jumped 2% to a 5-year high against the US dollar, while the Swiss franc rose 0.9% to a 6-year high against the euro. The US dollar index fell 0.75% as investors took profits after the currency's recent gains. The new variant led to restrictions on travel from South Africa and neighboring countries, further contributing to the safe-haven seeking behavior.

site_title: Pantheon: Resting place of France's great and good
summary: Josephine Baker, a French-American dancer and singer who fought in the French Resistance and battled racism, will become the first Black woman to enter the Pantheon, France's most hallowed resting place, on Nov 30. Only five women have been allowed through the grand portals since its inception, prompting feminist protests. Simone Veil, the last woman to be admitted, was buried in 2018. The French president decides who has the right to be laid to rest there, but descendants can overrule the decision. Baker's admission marks a significant milestone in France's recognition of its Black heritage.

site_title: Australia's reopening plans in doubt after Omicron cases
summary: Australia's border reopening plans for skilled migrants and students have been put on hold due to the country's first reported cases of the Omicron coronavirus variant. The two cases, from southern Africa, have led to 14-day quarantines for returning citizens and a ban on entry from nine African countries. Prime Minister Scott Morrison urged calm, citing that data on the Omicron strain's severity and transmissibility is still emerging. The review of reopening plans will begin on December 1, as officials assess the risks and potential impact on the country.

site_title: Global firms are paying up to deal with Hong Kong's quarantine policy
summary: Global firms, including JPMorgan Chase, are compensating employees for Hong Kong's strict quarantine regime, which has led to a brain drain in the city. Companies like Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs are offering one-time reimbursements to cover quarantine costs, while Black Sheep Restaurants is spending $650,000 to allow staff to see their families. The quarantine policy, which includes hotel stays of up to 3 weeks, is deterring international banks and asset managers from retaining staff, with nearly half considering relocation.

site_title: New coronavirus variant Omicron keeps spreading around the world
summary: A new Omicron coronavirus variant is spreading globally, sparking concerns it may resist vaccinations and prolong the pandemic. The variant, first detected in South Africa, has been found in 13 countries, including the Netherlands, Denmark, Australia, and several European nations. Travel restrictions have been imposed on southern Africa, but experts warn these measures may be too late to stop the variant's spread. The World Health Organization has dubbed Omicron a "variant of concern," and its contagiousness and severity remain unclear.

site_title: Singapore defers VTL with Qatar, Saudi Arabia, UAE amid fears of Omicron variant
summary: Singapore has deferred the launch of Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE until further notice due to concerns over the Omicron variant. The decision aims to reduce the risk of importing and spreading the potentially more contagious variant. The World Health Organisation (WHO) had flagged Omicron as a variant of concern on November 26. Singapore will review its border measures and announce more details soon.

site_title: Daily tally under 1,000 for first time since Sept 20 with 747 new Covid-19 cases; 11 more deaths reported
summary: Singapore reported 747 new Covid-19 cases, the lowest daily tally under 1,000 since Sept 20, with 11 additional deaths linked to the virus. The weekly infection growth rate fell to 0.69, marking the 16th consecutive day below 1. The ICU utilisation rate rose to 57.4% and the total number of fatalities in Singapore now stands at 701. The majority of new cases were in the community, with three imported cases.

site_title: Bond traders focus on Fed's inflation fight even amid Omicron fear
summary: Bond investors are focusing on the Federal Reserve's inflation fight in 2022, despite concerns over the Omicron virus strain. A dramatic Treasuries rally last week, driven by worries over the variant, has subsided, and yields are expected to be driven by the Fed's efforts to combat inflation. The Fed is likely to become more restrictive with monetary policy, potentially leading to an accelerated pace of asset-purchase tapering in January, which could pave the way for interest rate hikes in mid-2022.

site_title: Logistics S-Reit with pure Japan assets lists on SGX
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 26, 2021, with an initial portfolio of 14 logistics properties in Japan valued at approximately S$952.9 million. The IPO attracted strong support, with 4.9 times the placement tranche and 9.5 times the public tranche subscribed. The Reit manager believes the diversified portfolio minimizes concentration risk and takes advantage of overlooked markets. The IPO portfolio has a 96.3% occupancy rate and an aggregate weighted average lease expiry of 7.2 years.

site_title: Australia committed to being world leader in clean energy
summary: Australia has committed to becoming a world leader in clean energy, with a national hydrogen strategy released in 2019 and a Technology Investment Roadmap to drive down the cost of low-emissions technologies. The roadmap aims to make clean energy the economically rational choice, with a focus on clean hydrogen, electrical energy storage, green steel and aluminium, geosequestration, and soil organic carbon sequestration. The government has set targets for these technologies, including clean hydrogen production at under $2 per kg and low-cost solar electricity at $15 per megawatt-hour by 2030. This commitment is part of Australia's plan to deliver net-zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Jubilee enters MOU to sell electronics unit for indicative US$11m
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings has entered a MOU to sell its electronics unit, WE Components, to Hangzhou Yu Ye Technology for an indicative US$11 million. The deal will expand Hangzhou Yu Ye's overseas chip agency business and allow Jubilee to focus on its mechanical business unit, which has seen significant growth since the acquisition of Honfoong Plastic Industries in 2018. Post-transaction, Jubilee expects to drive growth through its MBU, driven by customer shifts in Asean amid US-China tensions.

site_title: Black Friday: Store visits by US shoppers up 48%
summary: US shoppers visited stores on Black Friday by 48% this year, but traffic remained below pre-pandemic levels, with crowds down 28% from 2019. Demand was brisk, with shopping spread out over several days, and retailers started holiday deals early to avoid congestion. In-store visits are expected to lag 2019 levels by 10-15% this holiday season. Online spending on Black Friday was flat at $5.1 billion, but Adobe predicts $10.2 billion to $11.3 billion on Cyber Monday, the biggest online shopping day.

site_title: Facebook offers remedies to address EU concerns about Kustomer deal
summary: Facebook has offered remedies to address EU concerns about its acquisition of US customer service startup Kustomer, aiming to secure antitrust approval. The European Commission extended its decision deadline to Jan 28, seeking feedback from rivals and customers. The deal, valued at around $1.8 billion, may harm competition and reinforce Facebook's power in online advertising. Facebook has already won clearance from regulators in the UK and Australia.

site_title: India's Paytm September quarter net loss widens
summary: Paytm, India's largest fintech firm, reported a 8.4% widening of its net loss in the September quarter, reaching 4.74 billion rupees. Revenue rose 49.7% to 11.35 billion rupees, but analysts warn of challenges in customer acquisition and high execution risks to profitability. Despite being well-funded, the company's stock remains 17% below its issue price following a dismal debut on the stock exchanges.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week of Nov 26, 2021, highlights a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Capesize market was positive but couldn't sustain gains, with the 5TC settling at $32,393, up $2,455 week-over-week. Weather concerns disrupted tonnage schedules from North Asia, affecting routes in the region. The Panamax market rebounded, with improved levels in the Atlantic Basin. The Ultramax/Supramax market saw better activity from Asia, while the Handysize market ended the week with a resurgent Asia market turning the tide. VLCC rates eased slightly, while Suezmax and Aframax markets experienced declines. The Baltic Exchange report also covers market trends for LR2s, MRs, and MRs, with freight levels continuing to rally in the UK-Continent region.

site_title: Omicron variant may force Singapore to roll back easing of Covid safety measures: PM Lee
summary: Singapore may roll back eased Covid-19 safety measures due to the emerging Omicron variant, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. Despite the potential setback, Lee is confident the country can live with the virus, citing progress made in dealing with Covid-19 over the past two years. Singapore has closely monitored the Omicron variant, a new and potentially more contagious strain, and has restricted travel from southern Africa.

images.alt_text: PM Lee speaking at the People's Action Party Convention 2021.

site_title: Israel first nation to ban entry of travellers from all countries over Omicron variant
summary: Israel has become the first country to ban entry to all foreigners due to the Omicron coronavirus variant, with Prime Minister Naftali Bennett announcing a 14-day ban starting Sunday. The ban will be enforced using counter-terrorism phone-tracking technology to contain the spread. Israelis entering the country will be required to undergo quarantine, regardless of vaccination status. The move comes as the variant has been detected in several countries and global concern has grown, with epidemiologists warning that restrictions may be too late to stop its spread.

site_title: BT podcast: How to prepare for mandatory ESG disclosures
summary: HSBC's Managing Director, Head of Sustainable Finance & Investments, Kelvin Tan, discusses preparing for mandatory ESG disclosures with BT correspondent Howie Lim. Key points include the importance of ESG data for investors, issues with current available data, and the need for a global reporting framework standard. Companies have a limited timeframe to prepare, with smaller ones advised to take action early. A global framework standard will ensure interoperability, and standardization efforts are underway.

site_title: Miami's mini condos offer investors a small slice of a hot market
summary: Miami's mini condos, offering short-term rentals, are attracting investors with lower price points, drawing from South America. Four out of nine planned towers have sold out, including the 448-unit Natiivo, with prices starting at around US$300,000. In contrast, luxury condos in Miami have seen a 47% increase in median sale price to US$1.25 million. Developers are betting on the future of the hospitality industry, with some projects not set to be completed until 2025 or 2026. Investors are seeking income-producing properties, not primary residences, in this growing market.

images.alt_text: It is not just home sales that are sizzling in Miami. Investors eager to play in the hot property market are also buying up tiny condos that can be rented out as hotel rooms.

site_title: UK tightens social, travel rules as Omicron cases surface in UK, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Israel
summary: The UK has confirmed the presence of the omicron Covid-19 variant in people with travel connections to southern Africa, prompting Prime Minister Boris Johnson to announce measures to combat its spread. The UK will require airline travelers to take a PCR test and isolate upon arrival, while face mask rules will be tightened. Several European countries, including Germany, Italy, and Belgium, have also identified cases of the variant. The World Health Organization has declared the strain a "variant of concern," and global markets have been affected by the news, with investors seeking havens.

site_title: Will the Omicron variant change Singapore's Covid rules?
summary: Singapore is closely monitoring the Omicron variant, but experts say more information is needed to determine if current pandemic protocols should change. Professor Teo Yik Ying notes that if Omicron increases transmissibility but not disease risk, the impact on healthcare systems may be minimal with high vaccination uptake. However, if Omicron increases disease risk for vaccinated individuals, countries may need to review endemic Covid-19 strategies. Singapore has already implemented travel restrictions and is expanding vaccinated travel lanes to mitigate the risk.

site_title: HSBC to grow alternative funds in broader Asean market
summary: HSBC is expanding its asset management business in Asean markets, particularly in Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with a focus on alternative assets and ESG (environmental, social and governance) funds. The bank aims to grow its assets under management (AUM) to US$3.5-4 trillion by 2025, with a strategy that includes in-house funds, new investment teams, and innovative ESG-themed investments. HSBC has already launched several ESG-themed funds and has partnered with climate change investment firms to tap into the growing demand for sustainable investing.

site_title: Land VTL travellers from Malaysia to Singapore must take ART on arrival in view of Omicron variant
summary: Singapore requires land VTL travellers from Malaysia to take an antigen rapid test (ART) upon arrival due to the Omicron variant. Starting Nov 29, the on-arrival ART will be administered at designated points for those using the land VTL. This measure aims to reduce the risk of spread of the B11529 strain in Singapore. Pre-departure tests are also mandatory for those traveling from Malaysia to Singapore, with on-arrival ART required for those traveling from Singapore to Malaysia.

images.alt_text: The Causeway between Singapore and Malaysia was one of the busiest land borders in the world before the Covid-19 pandemic disrupted cross-border activities, said PM Lee.

site_title: WTO's big conference postponed due to new Covid variant
summary: The World Trade Organization's (WTO) ministerial conference, scheduled for November 29 to December 2, has been postponed due to the new Omicron Covid-19 variant. The conference, aimed at revitalizing the WTO and addressing issues such as fishery subsidies and vaccine patents, was postponed by four days after the World Health Organization declared Omicron a variant of concern. The WTO's director-general, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, cited health and safety concerns as the reason for the postponement, which will reconvene "as soon as possible" when conditions allow.

site_title: Investors can expect high uncertainty
summary: Investors expect high uncertainty as the S&P500 takes a pause after breaking all-time highs in early November. The benchmark US equity index has broken above its year-long bull market trend line at 4,580 points, with a successful test of the 4,650-4,680 price region expected to continue the upward trend. Despite this, investors remain cautious due to the uncertainty surrounding the tapering off of quantitative easing.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth rebounds for second month
summary: China's industrial profit growth rebounded for a second month in October, with a 24.6% increase to 818.7 billion yuan, driven by sectors like mining and raw materials manufacturing. The 10-month increase in profits was 42.2% year-over-year. Profitability of consumer goods manufacturing turned positive, while coal production companies saw profits surge 438% year-on-year. The improvement is attributed to government policies to secure supplies and stabilize prices, amid a power crunch.

site_title: WhatsApp wins approval to double payments offering to 40m users in India: source
summary: WhatsApp has won approval to double its payment service users in India to 40 million, a source with direct knowledge told Reuters. The National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI) granted the approval, allowing the company to lift its current cap of 20 million users. WhatsApp's messenger service has over 500 million users in India, its largest market, and the new cap is expected to hinder the company's growth prospects. The approval comes after WhatsApp spent years complying with Indian regulations, including data storage norms.

site_title: Top US diplomat for Asia to visit 4 Asean countries
summary: US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia Daniel Kritenbrink is set to visit Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand from Dec 4, reaffirming the US commitment to a "rules-based order" in the Indo-Pacific and supporting efforts to address human rights challenges, climate change, and the COVID-19 pandemic. The visit comes after US President Joe Biden pledged stepped-up engagement with South-east Asia during a virtual summit with Asean leaders last month, aiming to strengthen economic relationships and develop a regional economic framework.

site_title: New coronavirus variant Omicron keeps spreading around the world
summary: The new Omicron coronavirus variant continues to spread globally, with 13 cases found in the Netherlands, 2 in Denmark, and 2 in Australia. The cases were detected among passengers from South Africa who arrived in Amsterdam last Friday. The World Health Organization has dubbed Omicron a "variant of concern" due to worries it may resist vaccinations and prolong the pandemic. Countries are imposing travel restrictions in an attempt to contain its spread.

site_title: Spain's bad bank sues banks over debt portfolio
summary: Spain's bad bank, Sareb, has sued Spanish lenders Caixabank and Sabadell in a Madrid court, seeking to recoup negative interest payments on its 34.5 billion euros senior debt portfolio. Sareb, set up in 2012 to take on bad loans from the financial crisis, had previously issued debt with a 0% floor to prevent negative interest payments. However, the European Central Bank's (ECB) acceptance of bonds with negative yields in 2017 changed the criteria, and Sareb now demands to remove the floor and charge lenders for the negative interest.

site_title: Black Friday discounts fade as demand, inflation power ahead
summary: Black Friday deals offered the lowest discounts in years, with an average 24% discount globally, down 2-4 percentage points from recent years. Retailers have the "lowest level of clearance goods in five years or more," according to analyst Oliver Chen. This trend suggests that consumers are not being drawn to deep discounts, potentially due to inflation concerns. The results may indicate a shift in consumer behavior, with shoppers opting for more affordable everyday prices rather than seeking significant discounts on Black Friday.

site_title: Tesla's Texas battery bet costs carmaker US$1.3b German aid
summary: Tesla will forfeit €1.14 billion (S$1.77 billion) in German state aid for its factory in Gruenheide, Germany, due to its decision to prioritize battery cell production in Texas instead. The company had been eligible for the aid as part of the European Union's Important Project of Common European Interest initiative. CEO Elon Musk stated that Tesla aims to eliminate all subsidies, including those for oil and gas. The decision has led to a 3.1% decline in Tesla shares.

site_title: Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna expect data on shot's protection against new Covid-19 variant soon
summary: BioNTech and Pfizer expect data on the protection of their Covid-19 vaccine against a new South African variant, B.1.1.529, within 2 weeks. If necessary, they can ship a new vaccine tailored to the variant in approximately 100 days. Moderna is also working on a booster candidate and testing higher doses to protect against multiple variants. Global authorities have tightened border controls amid concerns over the variant's potential vaccine resistance, and Pfizer and BioNTech have already created versions of their vaccine to target previous variants.

site_title: JBE's The Commodore sells over 70% of units on launch weekend
summary: THE Commodore condominium in Canberra, Sembawang, has sold over 70% of its 219 units, with 162 units sold by the end of its launch weekend. The 99-year leasehold development, developed by JBE Holdings, attracted 93% Singaporean buyers and 60% below the age of 40. The strong sales indicate a rising aspiration among young buyers to own private homes, according to JBE.

site_title: Developing energy-saving solutions for data centres
summary: KoolLogix, a Singapore-based company, is developing energy-saving solutions for data centers. The company's cooling systems aim to optimize limited resources and reduce carbon emissions. KoolLogix's unique solution removes lingering heat energy from surroundings before introducing cooling, resulting in lower energy consumption. The system also redeployes waste heat energy, making it non-corrosive, non-flammable, and non-toxic. With plans to grow and expand globally, KoolLogix aims to address the data center industry's sustainability challenges and provide a means to address their sustainability goals. The company plans to enter the Indonesian market next year, with ambitions to become the global leader in creating green and sustainable solutions for the data center industry.

site_title: ATA says it takes 'serious view' of forced labour allegations, claims by whistleblower
summary: ATA IMS, a Malaysian company, has taken "serious view" of forced labor allegations and claims of physical abuse by a former worker, following an audit by Dyson, a major client. The allegations led to Dyson cutting ties with ATA IMS, causing its shares to tumble. ATA IMS claims to be cooperating with the investigation and taking steps to address the allegations.

site_title: Apple global battery development chief moves to Volkswagen
summary: Apple's global battery development chief, Ahn Soonho, has moved to Volkswagen to lead the automaker's electric vehicle battery development. This is the second time an Apple executive has left for an automaker, following the departure of head of car project Doug Field to Ford Motor in September. Industry sources suggest Apple aims to launch an electric car with advanced battery technology by 2024, although the company declined to comment on the matter. Volkswagen plans to build 6 battery factories across Europe by the end of the decade to overtake Tesla as the world's leader in electric vehicles.

site_title: Novavax testing vaccine that targets new Covid-19 variant
summary: Novavax has begun developing a Covid-19 vaccine targeting the South Africa variant B.1.1.529, with the shot expected to be ready for testing and manufacturing in the next few weeks. The company's vaccine contains an actual version of the virus' spike protein that triggers the immune system. Novavax has already received emergency use approval in Indonesia and the Philippines, and is on track to file for US approval by the end of the year. Other companies, including BioNTech and Johnson & Johnson, are also testing their vaccines against the new variant.

site_title: Output at Chevron's Australia Gorgon gas plant resumes
summary: Chevron's Gorgon liquefied natural gas plant in Western Australia has resumed production after a minor gas leak at one of its processing units was detected nearly two weeks ago. The issue was identified during routine duties and the unit was shut down as a precautionary measure. Repair work was completed, allowing production to resume at Train 1, while Trains 2 and 3 continued to operate normally, delivering LNG to customers and gas to Western Australia.

site_title: Currency volatility soars as traders worry over new Covid-19 variant
summary: Currency volatility surged as traders reacted to the discovery of a new Covid-19 variant in South Africa, with euro and yen volatility reaching the highest levels in a year. The Swiss franc and yen gained among Group-of-10 currencies, while the dollar weakened. Traders worry about potential restrictions and its impact on the global economic recovery, with central bankers considering interest rate hikes. Money-market bets on interest rates and the variant's impact drive foreign-exchange price action, potentially weakening currencies in Canada and New Zealand.

site_title: Telecom Italia CEO Gubitosi resigns amid KKR offer
summary: Telecom Italia CEO Luigi Gubitosi resigned amid a KKR offer, following a surprise profit warning and pressure from largest shareholder Vivendi. The company's directors accepted Gubitosi's offer to step down, with Chairman Salvatore Rossi taking over strategic assets. Pietro Labriola, a 54-year-old telecommunications veteran, was promoted to group general manager. This is the fourth overhaul of top management at Telecom Italia in less than 6 years, as the company prepares for a potential sale to KKR. Vivendi has rejected the KKR bid, citing it as too low.

site_title: Thailand probes Amnesty International after ultra-royalist complaint
summary: Thailand is investigating whether Amnesty International has broken any laws after ultra-royalists complained that the human rights group's support for activists facing prosecution undermined national security. Over 1,600 activists, including 160 charged under strict laws against insulting the monarchy, are facing security-related charges. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha stated that the government will check for any law violations and may revoke Amnesty's licence if wrongdoing is found. Amnesty vowed to continue working independently and impartially on human rights abuses under international law.

site_title: Oil settles down US$10/bbl in largest daily drop since April 2020
summary: Oil prices plummeted US$10 a barrel, their largest daily drop since April 2020, due to concerns over a new coronavirus variant, Omicron, which may dampen economic growth and fuel demand. The World Health Organization has designated Omicron as "of concern," prompting travel restrictions from southern Africa. Oil prices fell 11.6% for Brent crude and 13.1% for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude, marking a fifth week of losses and the steepest falls since April 2020.

site_title: Gold pauses after safe haven rush sparked by new virus variant
summary: Gold prices paused after rising 1% on Friday, Nov 26, amid concerns over a new coronavirus variant. The spot gold rose to $1,791.97 per ounce, but retreated as the overall bearish turn in commodities claimed gold. The market reaction was deemed overblown, with analysts attributing the price movement to safe-haven appeal. Gold is still headed for its worst week since mid-June, down 2.9% due to expectations of US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. Other precious metals, such as silver and palladium, also declined.

site_title: China property turmoil risks upending green debt market
summary: China's real estate sector is facing a debt crisis, threatening the sustainability of green debt issued by developers to fund environmentally-friendly projects. Two firms, Kaisa Group Holdings and Fujian Yango Group, are at risk of default due to their inability to meet debt obligations. The crisis has led to a sell-off in green property debt, with yields increasing to 25% and prices plummeting to 68 cents on the dollar. The situation raises concerns about the sector's ability to attract global investors and meet China's ambitious carbon neutral targets.

site_title: WTO's big conference postponed due to new Covid variant
summary: The World Trade Organization's (WTO) ministerial conference, set to take place in Geneva, has been postponed due to the new Omicron Covid-19 variant. The 4-day conference, aimed at resolving issues such as fishery subsidies and lifting Covid vaccine patents, was postponed just hours after the World Health Organization declared Omicron a variant of concern. The decision was made to ensure the health and safety of participants, and the WTO intends to reconvene "as soon as possible" when conditions allow. The postponement has been met with disappointment from trade experts, who had seen the conference as a test of Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala's ability to revitalize the WTO.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops sharply at open on fears over new virus variant
summary: US stock indexes dropped sharply at open on Friday due to fears over a new, possibly vaccine-resistant coronavirus variant. The Dow Jones fell 437.69 points, or 1.22%, to 35,366.69, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The selloff affected travel, bank, and commodity-linked stocks.

site_title: Some stress may not harm your mental well-being
summary: Mental health experts argue that stress and poor mental health are not the same, with some individuals able to cope with stress without harming their well-being. Researchers emphasize the importance of resilience and adaptability, which can be learned and cultivated. Experts highlight the need for a delicate balance between facing challenges and maintaining well-being, and encourage individuals to seek help if they're struggling. Employers are also urged to establish strong community support systems to help employees cope with stress, rather than limiting benefits for those who may abuse them.

site_title: China asks Didi to delist from US on security fears: sources
summary: Chinese regulators have asked Didi Global's top executives to devise a plan to delist from US bourses due to concerns about data leakage, citing sensitive information. The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) wants Didi to take the company off the New York Stock Exchange, subject to government approval. This unprecedented request is likely to revive fears about Beijing's intentions for its giant tech industry. The request comes amid heightened scrutiny of China's tech sector and its handling of sensitive data.

site_title: US health panel says Merck pill can prevent grave Covid-19 infections
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved an anti-Covid-19 pill developed by Merck, known as molnupiravir, to prevent grave Covid-19 infections. The pill, which reduces hospitalization and death rates by 30% in high-risk patients, can be dispensed by a pharmacy and taken at home. However, the FDA advisory panel has cautioned against using the drug in pregnant women due to potential risks, and Merck has stated that data was not collected on pregnant patients in the clinical trials. The approval represents a major step forward in the battle against the global pandemic.

images.alt_text: An anti-Covid pill developed by Merck has proved effective in treating the disease, the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) said Friday (Nov 26) in a much-awaited preliminary report.

site_title: HK Oct home prices ease for 2nd month after record high
summary: Hong Kong private home prices dropped 0.9% in October, the second consecutive month, after reaching a record high. Potential buyers became cautious before a policy meet, but the announcement of little substantial changes led to a surge in transactions in November, with a 40% increase in volume. The Hong Kong government aims to build a Northern Metropolis to tackle the city's housing shortage, but a delayed reopening of the border with mainland China is expected to boost the local economy and property demand.

site_title: How exercise affects your appetite
summary: A new study found that exercising after eating does not significantly affect appetite or food intake, contradicting previous research that suggested exercise blunts appetite. In a study involving 24 overweight, sedentary adults, participants who exercised after eating consumed similar amounts of food as those who did not exercise. However, the study suggests that exercise may help with weight control over time by burning calories, with participants burning approximately 300 calories per session. The findings offer a reminder that exercise may not lead to weight loss, and individuals should not be discouraged from exercising if they enjoy eating.

site_title: US: Dow tumbles 900 points on new coronavirus variant fear
summary: The US stock market plummeted on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 905.04 points, or 2.53%, to 34,899.34, and the S&P 500 losing 106.84 points, or 2.27%, to 4,594.62. The decline was triggered by concerns over a new coronavirus variant found in South Africa, which prompted the European Union and Britain to tighten border controls. Retailers and cruise operators were particularly hard hit, with the NYSE Arca Airline index falling 6.45% in its biggest one-day percentage decline since September 2020.

site_title: More than half of financial disputes filed in Singapore were against banks, finance companies
summary: More than half of financial disputes filed in Singapore (1,097 claims) in the 2021 financial year were against banks and finance companies. This marks the third consecutive year that the total number of claims surpassed 1,000. The number of claims decreased from the previous year.

site_title: Thai oil firm PTT expands pharma business with US$475m Alvogen deal
summary: Thai state-owned oil firm PTT has agreed to acquire a US$475 million stake in Alvogen Emerging Markets Holdings, which holds a 57.48% stake in Taiwan's Lotus Pharmaceutical. The deal will expand PTT's pharmaceutical business, with Alvogen also owning a business-to-business pharmaceutical firm in Malta. The acquisition is part of a consortium between PTT and Icelandic investment fund Aztiq. The deal is expected to further diversify PTT's portfolio and enhance its presence in the pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Wall Street grudgingly allows remote work as bankers dig in
summary: Wall Street banks are struggling to get employees to return to the office after the pandemic, with many workers preferring to continue remote work due to concerns about the coronavirus and long commutes. Despite record profits and revenue, attendance numbers remain low, with only 27% of employees in New York City attending daily in October. Some large banks, such as Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, have relaxed dress codes and implemented safety protocols, but many employees are resistant to returning to the office full-time. The financial industry is grappling with the shift in work habits, with some firms embracing hybrid working arrangements.

images.alt_text: Most banks in Manhattan have been asking their employees to return to the office. But Jefferies, where Nadia Batchelor (right) works, has embraced hybrid working on a longer-term basis.

site_title: China Evergrande soccer stadium taken over by government: source
summary: China Evergrande Group's soccer stadium in Guangzhou has been taken over by the government, with the aim of selling it. The stadium, initially set to be completed by the end of 2022, has been halted due to lack of capital. Evergrande, struggling to meet its US$300 billion debt, is also considering selling its money-losing Guangzhou Football Club. The move is part of the government's efforts to steer sales of Evergrande's assets amid its financial struggles.

site_title: StanChart on marathon trail for 20 years and counting
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has sponsored the Singapore Marathon for 20 consecutive years, with the current deal set to expire in 2023. The bank's Cluster CEO, Patrick Lee, expressed his commitment to extending the sponsorship, citing the event's growth in size and relevance, as well as its alignment with the bank's values. The marathon has become more inclusive, with a hybrid format that includes in-person and virtual races. Lee stated that as long as the event remains relevant and aligns with the bank's values, he expects to continue the sponsorship.

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer worst day in 17 months on virus fears
summary: European stocks plummeted 3.7% on Friday, their worst session in 17 months, amid fears of a newly identified and possibly vaccine-resistant coronavirus variant. The variant, detected in South Africa, Botswana, and Hong Kong, has raised concerns about its potential to evade immune responses and increase transmissibility. This has led to widespread selling, driving investors out of riskier assets and prompting a near 10-month high in volatility.

site_title: Millennials are getting coaxed into the grueling world of Indonesian farming
summary: Indonesia aims to convert 2.5 million millennials into farmers within 5 years, reversing the trend of tech-savvy youngsters leaving rural areas. Despite a tropical climate and fertile land, farms often lack capital, expertise, and technology. Farming families earn an average of 26.6 million rupiah ($2,530) a year, with demanding and insecure work subject to weather conditions. Initial results show encouraging progress in reversing the trend, offering a potential solution to Indonesia's labor shortage.

images.alt_text: Globally, the share of agricultural workers has been dropping for decades as automation wipes out roles and job-seekers turn to better paid and less back-breaking employment in cities.

site_title: In Japan, a weaker yen may not be the blessing it once was
summary: Japan's weaker yen, once considered a boon for exports, has become a burden as it increases household finances and confounds policymakers. The yen's value has dropped to 115.525 yen against the US dollar, its highest level since 2017, due to expectations of higher US interest rates. A weaker yen has led to higher import costs, weighing on profits and household purchasing power, with some analysts warning of potential profits decline and increased debt burden.

site_title: Lexus ES 250 F Sport review: F marks the Sport
summary: The Lexus ES 250 F Sport has been updated with a mid-life facelift, introducing a new F Sport package that adds aggressive styling elements such as black wheels, a mesh grille, and a spoiler. The package also includes sporty interior features like red-trimmed seats and a sporty instrument panel. The ES 250's performance remains adequate, with a 4-cylinder engine producing 206 hp. The car excels in handling, with a precise steering feel and a smooth ride. The F Sport package enhances the ES 250's visual appeal, but the ES 300h in Luxury trim remains the top pick due to its hybrid drivetrain and luxurious features.

site_title: Amazon's Black Friday struck by climate activists, strikes in Europe
summary: Climate activists blocked 15 Amazon depots across Europe, including the UK, Germany, France, and Italy, on "Black Friday" to protest the company's environmental impact and treatment of workers. The Extinction Rebellion group criticized Amazon for its excessive consumption and lack of tax payments, while trade unions called for better wages and working conditions. Amazon defended its commitment to being net zero carbon by 2040 and paying its workers fairly, but acknowledged that there is always more to do.

site_title: 'Lying flat' can be a winning investment strategy too
summary: The "lie flat" investment strategy, which involves doing minimal research and taking calculated risks, has proven profitable for some investors, particularly in China's distressed-debt market. The strategy was exemplified by investors who bought China Evergrande Group's bonds despite the company's high debt and lack of guarantees, ultimately reaping significant returns. This approach is gaining traction as investors seek to capitalize on cheap assets and avoid the complexity of due diligence, with some seeing it as a sensible response to the challenging 2021 market.

site_title: Ju Hua Tai's tribute to Jay Chou
summary: Singaporean bar Ju Hua Tai pays tribute to Taiwanese singer Jay Chou with its name and design, incorporating Eastern influences and Chinese herbs in its cocktails. The bar features a chrysanthemum motif and uses cordyceps, other Chinese herbs, and premium liquor like Moutai baijiu in its creations. Signature cocktails include "Follow Your Heart" and "Qin Emperor", which pay homage to Chou's music and Chinese culture. The bar offers a relaxed atmosphere, craft beers, and a food menu featuring Chinese-style skewers and bao sliders.

site_title: What does COP26 mean for climate change investors - and what's next?
summary: COP26, the 26th United Nations Climate Change Conference, did not yield significant progress on climate change from an investment perspective. While tangible agreements were made, they are not considered game-changing. Key positives include the potential for Asia to drive dollar asset diversification and the expected growth of retail investors in ETFs in Asia and Europe. However, the US climate bill's passage remains uncertain, and policy details are being re-examined. Overall, COP26's outcome is seen as a step back, with investors looking to the US climate bill for further progress.

site_title: Billionaire economy is booming with private jets in short supply
summary: The global economy is booming, driven by cheap debt and rising wealth among the ultra-rich. Private jets, superyachts, and mansions are in high demand, with manufacturers struggling to keep up. Billionaires like Michael Spencer are snapping up new jets, with prices ranging from $45 million for a twin-engine jet capable of flying at 594 miles per hour. This surge in luxury goods is expected to continue as the ranks of the ultra-rich grow.

site_title: Singapore adds 6 countries to its VTL scheme, raises traveller quota to 15,000
summary: Singapore is launching Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with six new countries, including Thailand, Cambodia, Fiji, Maldives, Sri Lanka, and Turkey, starting December 14 and 16. The daily traveller quota will increase to 15,000 from 10,000. Returning Singapore citizens and permanent residents will not need a Vaccinated Travel Pass (VTP) when entering under the VTL scheme. The expansion aims to restore 2-way quarantine-free travel between Singapore and VTL countries whose borders are now open to visitors from Singapore.

site_title: Hotel occupancy rates remain steady as Singapore visitor arrivals pick up in October
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals increased 26.2% in October to 23,980, with 6,060 from mainland China, and 2,930 from India. Despite the rise, hotel occupancy rates remained steady at 63% in September and October, possibly due to travelers staying with relatives rather than booking hotel stays. Revenue per available room and average room rates edged up, with overall hotel industry room revenue rising to S$80 million in October. Experts expect the VTLs to bring in more international travelers, potentially leading to increased hotel rates, but the new Covid-19 variant detected in South Africa may dampen recovery.

site_title: ThaiBev mulling price increase on key products amid cost pressures; FY21 net profit up 8.3% to 24.6 billion baht
summary: ThaiBev reported a 8.3% increase in FY21 net profit to 24.6 billion baht, driven by non-recurring costs and deferred tax utilization from the restructuring of its beer business last year. The company's earnings per share rose to 0.98 baht from 0.91 baht in FY20.

site_title: Asia, Europe well-positioned as partners to build up resilience, overcome Covid-19 impact: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of building resilience to overcome the social and economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic through partnerships with Asian and European countries. At the biennial Asia-Europe Meeting (Asem) Summit, Lee proposed facilitating knowledge and expertise sharing, restoring supply chains, and reopening international travel safely. Singapore has already implemented quarantine-free vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs) with 27 countries, including 10 European and 8 Asia-Pacific nations. The VTLs serve as a model for countries to resume safe travel arrangements, and Lee hopes for further collaboration on interoperable digital solutions.

images.alt_text: PM Lee said Asian and European countries should "work closely to fully restore supply chains and reopen international travels in a safe manner".

site_title: Europe and Asia, alarmed by Covid variant, tighten borders
summary: A new coronavirus variant, B.1.1.529, detected in South Africa has prompted global authorities to tighten border controls, with the EU, Britain, and India imposing stricter measures. The variant has a dramatically different spike protein, raising concerns about its effectiveness against current vaccines. The World Health Organization will discuss the risks and designate the variant as a variant of interest or concern. Several countries, including South Africa, Botswana, and Hong Kong, have reported cases of the variant, and experts warn that it may be too late to implement travel curbs.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: London's Heathrow is considering increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade, while Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC appoints Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings slowdown. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increases 30.5% to S$3.1 million. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore factory output to stay positive - but electronics slowdown may kick in soon
summary: Singapore's industrial output rebounded in October, with year-on-year production growth of 16.9%, led by a rebound in the biomedical manufacturing cluster. However, economists warn that the electronics sector, which has driven growth this year, may slow down in 2022 due to supply chain issues. Despite this, the overall manufacturing landscape is expected to remain resilient, with transport engineering and chemicals production showing strength. Factory growth is expected to slow to a single-digit pace in 2022, with economists forecasting a 2-4% year-on-year growth rate.

site_title: Active versus passive? Why it's not that simple anymore
summary: The global asset management industry is shifting away from the traditional active vs. passive debate, as both approaches are becoming more integrated. The rise of index funds and ETFs has led to a surge in passive investing, with over half of US equity funds now using passive strategies. However, active managers are adapting by creating hybrid styles that combine passive and active approaches, with some funds achieving market-beating results. As the industry continues to evolve, concerns remain about the potential impact on financial markets and the role of active managers in promoting ethical investing.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists H2 profit up 56.4 per cent to S$2.45m
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS) reported a 56.4% increase in net profit to S$2.45 million for the second half of the year, bringing full-year net profit up 73.2% to S$4.48 million. The company proposed a final one-tier exempt dividend of S$0.0028 per share, subject to shareholders' approval at an upcoming annual general meeting.

site_title: Japan approves US$6.8b boost for domestic chip industry
summary: Japan's government approved a US$6.8 billion funding package to support domestic semiconductor investment, aiming to make the nation a major global provider of essential computer chips. The package consists of funding for cutting-edge chip manufacturing, legacy production, and research and development of next-generation silicon. The investment will also support a planned semiconductor plant in Kumamoto prefecture. This move is part of Japan's efforts to fortify domestic chipmaking capacity, driven by growing demand for computing power in emerging technologies like 5G and autonomous driving.

site_title: Singtel, M1-StarHub tie-up, and TPG provisionally awarded 2.1 GHz spectrum rights for 5G networks
summary: Singtel and an M1-StarHub consortium have been provisionally awarded 25MHz of 2.1GHz spectrum for 5G networks in Singapore. TPG Telecom was awarded 10MHz. This allows mobile users to choose from three 5G standalone networks if operators meet deployment conditions. The spectrum auction aims to support the deployment of 5G networks in the country.

site_title: ecoWise EGM 'voluntarily postponed'
summary: ecoWise Holdings has voluntarily postponed its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove the deputy chief executive, Cao Shixuan, after he applied for an injunction against the meeting. The EGM, which was set for November 26, was called by shareholders who wanted to remove Cao due to his involvement in the company's recent struggles. The board had previously filed an update stating that the outcome of Cao's injunction application was unknown, but the postponement was announced by the company's founder and CEO Lee Thiam Seng.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.38 points to 1,512.22. Volume reached 4.901 billion lots worth RM3.484 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 993 to 195.

site_title: Bitcoin slumps as coronavirus variant shakes markets
summary: Bitcoin plummeted almost 8% on Friday, falling to its lowest since October 12, as investors sought safer assets amid a new, potentially vaccine-resistant coronavirus variant. The variant, detected in South Africa, Botswana, and Hong Kong, has unusual mutations and may evade immune responses. This has led to a slump in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, with smaller coins also falling. The market is expected to continue losing value, with experts warning of a further decline in Bitcoin's upside potential.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble on fears over new virus variant
summary: European stocks plummeted over 3% on Friday due to fears of a new, possibly vaccine-resistant coronavirus variant. The variant, detected in South Africa, Botswana, and Hong Kong, has an unusual combination of mutations that may evade immune responses or increase transmissibility. This sparked a global economic slowdown worry, leading to a drop in cyclical-heavy stocks, oil, and gas producers, and travel companies. The pan-European STOXX 600 index fell 3.3%, with the UK's FTSE 100 and Germany's DAX also experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Singapore factory output to stay positive - but electronics slowdown may kick in soon
summary: Singapore's industrial output rebounded in October with a 16.9% year-on-year growth rate, reversing a 2.2% decrease in the previous month. The rebound was led by the biomedical manufacturing cluster, where pharmaceuticals output nearly doubled. However, economists predict that factory growth will slow down from here, mainly due to a slowdown in the electronics sector, which may be affected by supply chain issues. The sector's growth is expected to be slower, but overall, Singapore's industrial output is expected to remain positive in 2022.

site_title: Evergrande's Hui cuts stake for first time in race for cash
summary: China Evergrande Group Chairman Hui Ka Yan cut his stake in the company to 67.87% after selling 1.2 billion shares for $344 million. The sale, his first since 2009, is part of efforts to liquidate personal assets to avoid a default. Hui has injected over $1 billion into Evergrande since July, mainly by disposing of personal assets and pledging shares. The move comes as regulators urge Hui to use his own wealth to shore up the company's finances, which have liabilities exceeding $300 billion.

site_title: Asia, Europe well-positioned to build up resilience, overcome Covid-19 impact: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for Asia and Europe to build resilience and overcome the COVID-19 pandemic's impact. He highlighted the potential for knowledge and expertise sharing, supply chain restoration, and safe international travel. Singapore has introduced quarantine-free vaccinated travel lanes with 27 countries, including 10 European and 8 Asia-Pacific nations. Lee hopes this model will facilitate safe travel arrangements among countries in Asia and Europe. The Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM) Summit, hosted by Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, focused on collaboration, connectivity, and COVID-19 recovery.

site_title: Tata in talks to set up US$300m semiconductor assembly unit
summary: Tata Group is in talks with three Indian states to invest up to $300 million to set up a semiconductor assembly and test unit, as part of its push into high-tech manufacturing. The unit, expected to employ up to 4,000 workers, will be built by Tata, which is also scouting for land in southern states of Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, and Telangana. This move bolsters India's 'Make in India' drive for electronics manufacturing and will bolster Tata's portfolio with hardware capabilities, critical for long-term growth.

site_title: China Everbright signs 1.43b yuan deal to expand and upgrade wastewater treatment plant in Qingdao
summary: China Everbright Water has signed a 1.43 billion yuan (S$307 million) deal to expand and upgrade its wastewater treatment plant in Qingdao, China. The 25-year project, under a build-operate-transfer model, will increase the plant's capacity to 220,000 cubic meters a day and upgrade discharged water to meet China's national environmental standards. The expansion aims to create an "iconic water project" with high-quality facilities and a neighborhood-friendly park, engaging the local community.

site_title: Mizuho CEO steps down after regulator hit on system issues
summary: Mizuho Financial Group's CEO Tatsufumi Sakai will step down on April 1 after Japan's banking regulator issued a business improvement order due to system glitches. The regulator criticized Mizuho for inadequate risk management and failure to learn from past incidents. The bank's leadership, including CEO Koji Fujiwara and Chairman Yasuhiro Sato, will also leave their positions on April 1. Mizuho has been plagued by major IT problems since its merger in 2002 and has struggled to catch up with bigger rivals in the Japanese banking industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.67% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 24,080.52, due to fears over a new coronavirus variant. Firms linked to travel and tourism were among the worst hit. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index experienced smaller declines. The decline follows a global trend of market volatility amid uncertainty over the new variant and its potential impact on vaccines.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post biggest weekly drop in a month on virus fears
summary: South Korea's shares plummeted, posting the largest weekly drop in a month, due to fears of the new coronavirus variant spreading in Africa and concerns it may make vaccines less effective. The benchmark KOSPI index fell 1.47% to a 2-week low, while the won and bond yield also declined. Key stocks, including Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix, fell 1.9% and 1.7%, respectively, amid heightened virus-related risks.

site_title: Berjaya Corp divests stake in Razer Fintech
summary: Berjaya Corp sold a 30% stake in Razer Fintech to Razer for $53.6 million, reducing its stake to 19%. The sale is part of Berjaya's operations transformation efforts. Razer Fintech had failed to secure a digital banking license in Singapore and instead focused on payment services. The sale comes as Razer considers a buyout with a consortium to take the company private, valuing it at up to $35 billion.

site_title: Singapore stocks slump on Friday on new Covid-19 variant fears; STI falls 1.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.7% on Friday, closing at 3,166.27 points, due to fears over a new Covid-19 variant in South Africa. The drop was the highest percentage decline since May 14, with all 30 STI constituent stocks registering losses. Key performers declined 4.2% and 3.8%, while local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC also dropped 1.6% each. Market strategist Geoff Howie attributed the decline to investors seeking to exit the market amid concerns over the new strain's potential for being more infectious and vaccine-resistant.

site_title: Singapore's alleged nickel scammer sued in S$517m action
summary: Singaporean businessman Ng Yu Zhi, accused of a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, has been sued by the liquidators of his Envy Group for damages totaling S$517.4 million. Ng, 34, faces 69 charges and had raised at least US$1.46 billion in the alleged investment fraud scheme. Hundreds of investors, including businessmen and financiers, were affected. Ng remains on bail and has not pleaded guilty. The lawsuit was filed by the liquidators, led by Bob Yap of KPMG Singapore, on November 19.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices ease for 2nd month after record high
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 0.9% in October for the second consecutive month, easing from a record high. The prices had risen for eight months before that, reaching historical highs in May 2019. Buyers became cautious before a policy address, but after the announcement, transaction volume increased by 40% in November. The Hong Kong government plans to build a Northern Metropolis on the border with Shenzhen to tackle the city's housing shortage. Experts expect November home prices to be flat or post a small gain, with a potential boost from a delayed mainland China border reopening.

site_title: Philippines reopens to vaccinated tourists next week
summary: The Philippines will reopen to fully-vaccinated tourists from 157 countries on December 1, more than 20 months after shutting its borders due to the pandemic. The decision comes as the country's daily infection rate hovers at its lowest level since the beginning of the year and vaccination rates increase. Fully vaccinated tourists will not be quarantined if they test negative before their flight and have not traveled to high-infection countries in the previous two weeks. The reopening aims to revive the country's battered tourism sector, which accounts for nearly 13% of its GDP.

site_title: SIA, Garuda ink MOU in 'wide-ranging commercial partnership'
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Garuda Indonesia have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) for a "wide-ranging commercial partnership" aimed at improving customer travel experience and promoting inbound tourism into Indonesia. The partnership includes potential alignment of frequent-flyer programs, joint marketing activities, and air-freight cooperation. Regulatory approval is required for the scope of the partnership, which also includes code-sharing on flights to Mumbai. The agreement was signed by SIA's CEO Goh Choon Pong and Garuda Indonesia's CEO Irfan Setiaputra, reflecting the strong bilateral ties between the two countries.

site_title: WHO cautions against travel curbs over new Covid variant
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has cautioned against imposing travel restrictions due to the B.1.1.529 Covid-19 variant, urging countries to take a risk-based and scientific approach. The WHO's Technical Advisory Group on Virus Evolution is holding a meeting to discuss the variant, first detected in South Africa. The organization warned that travel curbs would take weeks to understand the implications of the newly discovered strain, and cautioned against restrictions without sufficient data.

site_title: Malaysia's ATA takes 'serious view' of forced labour allegations, whistleblower claims
summary: Malaysia's Dyson supplier ATA IMS has taken a "serious view" of forced labor allegations and physical abuse claims made by a former worker, Dhan Kumar Limbu. After a Reuters report, Dyson cut ties with ATA, sending its shares plummeting. ATA appointed consultants and a law firm to review the allegations, finding that the claims may be unjustified. Analysts forecast years of losses for ATA, citing a dent in the company's reputation and challenges in securing new customers.

site_title: New virus variant boosts sagging glove maker stocks in South-east Asia
summary: A new coronavirus variant in South Africa has boosted shares of South-east Asian glove makers, reversing a slump in the sector this year. Top Glove Corporation and other manufacturers, such as Supermax Corporation and Hartalega Holdings, saw significant gains, with Top Glove jumping 15% and Supermax rising 16%. The rally was the largest in months for some companies, which had lost pandemic gains due to vaccine rollouts and economic reopening. The sector's performance outperformed regional benchmarks, highlighting the importance of global hygiene in the post-pandemic economy.

site_title: Asian markets battered in knee-jerk reaction to new Covid variant
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday as investors reacted to the emergence of a new Covid-19 variant in South Africa and Hong Kong, with the Delta variant being compared to the new B11529 strain for potential infectiousness and vaccine resistance. The Asia-Pacific region saw a major sell-off, with India's S&P BSE Sensex and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 2.9% and 2.7%, respectively. In Singapore, the Straits Times Index tumbled 1.7%, with healthcare and travel-related stocks experiencing gains while hospitality and aviation stocks declined. Analysts warn of a cautious market environment, with haven currencies expected to outperform.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 16.9% in October, driven by a rebound in pharmaceutical manufacturing. The services sector saw a 16% year-over-year increase in takings, while business receipts rose 4.8% quarter-over-quarter. Singapore banned entry from 7 African countries amid concerns over a new Covid-19 variant. The logistics sector is expected to experience significant job changes with 54% of roles experiencing a medium degree of change with Industry 4.0 adoption. The STI fell 1.7% on Friday due to fears over the new variant.
