images.alt_text: Singapore's factory sector returned to growth in October, after a worse-than-expected decline in the month before, with help from a rebound in the volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster.

site_title: Flights cancelled, schools shut over 3 Covid-19 cases in Shanghai
summary: Hundreds of flights were cancelled and schools shut in Shanghai after three Covid-19 cases were reported, as China continues its strict zero-Covid policy. The cases, all fully vaccinated, were linked to a group of friends who traveled to Suzhou. Authorities also suspended tour groups and closed hospitals, with Beijing on high alert for potential outbreaks ahead of the Winter Olympics. The Shanghai government's "closed-loop" bubble, sealed off for the Olympics, has been reinforced, with the city's leadership determined to host a Covid-free Games.

site_title: Europe rushes to bolster virus defences as South Africa detects new strain
summary: Europe rushes to bolster virus defenses amid a new Covid-19 strain detected in South Africa, which scientists fear could undo gains against the pandemic. The heavily mutated B.1.1.529 variant has at least 10 mutations, raising concerns about its transmissibility and vaccine-susceptibility. European countries accelerate booster campaigns, enforce stricter curbs, and target the unvaccinated as cases multiply to record levels, with some announcing new measures to stem the tide of infections. The World Health Organization closely monitors the variant and is expected to determine its classification.

site_title: Pacific International Lines creditors to receive US$1b repayment ahead of schedule
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) has announced it will repay US$1 billion in scheme debts ahead of schedule by December 30, 2021, to its main creditors including financial institutions and security holders. This repayment includes reinstated senior debt creditors and holders of option A and option B securities. Upon redemption, option A securityholders will receive the principal amount along with accrued distributions.

site_title: Bank of Japan's newest board member sees inflation creeping up
summary: Bank of Japan's newest board member, Junko Nakagawa, suggests inflation is creeping up in Japan, despite the bank holding its monetary stimulus in place. Japan's consumer prices have edged up over the last two months, driven by higher energy costs, and Nakagawa sees upward pressure strengthening. The bank's 2% inflation target may not be reached until years from now, but processed foods and other items are rising due to foreign exchange rates and rising oil costs. The yen's weakness is a mixed bag for the economy, with both positive and negative impacts.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH initiates Trans-China Automotive with 'buy', S$0.39 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on Trans-China Automotive (TCA) with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.39, citing the growing demand for after-sales services in China due to the increasing number of high-net-worth individuals. The research house expects TCA's after-sales services segment to grow in line with the rising BMW automobile population and the company's growth in new automotive sales. TCA's high service absorption ratio provides high earnings visibility for the segment.

site_title: JTC awards Jalan Papan site tender for S$5.6m to Trans-Euro
summary: JTC awards tender for Jalan Papan site to Trans-Euro for S$5.6m. The 8,814 sqm site, zoned for general and special industries, has a 20-year tenure and gross plot ratio of 1.4. This is the second time the site was tendered, following an unsuccessful bid in April 2021. The project completion is expected to be 60 months.

site_title: What do we know about the new Covid-19 variant from South Africa with 'unusual' mutations?
summary: A new, heavily-mutated variant of Covid-19, B11529, has been detected in South Africa, raising concerns over its transmissibility and ability to evade vaccines. The variant has rapidly increased in Gauteng province and may already be present in other provinces. It has 32 mutations in its spike protein, potentially reducing vaccine effectiveness. The World Health Organisation is monitoring the variant and has called a special meeting to discuss its impact. South Africa has reported 22 confirmed cases, and cases have been detected in neighboring countries, including Botswana and Hong Kong.

site_title: Singapore bans entry from South Africa and 6 other African countries amid new Covid variant from that region
summary: Singapore has banned entry from 7 African countries, including South Africa, amid concerns over the new B.1.1.529 Covid-19 variant. Starting November 27, non-resident visitors who have traveled to Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, and Zimbabwe in the last 14 days will not be allowed to enter or transit through Singapore. Singaporeans and permanent residents returning from these countries will serve a 10-day stay-home notice. The restrictions will initially last for 4 weeks, with further review and extension possible.

site_title: Unusual enters JV to expand into NFT market
summary: Unusual Limited, a CATALIST-listed company, announced a joint venture (JV) with Season Culture and an unnamed angel investor to expand into the non-fungible token (NFT) market. The JV, called FunBase, will incorporate NFTs into live events, such as special edition collectibles, digital tickets, and audio/video assets. Unusual will hold a 30% equity interest, with the option to increase its stake to 51% over the next 3 years. This move aims to build an interactive fan-based community and alternative distribution channel for future product innovation.

site_title: China Evergrande soccer stadium taken over by government: source
summary: China Evergrande Group's soccer stadium, the Guangzhou Evergrande Football Stadium, has been taken over by the government with plans to sell it. Construction halted due to lack of capital, and the stadium's future is uncertain. Evergrande is also considering selling its money-losing Guangzhou Football Club. The company, struggling to meet debt repayments, has halted construction on the stadium, which was set to be the world's largest soccer venue by capacity. The move is part of efforts by local governments to steer sales of Evergrande's assets.

site_title: More than half of financial disputes filed in Singapore were against banks, finance companies
summary: More than half of financial disputes filed in Singapore were against banks and finance companies, with 52% of claims made against these institutions in the 2020/2021 financial year. The majority of disputes (42%) related to unauthorised transactions, frauds, and scams, while 31% involved inappropriate advice or misrepresentation issues. The Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre (FIDReC) resolved 862 claims in the first stage of mediation, with 48% resulting in a settlement. The centre attributed the surge in claims to the Covid-19 pandemic, which led to more online transactions and increased financial stress.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Metroline Travel acquires London site for £3.6m
summary: ComfortDelGro's Metroline Travel acquired a 1.01-hectare property in Brentford, London, for £3.6m (S$6.6m). The purchase allows Metroline Travel to invest in a new bus garage development in London, further expanding its presence in the UK. The transaction was facilitated by Waterside Places, a joint venture between Canal & River Trust and Muse Developments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 4.66 points or 0.31% to 1,512.94. Losers outnumbered gainers 347 to 122, with a trading volume of 313.84 million lots worth RM160.66 million.

site_title: Australia steps up efforts to boost gas supply
summary: Australia's government has proposed a plan to increase gas supply by investing in new pipelines, despite its goal of achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The plan aims to support job-creating industries, including food production and manufacturing, which rely on cheap gas. Industry Minister Angus Taylor stated that unlocking gas reserves and delivering gas to where it's needed will drive economic growth. The move is seen as a response to the economic slump caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks plunge on variant fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 3% on Friday, Nov 26, as a heavily mutated Covid-19 variant sparked investor fear. The Nikkei 225 index fell 2.53% to 28,751.62, while the Topix index dropped 2.01% to 1,984.98. The yen strengthened as investors sought safe-haven assets. The decline was attributed to concerns over the variant's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH upgrades Maybank to 'buy' on faster-than-expected recovery in provisions
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded its call on Maybank to "buy" from "hold" with a higher target price of RM9.20, citing a faster-than-expected recovery in provisions. The bank reported a higher-than-expected net profit for its third quarter, with core earnings up 16.9% year-over-year. Analyst Keith Wee attributed the upgrade to lower-than-expected credit costs and attractive dividend yield, despite weaker-than-expected investment and trading income. The bank's management also indicated a possibility of lower credit costs for 2021, further supporting the upgrade.

site_title: Takings rise 16% year on year for Singapore's services industries in Q3
summary: Singapore's services industries saw a 16% year-on-year increase in business receipts for the third quarter, according to Singstat figures. This growth was driven by sectors such as information and communications services, transportation and storage, real estate, and finance and insurance. Economists expect services business receipts to continue improving in the fourth quarter, driven by the relaxation of travel curbs and domestic restrictions. The lone exception was the recreation and personal services industry, which saw a 13.3% year-on-year decline due to tightened Covid-19 curbs.

images.alt_text: On a quarterly basis, transportation and storage saw the largest revenue increase of 13.9 per cent in Q3, due mainly to shipping lines seeing higher freight rates and volume.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust closes flat at IPO price of S$0.80 in SGX mainboard debut
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) made its trading debut on the SGX mainboard at S$0.80, closing flat. The Reit raised S$575.5 million from its IPO, with 28.9 million shares changing hands. The public offer was 9.5 times subscribed, and the international placement tranche was 4.9 times subscribed. The majority of the proceeds will fund the purchase of 14 logistics properties in Japan.

site_title: VTLs launched with Thailand, Cambodia, Fiji, Maldives, Sri Lanka and Turkey
summary: Singapore launches Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with Thailand on Dec 14 and with six other countries (Cambodia, Fiji, Maldives, Sri Lanka, and Turkey) on Dec 16, increasing the total to 27. Returning Singapore citizens and permanent residents can use VTLs without applying for travel passes. Countries in Category 2 (Argentina, Kuwait, Mexico, Mongolia, Morocco, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Romania, and Thailand) require a 7-day stay-home notice, while those in Category 3 (Belize, Costa Rica, Kazakhstan, Mauritius, Panama, Peru, Uruguay, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Czech Republic, Liechtenstein, and Slovakia) require a 10-day notice.

images.alt_text: Singapore is launching Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with Thailand from Dec 14 and with Cambodia, Fiji, Maldives, Sri Lanka and Turkey from Dec 16.

site_title: China asks Didi to delist from US on security fears: sources
summary: Chinese regulators have asked Didi Global's executives to devise a plan to delist from the US bourses due to concerns about sensitive data leakage. The Cyberspace Administration of China has directed the company to work out precise details subject to government approval. This request is seen as a revival of fears about Beijing's intentions for its tech industry, raising questions about data security and potential repercussions for Didi's operations globally.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as energy stocks weigh; set for third weekly loss
summary: Australian shares slipped to 7,375.0, set for a third consecutive weekly loss, due to energy stocks' decline. Oil prices dipped as investors eyed US-led emergency oil release, affecting companies like Woodside Petroleum, Oil Search, and Santos. Miners also fell, while financial stocks and gold stocks dropped. Payments solution provider EML Payments rose 8.3% despite the overall market decline.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.96% decline, falling 237.48 points to 24,502.68, following a sell-off in Asia due to fears over a new virus variant with multiple mutations that could spread globally. The Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also decreased by 0.23% and 0.18%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply lower on Friday (Nov 26) morning, in line with a sell-off across Asia following the discovery of a new virus variant that has several mutations and has fanned fears it could spread globally.

site_title: Gold set for worst week in 5 months on hawkish Fed view
summary: Gold prices are set for their worst week in 5 months due to increasing bets on the US Federal Reserve accelerating stimulus tapering and raising interest rates to curb inflation. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,792.62 per ounce, while US gold futures advanced 0.5%. The metal has declined 2.8% this week, its worst week since June 18. A stronger dollar and reduced stimulus also push government bond yields up, raising the opportunity cost of gold.

site_title: US Thanksgiving online shopping spending to set record
summary: US consumers are expected to spend a record US$5.1-5.4 billion online on Thanksgiving Day, according to Adobe Analytics. This represents a decline from the initially estimated US$5.9 billion, as shoppers are forced online due to physical store closures. Electronics and apparel are popular categories, with online spending reaching US$2.3 billion by 3 pm New York time. This marks a busy shopping season for the US retail industry, despite inflation and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Beijing Capital weighs sale of Singapore waste recycling unit: sources
summary: Beijing Capital Group Co is considering selling its waste management business in Singapore, ECO Special Waste Management, for up to $500 million. The state-owned Chinese firm is in talks with advisers about the potential divestment, which is at an early stage. This move follows a trend of waste recycling businesses being acquired by investors, with recent deals including Macquarie Group's purchase of Bingo Industries for $1.9 billion and Platinum Equity's purchase of Urbaser for $4.2 billion. Beijing Capital acquired ECO Special Waste Management for $246 million in 2015.

site_title: Singapore factory output up by 16.9% in October on pharmaceuticals rebound
summary: Singapore's factory sector experienced a 16.9% year-over-year increase in October, driven by a rebound in the pharmaceutical manufacturing cluster. This rebounded from a 2.2% decline in September. The biomedical manufacturing sector saw a 56.1% jump, with pharmaceuticals output nearly doubling from a low base. This growth outpaced the median estimate of 14.5%. The Economic Development Board released the figures, showing a return to growth for the factory sector after a decline in the previous month.

site_title: Asia: Fears over new Covid variant hit markets, oil prices
summary: Asian markets and oil prices dropped on Friday due to fears of a new Covid-19 variant, B.1.1.529, which scientists believe could be more infectious and resistant to vaccines. The World Health Organization is set to decide whether to designate it a variant of "interest" or "concern". As a result, Britain and Israel banned travel from countries in southern Africa, including South Africa, where the variant has been reported. This led to a decline in stocks and oil prices, while safe havens such as gold and bonds rose.

site_title: EU sees 'decisive moment' for building single capital market
summary: The European Union has proposed its third wave of reforms to create a seamless securities market, or capital markets union (CMU), in a bid to compete with London and New York. The proposals include establishing a "tape" or record of stock and bond prices, giving investors free information on companies, and tweaks to long-term investment funds. The goal is to make it easier for companies to raise money for climate goals and recover from the pandemic. The proposals need approval from the European Parliament and EU states, with industry lobbyists expected to push for changes, including real-time data and tax reforms.

site_title: Japan PM to call for 3% wage hike in next year's labour talks: Kyodo
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to request a 3% wage hike in next year's labor talks, aiming to distribute wealth to households and ease consumer pain from rising costs. This would be the first time the government sets a numerical target for businesses on wage hikes in four years. However, companies may be cautious about increasing wages amid economic uncertainty, and the proposal's success is uncertain.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine returns to profit for H2
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a net profit of S$8.8 million for its half-year ended Sep 30, 2021, reversing a net loss of S$8.5 million from the same period last year. Revenue grew 103.3% to S$25 million, driven by growth from its ship chartering and shipbuilding and repair operations segments. This marks a significant turnaround from the same period last year, showcasing the company's recovery and growth in the marine logistics industry.

site_title: Half of all logistics sector jobs to change or be displaced with Industry 4.0
summary: The logistics sector is expected to undergo significant changes, with at least 54% of job roles (30 out of 56) undergoing a medium degree of change or displacement due to the adoption of Industry 4.0. The Jobs Transformation Map, a study by the Economic Development Board and supported by various government agencies, predicts that 30 job roles will experience significant changes, while 26 will experience incremental changes. This shift is expected to occur within the next 3-5 years.

site_title: Cuscaden says scheme should 'proceed expeditiously' if SPH shareholders vote against Keppel deal
summary: Cuscaden Peak's proposed acquisition of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) can proceed expeditiously if SPH shareholders vote against Keppel's deal, according to Cuscaden. The 8-week restriction clause imposed by Keppel BN4 would not apply if either party votes against the deal. Cuscaden's revised offer of S$2.40 per share is considered superior to Keppel's S$2.351 per share offer, prompting SPH to call for shareholders to vote down Keppel's proposal.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.65% and the Topix index down 0.60%. The move followed US markets closing for the Thanksgiving holiday, with no fresh cues.

site_title: What makes a dysfunctional work culture?
summary: A dysfunctional work culture is characterized by traditional power structures, devaluing staff empowerment, and poor conflict management. This can manifest in practices such as professional hazing, where younger staff are burdened with grunt work, and managers reject disagreements over workload allocation. The "myth of family" also perpetuates a culture of guilt-shaming, emotional manipulation, and rank-pulling, leading to diminished respect and constructive disagreements. Companies that fail to address these issues risk losing top talent, particularly during the Great Resignation.

images.alt_text: Culture is about how an organisation treats and values its people, wherever they may be.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.7% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 23.91 points to 3,197.61. European shares rebounded, while US markets were closed for the Thanksgiving holiday. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, while Tritech Group gained 9.5%. The decline was attributed to worries about soaring coronavirus cases in Europe and the impact on global markets.

site_title: More than 50 reported dead in Siberia coal mine accident
summary: At least 52 people, including 6 rescuers, have died in a Siberian coal mine accident in Russia's Kemerovo region. The mine, Listvyazhnaya, filled with smoke after a spark or methane explosion, prompting a rescue operation that ended in tragedy. Senior managers have been detained for suspected safety violations. The incident marks another deadly accident in Russia's mining industry, with 40 people hospitalized and a three-day mourning period declared.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided text appears to be a collection of article titles and publication dates, but no specific article content is provided.

site_title: Canada worst on climate of G-7 nations: commissioner
summary: Canada ranks as the "worst performer" among G-7 nations in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, according to Environment Commissioner Jerry DeMarco. Despite having a 1.6% global share of emissions, Canada has seen a 20% increase since 1990. DeMarco criticized the government for failing to deliver results, citing a fund for oil and gas companies to reduce emissions, which instead increased production. Canada aims to cut emissions 40-45% by 2030, but lacks an updated climate plan.

site_title: Britain alarmed by new Covid-19 variant spreading in South Africa
summary: Britain is concerned over a newly identified Covid-19 variant, B.1.1.529, spreading in South Africa that may make vaccines less effective. The UK Health Security Agency has launched urgent research to understand its transmissibility, severity, and vaccine-susceptibility. The variant's spike protein is dramatically different from the original coronavirus used in Covid-19 vaccines, prompting alarm over efforts to fight the pandemic.

site_title: Frasers Property proposes tie-up with JV partner involving investment, bridging loan
summary: Frasers Property has entered into a framework agreement with an unnamed joint-venture partner to potentially invest in land, with the company's wholly-owned subsidiary Suzhou Sing He Xiang Management Consultancy providing 1.6 billion yuan (S$337 million) in funding. The deal also includes an interest-bearing bridging loan of 1 billion yuan, set to be repaid by Apr 1, 2022. If successful, the investment would reduce Frasers Property's earnings per share by S$0.004 and its profit attributable to shareholders by S$14.4 million.

site_title: Australia's securities regulator sues ANZ over home loan referrals
summary: Australia's Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has sued ANZ Banking Group over home loan referrals under its 'introducer programme'. The regulator alleges ANZ breached consumer protection laws between June 2016 and March 2018 by accepting customer information from unlicensed individuals. ASIC claims this was in breach of credit laws, which only allow licensed individuals to act as introducers. The regulator's actions follow a review of ANZ's practices. The lawsuit seeks enforcement action and damages.

site_title: Why the meta matters
summary: The metaverse has garnered attention from futurists, crypto-evangelists, and companies like Facebook due to its potential to revolutionize digital economies. However, there is also skepticism regarding gamified worlds and virtual wealth. Despite a lackluster outcome from COP26, the metaverse is expected to take digital economies to a new level. The concept has sparked debate about the importance of addressing climate issues and the potential for a talent shakeout in workplaces due to defensive corporate practices.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit 3-month lows, upbeat data no help
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hit three-month lows due to global risk aversion, overshadowing economic strength at home. The Aussie fell 0.5% to a three-month trough of US$0.7159, while the kiwi dollar dropped 2.4% to US$0.6830. The decline is attributed to a broad-based rally in the US dollar and concerns over a newly identified coronavirus variant making vaccines less effective. Despite upbeat domestic data, including a 4.9% jump in Australian retail sales, the currencies are expected to continue their losses.

site_title: Australian retail sales surge in Oct as economy revives
summary: Australian retail sales surged 4.9% in October to A$31.1 billion, exceeding forecasts and further evidence of the economy's rapid recovery. Clothing stores, department stores, and restaurants saw significant gains, with the A$360 billion retail sector expected to contribute to economic growth. With vaccination rates high and lockdown restrictions lifted, real consumer spending could bounce back by 10% this quarter, and consumption will continue to expand at a rapid pace next year.

site_title: Tokyo core consumer prices rise at fastest pace in more than a year
summary: Tokyo's core consumer prices rose 0.3% in November, the fastest pace in over a year, driven by higher electricity and fuel costs. This uptick suggests nationwide inflation may increase in coming months as raw material shortages pass through to retailers and consumers. The increase highlights the impact of global energy prices and overnight stays on local costs.

site_title: China regulator seeks to avoid US delistings of Chinese firms
summary: China's regulatory official, Shen Bing, said the country is working to prevent US delistings of Chinese firms amid a dispute over auditing standards. China has been reluctant to allow overseas regulators to inspect audit working papers, citing national security concerns. US authorities are moving towards kicking foreign companies off US exchanges if their audits fail to meet US standards. China and the US are in talks to resolve the issue, with Shen Bing stating that preventing delistings would be beneficial for companies, investors, and China-US relations.

site_title: UK sets out plans to boost global digital trade
summary: The UK government has set out plans to boost global digital trade, aiming to become a world leader in modern services and online goods. The Board of Trade report highlights the need to address digital protectionism and champion a free, open, and competitive digital economy. This move is expected to provide opportunities for British businesses and boost economic growth. The government will focus on striking digital trade deals and shaping global trade rules to support UK companies exporting innovative services and goods globally.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust IPO public offer 9.5 times subscribed
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, announced that its initial public offering (IPO) public offer was 9.5 times subscribed, with 7,543 valid applications for 237 million units received. The international placement tranche was 4.9 times subscribed, and cornerstone investors subscribed for nearly 336.1 million units. The trust plans to use the funds to purchase 14 logistics properties in Japan, with the majority of the proceeds going towards this purchase.

site_title: Lowest October UK car output since 1956 amid chip shortage
summary: British car output fell 41.4% in October to 64,729 vehicles, the lowest since 1956, due to a global chip shortage and Honda's factory closure. This year's car output is down 2.9% from 2020, with the industry expecting a return to above 1 million vehicles in 2022. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) attributes the challenges to COVID resurgence and stretched supply chains, with the sector considered resilient but facing significant operational hurdles.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce off 3-week lows as utilities rise
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Thursday, bouncing off three-week lows, driven by gains in utilities and healthcare sectors amid concerns about soaring coronavirus cases. Technology stocks also rose 0.6%, while strong economic data and a relatively calm US market supported global sentiment. Despite rising Covid-19 cases, European markets have enjoyed a relatively upbeat day, with some companies, such as Remy Cointreau and Elekta, reporting strong earnings.

site_title: China criticises US for putting Chinese firms on trade blacklist
summary: China has criticized the US for adding 27 Chinese companies to its trade blacklist, citing national security and foreign policy concerns. The US Commerce Department claims the companies support China's military modernization, including quantum computing and counter-stealth technology. China opposes the sanctions, warning it will take countermeasures and lodge formal representations with the US. The move comes amid growing tensions over Taiwan and trade issues.

site_title: Singapore can avoid a Europe-style Covid-19 resurgence: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore can potentially avoid a Europe-style Covid-19 resurgence due to its high vaccination rate of 85% and growing natural immunity. The country's immunized population is half as likely to die from Covid-19 as from the flu, while unvaccinated individuals are 5 times more likely to succumb to the infection. With continued vaccination efforts, booster shots, and mitigation measures, Singapore aims to keep ICU cases and deaths low, even if another wave hits, and move towards an endemic disease.

site_title: Dimon says he regrets comment on JPMorgan outlasting CPC
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon apologized for comments suggesting the bank would outlast China's Communist Party, which risked jeopardizing the company's growth ambitions in China. Dimon said he regretted the remark, emphasizing the strength and longevity of his company, and acknowledged that it was a mistake. Experts say his apology should minimize damage, as Beijing sees foreign banks' involvement as crucial for China's financial development. Despite the incident, some experts believe it won't have long-term consequences for JPMorgan's business in China.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi Materials to sell aluminium business to US fund
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi Materials will sell its aluminium business to US investment fund Apollo Global Management for an undisclosed sum. The move is due to difficulties in finding synergies with other businesses, such as electric vehicle parts and cement. The company will book a 29 billion yen (S$343 million) loss as a restructuring charge in the January-March quarter, but this has been discounted in its full-year earnings forecast.

site_title: Soaring Australia house price inflation set to lose altitude next year: survey
summary: Australia's house price inflation rate is expected to lose altitude next year and in 2023, according to a Reuters poll. Despite this, prices are still anticipated to rise in the country's hot property market. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate cuts and cash injection since the pandemic have driven the housing market, with prices nearly doubling since the 2007-09 financial crisis.

site_title: Lights, camera... art!
summary: Singaporean artist Chua Mia Tee's first museum show in 29 years celebrates his cinematic techniques, featuring accurate depictions of Singapore politicians from the 1970s, including Lee Kuan Yew and Goh Chok Tong. The exhibition showcases Chua's use of oil and charcoal to capture the personalities and mannerisms of his subjects. The show highlights Chua's unique ability to render reality, making him one of few Singaporean artists to excel in this area.

site_title: Oil dips, focus on Opec+ response to US-led oil release
summary: Oil prices dipped 0.1% and 0.5% to $82.17 and $78.03 per barrel respectively, as investors await Opec+ response to US-led oil release. Opec+ is expected to meet on Dec 1-2 to set policy, with a source indicating the release is expected to swell oil markets by 1.1 million barrels per day. Despite US-led releases, Opec+ is not discussing pausing output increases, and Opec members remain committed to the agreement. A coordinated release could add 70-80 million barrels of crude supply to markets, analysts say.

site_title: SGX, Changi Airports International launch aviation and travel index
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Changi Airports International (CAI) have launched the iEdge-GateEq Aviation and Travel Index, a market capitalisation-weighted index covering the top 50 listed companies in the global travel and aviation industry. The index aims to capture long-term growth in the sector, which has reached pre-Covid-19 levels, driven by a rally in hospitality and travel-related stocks. The top 10 constituents include major airlines, hospitality companies, and travel booking services.

images.alt_text: One of the top 10 constituents of the iEdge-GateEq Aviation and Travel Index is United Parcel Service (UPS).

site_title: Aurum Land CEO tears walls down to build communities
summary: Aurum Land CEO Michelle Yong is transforming the property development industry through unique designs and lifestyle offerings. The boutique developer focuses on high-end projects with innovative concepts, such as drywall and textured concrete walls. Yong aims to create communities and experiences, hosting group activities and events, and diversifying into co-living retirement spaces and coworking medical spaces. With a strong team and hands-on approach, Yong is driving growth and setting a new standard for the industry, differentiating herself from conventional developers.

site_title: Bus tickets still available for first 30 days of land VTL between Singapore and Malaysia: MTI
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry announced that bus tickets for the first 30 days of the land VTL between Singapore and Malaysia are still available, with over 90% of Transtar tickets and 70% of Causeway Link/Handal Indah tickets remaining. As of 4pm on Nov 25, 4,400 tickets were sold, with 3/4 for trips from Singapore to Malaysia. The daily quota for vaccinated travelers is 2,880, and 240 applications for vaccinated travel passes have been received.

site_title: Singapore's NFT adoption rate set to double
summary: Singapore's adoption rate of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) is expected to double, with 17.8% of the population planning to own them in the near future, according to a survey by Finder.com. The survey found that Singaporeans in the 25-34 age group are most likely to own NFTs, with 12% of respondents in this age group stating they already own an NFT. The country's adoption rate is lower compared to some Asian countries, but higher than Japan and some Western countries.

site_title: Philippines market operator has record-breaking year, sees more listings of Reits, SMEs ahead
summary: The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) has had a record-breaking year, with increased listings of real estate investment trusts (Reits) and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). This growth is attributed to efforts made by the exchange to make it more attractive as a listing destination. PSE president Ramon Monzon attributes the success to these efforts, which have resulted in the exchange's largest-ever initial public offering (IPO) and a surge in capital-raising activities. The exchange's buoyant activity is expected to continue in the coming years.

site_title: A month after reopening, Thailand sees gradual tourism recovery
summary: Thailand is seeing a gradual tourism recovery a month after reopening to foreign arrivals. The country welcomed 106,117 foreign tourists in the first 10 months of 2021, down from 6.7 million in 2020. Hospitality firms are focusing on Western countries and the Middle East, with 70% of bookings coming from Europe. Thailand expects only 200,000 foreign tourists this year and 5 million in 2022. Despite the reopening, some businesses are still struggling with government Covid-19 rules, citing confusion among tourists.

site_title: Kaisa offers to swop bonds for new notes due 2023 in a bid to avert default
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, is offering to exchange its US$400 million 6.5% offshore bonds due December 7 for new notes due June 6, 2023, at the same interest rate, in an effort to avoid default and resolve a liquidity crisis. The proposal must receive at least 95% approval from bondholders to proceed. This move is part of Kaisa's efforts to address its financial difficulties and maintain investor confidence.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, Keppel, Yanlord, Kimly, Daiwa House Logistics Trust
summary: Frasers Property's subsidiary Suzhou Sing He Xiang Management Consultancy agreed to participate in a potential investment in land with a joint venture partner, with an indirect interest of up to 40%. Keppel Corporation won a S$200 million project for converting a floating storage and regasification unit. Yanlord Land Group achieved S$1.09 billion in pre-sales for apartment units in Shanghai. Kimly reported a 55.7% growth in net profit to S$39.3 million for the full year ended Sep 30, 2021. Daiwa House Logistics Trust's public offer was 9.5 times subscribed, with trading set to commence on Friday.

images.alt_text: Keppel Offshore & Marine has been awarded work worth around S$200 million for the conversion of a floating storage and regasification unit, and the integration of a floating production storage and offloading vessel.

site_title: Christmas feasts to savour
summary: Several hotels in Singapore offer festive takeaways and dining options for the holiday season. The Fullerton Hotel Singapore and The Fullerton Bay Hotel Singapore offer a range of festive dishes, including Roasted Biryani Christmas Turkey and Yule Log Cake flavors. The St. Regis Singapore offers traditional roast options, including Whole Roasted Turkey and Smoked Salmon, as well as a classic Buche de Noel. Carlton Hotel Singapore and Orchard Hotel Singapore also offer festive takeaway goodies and party packs, while Orange Clove Catering provides gourmet platters and festive feasts for delivery.

site_title: UK retailers report strong pre-Christmas demand, biggest price rises since 1990
summary: UK retailers reported the strongest pre-Christmas demand since 2015, with sales volumes increasing by 35% in November, a 3-month high. However, this surge in demand came with the highest price rises since 1990, as retailers sought to stock up ahead of potential shortages. Despite adequate stock levels, early buying was driven by fears of shortages, and employment in the sector rose for the first time in 9 years. The data suggests price pressures may lead to interest rate hikes next month, adding to concerns about the UK economy.

site_title: General counsel and lawyers: Influencers and leaders in sustainability
summary: General counsel and lawyers are playing a pivotal role in sustainability matters as the ESG landscape continues to evolve. With increasing expectations from stakeholders, companies are turning to their in-house lawyers for guidance on sustainability, governance, and risk management. The UN Global Compact defines corporate sustainability as delivering long-term value to various stakeholders. GCs are well-positioned to assume a lead role in sustainability, providing informed advice to boards and C-suite colleagues on ESG matters. As companies articulate their sustainability commitments and targets, GCs play a critical role in reviewing these commitments to ensure they meet stakeholder expectations.

site_title: Singapore reports 1,275 new Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate falls to 0.72
summary: Singapore reported 1,275 new Covid-19 cases, down from 2,079 on Wednesday, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.72, the 13th consecutive day below 1. The Ministry of Health attributed the decline to continued vaccination efforts and enhanced public health measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.67 points to 1,517.60. The decline followed a stronger showing from the STI, which rose 0.4% despite uncertainty from tariffs and split Federal Reserve views. Losers outnumbered gainers 712 to 302, with a total volume of 3.812 billion lots worth RM2.416 billion.

site_title: Dollar slips from 16-month highs as Fed hawkishness dominates
summary: The US dollar slipped from its 16-month highs on Thursday, November 25, 2021, as market expectations shifted towards a sooner rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Minutes from the Fed's meeting indicated increased concern over inflation, boosting the dollar. Despite this, the dollar index paused slightly, and the euro recovered slightly, while the Japanese yen reached a 5-year peak. Analysts predict further dollar strength, but a period of tactical consolidation might be close, especially with US markets closed for Thanksgiving.

site_title: The post-pandemic CEO: leadership capabilities have never been more important
summary: The post-pandemic business landscape has presented a significant test for CEOs, who had to balance immediate concerns with long-term planning. As the global economy recovers, the role of corporations has been re-imagined with growing societal expectations and external realities. Effective leadership capabilities have become more crucial in this new environment, and companies should prioritize authentic leadership to thrive in uncertain times. The shift towards hybrid work and digital transformation has also changed the way organizations operate, and CEOs must adapt to these changes to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: CEOs today need to be well-versed in issues such as sustainability and social justice, along with the areas specific to their business and the markets they operate in.

site_title: Foxconn's US$4b unit Jusda seeks pre-IPO financing: sources
summary: Jusda, a logistics arm of Foxconn Technology Group, is seeking US$300-400 million in pre-IPO funding from private investors ahead of a potential initial public offering (IPO) in 2022. The company, valued at up to US$4 billion, plans to use the funds for expansion amid a boom in logistics services. Jusda is also evaluating a potential listing in Hong Kong in the second half of next year.

site_title: ESG hires into 7-digit pay league
summary: Private equity firms and hedge funds are significantly increasing salaries for specialists in sustainable finance, pushing the field into a 7-digit pay league. According to headhunters, top ESG jobs now command annual pay of £1 million, with bonuses and carried interest contributing to the high figures. The growing demand for sustainable finance talent is driving the shift, with some firms appointing executives to head up their sustainability efforts. The industry faces pressure to prove its commitment to ESG and avoid greenwashing, and a shortage of qualified staff is holding investors back from adopting more sustainable strategies.

site_title: StanChart CEO finds room for bank to disrupt itself
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters says the bank is well-positioned to "disrupt itself" and generate at least half of its income from digital streams in the next 5-10 years. The bank is repackaging existing products and venturing into new business models, such as partnerships with e-commerce giants and setting up digital-only banks. Winters believes the bank's size and agility give it an advantage in the digital world, allowing it to carve out a differentiated proposition and generate new market share. The bank is also exploring carbon offset schemes to help corporates transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.22% to 24,740.16, driven by gains in technology firms, following a positive lead from Wall Street. Despite soaring global inflation, traders remained cautious. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.24% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.33%. The rally came ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: New bonus GFA scheme is a carrot that comes with a stick
summary: Singapore has introduced a five-year Built Environment Transformation GFA Incentive Scheme, offering up to 3% bonus gross floor area for private developments that meet enhanced standards in productivity, digitalisation, sustainability, and quality. To qualify, sites must have a minimum GFA of 5,000 sqm. However, critics note that the scheme's all-or-nothing approach and associated costs may be a challenge for developers, with some warning of potential financial risks and difficulties in meeting the required criteria.

site_title: Kimly full-year profit up 55.7% to S$39.3m; proposes 0.84 cents final dividend, 0.6 cents special dividend
summary: Kimly, a coffee shop and food court operator, reported a 55.7% increase in net profit to S$39.3 million for the full year ended Sep 30, 2021. Revenue grew 13.2% to S$238.6 million. The company proposes a final dividend of 0.84 cents per share and a special dividend of 0.6 cents per share.

site_title: Dyson dumps Malaysian supplier ATA over labour concerns
summary: British tech company Dyson has terminated its contracts with Malaysian supplier ATA IMS due to labour concerns, following an audit and allegations by a whistleblower. ATA, which produces parts for Dyson's vacuum cleaners and air purifiers, has faced scrutiny over claims of migrant workers being subjected to abusive working and living conditions. The termination, effective six months from notice, is a significant blow to Malaysia's electronics manufacturing industry, which has faced scrutiny this year over forced labour allegations. Dyson has expressed hope that the move will prompt ATA to improve working conditions.

site_title: Yanlord sells all units in pre-sale of Shanghai residential project, nets 5.08b yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group sold all 299 units of its Shanghai residential project, Yanlord Arcadia, in 5 hours, generating 5.08 billion yuan (S$1.09 billion) in pre-sales. The units, ranging from 80 to 271 square meters, were sold at a high quality residential property development in Yangpu district, Shanghai. CEO Zhong Sheng Jian attributed the success to market preference for Yanlord's properties in the area, which is served by an excellent transport network and amenities.

site_title: Julien Royer does mum proud with Claudine
summary: French chef Julien Royer's new bistro, Claudine, is a tribute to his mother's and grandmothers' recipes. The upscale eatery offers a unique blend of rustic and Michelin-starred flavors, with dishes like sardine toast, onion soup, and choux farci. The menu is large, but sharing is recommended to stay within budget. Standout dishes include Gillardeau oysters and vol-au-vent, which showcases Royer's fine dining spin. Claudine's decor, inspired by his mother's free-picked flowers, is a demure peaches and cream color scheme with dramatic accents. The restaurant is open for lunch and dinner, Tues to Sun.

images.alt_text: Choux farci, said to be an Autumn dish, is turned into elegant fare with luxe ingredients.
(Left) The organic egg forestiere is a treat for oozy egg-yolk lovers. (Right) Claudine's decor is a demure peaches and cream, with a dramatic burgundy ceiling.

site_title: US dollar slips from 16-month highs as Fed hawkishness dominates
summary: The US dollar slipped from its 16-month highs on Thursday, despite remaining close to its highest level since July 2020 against the euro. The dollar's upward trend was boosted by the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on inflation, with policymakers indicating a possible earlier rate hike. However, the dollar's gains paused as market expectations of a temporary blip took hold. The euro recovered slightly, while other major currencies, such as the Japanese yen and Australian dollar, also showed some gains, with the euro up 0.2% and the yen near a 5-year peak.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Changi Airports International (CAI) launched the iEdge-GateEq Aviation and Travel Index, covering top 50 global travel and aviation companies. MatchMove's US$100 million funding raise remains unresolved. Robust IPO activity in South-east Asia, driven by Thailand, the Philippines, and Indonesia, boosted capital markets. Citigroup plans to split Institutional Clients Group's operations and technology units. 8i Acquisition 2 Corp raised US$86.3 million in its Nasdaq IPO. Singapore shares closed lower on Thursday due to inflation concerns and tapering worries.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Thursday amid lingering inflation, tapering worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% to 3,221.52 on Thursday due to lingering inflation concerns and faster US Federal Reserve tapering. Markets were mixed across the region, with the Nikkei 225 rising 0.7% and the Hang Seng Index adding 0.2%. Luxury retailers Cortina Holdings and The Hour Glass were top gainers, while DBS and Hongkong Land were the biggest decliners. Analysts expect a hawkish turn by the Federal Open Market Committee in December, with quicker rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Cyberattack not the cause of DBS digital-banking outage; services available again, says bank
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, resumed digital banking services after a two-day outage due to a problem with access-control servers. The disruption resulted in 700 outage reports and was described as a "serious disruption" by the Monetary Authority of Singapore. DBS stated its systems were not targeted by a cyberattack, and customers are advised to restart their devices and clear browser cache to access services. The bank is conducting a thorough investigation to identify root causes and implement necessary measures to prevent future recurrences.

site_title: Malaysia's 5G network fees will cost telcos less, says finance minister
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Zafrul Abdul Aziz, announced that the state agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB) will charge telcos RM350 million to RM400 million per year for 5G network services, significantly less than the RM1 billion invested by telcos for 4G. The pricing plan aims to ensure fair cost recovery, and the government is aware of the challenges of a single wholesale network. Telcos had raised concerns over transparency and pricing issues, but the minister believes they will welcome the pricing when informed.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust IPO sees public offer 9.5 times subscribed
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT), a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, announced that its public offer was 9.5 times subscribed, with 7,543 valid applications for 237 million units received. The international placement tranche was 4.9 times subscribed, while cornerstone investors secured 49.8% of the total units. DHLT plans to use the funds to purchase 14 logistics properties in Japan, with the remaining proceeds going towards expenses and cash reserves. Trading in DHLT's units will commence on the Singapore Exchange on Friday.

site_title: Startup fundamentals still prevail in a changed world
summary: Successful entrepreneurs' fundamental traits of having a problem to solve, resilience, and the ability to meet people and attract talent remain unchanged despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Companies like Airbnb, which was born out of a problem statement, adapted to emerging trends, such as longer-term stays and virtual experiences, to remain relevant. This underscores the importance of a well-defined problem, resilience, and people management in starting and growing a successful business, regardless of future challenges.

site_title: Civil servants get 1 month year-end bonus, lower-wage officers to get additional S$500
summary: Civil servants in Singapore will receive a 1-month year-end bonus, with junior grade officers receiving an additional S$500. This bonus recognizes their contributions amid the pandemic and acknowledges the government's economic recovery forecast, which includes a 7.1% GDP growth in the third quarter. Lower-wage civil servants will also receive a one-time payment of S$500, bringing their total bonus to 1.3 months for the year.

site_title: Keppel O&M awarded work for 2 projects worth S$200m
summary: Keppel O&M has been awarded two projects worth around S$200 million. The first project involves converting an LNG carrier into a floating storage and regasification unit, with engineering work starting in Q4 2021. The second project involves integrating a floating production storage and offloading vessel, with Keppel Shipyard expected to sign a contract by early 2022. Both projects will be undertaken by Keppel Shipyard, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel O&M.

site_title: Gucci reopens with stars and spectacle
summary: Gucci has reopened its flagship boutique at Marina Bay Sands with a star-studded event. Celebrities such as JJ Lin, Rebecca Lim, and Jeanette Aw attended the event, showcasing the brand's new Gucci Lifestyle collection featuring stationery, games, and loungewear. The revamped store spans two floors and includes ready-to-wear, handbags, and accessories, as well as a limited-edition Gucci centennial collection. A 5-metre artwork by Kelly Lim and a reimagined Floral Fantasy garden at Gardens By The Bay completed the spectacle.

images.alt_text: From left: JJ Lin, Jeannette Aw and Rebecca Lim.
Gucci Art Wall by Kelly Limerick.

site_title: Singapore's welcome-back party
summary: Singapore is slowly reopening its borders to international visitors, with the number of visitors increasing to 24,000 in October, a far cry from the 2.7 million in 2020. To revive the tourism industry, the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) is focusing on hosting international events, such as business conferences, concerts, and cultural festivals. New attractions and accommodations are also being introduced, including the SkyHelix Sentosa and the voco Orchard Singapore. The STB is also emphasizing the country's safety and hygiene measures, which have positioned it as a safe destination. However, experts warn that it may take time for visitor numbers to return to pre-pandemic levels, and the industry should focus on attracting discerning visitors rather than solely chasing high numbers.

site_title: SGX, Changi Airports International launch index for global travel, aviation stocks
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Changi Airports International have launched an index tracking global travel and aviation stocks. The index aims to provide a benchmark for investors to gauge the performance of companies in the travel and aviation sector. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for travel and aviation stocks following the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia court tells Jokowi to revise job creation law
summary: Indonesia's constitutional court has ordered President Joko Widodo to revise parts of the country's job creation law, which has been marred by controversy over labor rights and environmental protection. The court ruled that the law is "legally defective" due to improper approval process and cited mistakes in citations of existing regulations. The government has been given two years to address the issues, and it will continue to enforce the law while not issuing new implementing rules. The revisions are seen as a major step for the government to address concerns and ensure legal certainty.

site_title: Evergrande block trades show major holder sells at 20% discount
summary: Evergrande Group's major shareholder agreed to sell 300 million shares at a 20% discount, with the trades totaling HK$2.23 per share. This sale could be from the 2.8 billion share pool linked to founder Hui Ka Yan or Chinese Estates Holdings, which has been selling down its stake. Trading in Evergrande and related companies has been active, sparking speculation about Hui's potential need for funds. The sale follows a flurry of large trades, with other institutional holders also selling shares, including Haitong International Securities Group and Seekers Markets.

site_title: China's grid heeds Xi's call for more supply of clean energy
summary: China's State Grid Corp of China will create a forum for widespread power trading across provinces, aiming to enhance clean energy availability and smooth out supply. This follows President Xi Jinping's call for a better nationwide system for sharing power. The new spot market will allow generators and customers to buy and sell electricity, part of the government's efforts to achieve carbon targets. A start date for the initiative has not been announced.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to cut flights as Hong Kong Covid rules bite
summary: Cathay Pacific is cutting passenger flights into Hong Kong in December due to the city's strict COVID-19 travel curbs. The airline will cancel flights and convert some to cargo operations, with around one-third of scheduled flights handled by cargo. Hong Kong's quarantine measures, which have been in place for 20 months, are keeping international travelers away, while rival Singapore Airlines sees a rebound in flights and passenger numbers as the city reopens to the outside world.

site_title: German economy weaker than expected in third quarter
summary: Germany's economy expanded by 1.7% in the third quarter, lower than expected, with growth decelerating from 2% in the second quarter. The country's Bundesbank now expects output to be flat in the fourth quarter. The government forecasts a full-year GDP growth of 2.6%, down from 3.5% previously predicted. The economy's recovery is being hindered by the resurgence of the coronavirus pandemic, with new curbs imposed and a severe virus wave breaking just as a new government takes office. This poses an immediate challenge to the new coalition government.

images.alt_text: Germany lowered its growth estimate for the third quarter on Thursday (Nov 25), as clouds gathered over the economy with the coronavirus pandemic resurging.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 1-week low on hawkish Fed, BOK rate hike
summary: South Korea's stocks ended near a one-week low on Thursday, November 25, due to a hawkish Federal Reserve and Bank of Korea's rate hike. The KOSPI index fell 0.47% to 2,980.27, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading declines. The won ended down, and the benchmark bond yield fell, as concerns about rising household debt and consumer prices grew. Foreigners were net sellers of 94.4 billion won worth of shares, and the dollar strengthened amid the renomination of Fed chair Jerome Powell.

site_title: Australia: Shares close up on miners boost; banks cap gains
summary: Australia's shares rose marginally, closing 0.11% higher at 7,407.3, driven by gains in miners due to strong iron ore prices. Benchmark iron ore futures hit a 3-week high, lifting major miners BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group. The financial sector lost 0.9%, while tech stocks added 2.4% in their best session in over a month.

site_title: Citigroup to split Institutional Clients Group's ops, tech units
summary: Citigroup plans to split the operations and technology units of its Institutional Clients Group (ICG), which generated 63% of the bank's third-quarter revenue. The reorganization will see Stuart Riley manage the technology team and Allison Szmulewicz take over as interim operations chief, following Paco Ybarra's internal memo. The move aims to develop innovative solutions for clients, with operations and technology teams continuing to work closely together. The split is expected to take place by mid-2026.

site_title: China's Kaisa tries to avoid default with bondholder offer
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese real estate developer, is offering to swap at least $380 million of its bonds with new notes to avoid default. The move comes as the company faces a cash crunch due to a slump in home sales and prices, as well as government regulations to reduce leverage in the sector. Kaisa's bonds fell, while its shares jumped 14% after trading resumed. The company also agreed to sell its stake in a Hong Kong land site, and a failed bond swap could pose a risk for global investors.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS raises target price for AEM to S$6.04 on higher revenue estimates
summary: DBS Group Research raised its target price for AEM Holdings to S$6.04 from S$4.98 due to higher revenue estimates from key customer Intel and additional revenue streams from new customers. Analysts expect 11% and 16% earnings growth for FY2022 and FY2023, respectively, driven by Intel's projected capital expenditure. AEM's revenue also rose sequentially in Q3 FY2021, and the company has made significant progress in technical engagements with top semiconductor companies. The analysts maintain a "buy" rating on the stock.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on November 25, 2021, after solid US indicators boosted Wall Street shares and a rising dollar encouraged investors. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67% to 29,499.28, while the Topix index advanced 0.33% to 2,025.69. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which await GDP data.

site_title: Robust IPO activity in South-east Asia boosted by Thailand, Philippines, Indonesia: Deloitte
summary: South-east Asia's IPO market experienced robust activity in 2021, with Thailand, the Philippines, and Indonesia contributing 95% of funds raised. Thailand raised $4.2 billion, the highest amount in the region for the third consecutive year, while the Philippines raised $1.8 billion from 4 mega real estate investment trust listings. Indonesia surpassed the $2 billion mark for the first time, boosted by the second-largest IPO by tech company Bukalapak. Deloitte expects at least 10 more IPOs in Thailand and the region to reach $10 billion by the end of 2021.

site_title: South Korean game producers chase NFTs in real-money boost for players and firms
summary: South Korean game producers are embracing non-fungible tokens (NFTs) to boost player engagement and revenue, despite regulatory hurdles. NFTs, which can be traded for cryptocurrencies, are being used to create digital assets such as characters, weapons, and items in games. The trend has attracted millions of players worldwide, with games like MIR4 and Axie Infinity generating significant revenue. However, South Korea has banned NFT-applied games due to concerns over gambling addiction, and these games are currently only accessible offshore.

site_title: UOBKH sees further downside risks to Malaysian glove sector, maintains 'underweight'
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) maintains its "underweight" recommendation on Malaysia's glove sector due to normalizing average selling prices and deferred capacity expansion. Q3 earnings came in below expectations, with Top Glove and Supermax posting significant year-on-year declines in net profit. Analyst Philip Wong expects ASPs to return to pre-pandemic levels, but capacity growth may outstrip demand, leading to further downside risks and a 67% year-on-year decline in sector net profit in 2022. Investors are advised to minimize exposure due to unfavorable reward-to-risk payoff.

site_title: Chengdu becomes first China city to ease loan rules for property developers
summary: Chengdu, a city in China's Sichuan province, has introduced measures to boost liquidity for property developers, becoming the first major local government to do so. The city will accelerate home sales and property loan approvals, and ease restrictions on pre-sales proceeds. The move aims to stabilize the real estate industry, which accounts for nearly a quarter of China's economic output, as it faces a deepening slump. The measures are seen as a response to a cash crunch and pressure on authorities to support the industry.

site_title: A month after reopening, Thailand sees gradual tourism recovery
summary: Thailand is seeing a gradual tourism recovery after reopening to foreign arrivals in November last year. The country welcomed 106,117 foreign tourists in the first 10 months of 2021, a significant drop from 6.7 million in 2020. Hospitality firms like Asset World Corporation and Centara Hotels and Resorts are experiencing increased bookings, particularly from Western countries and the Middle East. Thailand expects only 200,000 foreign tourists this year and 5 million in 2022, but domestic travel and longer stays are helping the industry recover.

site_title: Earnings visibility to boost Thailand stocks and sectors in 2022: CGS-CIMB
summary: CGS-CIMB predicts Thailand's stock and sector performance will be driven by earnings visibility in 2022, rather than just earnings recovery. The brokerage maintains its target of 1,850 points for the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) in 2022, citing large-cap companies with domestic exposure. Downside risks include a new Covid-19 wave, while re-rating catalysts may come from foreign inflows and higher tourist arrivals. The SET index target is based on 18.5 times the 2023 price-to-earnings ratio.

site_title: Dtac-True merger reflects urgent need for scale as regional telcos invest in 5G: analysts
summary: A merger between Norwegian telco Telenor's majority-owned Dtac and Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group's True Corporation is set to create the largest telecom entity in Thailand with over 50% market share. The US$8.6 billion deal, subject to regulatory approval, will be 33% owned by Telenor and CP Group each. Analysts expect the merged company to save around 5-10 billion baht per year due to economies of scale, while Fitch Ratings notes that the merger is driven by a need for scale in the Thai telecom sector amid slow growth and high investment needs.

site_title: China probes insurance fund use in property sector to curb risk: report
summary: Chinese regulators have launched an investigation into the use of insurance funds in the property sector, citing serious compliance issues found during a routine inspection. The probe will examine investment activities beyond allowed scopes, including commercial real estate projects and unlisted property developers. Insurers must formulate rectification plans, including holding accountable staff and promoting reasonable capital replenishment. The investigation aims to curb risk and prevent irregular fund-raising for property projects.

site_title: Hot stock: SMI Vantage up 28.3% on crypto mining machines acquisition
summary: SMI Vantage's shares surged 28.3% after acquiring 3,000 crypto mining machines for S$705,000. The company has already received 100 machines and has an option to buy 2,000 more. SMI Vantage plans to develop a "mining-as-a-service" platform with The9 and NHASH. This comes after the group agreed to explore a non-fungible token publishing business with The9 last week.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars left reeling as longs get liquidated
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted to multi-week lows after a mass liquidation of long kiwi positions, driven by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's 25 basis point interest rate hike. The kiwi fell to a three-month low of US$0.6856, while the Aussie hit a seven-week trough of US$0.7185. Analysts predict further downside for the kiwi before year-end, citing an aggressive tightening cycle by the RBNZ and high milk prices.

site_title: South Korea's central bank raises rates, lifts inflation outlook
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.00% as expected, aiming to combat rising household debt and inflation. The bank also revised its inflation outlook for next year to 2.0%, indicating further rate hikes to manage price pressures.

site_title: China regulator seeks to avoid US delistings of Chinese firms
summary: China is working with US regulators to prevent Chinese companies from being delisted from US stock exchanges due to auditing issues. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) has complained of a lack of access to audit working papers for US-listed Chinese companies, citing national security concerns. Chinese authorities are seeking to resolve the issue, but a law signed by President Donald Trump in 2020 aims to remove foreign companies from US exchanges if they fail to comply with American auditing standards for three years in a row.

site_title: Australia's competitions watchdog approves NAB's acquisition of Citi's local consumer unit
summary: Australia's competition watchdog has approved National Australia Bank's (NAB) acquisition of Citigroup's local consumer unit for approximately $882.24 million. The deal was announced in August 2021 and has been cleared by the Australian regulator.

site_title: SPAC led by Singapore-based businessman raises US$86.3m in Nasdaq IPO
summary: 8i Acquisition 2 Corp, a Singapore-based special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), successfully raised US$86.3 million in its initial public offering (IPO) on the US Nasdaq stock exchange. The offering, which closed at US$10.16 per unit, included 8.63 million units sold at the offering price. The SPAC, led by CEO James Tan Meng Dong, plans to use the funds for its initial business combination. This marks the second SPAC listing by the 8i group, following the successful listing of 8i Enterprises Acquisition Corp in 2019.

site_title: Office fit-out costs up 10.8% y-o-y in APAC amid labour, materials shortage: JLL
summary: The average cost of designing and building workspaces in the Asia-Pacific region has risen 10.8% year on year to US$1,109 per square metre, driven by labour and material shortages. Tokyo remains the most expensive market, with costs at US$1,902 per sqm, while Ahmedabad is the cheapest at US$669 per sqm. JLL attributes the price increases to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on supply chains, labour shortages, and material availability, with prices expected to rise further in the next 12 months.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as gains in miners cushion subdued financials
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index slipping 0.09% to 7,392.6, despite gains in local miners due to rising iron ore prices. Mining stocks rose 1%, with sector heavyweights BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue gaining between 1% and 2.8%. Financial stocks, however, fell for a second consecutive session, down 0.6%, with the "Big Four" banks in the red.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on strong US data
summary: Tokyo's key Nikkei index opened higher on Thursday, rising 0.62% or 180.35 points to 29,483.01, driven by strong US data and a rising dollar. The broader Topix index also gained 0.43%. The positive sentiment was attributed to the boost in US Wall Street shares and investors' optimism despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Respite for Biden as US layoff wave ebbs, spending ramps up
summary: The US economy showed signs of recovery, with jobless claims at historic lows and Americans spending on goods and services during the holiday season. Weekly filings for unemployment benefits dropped below pre-pandemic levels, and spending rose 1.3% and incomes climbed 0.5% last month. Despite inflation concerns, the data suggests a "historic jobs recovery" and a "fiscally-stimulated recovery" as President Biden steers the economy out of the pandemic.

site_title: China's Kaisa offers bondholders option to exchange existing bonds with new bonds
summary: China's Kaisa Group is offering bondholders the option to exchange existing bonds with new bonds having an extended maturity in an effort to improve financial stability. The company plans to exchange at least $380 million of outstanding principal, aiming to stay afloat amidst financial challenges. This move comes after the embattled property developer faced financial difficulties.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop as data points to faster Federal Reserve taper
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday as strong economic data fueled expectations of a faster Federal Reserve taper, with interest rates potentially rising earlier than anticipated. The Fed's minutes showed officials moving towards reducing its bond-buying program, while San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly expressed a willingness to lift borrowing costs sooner. Despite some optimism for 2022, markets remain cautious, with analysts warning that data is needed to confirm the timing of the Fed's rate hikes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 0.70 points or 0.05% to 1,522.97. The index saw 252.37 million lots traded worth RM120.24 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 211 to 168. This comes as investors continue to stay positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jumbo, SMI Vantage, MNACT, IHH Healthcare
summary: Jumbo Group reported a widened net loss of S$11.8 million for its full year ended Sep 30, 2021, due to Covid-19 restrictions. Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust settled a claim for damage to its Hong Kong mall, with a total settlement amount of S$58.3 million. IHH Healthcare acknowledged discussions on its investments in China, but has made no definitive decisions. SMI Vantage acquired 3,000 crypto mining machines for S$705,000.

site_title: Canada PM Trudeau says he is extremely concerned by soaring cost of living
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed concern over the country's soaring cost of living, citing the 18-year high inflation rate of 4.7% in October. Trudeau attributed the issue to major government spending programs introduced to combat the Covid-19 pandemic, which pushed the national debt and budget deficits to record levels. He promised to focus on cutting costs for daycare and housing to help families deal with the increasing cost of living. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland plans to present a fiscal update later this year to address the issue.

site_title: Chaswood tries again for RTO, this time with HK battery tech company for US$500m
summary: Malaysian restaurant operator Chaswood Resources Holdings signed a binding term sheet to acquire battery maker HK Aerospace Beidou New Energy Technology (HKAB) for US$500 million. The acquisition, expected to result in a reverse takeover, will see Chaswood issue shares at a 322% premium over its previous price. HKAB, which owns a proprietary ultra-capacitor technology, plans to expand into new business areas and grow revenues. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and is expected to be completed within 90 days.

site_title: Dyson dumps Malaysian supplier ATA over labour concerns
summary: Dyson has terminated its contract with Malaysian supplier ATA IMS due to concerns over labour practices, following an audit and allegations from a whistleblower. The decision sends ATA shares plummeting 30% and is a significant blow to Malaysia, a major electronics manufacturing hub. Dyson had previously denied allegations of forced labour at its factories, but an audit found inadequate progress. The termination is also a blow to the thousands of workers employed at ATA and highlights concerns over migrant workers' working and living conditions in Malaysia.

site_title: Novavax applies for approval to use its Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore
summary: Novavax has applied for interim authorization to use its Covid-19 vaccine in Singapore, with the Health Sciences Authority (HSA) starting a thorough review of the data. The vaccine, which has an efficacy rate of around 90% across various viral variants, was found to be 100% effective in trials of 30,000 participants in the US and Mexico. Singapore had signed an advance purchase agreement with Novavax in January to secure supplies of the vaccine, with the company ready to begin delivery once regulatory authorization is granted.

site_title: Gold edges higher as dollar eases; hawkish Fed limits gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,792.05 per ounce as the dollar eased, but were limited by hawkish Federal Reserve comments suggesting stimulus tapering could accelerate. US gold futures added 0.4% to $1,791.70. Higher interest rates, which could reduce gold's appeal, were also a concern. The dollar index fell 0.1% off its 16-month high, reducing gold's cost to buyers holding other currencies.

site_title: Japan's service prices rise for 8th straight month as freight cost spikes
summary: Japan's service prices rose 1.0% in October, their eighth straight month of gains, as freight costs spiked due to robust global demand for raw materials. The services producer price index reached 105.4, its highest since 2001. However, wholesale goods inflation was 8.0% higher, suggesting slow wage growth will moderate consumer price rises. Transportation fees were the main driver of the services price increase, while hotel fees showed a slower decline. Japan's core consumer prices rose just 0.1% in October.

site_title: UK to expand development finance investment to boost growth
summary: The UK plans to expand its development finance institution, British International Investment (BII), to provide £9 billion of investment in infrastructure and technology globally by 2025. The new institution will focus on low- and middle-income countries, including Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean, and will partner with capital markets and sovereign wealth funds to scale up financing. The move aims to provide a reliable alternative to "strings-attached" investment and deepen economic, security, and development ties globally, with a focus on clean energy and trade benefits for Britain.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on November 25, 2021, as minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting suggested quicker bond-buying tapering than expected. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.16% to 24,646.65, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The move followed mixed signals from the Fed and ongoing tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open of trade Thursday (Nov 25) morning as minutes from the Federal Reserve's most recent policy meeting suggested it would taper its vast bond-buying financial support quicker than expected.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up after deluge of economic data
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Wednesday following solid economic data, including a record-low jobless claims rate and rising consumer income and spending. However, new home sales and durable goods orders fell short of expectations. Minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting highlighted inflation concerns. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Europe: Telecom Italia tops Stoxx 600 amid spiking Covid-19 cases
summary: European shares ended a four-day losing streak, with Telecom Italia leading gains, despite concerns over Europe's worsening Covid-19 situation and potential interest rate hikes. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1%, while the telecoms sector gained 1.2%. Telecom Italia surged 15.6% after KKR considered boosting its offer for the company.
