The market remained cautious due to the rising Covid-19 cases and the prospect of severe restrictions.

site_title: Australia business investment slips in Q3, outlook resilient
summary: Australian business investment decreased 2.2% in Q3 to A$32.7 billion, in line with market forecasts. Despite pandemic lockdowns, spending plans for the year to June 2022 were upgraded to A$138.6 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. This indicates business confidence has weathered disruptions, with a rapid recovery expected now that most restrictions have been lifted.

site_title: What's US$100m? MatchMove deal points to opacity in fundraising
summary: MatchMove, a Singapore-based fintech startup, secured a US$100 million investment from IT services group Nityo Infotech, but regulatory records indicate no funding has come through. The deal, valued at US$600 million post-money, is unusual as it involves a non-cash component, with Nityo providing services instead of cash. The lack of disclosure raises questions about the conditions surrounding the transaction and how it was publicly portrayed. MatchMove's financials show a revenue of US$7.7 million in 2019 and operating loss of US$9.5 million in the same year, casting doubt on the company's valuation.

site_title: UK truck shortage could take fizz out of Christmas: drinks sector
summary: The UK drinks sector is warning of a potential Christmas shortage due to the ongoing truck driver shortage. The Wine and Spirit Trade Association (WSTA) is urging the government to take immediate action to address the issue, citing shipping times that are up to five times longer than last year. The shortage could impact festive drinks, including champagne, and result in lost business, increased costs for consumers, and reduced tax revenue. The sector is calling for government intervention to prevent empty shelves and support businesses during the critical trading period.

site_title: Jumbo FY2021 net loss widens to S$11.8m amid Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singaporean seafood restaurant operator, reported a net loss of S$11.8 million for its FY2021, widening from S$8.2 million the previous year, due to the challenging operating environment amid Covid-19 restrictions. Revenue fell 16.2% to S$81.8 million. Despite this, the group has pivoted to day-to-day fast casual concepts and expanded in mainland China and Taiwan. CEO Ang Kiam Meng expressed confidence in riding out the pandemic uncertainty, backed by the group's healthy balance sheet.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia to launch VTL across Causeway from Nov 29
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will launch a Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) for land travel between the two countries on November 29, exclusively for citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass-holders. The daily quota for this group is 2,880, with designated VTL buses operating 32 daily trips each. The VTL for air travel is expected to be expanded to trains and private vehicles in the future, subject to public health conditions.

site_title: PropertyBT: Renting vs owning private property: an in-depth look (Ep 1)
summary: A recent episode of PropertyBT discusses the financial viability of renting versus owning private property in Singapore. Hosted by senior correspondent Leslie Yee, the conversation explores the financial implications of each option, featuring insights from industry players, including ERA Realty's Nicholas Mak and Knight Frank Singapore's Leonard Tay. The episode also touches on demographic trends and how they may impact the decision to rent or own private property in the future.

site_title: Oil steadies as investors question reserve release
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Wednesday as investors questioned the effectiveness of a US-led release of oil from strategic reserves, which is expected to add around 70-80 million barrels of crude supply. Despite this, analysts say the impact on prices is likely to be short-lived due to years of declining investment and a strong global recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. Global oil demand is expected to surpass 2019 levels by March 2022, according to JPMorgan Global Commodities Research.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at the open on Thursday, mirroring overnight gains on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,233.09. The most traded security, QT Vascular, slipped 12.5% after a 13.8 million-share trade, while SMI Vantage rose 25% after announcing a crypto mining machine acquisition deal. Local banks were mixed, with DBS slipping 0.6% and UOB rising 0.9%. US stocks finished mostly higher, with the S&P 500 nearing an all-time record, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Amazon's fight with Visa is about who keeps the profits
summary: Amazon has publicly clashed with Visa, emailing UK customers to stop taking Visa-branded credit cards and offer £20 off their next purchase if they switch payment methods. This move is part of Amazon's effort to renegotiate its global deal on fees and co-branded US credit card with Visa. The spat highlights the unequal profits in the card payments system, with Visa and Mastercard earning high margins, while merchants pay fees ranging from 2-3% of transactions. Amazon's ban on UK credit cards is seen as a negotiating tactic to pressure Visa to offer better terms.

site_title: Bank of Canada says investor rush into housing risks correction
summary: The Bank of Canada has warned of a risk of housing market correction due to a surge in investor activity and rising prices, which has fueled a boom in the Canadian housing market this year. The number of new mortgages held by investors has doubled, while those taken on by repeat homebuyers has increased by over 60%. This has led to households taking on high levels of debt, adding to the risks of a correction. The Bank's Deputy Governor, Paul Beaudry, cited "extrapolative" expectations driving the market and the potential for a disconnect between actual home prices and their fundamental levels.

site_title: ByteDance is seeking capital to build China's answer to Zillow
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, is seeking external investors to raise funds for its real estate listings and deals service, Xingfuli, also known as "Happy Lane." The company aims to spin off Xingfuli as an independent business to tap into China's booming real estate market. This move is part of ByteDance's efforts to streamline operations and focus on core businesses, following a slowdown in growth. Xingfuli, launched three years ago, features a personalized feed of rental home and property price information, and is seen as a competitor to established players like KE Holdings.

site_title: Meeting minutes show divide within Federal Reserve over inflation threat
summary: The US Federal Reserve, led by Chair Jerome Powell, is divided over the pace of tapering its pandemic stimulus measures amid rising inflation. Meeting minutes show officials worried about price increases and preferred a faster pace of reductions to control inflation. Despite this, the Fed voted to cut its monthly purchases by $10 billion for Treasury bonds and $5 billion for mortgage-backed securities, with officials agreeing to maintain flexibility to adjust policy if needed. The Fed aims to end net purchases by the middle of next year.

images.alt_text: At the meeting where they announced the rollback of their pandemic stimulus measures, some Federal Reserve officials wanted swifter action and worried about price increases, according to minutes released Wednesday.

site_title: Canada house prices poised to surge again despite central bank warning
summary: Canada's housing prices are expected to surge again in the coming months as investors and first-time buyers compete to purchase homes before interest rates rise. The Bank of Canada warned of a high risk of a sudden price drop due to market frothiness and renewed investor activity. Deputy Governor Paul Beaudry advised buyers to consider whether it's a "good time to buy or not." This could expose the market to a higher chance of a correction, according to Beaudry.

images.alt_text: Canadian housing prices are set to surge again in the coming months as investors and first-time buyers scramble to buy before interest rates go up, ignoring a warning from the Bank of Canada that there is a high risk of a sudden price drop.

site_title: Food inflation driving UK, US consumers to hoard for Christmas
summary: Global food inflation is driving UK and US consumers to hoard essential items, such as frozen turkeys and sweets, several weeks before Christmas. Key agricultural commodity prices are above 2019 levels, with coffee prices surging 77% due to droughts and frost in Brazil. Other commodity prices, like cotton, wheat, and palm oil, are also rising, leading to slower investments in production. This has resulted in higher prices for traditional Christmas foods, with families in the UK and Europe resigned to paying more for staples like turkeys, pork, and vegetables.

site_title: Euro falls as Germany's business morale darkens
summary: The euro fell 0.3% to $1.1216, its lowest level since July 2020, due to a survey showing German business morale deteriorating for a fifth month. The euro's decline was exacerbated by concerns of new COVID-19 restrictions in Germany, which could weaken the currency further. Meanwhile, the Turkish lira eased after President Erdogan defended rate cuts despite surging inflation. The US dollar continued its upward trend, rising 0.2% to 96.680, as investors await the Federal Reserve's decision on inflation.

site_title: India weighs new regulator to oversee social media
summary: India's parliamentary panel recommends treating social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook as publishers, setting up a regulatory body to oversee them. This move could increase liability for user-generated content. The recommendation comes from a review of the 2019 personal data protection bill, which aims to protect users' privacy and enforce data collection controls. Current laws treating these platforms as intermediaries are deemed insufficient, and the bill's provisions are seen as too broad. The proposed regulatory body would aim to provide tighter rules for social media companies.

site_title: Japan's journey from Dark Ocean Society to Sixth Eye
summary: The Five Eyes intelligence alliance, consisting of Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the UK, and the US, is considering admitting Japan as its sixth member. This move is seen as a response to Japan's growing intelligence capabilities and its strategic location in the Indo-Pacific region. The alliance views Japan as a key partner in countering the rise of China, Russia, and North Korea. However, critics argue that the alliance's colonial view of Asian countries is a barrier to inclusion. Japan's history of intelligence gathering, including its pre-WWII organizations like the Dark Ocean Society, is also being reevaluated.

site_title: Making the most of giving by adapting to changing times
summary: Fullerton Health Foundation and DFI Retail Group have adapted their corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives to address the changing needs of the community during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Fullerton Health Foundation launched an AI-enabled symptom checker and interactive chat function to provide healthcare access to financially challenged individuals, while DFI Retail Group focused on donating essential items such as food and healthcare products to vulnerable groups. The companies' efforts have been supported by the Company of Good Fellowship, which aims to groom talent in CSR initiatives and build capabilities in corporate giving.

site_title: AGV flags going concern uncertainty amid Covid impact
summary: AGV Group, a Singapore-based provider of hot dip galvanising services, has warned of material uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern due to the impact of Covid-19 on its business. The company has not lifted its trading halt and will request a voluntary trading suspension due to lack of financial support from its controlling shareholder. Production workers at its Tuas plant have tested positive for Covid-19, reducing production capacity, and the company expects a significant decline in revenue and net income.

site_title: SGAG has the last laugh; Singapore startup rakes in profits from day one
summary: Singapore startup SGAG, part of Hepmil Media Group, has secured US$10 million in Series A funding from Quest Ventures, Temasek unit Pavilion Capital, and Bent Pixels. The funding will support the company's expansion into e-sports, working with digital content creators, and setting up a joint venture with Bent Pixels to connect e-sports content creators with brands. Hepmil, which has been profitable since its inception, plans to double its headcount and expand into Thailand and Vietnam next year, driven by the pandemic-driven social media boom and the growth of e-sports.

site_title: The Pentagon needs new AI strategy to catch up with China
summary: The US Pentagon lacks a comprehensive AI strategy to compete with China, which has already surpassed the US in AI and cybersecurity capabilities. The US needs to adopt agility, invest in innovation and failure, and empower employees to learn continuously. A joint IT office and increased public-private partnerships are recommended. The Pentagon must also shift its focus from traditional military capabilities to software-defined warfare, investing in autonomous systems, space capabilities, and cyber defense. Failure to act will result in the US losing the AI war, and potentially the planet.

site_title: JPMorgan has US$20 billion at stake as its CEO Dimon jokes about China
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co CEO Jamie Dimon sparked concern by joking that the bank would outlast China's Communist Party, citing the party's 100th anniversary. With nearly $20 billion in exposure in China, JPMorgan is sensitive to maintaining cordial relations with the government. Despite internal discussions, the bank has yet to address the issue with local officials. The remarks may be perceived as insensitive, and China's financial markets remain a lucrative opportunity for major banks despite elevated tensions and an opaque regulatory environment.

site_title: Nelson Mandela's home turned into boutique hotel
summary: Nelson Mandela's former home, Sanctuary Mandela, has been transformed into a boutique hotel in Johannesburg, South Africa. The hotel, which Mandela lived in for eight years after his release from prison in 1990, features dishes inspired by his favorite meals, including oxtail stew. The hotel's chef, Xoliswa Ndoyiya, who served Mandela's meals for 20 years, now heads the kitchen, aiming to recreate the ex-president's simple and hearty meals. The hotel's goal is to maintain Mandela's legacy while being self-sustaining, and it has opened for guests seeking to experience his calm and positive energy.

site_title: Japan to spend US$313 billion in extra budget for FY2021
summary: Japan is set to craft an extra budget for fiscal 2021 featuring spending of $313 billion, exceeding initial estimates by 6.4 trillion yen, as the country recovers from the coronavirus pandemic. The record budget includes $55.7 trillion in spending and $22.1 trillion in new bond issuance. The government aims to maintain market issuance of interest-bearing bonds steady, while reviewing its issuance plan to offset any increase in market issuance of interest-bearing bonds.

site_title: Businesses hope land VTL with Malaysia will let in new workers too
summary: Singapore's business community welcomes the upcoming Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) with Malaysia, which will be launched on November 29, allowing citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders to travel between the two countries. However, they hope that new workers, including those on long-term passes and foreign hires, will also be allowed to use the lane, alleviating the labor crunch. The VTL is seen as a crucial step towards reopening land crossings with Malaysia, and businesses expect it to provide a new inflow of workers, particularly in sectors reliant on manpower from across the border.

site_title: 'No definitive decisions' made on China investments: IHH Healthcare
summary: Malaysia's IHH Healthcare has made "no definitive decisions" on its investments in China, despite discussions on strategic directions, according to a filing to the Singapore Exchange. The company is considering selling its China unit, Parkway China, which could fetch up to US$1 billion, with unnamed sources citing Taikang Insurance Group and Shanghai Hongxin Medical Investment Holding as potential buyers. IHH shares closed 0.15% lower on the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange.

site_title: Myanmar's shadow government hopes to raise US$1b from revolution bond
summary: Myanmar's National Unity Government aims to raise up to $1 billion from selling bonds to fund its efforts to overthrow the military regime. The group raised $9.5 million in 24 hours after opening the sale of its "spring revolution special bonds." The bonds, offered in four denominations, carry no interest and will be sold in phases, with the first tranche expected to raise $200 million from mostly Myanmar citizens overseas.

site_title: China's economy czar calls for stable housing market
summary: China's Vice-Premier Liu He calls for stabilizing housing prices while maintaining curbs on speculation, citing a slowdown in the economy. The goal is to solve household housing problems and promote healthy real-estate development. Beijing's curbs on property financing have led to a decline in housing sales, house prices, and new construction. Officials aim to redirect investment to high-tech manufacturing and infrastructure construction. Local governments may issue more bonds to boost infrastructure spending, with a potential quota of over $855 billion next year.

site_title: Crypto oversight road map set by US banking regulators
summary: US banking regulators have released a roadmap for regulating cryptocurrencies, outlining priorities for 2022, including weighing custody, crypto-backed loans, and capital standards. The Federal Reserve, Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp will provide clarity on whether certain crypto-related activities are legally permissible. The agencies also require banks to seek permission before offering digital currency products and have introduced new policies for managing custody of digital coins and issuing stablecoins. The road map aims to shape how banks use cryptocurrencies and could lead to new regulations for tokens.

site_title: The new era of mid-high, persistent global inflation
summary: The US is expected to enter a mid-high inflation era of 3.5-7.5% per year due to excess liquidity from quantitative easing (QE) and a rising Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation rate of 6.2% in October. This is not attributed to an overheated economy, but rather to speculative funds borrowing funds for speculation in futures markets, causing price surges in raw materials and transportation costs. The authors warn that the Federal Reserve's delay in raising interest rates could exacerbate the situation, and removing the US import tariff on Chinese products could be an effective policy option to mitigate inflation.

site_title: US capital goods orders increase by more than forecast
summary: US capital goods orders rose 0.6% in October, exceeding forecast, as businesses continued to invest in equipment. This growth extends a trend of healthy investment in equipment since May last year. Despite this, production efforts are hindered by shipping bottlenecks and shortages of labor and materials. The increase in capital goods orders suggests factory output will continue to be fueled by demand well into 2022.

site_title: Croatia's truffle hunters seek habitat protection amid climate change
summary: Croatia's truffle hunters face a growing threat from climate change and deforestation, which may jeopardize the country's prized white truffles. The delicate microclimate in Istria's forests, renowned for producing high-quality truffles, is being disrupted. This year's truffle harvest fetched up to 2,500 euros per kg, but habitat protection is urgently needed to preserve the fragile ecosystem and ensure the long-term sustainability of Croatia's truffle industry.

images.alt_text: Zeljko Zgrablic, helped by his dog, searches for white truffle in a forest near the Istrian town of Motovun.

site_title: Longfor seeks up to US$1 billion in unit's HK IPO
summary: Longfor Group Holdings is considering a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) for its property management business, which could raise up to US$1 billion. The Chinese real estate developer is working with major banks on the proposed listing, which could take place in the first half of 2022. Despite the challenging Chinese real estate market, Longfor's shares have declined only 12% this year, making it one of the least affected developers. This IPO would join other Chinese developers taking similar businesses public, including China Vanke, which could raise about US$2 billion.

site_title: New Zealand hikes rates again, warns homeowners to prepare for more
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), raised the official cash rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 0.75% in its final policy meeting of the year. This is the second consecutive rate hike aimed at curbing surging consumer prices. The bank warned homeowners to prepare for more rate hikes due to the country's red-hot housing market. Economists predict further rate hikes, with the RBNZ aiming for rates to reach 2.5% by 2023 and potentially higher by 2024.

site_title: Football industry embraces crypto as Lionel Messi helps 'fan tokens' take off
summary: Lionel Messi's recent signing with Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) has led to the widespread adoption of cryptocurrency "fan tokens" in the football industry. PSG's partnership with Socios.com, signed in 2018, allows fans to buy tokens using cryptocurrency "Chiliz" to vote on club issues. This move has helped "fan tokens" gain popularity, with Messi's one-off payment of 1 million euros (S$1.53 million) in PSG "fan tokens" being a notable example. The partnership is seen as a step towards increasing fan engagement and creating a new revenue stream for clubs.

site_title: Chinese Estates, a key Evergrande backer, cuts its stake further
summary: Chinese Estates Holdings, a major backer of China Evergrande Group, has further reduced its stake in the embattled property developer to 2.36% by selling 270 million shares. The stake cut lowers expected losses to HK$10.6 billion from HK$10.4 billion. Chinese Estates, led by CEO Chan Hoi-wan, had previously held a 9% stake and is now seeking to take the company private through a buyout offer. The move comes as Evergrande's woes worsen, with the developer's shares slumping 51% in the past 7 months.

images.alt_text: Chinese Estates Holdings, a long-time supporter of China Evergrande Group, has further cut its stake in the embattled property developer. The Hong Kong firm, led by CEO Chan Hoi-wan, sold about 270 million Evergrande shares since its last disclosure on Oct 6, lowering its stake to 2.36 per cent as at last Friday (Nov19), according to a company filing late Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore reports 2,079 Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate falls to 0.75
summary: Singapore reported 2,079 new Covid-19 cases on November 24, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.75, down from 0.83 the previous day. This marks the 12th consecutive day below one growth rate, indicating a slowing of the pandemic's spread.

site_title: Weekly jobless claims fall to 52-year low; Q3 growth revised slightly up
summary: US jobless claims fell to a 52-year low of 199,000 for the week ended Nov 20, signaling sustained economic strength. This marks the lowest level since mid-November 1969 and follows a decline in claims since October. The decline is consistent with data on retail sales and manufacturing production, suggesting the economy regained momentum in the fourth quarter. The US economy's GDP growth was revised slightly up to a 2.1% annualized rate, the slowest pace in over a year, but still indicating lasting economic strength.

site_title: Consortium of Japanese firms to test digital currency in coming months, launch in FY2022
summary: A consortium of approximately 70 Japanese firms, including three mega-banks, aims to launch a yen-based digital currency, "DCJPY", in fiscal 2022. The digital currency will be backed by bank deposits and utilize a common platform for large-scale fund transfers. The initiative, led by cryptocurrency exchange DeCurret, will test the currency in coming months and gauge its use in various industries. The project could influence the Bank of Japan's central bank digital currency (CBDC) experiment and promote cashless transactions in Japan.

site_title: Getting tourism to roar again in the Lion City
summary: Singapore is working to regain pre-pandemic visitor numbers with new attractions and activities. Hospitality and tourism experts discuss the factors needed for a successful recovery, including improved safety measures and marketing efforts. The city-state is also showcasing its arts scene, with a retrospective of Chua Mia Tee's paintings at the National Gallery. Meanwhile, Michelin-starred chef Julien Royer has opened a new restaurant, Claudine, in the French countryside, offering earthy, bistro fare.

site_title: SIA's recovery flight may hit some pockets of turbulence
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a significant improvement in its quarterly loss, with a loss of S$427.6 million, compared to S$2.3 billion a year ago. The carrier capitalized on the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme, which boosted passenger revenue and freight turnover. However, challenges persist, including higher operating costs, potential demand destruction in business travel, and uncertainty surrounding Covid-19. SIA's operating costs rose, and fuel costs climbed 31% quarter-on-quarter. The airline's cash burn and hedging strategy are also under scrutiny, with some experts suggesting SIA should hedge more of its fuel costs to mitigate price volatility.

site_title: COP26 agreement on carbon markets is a welcome boost for market integrity
summary: A broad framework for carbon markets was agreed upon at COP26, introducing standards, UN certification, and a transparent pricing mechanism. This development is significant for enabling governments and companies to trade carbon credits, crucial for the race towards net-zero emissions. The agreement addresses issues such as double counting and paves the way for climate change adaptation funding, but lacks guidelines for voluntary markets and an enforcement mechanism. Despite these limitations, the agreement is a step in the right direction, potentially boosting the integrity of carbon markets and stimulating growth, with the market projected to reach $50 billion by 2030.

site_title: Ryanair sees travel rebound threatened by European lockdowns
summary: Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary warns that European lockdowns, including a return to lockdown conditions in Austria, are putting the region's travel rebound at risk. Airlines face a "fraught" period through Christmas as they wait to see if a resurgence in demand will be strangled off. O'Leary criticizes the curbs as illogical, citing the negative impact on the travel industry.

site_title: Why allyship is key to gender balance
summary: Insead has committed to achieving gender balance by joining the UN HeForShe Alliance as a HeForShe Champion. The school aims to achieve 50% female students in its MBA and Master in Management programs, 50% female faculty members, and equal representation of men and women on its board by 2023 and 2025, respectively. To drive meaningful change, Insead emphasizes the importance of allyship, where male allies play a crucial role in challenging systemic biases, advocating for change, and promoting fairer systems. This iterative process enables the creation of a system where gender balance naturally emerges, benefiting everyone.

site_title: New bonus GFA incentive scheme for developments which hit certain standards on digitalisation, productivity
summary: Singapore introduces a 5-year Built Environment Transformation GFA Incentive Scheme, offering up to 3% bonus gross floor area (GFA) to developments meeting enhanced standards in productivity, digitalisation, sustainability, and quality. The scheme applies to residential, commercial, industrial, and institutional developments with a minimum GFA of 5,000 sq m. It will also be extended to Government Land Sales (GLS) sites until Q2 2022 with a 2% bonus GFA.

site_title: LHN applies to spin off and list logistics business on Catalist board
summary: Property player LHN has applied to spin off and list LHN Logistics on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The logistics business, along with space optimisation and facilities management segments, will be separate entities. LHN will retain majority shareholding in LHN Logistics, and the latter will continue to be consolidated with the group. The proposed spin-off is pending approval from the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong and the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips at open on mixed data, retail earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 61.49 points or 0.17% to 35,752.31, the S&P 500 down 14.92 points or 0.32% to 4,675.78, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 97.26 points or 0.62% to 15,677.88. Mixed economic data and disappointing retail earnings kept investors cautious ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.

site_title: US new home sales rise in October, September revised down
summary: US new home sales rose 0.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 745,000 units in October, but September's sales pace was revised down to 742,000 units. The median new house price soared 17.5% to $407,700. Despite a year-on-year decline of 23.1%, demand remains underpinned by a shortage of previously owned houses. It would take 6.3 months to clear the supply of houses on the market at October's sales pace.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed slightly higher on Wednesday, edging up 0.14% to 24,685.50, after a five-day losing streak. Energy firms benefited from a rally in oil prices, but traders remain concerned about surging inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter inching up 0.11 points to 2,520.48.

site_title: SMI Vantage acquires 3,000 crypto mining machines at S$705,000
summary: SMI Vantage acquired 3,000 crypto mining machines from NBTC Limited for S$705,000, with the option to buy an additional 2,000 machines. The purchase comes after SMI Vantage signed a pact with The9 to explore a non-fungible token publishing business. SMI Vantage's shares closed 11.5% lower on the day of the announcement. The company aims to democratize access to the new economy through crypto mining and NFT platforms, with plans to develop a "mining-as-a-service" platform with The9 and NHASH.

site_title: Japan's stimulus reportedly adding US$192b to debt pile
summary: Japan plans to issue $192 billion in bonds to finance an extra budget of 36 trillion yen, as Prime Minister Fumio Kishida seeks to shore up the economy before next year's elections. The new borrowing plan, which exceeds expectations, adds to Japan's growing debt pile and raises concerns about fiscal management. Analysts question the need for such a large stimulus package, given the economy's expected recovery, but Kishida's plan includes measures to boost growth, including cash payments to households and higher salaries for caregivers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.61 point to 1522.27. The index saw 3.037 billion lots traded worth RM2.093 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 506 to 402.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia to launch VTL across the Causeway from Nov 29
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will launch the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) across the Causeway on November 29, allowing citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders to travel between the two countries. The initial phase will feature two designated buses with a maximum capacity of 45 passengers per trip. Travelers must be fully vaccinated and meet specific requirements, including a pre-departure test and electronic health declaration. The VTL aims to reconnect people and economies, with plans to expand to more travelers in the coming weeks.

site_title: Covid cases hit records in Europe prompting booster shot rethink
summary: European countries have reported record-breaking Covid-19 cases, prompting health experts to reconsider booster vaccination shots. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control recommends boosters for all adults, with priority for those over 40, to increase protection against infection and severe disease. Several countries, including Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Hungary, have reported new highs in daily infections, leading to new curbs on movement and lockdowns. The World Health Organization's warning of a further spike in deaths and hospitalizations in Europe in December and January has prompted calls for increased vaccination efforts.

site_title: EU accepts Singapore's Covid-19 vaccination certificates
summary: The European Commission has accepted Singapore's Covid-19 vaccination certificates, allowing vaccinated Singaporeans to travel to Denmark without quarantine. This move comes after Singapore was added to the EU's Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme, which also includes other EU countries such as Germany, Italy, and France. The decision brings Singapore to 51 countries connected to the EU's certificate system, and the EU has also added Togo to the list of non-EU countries whose vaccination certificates will be recognized.

site_title: China demands Tencent submit new apps and updates for inspection
summary: China has required Tencent Holdings to submit new apps and updates for inspection before they can be uploaded to app stores, following a crackdown on tech giants for monopolistic behavior and user rights infringement. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) has issued a notice requiring all mobile apps and updates to undergo a 7-day review between November 24 and December 31. Tencent has stated its apps remain functional and available for download, while the company continues to enhance user protection features and cooperate with government agencies.

site_title: Opec+ urged to relieve 'artificial tightness' in oil market
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) urged Opec+ to accelerate the return of oil supplies to alleviate "artificial tightness" in the global oil market, citing high prices that threaten developing economies. Crude prices have surged 50% this year, prompting the US and its allies to release 50 million barrels from strategic reserves. The IEA's call comes as Opec+ has refused to increase supplies to tame soaring energy costs.

site_title: TDCX Q3 profit up 46.7% on strong revenue growth
summary: TDCX, a Singapore business process outsourcing provider, reported a 46.7% increase in profit to S$30.2 million for Q3 2021, driven by strong revenue growth across all business segments. Revenue rose 41.3% to S$148.8 million, with sales and digital marketing solutions increasing 93.4% and omnichannel customer experience solutions growing 37.9%. The company expects full-year revenue to be between S$549 million and S$553 million, representing a 26.7% growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's 2022 growth forecast is set at 3-5%, with outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing and wholesale trade expected to remain strong due to robust external demand. The country is on track for its highest export growth in a decade, with a 9.5-10% year-on-year increase in non-oil exports (NODX). Despite a resident employment recovery, total Covid job losses in Singapore far outstrip past recessions. The DBS digital services outage is expected to be fined for its 'broad and material' impact. Singapore and Malaysia will launch a Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) across the Causeway on November 29.

site_title: France's Orange boss gets suspended sentence over Tapie payout
summary: An appeal court in France sentenced Orange CEO Stephane Richard to a one-year suspended sentence for complicity in misuse of public funds related to a 2008 state payout to businessman Bernard Tapie. The payout was for a US$453-million arbitration payment to settle a dispute over Tapie's stake in Adidas. The ruling overturned a lower court's not guilty verdict against Richard and others, including former president Nicolas Sarkozy, who was also implicated in the case. Tapie was acquitted of defrauding the state, while former finance minister Christine Lagarde was found guilty of negligence in handling the case.

site_title: China-focused equity funds on course for weakest performance in 3 years
summary: China-focused equity funds are on track for their weakest performance in three years, with an average decline of 9.2% this year. This is attributed to an economic slowdown, a tech crackdown, and increased default risks in the property sector. China's Shanghai Composite index has gained just 3.45% this year, making it the fourth worst performer among Asian stock markets. China-focused bond funds have also underperformed, rising just 0.4% on average, compared to a 8.5% gain in 2020. Regulatory reforms and funding source restrictions are major contributing factors.

site_title: No certainty that ecoWise's EGM can convene after deputy CEO's new injunction application
summary: EcoWise Holdings' deputy CEO Cao Shixuan has applied for another injunction before Singapore's High Court to prevent an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) from convening to remove him from his post. The board of directors is unable to confirm when or if the EGM will take place, as shareholders' earlier call for the meeting was previously blocked by an interim injunction. The EGM resolutions, if passed, would remove Cao as director and appoint new directors. The outcome of Cao's latest injunction application is unknown, adding uncertainty to the company's future.

site_title: US consumer spending powers ahead despite inflation pickup
summary: US personal spending rose 1.3% in October, the largest gain since March, while inflation increased 5% from a year earlier, the largest annual increase in three decades. Consumer prices rose 0.6% month-over-month and wages and salaries increased 0.8%. Despite inflation concerns, the US economy remains driven by consumer spending, with disposable personal income dropping 0.3% and the saving rate falling to 7.3%. The Federal Reserve is considering faster tapering of its asset-purchase program amid robust demand and supply chain strain.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open after Asia gains
summary: Europe's leading stock markets rose at the open on Wednesday, following gains across much of Asia. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.3% to 7,290.04 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices gained 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims drop to 51-year low; Q3 growth revised slightly up
summary: US jobless claims hit a 51-year low of 199,000 for the week ended Nov 20, down 71,000 from the previous week, indicating sustained economic strength despite pandemic-related shortages. The data also showed a slight revision to Q3 GDP growth, now at 2.1%, and average monthly employment growth of 582,000 jobs this year. The decline in claims and Q3 growth revision suggest the economy is regaining momentum after a slowdown in the third quarter.

site_title: Biden invites Taiwan to democracy summit alongside 110 countries
summary: US President Joe Biden has invited Taiwan to a virtual democracy summit alongside over 100 countries, including 15 that recognize Taipei over Beijing. The move was met with China's "firm opposition" and has been seen as a significant coup for Taiwan at a time when Beijing is trying to keep it isolated internationally. The summit, scheduled for December 9 and 10, aims to promote democracy and counter authoritarianism, with the US as the main organizer.

site_title: Jamie Dimon walks back on China Communist Party comment
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon walked back on his comment that his bank would last longer than China's Communist Party, saying he regretted the remark and should not have made it. Dimon had joked that JPMorgan would outlast the party during a panel discussion, but later clarified that he meant to emphasize the strength and longevity of his bank's China business. The bank has significant exposure in China and aims to expand further, making it crucial to maintain cordial relations with the government. Dimon acknowledged that his comment could be viewed as insensitive and apologized.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to reduce liquidity in 2022, keep rates low until inflation rises
summary: Bank Indonesia plans to reduce excess liquidity in the banking system in 2022 without disrupting lending, while keeping interest rates low until inflation rises. This shift to "pro-stability" policy reflects a move to unwind pandemic-era monetary policies. The central bank aims to maintain low interest rates until there are signs of rising inflation, which hit a five-month high of 1.66% in October. The move is expected to be gradual and cautious to avoid interfering with lending and purchasing of state securities.

site_title: Red Bull billionaire grabs US$765m dividend in year of pandemic
summary: Austrian billionaire Dietrich Mateschitz received a US$765 million dividend from Red Bull's 2020 annual report, a 29% increase from the previous year. The company's net revenue reached 6.3 billion euros, with Mateschitz and his co-shareholders receiving half of the distributable profit and retained earnings. This payout is more than double the amount paid last year, with Mateschitz receiving an additional 165 million euros. The dividend payment comes despite the pandemic affecting the global economy.

site_title: Oil climbs past US$80 after 'drop in the ocean' reserve release
summary: Oil prices surged past US$80 per barrel after the US released a small amount of oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but the move was deemed "a drop in the ocean" by analysts, who expect prices to remain within a "comfortable range" of US$70 to US$90 a barrel. The coordinated release, aimed at cooling surging petrol prices ahead of the holiday season, was seen as insufficient to cool prices, and the market is now focused on the Opec+ meeting on December 2, where the cartel may retaliate to the reserve release.

site_title: Singapore's total Covid job losses far outstrip past recessions, despite resident employment recovery
summary: Singapore's total employment fell by 196,400 by Q3 2021, with non-resident workers accounting for the majority of job losses. This surpasses previous recessions, including the dotcom bubble and Asian financial crisis. Job losses were widespread, with services (-86,400), construction (-62,600), and manufacturing (-47,000) hit hardest. However, the overall unemployment rate remained low, at 2.6% in Q4 2021, due to the availability of employment opportunities and the loss of non-resident workers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower as US yields rise, virus cases surge
summary: South Korean shares closed lower on Nov 24, down 0.10% at 2,994.29, due to rising US Treasury yields and a surge in Covid-19 cases. The country reported a daily record 4,116 new cases, while Samsung Electronics fell 0.66%, and Naver slid 1.25%. Foreigners were net buyers of 316.6 billion won. The won gained, while the benchmark bond yield fell, with the 10-year yield dropping to 2.394%.

site_title: China developer Kaisa plans to propose 18-month extension for bond due Dec 7
summary: Cash-strapped Chinese property developer Kaisa Group plans to propose an 18-month extension for its $400 million bond due on Dec 7, citing two sources. This move may not include upfront cash or additional credit enhancement. Kaisa has missed coupon payments totaling $59 million, with 30-day grace periods for both. The company has the most offshore debt among Chinese developers, following China Evergrande Group.

site_title: Singapore stocks close flat; STI dips 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Nov 24, ending 0.01% lower at 3,227.15. Most Asian markets also declined due to investor concerns over the US Federal Reserve's potential policy tightening to combat inflation. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, but Wednesday's close was largely unchanged.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as firmer dollar, bond yields weigh
summary: Australian shares ended 0.15% lower at 7,399.4 on Wednesday, weighed down by a stronger US dollar and firmer Treasury yields. Local gold stocks fell 1.1%, while tech stocks such as Afterpay and TechnologyOne slid 0.2% and 8.6% respectively. Energy stocks, however, remained strong, despite uncertainty in oil prices. This came after the Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's nomination for a second term, which is expected to lead to rising US interest rates next year.

site_title: Temasek-backed Impossible Foods raises US$500m in round led by Mirae
summary: Impossible Foods, backed by Temasek, has raised nearly US$500 million in a funding round led by Mirae Asset Global Investments, valuing the company at around US$4 billion. This round makes Impossible Foods the most well-funded and richly valued plant-based burger startup in the US, with over US$2 billion raised since its founding in 2011. The company is set to go public next year, with a potential valuation of US$10 billion or more. This funding comes ahead of a surge in investor appetite for fast-growing plant-based meat makers, driven by a boom in popularity of climate-friendly and humane products.

site_title: Frasers Property scraps plan to acquire Vietnam property development company
summary: Frasers Property has cancelled plans to acquire a majority stake in Vietnam property development company Phu An Dien Real Estate Joint Stock Company (PAD). The agreement, announced in 2018, was for Frasers Property Investments (Vietnam) 2 to acquire 45 million shares worth $47.3 million. The conditions precedent for completion were not met by the long-stop date, leading to mutual agreement to terminate the proposed acquisition. The termination is not expected to have a material effect on Frasers Property's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Hong Kong hasn't done enough to handle a resurgence, says Health Secretary
summary: Hong Kong's Health Secretary, Sophia Chan, expressed concerns that the city is not adequately prepared for a potential resurgence of COVID-19, despite having some of the world's strictest measures in place. Chan emphasized the need for further digitalization and development of databases to track infections. Hong Kong has recently tightened restrictions, including mandatory contact tracing app check-in at restaurants and bars, but its adherence to the "Covid Zero" policy is raising concerns it may be left behind as the world reopens. A delegation of Chinese health experts is reviewing the city's measures ahead of potential quarantine-free travel with mainland China.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei drops as hawkish Fed bets unsettle investors
summary: Japan's Nikkei dropped 1.58% to 29,302.66 on Wednesday, November 24, amid concerns that the US Federal Reserve might speed up policy tightening to cope with broadening inflationary risks. Richly valued US tech shares fell, denting investors' risk appetite, while some value stocks gained, such as carmakers and banks. Semiconductor-related shares were also pounded, but resource-related firms rose due to a rebound in oil prices.

site_title: Singapore trade tipped to cool in 2022 but analysts rosy on upside to 'cautious' official forecast
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth is expected to cool sharply in 2022, with a cautiously optimistic forecast of 0-2% growth by trade agency Enterprise Singapore. Despite this, some economists are looking for upside to the projection, with the sector on track for its fastest growth since 2010. The agency upgraded its full-year forecast to 9.5-10% in 2021, but noted that growth will moderate in 2022 from the high base in 2021.

images.alt_text: Singapore's non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth will cool sharply in 2022 from a high base this year, though it is expected to stay in positive territory, official forecasts out on Wednesday (Nov 24) indicated.

site_title: iX Biopharma hands Seelos exclusive rights for lead drug Wafermine
summary: iX Biopharma has granted Seelos Therapeutics exclusive worldwide rights to its lead drug Wafermine, excluding China. Seelos will also gain rights to products incorporating ketamine enantiomers developed using WaferiX technology. The agreement allows Seelos to develop novel therapeutics for central nervous system disorders.

site_title: MAS says DBS digital services outage is 'serious'; analysts expect bank to be fined for 'broad and material' impact
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has deemed the two-day digital services outage at DBS a "serious" disruption, expecting the bank to conduct a thorough investigation and implement remedial measures. Analysts predict a reprimand and fine from the regulator due to the prolonged outage, which affected over 700 customers. DBS customers can continue banking through branches or phone banking until services are fully restored. The bank's recovery plan is crucial, as outages can have significant financial impacts on consumers and the economy.

images.alt_text: DBS's digital banking services outage has affected customer access since Tuesday (Nov 23) morning.

site_title: Nasa launches test mission of asteroid-deflecting spacecraft
summary: NASA launched the Dart spacecraft on a mission to deflect an asteroid from a potential collision with Earth. The spacecraft, about the size of a vending machine, was released from a SpaceX-owned Falcon 9 rocket and will travel 6.8 million miles to impact the Dimorphos moonlet, shifting its orbital track around the larger asteroid Didymos. The mission, costing $330 million, aims to demonstrate the world's first planetary defense system, testing the spacecraft's ability to alter an asteroid's trajectory with sheer kinetic force.

images.alt_text: The Dart spacecraft soared into the night sky at 0621 GMT on Wednesday from Vandenberg US Space Force Base, about 150 miles northwest of Los Angeles, carried aboard a SpaceX-owned Falcon 9 rocket.

site_title: Analysts turn positive on AirAsia, Airports of Thailand on endemic shift
summary: Analysts have turned positive on AirAsia Group and Airports of Thailand (AOT) as the shift to living with endemic Covid-19 leads to eased air travel restrictions and resumption of flights. DBS Group Research raised its target price for AOT to 75 baht and maintained "buy" for the company, citing solid earnings growth and a strong balance sheet. UOB Kay Hian upgraded its call on AirAsia to "hold" with a higher target price of RM0.92, citing a potential for meaningful recovery in Q4 FY2021.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on November 24, 2021, following 5 days of losses, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.08% to 24,672.10. Investors monitored central bank policy plans amid global inflation concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index were relatively unchanged, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Cuscaden Peak is offering a revised bid of S$2.36 all cash or S$2.40 in cash and SPH Reit units to SPH shareholders. Temasek is slashing stakes in Alibaba and Didi and exiting Baidu amid a Beijing crackdown. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150-point target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident his daughter will be cleared as Thai PM in an ethics case, while the UK economy shrinks for the second month.

site_title: New Zealand to reopen to foreign travellers from Apr 30
summary: New Zealand will reopen to fully vaccinated foreign travelers from April 30, easing its border curbs that have been in place since the pandemic. Fully vaccinated New Zealanders in Australia can travel to New Zealand without quarantine from January 16, and those from other countries can do so without quarantine from February 13.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.62 points to 1,523.50. Volume was 254.01 million lots worth RM155.36 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 194 to 188.

site_title: SIA, Scoot resume VTL and non-VTL flights to India
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its budget arm Scoot will resume flights between Singapore and India, with SIA operating daily VTL flights from Chennai, Delhi, and Mumbai starting Nov 29, and Scoot restarting non-VTL services from Hyderabad and Tiruchirappalli. Non-VTL flights to Singapore will be subject to health control measures. Travellers must ensure they are eligible to travel under the VTL arrangements before booking.

site_title: Gold hovers below US$1,800 on dollar strength, sooner rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,794.96 per ounce due to strength in the US dollar and anticipation of an earlier interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The dollar index remained near its 16-month high, increasing the cost of gold for buyers holding other currencies. Despite this, gold prices remained below the $1,800 mark, with US gold futures adding 0.6% to $1,793.90 per ounce.

site_title: China's birth rate plummets to lowest figure in decades
summary: China's birthrate has plummeted to a record low of 8.52 births per 1,000 people in 2021, the lowest figure since 1978. The relaxation of the "one-child policy" in 2016 and the extension to three children earlier this year have failed to boost population growth. The number of marriages registered in 2020 reached a 17-year low, and the number of divorces fell for the first time in at least 30 years. This marks a significant concern for Beijing, which is grappling with a rapidly aging workforce and slowing economy.

site_title: Major Toshiba shareholder objects to break-up, urges board to solicit offers
summary: Toshiba's second-largest shareholder, 3D Investment Partners, has objected to the company's plan to split itself into three companies, citing concerns that the break-up may create underperforming companies. The hedge fund, which owns over 7% of Toshiba, urges the company to solicit offers from potential buyers instead. The proposal has led to a decline in Toshiba's stock price, and the company's weak stock performance reflects shareholder discomfort with the plan.

images.alt_text: Toshiba's second-largest shareholder on Wednesday (Nov 24) objected to the Japanese conglomerate's plan to split itself into 3 companies and called on it to instead solicit offers from potential buyers.

site_title: Singapore's official 2022 growth forecast of 3-5% captures spread of private-sector predictions
summary: Singapore's official 2022 growth forecast remains at 3-5%, a range that has not surprised economists. The country's uneven recovery is expected to persist, with strong growth in outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing and wholesale trade. However, certain services and sectors are expected to stay below pre-pandemic levels, including retail trade, F&B services, and migrant worker-reliant sectors. The government has flagged four downside risks, including the pandemic, global supply disruptions, and inflation. Despite these challenges, economists expect a gradual recovery in aviation and tourism-related sectors, and a stronger labor market.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as tech, gold stocks track Wall Street sell-off
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% to 7,395.1 on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street sell-off, as Treasury yields rose and gold prices dropped to a near three-week low. Tech stocks fell 1.1% and gold miners, including Westgold Resources and Newcrest Mining, dropped 1.7% and 2.2%, respectively. However, domestic energy stocks rose 1.5% buoyed by higher oil prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after mixed US close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.33% due to investor skepticism over a US-led plan for coordinated oil reserve releases. Japan is expected to announce the release of 4.2 million barrels from its oil reserve. Oil prices rallied overnight despite US President Biden's announcement, with the dollar reaching 115.14 yen. Some exporters, such as Toyota and Hitachi, were higher, while chip-linked shares were lower due to falls in the US tech-rich Nasdaq.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank hikes rates by 25 bps to 0.75%, meets forecast
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 0.75% on November 24, 2021, to combat rising inflation and a housing market surge. The move was as expected by all but two economists polled by Reuters. The New Zealand dollar briefly touched a six-week low before recovering. The RBNZ continues its tightening cycle to control inflation, which is a concern in the country.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall again on inflation fear as oil prices extend gains
summary: Asian markets fell on Wednesday due to inflation concerns and expectations of tighter monetary policy. Oil prices surged, with Brent rising over 3% and WTI over 2%, as OPEC+ producers may rethink their plan to reopen oil taps. The New Zealand central bank raised interest rates for a second month, while investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes and consumer sentiment reading. Europe faces a resurgence of Covid-19, and the Turkish lira remains near all-time lows against the dollar.

site_title: Jury rules against pharmacy chains in big US opioid case
summary: A US jury has ruled against pharmacy chains Walmart, Walgreens, and CVS, finding them responsible for the opioid crisis in two Ohio counties. The companies were found to have filled significant opioid prescriptions, creating an "oversupply" of the drugs and a "public nuisance." The decision marks the first instance in which distributors of addictive painkillers have been held liable for the crisis, which has claimed over 500,000 lives. A federal judge will assess penalties, and the companies plan to appeal.

site_title: Myanmar junta firm applies to end Kirin brewery deal: state media
summary: Myanmar's military conglomerate Myanma Economic Holdings Limited (MEHL) has applied to dissolve its brewery partnership with Japanese beer giant Kirin, citing uncooperative negotiations. The move comes as Myanmar's economy struggles under a coup-inspired boycott, with Kirin having a majority stake in the brewery. A court hearing is set for December 10. Kirin had previously cut ties with MEHL in February, but wanted to maintain involvement in the Myanmar market. The decision is seen as a response to Kirin's efforts to wind down the venture.

images.alt_text: A Myanmar military conglomerate has applied to dissolve the brewery it runs with Japanese beer giant Kirin, state media said, as its once-popular drink reels under a coup-inspired boycott.

site_title: Mooreast debuts on Catalist at S$0.29; 31.8% above IPO price
summary: Mooreast, a mooring systems company, made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.29, 31.8% above its initial public offering (IPO) price of S$0.22. The company's post-offering market capitalization is estimated to be around S$57 million. Mooreast's IPO received strong interest, with the public offer subscribed 17.3 times and the placement shares subscribed 1.3 times. The company plans to use the bulk of its IPO proceeds to develop a waterfront facility and invest in equipment and renewable energy projects.

site_title: Thai economy to grow close to forecasts, but recovery to be fragile: central bank minutes
summary: Thailand's economy has bottomed out in the third quarter and is expected to grow close to forecasts, but the recovery will remain fragile and uncertain. The Bank of Thailand kept the benchmark interest rate at 0.50% for a 12th consecutive meeting to support economic recovery. Fiscal policy is the main driver of the economy, and the baht's volatility is higher than other regional currencies.

site_title: Singapore's growth forecast at 'around 7%' for 2021, 3-5% for 2022
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow at 7% in 2021 and 3-5% in 2022, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The Q3 growth rate was 7.1%, with outward-oriented sectors like manufacturing and wholesale trade expected to remain strong. However, sectors like construction, marine and offshore engineering, and food and beverage services are not expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2022. The government's easing of domestic and border restrictions is expected to support the recovery of consumer-facing sectors.

site_title: Sias questions Cuscaden and Keppel on SPH bid following investor feedback
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) has posed questions to Cuscaden Peak and Keppel Corporation on their competing offers for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) following investor feedback. Sias asked Cuscaden Peak to outline its long-term plans for SPH Reit and the factors determining the chain offer price. Sias also questioned Keppel's urgency for SPH shareholders to cast their votes, citing concerns over "further uncertainty and instability". The questions follow Keppel's revised final offer of S$0.868 cash and 0.782 SPH Reit units per share.

site_title: Dell's quarterly profit more than quadruples on strong PC demand
summary: Dell Technologies Inc. reported a quarterly profit surge of more than four-fold, driven by strong demand for personal computers and servers amid the shift to hybrid work models. Revenue at its client solutions unit rose 35% to US$1.1 billion, as consumers and businesses adopted better and faster computers to work and learn from home. This growth is attributed to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on in-person activity.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open after Q3 GDP results; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% at open on Nov 24, 2021, following the release of Q3 GDP growth at 7.1%, surpassing a preliminary figure of 6.5%. The full-year growth forecast for 2021 was narrowed to "around 7%" at the high end of a 6-7% range. The STI moved up 8.5 points to 3,236.03, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and DBS Bank among the top gainers.

site_title: New Zealand dollar slips, bonds rally as RBNZ hikes cautiously
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised its cash rate 25 basis points to 0.75% on Wednesday, meeting most analysts' expectations. The move was seen as cautious given the ongoing pandemic and high household debt levels. As a result, the New Zealand dollar slipped to US$0.6917, while the Australian dollar fell to US$0.7217. The RBNZ also revised its forecast for future rate hikes, expecting rates to peak at 2.6% by the end of 2023. This move helped bond markets rally, with two-year swap rates falling 17 basis points and yields on 10-year bonds dropping 10 basis points.

site_title: Platinum market heading for biggest surplus in years: WPIC
summary: The World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) forecasts a significant surplus in the platinum market, with 769,000 ounces expected in 2021 and 637,000 ounces in 2022, the largest since 2013. The surplus is driven by increased supply from South Africa and lower demand from automakers and investors. Platinum prices have risen to a 6-1/2 year high but have since fallen to around $1,000 per ounce, with prices expected to remain high in 2022 but decline in 2023 as inventories are depleted.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mooreast, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Keppel, HPL, SPH, SPH Reit
summary: Mooreast's shares for its initial public offering were subscribed 1.3 times, with trading set to begin on the Catalist board on Wednesday. Mapletree Logistics Trust announced a private placement at S$1.88 per new unit, with total gross proceeds of S$692.8 million. Keppel Corporation, Hotel Properties Limited, and Singapore Press Holdings are set to face a Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) probe over their competing offers for SPH.

site_title: Japan's factory activity grows at fastest pace in nearly 4 years: Flash PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity grew at its fastest pace in nearly 4 years in November, according to the au Jibun Bank Flash PMI, with the manufacturing index rising to 54.2. The services sector also saw expansion, with the au Jibun Bank Flash Services PMI Index improving to 52.1. The growth was driven by loosening Covid-19 restrictions, but firms faced soaring price pressures. The composite PMI index rose to 52.5, indicating the fastest pace of growth since September 2019.

site_title: Booking to buy Swedish travel agency Etraveli for 1.63b euros
summary: Booking Holdings is set to acquire Swedish travel agency Etraveli Group for approximately 1.63 billion euros (S$2.5 billion), its second major deal this month. Etraveli, owned by private equity firm CVC Capital Partners, offers flight search, booking, and fulfillment services through brands Gotogate and Mytrip. The acquisition aims to expand Booking's presence in the European market.

site_title: Biden dives into US oil reserves to reassure Americans on inflation
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a coordinated plan with major energy-consuming nations to release national oil reserves onto the market, aiming to reassure Americans about inflation and fuel prices. The move is part of a bid to buoy his sinking poll ratings amid growing discontent over inflation and shortages. The US strategic oil reserves, the largest emergency supply in the world, will be released in mid- to late December, with the goal of reducing fuel prices, which have reached a 7-year high.

site_title: MLT's private placement priced at S$1.88 per unit; preferential offering at S$1.84 per unit
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) priced its private placement and preferential offering at S$1.88 and S$1.84 per unit, respectively, with total gross proceeds of S$692.8 million. The trust will acquire 17 grade-A logistics assets in China, Vietnam, and Japan for S$1.4 billion. The acquisitions are expected to boost assets under management by 13.5% to S$12.2 billion. The trust manager declared an advanced distribution for the period from Oct 1 to Dec 2, with the distribution per existing unit estimated to be between S$0.0145 to S$0.0147.

site_title: Hong Kong makes yuan green bond debut with 5b yuan debt sale
summary: Hong Kong sold 2.5 billion yuan of 3-year and 2.5 billion yuan of 5-year yuan-denominated green bonds at 2.8% and 3%, respectively, with order books exceeding 15.9 billion yuan. This follows the city's debut euro green bond deal last week, aimed at encouraging Chinese issuers to use Hong Kong for green financing. The sale is part of the city's efforts to become a regional green financial center, with the government and central bank developing platforms to track environmental impact.

site_title: South Korea expects revenue from real estate tax to be 3 times higher in 2021
summary: South Korea's revised real estate holding tax law is expected to generate 5.7 trillion won (S$6.5 billion) in revenue in 2021, a three-fold increase from 2020. The tax increase, implemented in 2021, aims to cool the country's red-hot real estate market, but critics argue it may not have the desired effect, particularly for those who own high-valued homes. The tax applies to 2% of the population, but many feel it unfairly targets those with the means to pay, rather than addressing the root causes of the market's growth.

site_title: Financing pandemic and climate readiness
summary: The G20's Finance-Health Task Force has highlighted the need for multilateral organizations and governments to close the climate finance gap, with developed countries committing to provide $1 trillion in climate finance to developing countries. The task force aims to strengthen pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response capacities by providing greater access to healthcare financing. This comes as the COVID-19 pandemic has widened the annual health financing gap of $176 billion among the world's poorest countries, with the IMF warning of a "great financial divide" between countries with access to finance and those without it.

site_title: Poor diets imperilling people and the planet: report
summary: A global assessment, the Global Nutrition Report, found nearly half of the world's population suffers from poor nutrition, linked to inadequate or excessive food consumption. This results in 48% of people being overweight, obese, or underweight. The report warns that the world will fail to meet 8 out of 9 nutrition targets by 2025, with avoidable deaths due to poor diets increasing by 15% since 2010. The report emphasizes the need for increased nutrition spending to meet global health targets, with a required annual increase of nearly US$4 billion until 2030.

site_title: Apple sues Israeli spyware maker for targeting its users
summary: Apple sued Israeli spyware maker NSO for targeting its users, claiming the firm's "state-sponsored surveillance technology" enables highly targeted spyware to surveil victims. The lawsuit seeks a permanent injunction to ban NSO from using Apple software and services. NSO has faced controversy over reports of its Pegasus spyware targeting activists, journalists, and politicians. US authorities recently restricted relations between NSO and American groups due to allegations of transnational repression. The lawsuit aims to prevent further abuse and harm to Apple users.

site_title: AGV flags going concern uncertainty; requests voluntary trading suspension
summary: AGV Group has warned of material uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern due to lack of financial support amid the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its business. The company's controlling shareholder, Chua Wei Kee, has refused to provide financial support, citing only a less than 25% of the estimated 4-month cash gap. AGV has requested a voluntary trading suspension and will continue to halt trading on its shares, which have been suspended since November 19, 2021. The company is working with creditors and suppliers to minimize disruption to its operations.

images.alt_text: AGV Group warns that the lack of financial support amid Covid-19's impact on its business has resulted in a material uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Tan Chong to sell 2 properties in Upper Bukit Timah Road to CDL for S$126.3m
summary: Tan Chong International has agreed to sell two properties in Upper Bukit Timah Road to CDL for S$126.3 million, with the collective fair value of assets totaling S$95.9 million as of end-June 2021. The sale includes the site, buildings, and fixed plant and equipment. Tan Chong expects to net a gain of S$29.8 million post-disposal, which it plans to use as working capital. The transaction is seen as a "good opportunity" for the group to realize certain investments and non-core assets.

site_title: Samsung to build advanced chip plant in Texas
summary: Samsung Electronics Co plans to build an advanced chip plant in Taylor, Texas, investing $17 billion and creating 1,800 jobs over 10 years. The move aims to win more American clients, narrow the gap with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, and bolster supply chain security in the US. This decision follows Intel's plans to spend billions on cutting-edge facilities and comes after the Biden administration's efforts to secure critical supply chains.

site_title: US retailers cheery about holiday season despite inflation
summary: US retailers are optimistic about the holiday season despite inflation concerns, with consumers expected to spend more than usual. Retailers have taken steps to ensure popular items are in stock, including importing and storing items earlier, ordering by air freight, and chartering vessels. However, shortages and higher prices are still a worry, particularly for items like game consoles and electronics. The National Retail Federation projects a 8.5-10.5% growth in holiday sales, with retailers hoping to replenish merchandise and minimize gaps in stock.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 3-week lows on Covid-19 surge; oil stocks, miners rise
summary: European stocks fell 1.3% to a three-week low on Tuesday, driven by a surge in Covid-19 cases and concerns of tighter restrictions. Energy stocks and miners rose on higher commodity prices, while tech stocks tumbled 3.4% due to rising interest rate expectations. The European Central Bank is now expected to raise interest rates in December, with investors pulling out of equities. A fourth wave of Covid-19 infections threatens European recovery, with the Euro Stoxx 50 volatility index reaching its highest level in almost seven weeks.

site_title: Twitter will test live shopping feature with Walmart
summary: Twitter will test its live shopping feature with Walmart on November 28, allowing users to browse and purchase products during a real-time video broadcast. The feature, which will be available on the Twitter app, will send viewers to Walmart's website to complete a transaction. This test marks a push by Twitter into businesses beyond advertising, as the company seeks to diversify its revenue streams. The move follows similar efforts by Meta Platforms and Pinterest, and is part of Twitter's efforts to expand its business beyond digital advertising.

site_title: Managing cyber risks in a shipping context
summary: A recent surge in high-profile ransomware attacks and Europol's warning of evolving mobile malware highlights the growing threat of cybercrime in the shipping industry. As digitalization increases, shipping companies are becoming more dependent on information technology (IT) and operational technology (OT), making them vulnerable to cyber attacks. In response, the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) and the International Maritime Organization (IMO) have published guidelines and a Cyber Security Workbook for On Board Ship Use to help manage cyber risks. The workbook provides practical skills for ship's security officers to identify and protect vulnerable systems, detect, respond, and recover from cyber attacks.

site_title: It's time to expand your investment horizon
summary: A Singaporean investor reflects on the "home bias" phenomenon, where locals tend to invest in familiar local blue-chip companies. This narrow focus can lead to missed opportunities for growth and diversification. The local bourse, compared to global markets like the US and China, is a small microcosm of a larger ecosystem. Investing in overseas-listed companies can provide a wider spread of businesses, including technology giants like Meta Platforms and Apple, and pharmaceutical companies like Pfizer and Moderna. A balanced portfolio that combines Singapore and foreign stocks can offer the best of both worlds, but requires careful consideration of risks and tax implications.

images.alt_text: By restricting our investment choices to local stocks, we miss out on valuable opportunities to capture growth and diversify our investment portfolio.

site_title: Singapore on track for highest export growth in a decade in 2021
summary: Singapore is on track to achieve its highest export growth in a decade, with non-oil domestic export (NODX) growth expected to reach 9.5-10% in 2021, up from 7-8% projected in August. This would mark the fastest pace of growth since 2010. In contrast, NODX growth is expected to slow to 0-2% in 2022, according to Enterprise Singapore's cautiously optimistic forecast.

site_title: Putting gender equality first
summary: The European Union has reaffirmed its commitment to promoting gender equality and women's rights, particularly in Afghanistan. The EU's future development assistance will depend on respect for human rights, including women's and girls' rights. The EU Gender Action Plan III aims to promote gender equality through education, economic opportunities, and access to sexual and reproductive health services. The plan, supported by a 79.5 billion euro instrument, will focus on girls' education, women's empowerment, and addressing violence against women. The EU seeks to achieve sustainable change and promote a post-pandemic world that is more equal and diverse.

site_title: Ikea's malls business to build shopping centre in Gurugram outside Delhi
summary: IKEA's malls business, Ingka Centres, has announced plans to build a shopping centre in Gurugram, India, its first in the country. The estimated £400 million investment will be completed in late 2025, with a second store in Noida expected to open shortly after. Ingka Centres will also house office space besides the Ikea store, and will focus on Delhi projects for the time being. This marks a significant expansion for the company, which owns most Ikea stores worldwide.

site_title: Metropolitan Museum of Art returns three artworks looted under British colonial rule to Nigeria
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art returned three looted artworks from the Kingdom of Benin to Nigeria. The 16th-century brass plaques and 14th-century brass head were taken in 1897 and held at the British Museum in London until repatriated in 1950. The return marks a significant step in museums' efforts to repatriate foreign treasures. The artworks were taken during British colonial rule and were moved to the Nigerian Royal Palace. This return is part of a growing trend of museums repatriating cultural artifacts to their countries of origin.

site_title: US business activity slows moderately in mid-November
summary: US business activity slowed moderately in November due to labour shortages and raw material delays, with the services sector accounting for the pullback. The flash US Composite PMI Output Index fell to 56.5 from 57.6 in October, indicating growth above the pre-pandemic average. Despite this, inflation concerns remain as prices paid by businesses for inputs jumped to 78.1, the highest since 2009, and employment at businesses remained little changed.

site_title: UBS CEO brings tech iteration to world of wealth management
summary: UBS Group CEO Ralph Hamers is bringing technology expertise to the world of wealth management, aiming to capture a bigger share of the private-markets business and hybrid digital wealth management model.
