summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced an 11.9% growth in the first 9 months of 2021, driven by strong demand for semiconductors, healthcare equipment, and precision-engineered products. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can bridge the gap with larger players by adopting standards, which help level the playing field, enhance manufacturing capabilities, and penetrate overseas markets. Standards ensure comparable quality, trust, and compliance with regulatory requirements, enabling SMEs to compete on a common basis. Examples of SMEs that have benefited from standards include Lionsbot and ForeFront Medical, which have secured business opportunities with local and global customers by meeting safety and quality requirements.

site_title: Shell expands into Australian retail power market with A$729m deal
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has acquired Meridian Energy's local electricity business in Australia for A$729 million, expanding into the retail power market. The deal, which includes 300 megawatts of Australian power assets, aims to increase Shell's global power sales to 560 terawatt hours per year by 2030. Meridian's 185,000 customers will now be supplied by Shell, with infrastructure fund ICG acquiring the assets' output. The deal is expected to close in early 2022 pending Australian government approval.

site_title: Indonesia's hosting of G20 is 'strategically important' for global economy, says finance minister
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has emphasized the strategic importance of the country's upcoming G20 presidency, aiming to promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth. The theme "Recover together, recover stronger" will focus on addressing key issues, including digital payment systems, sustainable finance, and international taxation. Indonesia aims to boost the global Covid-19 vaccination rate to 70% by mid-2022 and expects the G20 presidency to increase domestic consumption by 1.7 trillion rupiah and generate around $533 million in GDP.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise despite new Austria lockdown
summary: European stocks rose on Monday despite Austria's return to lockdown, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX index adding 0.2%. The move follows Austria's closure of shops, restaurants, and festive markets, and is part of a broader effort to curb soaring Covid-19 infections across the region. Analysts say the lockdown highlights the ongoing pandemic risks in Europe, with further curbs expected in other countries.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher as Fed Chair Powell is renominated
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as President Joe Biden renominated Jerome Powell as head of the US Federal Reserve, maintaining continuity during the coronavirus pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.5%. This move is seen as a sign of stability during uncertain economic times.

site_title: Biden keeps Powell as Fed chief, elevates Brainard to vice-chair
summary: President Joe Biden has re-nominated Jerome Powell for a second four-year term as US Federal Reserve chair and elevated Governor Lael Brainard to vice-chair, maintaining consistency at the central bank as it grapples with the fastest inflation in three decades and the lingering effects of the coronavirus pandemic. The move aims to protect the recovery from rising consumer prices. Powell's re-nomination is expected to be smooth in the Senate, while Brainard may face opposition from Senate Republicans for her confirmation.

site_title: Julius Baer posts 'significant' rise in profitability
summary: Julius Baer reported a significant rise in profitability for the first 10 months of 2021, driven by strong growth in client assets and improvements in cost efficiency. Assets under management increased 12% to 484 billion Swiss francs, with a 4.4% rise in net new money and positive stock market performance. The bank's half-year net profit rose 23.4% to a record 606.0 million Swiss francs in July. Initial results for November suggest a potential recovery for the final two months of the year.

site_title: US home sales unexpectedly hit 9-month high in the US
summary: US home sales unexpectedly rose to a 9-month high in October, reaching 6.34 million contract closings, exceeding forecasts. The median selling price increased 13% to $353,900, while inventory remained low, with 1.25 million homes for sale. Sales are on track to exceed 6 million this year, the strongest since 2006. The strong demand is attributed to job growth and low mortgage rates, with all-cash sales accounting for 24% of transactions.

site_title: Temasek's retail bond offering sees 6 times subscription
summary: Temasek's 5-year Singapore dollar bond issue, valued at S$350 million, has seen 6 times subscription in its retail tranche, with over S$649.5 million in applications. The bond, offering a fixed interest rate of 1.8%, has been rated "Aaa" by Moody's and "AAA" by S&P. An allocation process will take place after the closure of the offer, with results expected by November 23. This is Temasek's second retail bond offering, following a 2018 issue.

site_title: Elizabeth Towers up for collective sale with S$630m reserve price
summary: Elizabeth Towers, a freehold residential site in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$630 million. The 54,317.9 sq ft site, located in District 9, offers a rare corner plot with a 7% bonus balcony area. The site's land rate is about S$2,400 psf ppr, making it a "compelling land rate". The tender will close on Dec 15, with Edmund Tie expecting "keen interest" from developers due to increasing demand for luxury homes.

site_title: SafeTravel website disrupted for 5 hours following surge in travel pass applications
summary: Singapore's SafeTravel website was disrupted for 5 hours on Nov 22 after a surge of 35,000 users tried to log in for vaccinated travel passes. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) attributed the issue to an error in the system's configuration. The website resumed operations at 3pm. The ICA stated that there is no quota for vaccinated travel passes for air travel, and Singaporeans and permanent residents do not need to apply. The vaccinated travel lane (VTL) between Singapore and Malaysia is set to open on Nov 29.

site_title: Russian caviar prices surge ahead of holidays
summary: Russian caviar prices have surged to historic highs, exceeding 5,000 rubles (S$92.60) per kilogram, ahead of the country's New Year's Eve celebrations. The price increase is attributed to rising inflation, which has led to a surge in food prices. Despite an increase in salmon fishing, prices are being raised by producers due to market concentration among 10-15 companies in the Far East, ahead of the holiday rush. This marks a seven-fold increase in caviar prices over the last two decades.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close on a negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed on a negative note, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.39% to 24,951.34, amid concerns over a spike in Covid cases in Europe and potential containment measures. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.61% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 1.42%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.33 points, or 0.09%, to 1,526.87 on Monday, with a total trading volume of 2.451 billion lots worth RM1.993 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 569 to 373.

site_title: New SATS chief leans on his supply chain expertise to grow food solutions
summary: Incoming SATS president and CEO Kerry Mok is focusing on growing the company's food solutions segment, leveraging his supply chain expertise. He aims to make SATS a great workplace and is working closely with branded hawkers to develop inflight cuisines. The company's non-travel business accounted for 47% of total revenue in the half year ended Sep 30, neck-and-neck with aviation. Mok also sees opportunities in introducing alternative proteins and serving new customer segments through overseas expansion, with central kitchens set up in China and India.

images.alt_text: Incoming SATS president and chief executive Kerry Mok says his key focus is making sure employees - regardless of their seniority - are aware that they are making a difference to the company.

site_title: MoonPay, a PayPal for Crypto, on hiring spree With US$555m
summary: MoonPay, a cryptocurrency payments company, has raised $555 million in funding to accelerate growth. The company plans to hire around 200 people worldwide, doubling its current headcount, and make acquisitions. CEO Ivan Soto-Wright aims to attract top talent and expand coverage to more countries, enabling seamless transactions between individuals and crypto firms. This funding round is part of the growing interest in crypto-focused financial technology, with MoonPay describing itself as a "PayPal for the crypto economy." The company will focus on expanding payment methods and user base.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Over S$470 million in rental support will be disbursed to more than 40,000 tenants and owner-occupiers from Nov 26. This is the third and final payout from the Rental Support Scheme, which aims to help those affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The payments will be made directly to the recipients by the government, bypassing their landlords.

images.alt_text: A view of the interior of a shopping mall taken during the Stabilisation Phase of Singapore's Covid-19 pandemic roadmap on Nov 3, 2021.

site_title: MiRXES co-founders named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2021 Singapore
summary: MiRXES co-founders Zhou Lihan, Zou Ruiyang, and chief investment officer Isaac Ho have been named EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2021 Singapore. The biotechnology startup, known for its cancer detection test kits and Covid-19 test kits, edged out four other winners in their respective categories. The judging panel praised the trio's combination of science and entrepreneurship, agility, and purpose-driven leadership in developing life-changing technologies and supporting socioeconomic goals. The award recognizes their dedication, resilience, and agility in navigating unprecedented times.

site_title: Medtecs 9M net profit down 77% to US$19.3m; ventures into disposable nitrile gloves
summary: Medtecs International Corp, a CATALIST-listed protective gear manufacturer, reported a 77% decline in 9-month net profit to US$19.26 million, due to a fall in demand for personal protective equipment. The company, however, is venturing into disposable nitrile gloves, with a new facility in Cambodia expected to be completed in Q1 2022, with a production capacity of 50 million pieces per month. Despite this, the group expects lower sales and profitability for the second half of the year.

site_title: Thailand plans to join talks on trans-Pacific trade pact membership
summary: Thailand plans to join talks on the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a free-trade agreement between 11 countries, despite opposition from some politicians and business groups. The government aims to boost the economy and make sectors like electronics and agriculture more competitive. A deputy government spokeswoman said the plan would be proposed to the Cabinet and that some terms could be negotiated before joining. The move follows China's application to join the CPTPP in September.

site_title: Sterling holds near early-2020 high against euro
summary: The British pound holds near its strongest levels since early 2020 against the euro, briefly reaching 83.80 pence per euro. However, it slipped against the dollar to US$1.3424. Traders focus on the Bank of England's (BoE) potential interest rate hike in December, with BoE Governor Andrew Bailey expressing concerns about inflation being elevated for longer. Despite his comments, market pricing for a December rate hike remains unchanged, and hedge funds have increased their net short sterling position to 31,599 contracts.

site_title: K-pop kings BTS are first Asians to win Artist of the Year at American Music Awards
summary: BTS, the South Korean K-pop group, made history by becoming the first Asian group to win Artist of the Year at the American Music Awards. They also won awards for Favorite Pop Duo/Group and Favorite Pop Song for their hit "Butter." This achievement cements their place in US chart history, following their hit single "Dynamite" topping the Billboard Hot 100 rankings last year. BTS joined Coldplay for a world television premiere performance and paid tribute to their fans, known as the "ARMY." The group now has nine AMAs.

site_title: Entrepreneurship in Singapore gets a boost
summary: Entrepreneurship in Singapore has received a boost with the 20th EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2021 Singapore awards. Seven leading entrepreneurs from five organizations were recognized for their determination and hard work, including MiRXES' Zhou Lihan, Zou Ruiyang, and Isaac Ho, who won the biotechnology award. The winners were selected based on six global judging criteria, including entrepreneurial spirit, financial performance, and innovation. The awards aim to celebrate entrepreneurs who have made a significant impact in their chosen field, with the theme "The Unstoppables" reflecting the winners' achievements.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2021 Singapore awards trophy; Aaron Tan, founder and CEO, Carro (digital automotive solutions); Alex Chua, CEO, Goldbell Financial Services (financial services); Jackson Aw, founder and CEO, Mighty Jaxx (collectibles and lifestyle products); Walter de Oude, founder and deputy chairman, Singlife (digital insurance solutions); Isaac Ho, CIO; Zou Ruiyang, co-founder and CTO; and Zhou Lihan, co-founder and CEO, MiRXES (biotechnology).

site_title: Ericsson inks record deal with US$6.2b Vonage takeover
summary: Ericsson has agreed to buy Vonage Holdings Corp for US$6.2 billion, its largest-ever deal. The all-cash offer dwarfs Ericsson's 2005 acquisition of Telent Ltd telecom equipment assets. Jana Partners, which owns 4% of Vonage, had pushed for a sale. Ericsson's CEO Borje Ekholm said the deal will help customers monetize network investments, benefiting developers and businesses. The deal concludes a brief activism campaign by Jana Partners and will accelerate Ericsson's growth in the enterprise segment.

site_title: BNP Paribas Real Estate Asia Pacific co-head Han Khim Siew to be appointed CEO of OUE C-Reit Management in Feb 2022
summary: BNP Paribas Real Estate Asia Pacific co-head Han Khim Siew will become CEO of OUE C-Reit Management in February 2022, succeeding Tan Shu Lin. Han, 47, was promoted to co-lead in March 2021 and previously worked at Jones Lang LaSalle Indonesia. He will oversee OUE C-Reit's management, following Tan's departure to pursue other opportunities on November 30, 2021.

site_title: Marks & Spencer gains on report of Apollo's interest in grocer
summary: Marks & Spencer rose 3.5% in early London trading after a report that Apollo Global Management Inc considered a bid for the UK retailer. The interest comes as supermarkets remain in the cross-hairs of buyout funds, following deals for Asda and Wm Morrison Supermarkets. Apollo's assessment of M&S as undervalued due to the pandemic and its 50% stake in Ocado Group may have fueled the interest. The company's recent profit forecast increase has also boosted hopes for a recovery. Apollo declined to comment on the report.

site_title: Crypto Blockchain Industries sells NFTs linked to DJ star Guetta, shares surge
summary: Crypto Blockchain Industries sold non-fungible tokens (NFTs) linked to French DJ David Guetta, raising over $250,000 for United At Home, a charitable organization co-founded by Guetta. The sale of NFTs, a digital asset on a blockchain, resulted in a 21.7% surge in the company's shares to 43 euros. This marks a significant increase from the debut price of 2 euros, giving the company a market capitalization of around 830 million euros.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund adds new leaders and first woman managing partner
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund has promoted four investors to its top rank of managing partner, including Lydia Jett, the firm's first woman managing partner. Jett, who focuses on e-commerce, has an internal average rate of return higher than any other managing partner. The promotions also include Vikas Parekh, Dennis Chang, and Sumer Juneja, bringing the total number of managing partners to 13. The move aims to add more high-ranking women investors in an industry where they are rare, and reflects the sector's importance to the Vision Fund, with e-commerce ventures such as Coupang Inc. being a key focus.

site_title: India's Paytm tumbles another 14% after first-day IPO flop
summary: India's Paytm shares plummeted 14% on their second consecutive day of trading, falling to about $12 billion after a record $2.5 billion initial public offering. The IPO's poor debut has sparked criticism of the company's investment bankers and raised concerns about the company's prospects. Despite a 131% rise in gross merchandise value and a 400% increase in loan disbursals, analysts question Paytm's path to profitability and corporate governance. The company's founder and CEO, Vijay Shekhar Sharma, has defended the company's prospects, but the slump may chill India's stock market boom.

site_title: Elizabeth Towers up for collective sale with S$630m reserve price
summary: Elizabeth Towers, a freehold residential site in Orchard Road, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$630 million. The 54,317.9 sq ft site is zoned for residential use with a building height of up to 36 storeys. The site's land rate is about S$2,400 psf per plot ratio, making it a "compelling land rate." The tender will close on Dec 15 at 3 pm, with Edmund Tie expecting "keen interest" from developers for the luxury home site.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes marginally higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed marginally higher at 29,774.11, reversing earlier losses, on a cautious day ahead of a public holiday in Japan. The broader Topix index slipped 0.08% to 2,042.82. Despite investor caution, the Nikkei index still ended 0.09% higher.

site_title: StarHub to drive growth through bundled services, digitalisation of operations
summary: StarHub plans to drive growth through its "Infinity Play" products and digitalization of operations, aiming for 70% of gross profit growth from consumer services and 30% from its IT transformation. The telco expects to save S$280 million and generate S$220 million in gross profit between FY2022 and FY2026 through its Dare+ initiative. StarHub plans to allocate 45% of its investments to growth areas, 32% to IT and cost optimization, and 23% to its network, with the goal of increasing dividends and reducing operating expenses.

site_title: Singapore firm to build US$10b wind farm off Ireland to power green hydrogen facility
summary: A Singapore-based offshore wind developer, Enterprize Energy, has signed an agreement to build a US$10 billion wind farm off Ireland's coast to power a green hydrogen facility. The 4-gigawatt wind farm will supply electricity for hydrogen production and consumption in Ireland, or for conversion into ammonia for export. The project, valued at US$10 billion, will not seek a subsidy and will be funded through project financing and private equity investment. The wind farm is part of Europe's goal to produce 6 gigawatts of green hydrogen by 2024 and 40 gigawatts by 2030.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin week higher, STI inches up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks began the week higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.2% to 3,237.08, driven by easing Covid-19 restrictions and improving infection numbers. The STI's gains were mirrored by other regional markets, including the KLCI and Nikkei 225. Jardine Matheson Holdings and tech names such as Creative Technology and Nanofilm Technologies International were among the top gainers, while Dairy Farm International was the biggest decliner.

site_title: Austria returns to partial lockdown amid violence in several European cities
summary: Austria has returned to a partial lockdown amid rising Covid-19 cases in Europe. The Alpine nation, along with several other countries, has seen violent protests against virus measures, including clashes in Belgium, the Netherlands, and Denmark. Austria has also imposed a vaccine mandate from February 1, threatening fines of up to $4,000 for those who refuse the jab. The measures come as Europe faces a surge in cases, with Germany's Health Minister calling for citizens to get vaccinated to avoid a "very contagious" Delta variant.

images.alt_text: Participants in an anti-coronavirus measures protest in Brussels, Belgium, on Sunday (Nov 21). The Belgian government had imposed strict In a move to tackle yet another Covid-19 wave, pushing thousands to the streets to protest against mandatory vaccinations, health pass and anti-coronavirus measures,

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 3-week high on chip demand boost
summary: South Korean stocks reached a 3-week high on Monday, closing at 3,013.25, driven by chip demand and a 27.6% year-on-year jump in exports for the first 20 days of November. The Kospi index rose 1.42% as investors took advantage of a brightening outlook for memory chip demand. The won remained nearly flat, while the benchmark bond yield rose.

site_title: Evergrande EV unit's shares fall after HK$2.7b share sale
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group sold 900 million shares at HK$3 each, raising HK$2.7 billion, but the stock fell to HK$3.42 in early trading. This sale, at a 15% discount, aims to bolster the company's finances and put delayed vehicles into production. The sale adds to the US$64 million raised on November 10, but the stock's price drop indicates investors' concerns about the company's financial health.

site_title: Digital Realty seeks to list data centre-focused Digital Core Reit in Singapore
summary: Digital Realty Trust, the largest owner and operator of data centres, is seeking to list its data centre-focused Reit, Digital Core Reit, on the Singapore Exchange. The Reit will offer over 267 million units at US$0.88 per unit, with a total appraised valuation of US$1.4 billion. The listing will provide Digital Core Reit with a right of first refusal to a potential pipeline of over US$15 billion of data centres, and the sponsor intends to co-invest in 10% of each acquisition. The Reit is expected to have an aggregate leverage of 27% and forecast a distribution yield of 4.75% for 2022.

site_title: A 2.5b yuan fine has Chinese companies' board members quitting en masse
summary: Chinese companies' independent directors are quitting en masse after a Guangzhou court ruled that some executives and external accountants of Kangmei Pharmaceutical Co fabricated financial statements, resulting in a 2.5 billion yuan fine. The ruling led to the resignation of at least 20 independent directors of listed companies on Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges. This mass departure highlights growing wariness among corporate executives as Chinese regulators crack down on the nation's private sector, targeting industries from technology to education.

site_title: Temasek-founded Trustana launches programme for F&B SMEs to tap S$4.5t global market
summary: Temasek-founded Trustana has launched its Global Expansion Program, a cross-border trade and sourcing platform, to enable Singapore and Chinese food and beverage SMEs to tap into the S$4.5 trillion global market. Over 100 suppliers have been onboarded, with support from the Infocomm Media Development Authority, Enterprise Singapore, and the China-Singapore Demonstration Initiative. The program offers an "all-in-one solution" to help SMEs overcome barriers in expanding overseas, including access to buyers, exporting assistance, and digital sales channels.

site_title: Ericsson to buy cloud provider Vonage in US$6.2b deal
summary: Ericsson has agreed to acquire Vonage Holdings in a US$6.2 billion deal, with the Swedish telecommunications group paying US$21 per share. The acquisition aims to boost Ericsson's presence in cloud communications services. Despite earnings challenges due to lost business in China and global supply-chain shortages, Ericsson remains committed to its long-term Ebita margin target of 15-18%. The deal is expected to expand Ericsson's capabilities in cloud-based services and enhance its market presence.

site_title: India's Reliance sees shares fall after slamming brakes on US$15b Aramco deal
summary: Reliance Industries halted a $15 billion stake sale to Saudi Arabia's Aramco and pulled back from a potential spinoff of its most profitable unit, causing its shares to fall 4.2% on Monday. The move, initially aimed at cutting debt, comes as the company has become net-debt free through other sales. Analysts see the deal cancellation as disappointing but note that Reliance has factors working in its favor, including a sharp recovery in refining margins and Jio subscriber additions.

site_title: In a first, Japan considers release of oil reserves after US request: sources
summary: Japan is considering releasing its state oil reserves in response to a US request to combat soaring energy prices. The move, unprecedented in Japan, would be a workaround to Japan's law, which only allows reserve releases in cases of shortage or natural disasters. The government has 145 days' worth of oil reserves, exceeding the minimum 90 days required by law, and private-sector reserves also exceed the minimum 70 days requirement. The plan has not been made public, with Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno stating that nothing has been decided.

site_title: JPMorgan to reimburse US$5,000 to HK bankers for quarantine
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is offering US$5,000 reimbursement to Hong Kong-based employees who were quarantined for personal trips to visit family members. The move follows a visit by CEO Jamie Dimon, who expressed concerns about the city's zero-Covid policy affecting talent retention. The bank's decision aims to support its 4,000 Hong Kong employees and comes amid pressure on policymakers due to slowing China's GDP growth.

site_title: Around the world, food delivery drivers question gig platforms' safety nets
summary: Millions of food delivery drivers worldwide face safety concerns due to inadequate safety equipment and training, leading to accidents and injuries. Despite the surge of gig economy during the Covid-19 pandemic, many platforms lack robust safety nets, leaving drivers to sink into debt. Researchers and activists call for regulations, policy changes, and enforceable laws to protect workers' rights. Some platforms have introduced safety measures, but caveats and limited insurance coverage continue to pose issues. Drivers are taking action, including online protests, strikes, and court cases, to demand better working conditions and social security.

site_title: Malaysia's retail sales still below pre-Covid levels, but 'formalised' sector gained: Fitch Solutions
summary: Malaysia's retail sales have yet to recover to pre-Covid levels, growing 4.3% year-on-year in the first 9 months of 2021. However, certain categories such as food and consumer electronics have outperformed, while non-specialty stores have gained ground, accounting for 41% of total retail sales in 2021. The formalization of the retail market in Malaysia has been accelerated by Covid-19 restrictions, with consumers shifting towards essential items and non-specialty stores.

site_title: Private equity firms CVC, HPS to buy stake in Forever 21 owner at US$12.7b valuation
summary: Private equity firms CVC Capital Partners and HPS Investment Partners have agreed to buy a significant stake in Authentic Brands Group (ABG), the owner of Forever 21, valued at $12.7 billion. The deal will see CVC and HPS join ABG's board of directors, while BlackRock Long Term Private Capital will remain the largest shareholder. ABG has postponed its US initial public offering (IPO) to 2023 or 2024. This acquisition follows ABG's recent deal to buy Reebok from Adidas for up to $3.2 billion.

site_title: Xi says China will never seek hegemony at summit with Asean
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated at a summit with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) that China will not seek hegemony and will work to eliminate "interference" with smaller countries. Xi emphasized regional peace, stability, and development, while also excluding Myanmar's junta leader Min Aung Hlaing from the meeting due to his regime's human rights abuses. The summit marks 30 years of dialogue between China and Asean, with China pledging to respect the sovereignty and interests of its regional neighbors.

site_title: Keppel FELS lands contract for offshore wind farm substations worth S$110m
summary: Keppel FELS, a subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine, has secured a S$110 million contract to construct two offshore substations for an offshore wind farm. The project is scheduled for completion in 2024. This marks Keppel O&M's strengthening of its foothold in the offshore renewables value chain, following recent projects in Taiwan and the US. The contract highlights Keppel O&M's growing presence in the renewable energy sector.

images.alt_text: Global offshore group Keppel FELS has landed a contract from a renewable energy company to construct two offshore substations worth around S$110 million

site_title: Bangladesh demonstrators demand foreign treatment for ailing ex-PM
summary: Bangladesh police used tear gas to disperse thousands of opposition demonstrators demanding the government allow ailing ex-PM Khaleda Zia to fly abroad for treatment. Zia, 76, is barred from traveling overseas due to a court conviction on graft charges in 2018. Demonstrators gathered in Dhaka, calling for her treatment abroad, amid her worsening health.

site_title: Australian regulator says crypto investors 'on their own' for now
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, warns that investors in cryptocurrencies are "on their own" for now due to lack of regulation. ASIC chair Joe Longo cautions investors to approach crypto investments with great caution, citing many assets as unregulated. The regulator is working with lawmakers to develop rules, including a licensing regime for crypto exchanges and changes to laws allowing decentralized autonomous organizations. Longo emphasizes that while risk cannot be eliminated, it should not be ignored. ASIC aims to balance risk with consumer demand as the country's largest bank, Commonwealth Bank, recently launched a cryptocurrency trading platform.

site_title: Reimagining the future of security solutions, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025. This move is part of the city-state's efforts to become carbon neutral by 2050. The agreement will facilitate the transfer of excess carbon credits from Singapore to another ASEAN country, allowing the recipient to offset its own greenhouse gas emissions. This partnership is seen as a significant step towards reducing emissions and promoting sustainable development in the region. The agreement is expected to be inked with Indonesia, the world's third-largest emitter, in the coming months.

site_title: 'Buy now, pay later' startup Pace snags US$40m funding to tap Japan, Korea, Taiwan
summary: Singapore-based "buy now, pay later" startup Pace has secured US$40 million in funding from investors across Asia, including Marubeni Ventures, Atinum Partners, and AppWorks, to expand into Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Founded in 2021, Pace aims to tap into the highly competitive fintech market, where bigger players such as Grab and Shopee are aggressively expanding their financial services. The fresh funds will be used to boost its user base and online transactions, with Pace currently operating in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and Thailand.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop on renewed Covid, inflation concerns
summary: Asian markets declined on renewed concerns over COVID-19 and inflation, with Austria's reintroduction of lockdowns and mandatory vaccinations adding to fears. Oil prices continued to drop, partly due to US consumers releasing reserves to control prices. Despite the downturn, the Nasdaq reached a new record above 16,000.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as Europe Covid-19 woes spark recovery fears
summary: Australian shares fell 0.59% to 7,353.1 on Monday, November 22, amid fears of a global post-coronavirus recovery due to Europe's resurgence of Covid-19 cases and fresh lockdowns. Travel stocks, including Flight Centre and Qantas, dropped 4-7.1%, while banking stocks declined 1.4% and energy stocks hit a 7-week low. Iron ore prices rose 4%, lifting miners like BHP and Fortescue.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares barely moved at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Monday, November 22, 2021, following last week's losses, with the Hang Seng Index inching up 7.09 points to 25,057.06. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also ticked up, driven by Wall Street's tepid lead and traders monitoring central banks' monetary policy plans amidst surging inflation.

site_title: Myanmar junta chief to be absent from China-Asean leader summit: sources
summary: Myanmar's junta leader Min Aung Hlaing will not attend the virtual China-Asean leaders' summit on Monday, instead being represented by its ambassador to China, according to sources. This decision comes as ASEAN has stated that Myanmar's election is not a priority, reflecting growing international pressure on the country's military regime.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower following Dow's loss
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.45% to 29,613.13, and the Topix index slipping 0.65% to 2,031.33. The decline followed the Dow's loss last week, sparking investor wariness.

site_title: Over S$470m in third round of rent support to be disbursed from Nov 26
summary: The Singapore government will disburse over S$470 million in rent support to over 40,000 tenants and owner-occupiers through the Rental Support Scheme (RSS) on November 26. This is the third and final payout, totaling more than S$900 million since the first disbursement on August 6. Eligible individuals can expect the cash payouts to be automatically transferred via PayNow or Giro arrangements, while those without these arrangements will receive cheques by December 10.

site_title: TiffinLabs hires more tech alumni, sees Malaysia as key growth market
summary: Digital restaurant group TiffinLabs has made 5 key appointments, including Soon Sze Meng as CEO, Jason Koven as head of operations, and Connie Sun as head of marketing. The company is gearing up for growth in Malaysia, Thailand, and the US, with a focus on its cloud kitchen network and partnerships with major F&B brands. TiffinLabs has raised S$7 million in funding and aims to capture the next wave of growth for its F&B partners.

images.alt_text: Soon Sze Meng, incoming CEO of TiffinLabs

site_title: Oil slumps on prospects of emergency supply releases, Europe Covid-19 surge
summary: US crude prices dropped 65 cents, or 0.9%, to $75.25 a barrel, extending Friday's losses. This comes after Japan considered releasing oil reserves to help dampen prices amid soaring oil demand concerns due to a surge in Covid-19 cases in Europe. Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida signaled readiness to release reserves, but laws only allow this in cases of supply constraints or natural disasters. Oil prices also fell around 3% on Friday.

site_title: GE Aviation to hire over 300 in 2022, adds on to the 510 hired this year
summary: GE Aviation plans to hire over 300 workers in 2022, bringing its total workforce to 2,100, as the aerospace sector recovers from the pandemic. The company has already filled 520 positions this year, exceeding its initial target of 200. This move comes after the company reduced its workforce by about 600 last year due to the pandemic's impact on travel demand. The hiring is part of the company's efforts to support the recovery of the aviation industry in Singapore.

site_title: Are TraceTogether, SafeEntry rules still relevant amid endemic Covid-19?
summary: Singapore's infectious diseases experts question the need for widespread enforcement of TraceTogether and SafeEntry rules as the country moves towards more targeted contact tracing and living with endemic Covid-19. The experts note that 94% of the population is fully vaccinated and most will show mild or no symptoms if infected, making extensive contact tracing impractical. Authorities are shifting focus to targeted contact tracing efforts in specific settings like nursing homes, hospitals, and schools. Experts suggest relaxing mandatory check-ins for the general population while continuing to enforce them in specific settings, as the balance between civil liberties and protection from disease will shift towards the latter.

site_title: Gold steadies after hitting 2-week low as dollar retreats
summary: Gold prices stabilized at US$1,845.48 per ounce after hitting a 2-week low due to a retreating dollar. The dollar index fell 0.1%, reducing the cost of gold to buyers holding other currencies. Federal Reserve policymakers debate tapering asset purchases, while Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann warned of potential inflation above 2% and interest rate hikes reducing gold's appeal. Speculators increased net long positions in gold futures and options.

site_title: Australia to reopen borders to students, workers
summary: Australia announced it will reopen its borders to foreign students and skilled workers starting December 1, easing pandemic travel restrictions after 20 months. Visa holders and citizens from Japan and South Korea will be eligible to enter, with vaccinated Australians also allowed to visit with a pre-departure Covid-19 test. The move aims to revive the tourism sector, which has been severely impacted by border closures, but does not include leisure travelers. The decision is seen as a step forward for Australia, with the government hoping to boost economic growth and attract international visitors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.60 points or 0.10% to 1,527.14. The country's stock market saw a slight increase in volume, with 211.15 million lots traded worth RM122.47 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 225 to 191.

site_title: Australia: Shares slide as rising Europe Covid-19 cases caution investors
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to their lowest in over a week, as energy stocks dropped due to rising Covid-19 cases in Europe, threatening demand and economic recovery. The energy index fell 2.1%, with sector heavyweights Woodside Petroleum and Santos down between 2.1% and 3.3%. Travel and financial stocks also slid, while gold stocks fell to a one-week low. In contrast, Nickel Mines jumped to its highest in nearly seven months after signing a multi-year agreement with Shanghai Decent Investment.

site_title: More property executives cite rising construction costs as key risk: poll
summary: Singapore's real estate market is concerned about rising construction costs, increasing inflation, and interest rates as key risks, according to a Q3 2021 Real Estate Sentiment Index. 93% of senior executives polled highlighted rising construction costs, while 74.4% mentioned rising inflation and interest rates. Labour and building material costs were the top concerns, with 86.4% and 77.3% of developers very concerned. Despite this, the overall sentiment index remains optimistic, staying above 5 since Q3 2020.

site_title: SMEs in expansionary territory for third consecutive quarter: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have expanded for the third consecutive quarter, according to OCBC's latest SME Index report. The Q3 2021 index rose to 53.6, driven by growth in industries such as manufacturing, ICT, and transport and logistics, despite a moderation due to lower base periods. However, the F&B sector contracted, and the overall recovery is expected to be uneven in Q4 2021, with industries like F&B and retail being more vulnerable to restrictions and supply shocks.

images.alt_text: The Q3 2021 SME index rose for the third consecutive quarter at 53.6, despite the impact from the Phase 2 heightened alert measures in July and August.

site_title: ADDX tokenises Temasek-backed SeaTown's private credit fund
summary: Temasek-backed investment firm SeaTown is raising capital for its private credit fund via tokenisation on digital securities exchange ADDX, allowing individual accredited investors to invest with a minimum of US$20,000, down from US$5 million. The close-ended, 4-year fund has deployed over US$500 million in investments and has raised US$7 million from investors through the ADDX platform. This marks the first private credit fund tokenised via ADDX, which uses blockchain and smart contracts to streamline administration and reduce costs for issuers and investors.

site_title: Singapore boosts supply chain resilience at ITAP 2021, A*Star invests S$18m
summary: Singapore boosts supply chain resilience by investing S$18m in a Supply Chain 4.0 initiative with the National University of Singapore and the Singapore University of Technology and Design's Centre for Next Generation Logistics. The government also launched a supply chain control tower to trial solutions and aims to tackle inefficiencies in the flow of goods and documentation required as cargo flows through the supply chain. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for a more seamless and cost-efficient setup in South-east Asia, with the goal of fully riding the wave of Industry 4.0.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SPH, Keppel, HPL, Keppel Infra Trust, GSS Energy, QT Vascular
summary: Keppel Corporation secured most regulatory approvals for its takeover bid of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), further solidifying its advantage in the bidding contest for SPH's property assets. HPL shares closed flat, and SPH shares dropped 0.4%. Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) saw its units decline 0.9% after APA Group acquired an interest in its Australian subsidiary Basslink's debt. GSS Energy's shares rose after the company's wholly-owned subsidiary entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to own 100% of Thai electric motorcycles maker Edison Motors. QT Vascular's shares dropped 10% after the company's CEO and executive director stepped down.

site_title: UK to require charge points for electric vehicles in new buildings
summary: The UK will require charging points for electric vehicles in new buildings, including homes and non-residential spaces, starting from next year. The move aims to accelerate the transition to electric vehicles, with up to 145,000 extra charge points to be installed annually until 2030. The regulation will apply to buildings with over 10 parking spaces and is part of the UK's Net Zero Strategy to reduce carbon emissions. Prime Minister Boris Johnson will announce the new legislation in a speech to the Confederation of British Industry's annual conference.

site_title: Joining forces to develop innovative solutions
summary: Open innovation, a demand-led approach to problem-solving, allows companies to tap into external sources, typically SMEs and startups, to develop new and innovative solutions. Enterprise Singapore and the Infocomm Media Development Authority launched the Open Innovation Network (OIN) to facilitate collaborations. The Southeast Asia Open Innovation Challenge (SEA OIC) was held at SWITCH 2021, featuring leading corporates from Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam. Companies such as SG Enviro, Datature, and Aimazing showcased successful collaborations, with SG Enviro securing several projects and Datature launching its platform, while Aimazing implemented its digital tenant management platform for Hong Leong.

site_title: US, Australia, UK sign key deal in nuclear submarine alliance
summary: The US, UK, and Australia have signed an agreement allowing the exchange of sensitive nuclear propulsion information, marking a key step in the AUKUS defence alliance. The deal, which was announced in September, will enable Australia to acquire eight nuclear-powered submarines capable of stealthy, long-range missions. The agreement has sparked concerns from China, which describes it as an "extremely irresponsible" threat to regional stability. The move has also infuriated France, which had a diesel-electric submarine contract with Australia that was recently scrapped.

site_title: Move to hinterland triggers brain drain at South Korea's mega pension fund
summary: A brain drain has occurred at South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS) since the relocation of its major agencies from Seoul to Jeonju in 2017. Over 140 money managers have left the fund since 2016, with nearly half of the current 320 working staff expected to retire in the coming years. The NPS, which manages nearly half of South Korea's GDP, is struggling to fill roles and has implemented measures to attract and retain talent, including offering opportunities to work abroad and improving working conditions.

site_title: China property moguls use billions of their own cash on rescues
summary: China's property moguls are injecting billions of their own cash into their struggling companies to avoid default, with at least $3.8 billion in recent weeks. Founding chairmen of seven real estate companies are tapping their wealth to support their firms, as the industry faces a severe liquidity crisis. This move stands in contrast to overseas counterparts, where personal wealth is generally shielded from creditors' claims. The efforts have boosted sentiment among bondholders, with some companies' bonds rebounding after their chairmen pledged personal assets or shares.

site_title: Australian mining billionaire to help publishers strike content deal with Google, Facebook
summary: Australian mining billionaire Andrew Forrest's philanthropic organization, Minderoo Foundation, will help 18 small news publishers in Australia negotiate content deals with Google and Facebook to secure licensing agreements. This move comes after the competition regulator allowed a body representing 261 radio stations to negotiate a content deal. The publishers, which include online publications with multicultural audiences and local issues focus, have complained about the big tech companies using their content without payment. The application to the ACCC allows the publishers to bargain without breaching competition laws, potentially avoiding government intervention.

site_title: Dutch police arrest dozens in new Covid-19 riots
summary: Dutch police arrested 48 people after two nights of violent riots over the government's coronavirus measures. The riots, which occurred in multiple cities, including The Hague, Rotterdam, Stein, and Urk, involved clashes with police and vandalism. Four people were shot by police during the violence in Rotterdam, and five officers were injured. The riots were sparked by frustration over the government's plans to introduce "2G measures" that would allow cafes and bars to turn away unvaccinated customers. The Dutch government has been under pressure to address the rising number of COVID-19 cases and the low vaccination rates in some areas.

site_title: WealthBT: Approaches to sustainable investing: a primer (Ep 8)
summary: WealthBT, a podcast series, discusses sustainable investing approaches in its eighth episode. Host Genevieve Cua explores various strategies, including mitigating climate risk, aligning with personal values, and thematic ESG investing. The OECD and GSIA list four approaches: ESG integration, engagement and shareholder action, thematic ESG, and ESG metrics. Guest El Lynn Yeoh from Prudential discusses evaluating ESG factors and setting risk and return expectations. The episode aims to educate affluent individuals on sustainable investing options.

site_title: UK to probe 'systematic bias' in medical devices tech
summary: UK Health Secretary Sajid Javid has launched an independent review to investigate "systematic bias" in medical devices, following the COVID-19 pandemic. The review aims to assess bias in devices such as oximeters, which have been less accurate for people with darker skin. Javid also plans to work with the US Health Secretary Xavier Becerra and other nations to address the issue, citing research showing disparities in critical-care admissions among minority ethnic groups. The review will examine all medical devices and potential biases, including racial and gender bias.

site_title: Get used to expensive coffee - and it'll probably taste worse too
summary: A global shortage of arabica coffee, the smoothest variety and 60% of world production, is threatening to drive up prices at cafes and supermarkets. Extreme weather destroyed crops, and a La Nina pattern forecast to hurt yields further. Arabica prices have surged 80% this year, while robusta prices have risen but lagged arabica's gains. To cope, coffee roasters may switch to robusta, which is cheaper but has a harsher flavor. The crisis could lead to years of supply issues, with prices likely to rise and impact consumers.

site_title: China FX committee urges banks to cap speculation as yuan surges
summary: The China Foreign Exchange Committee has urged banks to cap speculation in the foreign exchange market, following a surge in the yuan to a 6-year high. The committee advises banks to be risk-neutral and improve risk management, particularly for proprietary trading. The move aims to strengthen standards for banks' forex businesses and address concerns over a rapid ascent in the yuan. The proposal affects over 50 Chinese and overseas banks, covering 90% of the country's forex market.

site_title: Travel bubble with Singapore brings international students back to Australia
summary: A travel bubble between Australia and Singapore has brought the first international university students back to Australia after nearly two years, as the country gradually reopens its borders. Fully vaccinated students from Singapore are allowed to enter Melbourne or Sydney without quarantine. This marks a significant step towards allowing more international students to return to classes, with about 130,000 remaining outside Australia. The move aims to address a skills shortage and follows Australia's successful management of the pandemic.

site_title: Coffee grinding higher
summary: Coffee prices have reached a 7-year high due to a series of bad weather events in major coffee-producing countries, including Brazil and Colombia. Extreme weather, inflation, and supply chain issues have disrupted the global coffee supply, causing logistical costs to rise and shipments to take longer. This has led to some coffee producers defaulting on contracts, further straining operations. The ICE Coffee C futures market is on an uptrend, with prices expected to continue surging higher, but may see a short-term pullback due to overbought conditions.

site_title: New York City hotel hot spot NoMad will become outpost of London's Ned
summary: The NoMad hotel in New York City is set to reopen in summer 2022 as The Ned, a Soho House-operated hotel and members club, following a partnership between Membership Collective Group and Soho House. The 167-room hotel will feature refurbished interiors designed by Soho House, honoring the original architectural features. The move marks a resolution to the years-long legal battles between the hotel's previous owner, Andrew Zobler, and billionaire Rob Burkle. The Ned will offer a more dramatic and colorful aesthetic, with a public bar and restaurant, and several members-only spaces.

site_title: CMA CGM posts earnings surge in Q3, expects even stronger Q4
summary: French shipping group CMA CGM reported a surge in Q3 earnings, with net profit rising to $5.6 billion and core Ebitda earnings increasing to $7.1 billion. The company attributes the strong performance to high freight rates and stretched container capacity. CMA CGM expects an even stronger Q4, driven by intense demand for shipping services.

site_title: How financial inclusion is an economic benefit for all
summary: Financial inclusion, particularly digital financial inclusion, is a socially and economically beneficial concept that allows everyone to access financial products and services at a reasonable cost. Despite the devastating effects of COVID-19, financial inclusion is crucial for vulnerable groups, and its importance has been highlighted by the pandemic. Research shows that extending traditional financial services to low-income households and small businesses can reduce income inequality and contribute to economic growth, with the potential to generate 95 million jobs and boost global GDP by $3.7 trillion by 2025. Governments and the private sector can work together to support financial inclusion through initiatives such as financial education, subsidies for rural broadband, and innovative technologies like peer-to-peer payments and blockchain bonds.

site_title: APA acquires interest in debt of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Aussie subsidiary Basslink
summary: APA Group has acquired an interest in the debt of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary Basslink, valued at approximately A$99 million. Basslink, which owns and operates a 370km high voltage direct current electricity interconnector between Victoria and Tasmania, went into voluntary administration earlier this month amid disputes with Hydro Tasmania. If successful, APA plans to convert Basslink to a regulated asset and work with stakeholders to expand its electricity transmission footprint and invest in renewable energy sources.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary Basslink went into voluntary administration on Nov 12 amid ongoing disputes with its customer Hydro Tasmania and an unsuccessful sale process with APA.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,235.73 at the open on Monday, driven by the easing of dining restrictions announced by the Ministry of Health over the weekend. Addvalue Technologies and Genting Singapore were among the top traded securities, with the former rising 30.8% and the latter gaining 0.6%. US stocks ended on a mixed day, while European shares declined for the first time in 7 weeks.

site_title: A quieter but more efficient dealing room
summary: DBS's treasury and markets team achieved record income for the first nine months of the year, with 20% growth in trading and 12% growth in customer flows, contributing to the bank's 16% overall growth. The team aims to shift its focus towards sales revenue, which currently accounts for 55% of its income, with a target of 70:30. DBS is also investing in digital initiatives, such as its FIX Marketplace platform, and exploring opportunities in sustainable financing, including ESG bonds and carbon credits. The bank is targeting growth in China, particularly in the Greater Bay Area, and has established a joint venture securities company in the country.

site_title: Flying-taxi startup Lilium sees opening to grab airline orders from rivals
summary: German flying-taxi startup Lilium sees potential to grab airline orders as the eVTOL market heats up. Despite agreements with carriers like Azul and JetBlue, Lilium's CEO warns that deals are not final due to uncertainty over certification. The company aims for service entry in 2024 and is focusing on developing its aircraft, with a seven-seater model powered by 36 electric motors. Lilium's business model includes pay-per-ride services and fleet sales to corporate and government customers, with plans to target commuter routes and isolated communities. Certification and production capacity will determine its success.

site_title: Strategy trumps size
summary: A business model dominated by conglomerates may not be on its way out, contrary to some predictions. Instead, the format is changing, with investors preferring companies with single, defined business models. However, conglomerates with integrated industries within a single space, such as vertically integrated conglomerates or those with linked adjacent business lines, may still thrive. The key to success lies in achieving synergy and combining disparate pieces into a cohesive whole. As technology and innovation continue to drive business, conglomerates that adapt and refocus on core competencies may remain relevant, while those that fail to do so risk becoming less agile and vulnerable to disruption.

site_title: BTO demand-supply mismatch jumps to 70,000 in 2020
summary: In 2020, demand for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Singapore surged to 87,800 applications, a 70% year-over-year increase, driven by marriage and family formation and declining multigenerational living. However, the number of BTO flats launched only reached 16,800, widening the gap between supply and demand. The strong demand is attributed to rising married couples, increasing household size, and support for first-time homebuyers. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to ramp up BTO flat supply and secure new housing sites to meet housing needs, with a goal of launching at least 17,000 flats next year.

site_title: Asean inflation below global levels, but region still vulnerable to rising prices
summary: Asean's inflation rate remains relatively low compared to the global average, despite rising factory gate prices globally. The region's lagged recovery from the pandemic and limited consumer spending have limited the ability of businesses to pass on rising costs to consumers. Analysts expect minimal pass-through from producer price index (PPI) to consumer price index (CPI), and the region's lower cost of labor is expected to continue bolstering its attractiveness as an investment destination. However, rising commodity and raw material costs, as well as supply-chain disruptions, may impact investment flows, and inflation is expected to creep up in economies such as Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

site_title: QT Vascular CEO steps down after shareholder letter
summary: QT Vascular CEO Eitan Konstantino will step down on November 30 after a shareholder letter sought to oust him and three other board members. Konstantino's resignation was approved by the board, following a petition by Mission Well and another shareholder to remove him and other executives. The move comes amid concerns over the company's future, including its ability to operate and pay liabilities. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on December 15 to vote on the removal of the affected directors.

images.alt_text: Dr Eitan Konstantino, chief executive of QT Vascular will step down from his role on Nov 30.

site_title: 'Mispriced' UK retail parks win favour with Savills IM, John Lim's family office
summary: Singapore-based investors and Savills Investment Management (Savills IM) are investing in the UK's out-of-town retail parks, despite the broader retail landscape's challenges. The asset class has remained resilient due to steady occupier demand and dwindling supply of available stock. Savills IM is seeking £360 million in capital to acquire retail parks with strong tenants and yields of 7-9.5%. The strategy aims to capitalize on the segment's high yields and low vacancy rates, and investors are attracted to the segment as a potential inflation hedge.

site_title: The US$5 billion hoard of metal that the world wants but can't have
summary: A US$5 billion hoard of aluminium, approximately 1.8 million tonnes, sits in Vietnam under guard, likely the last notable stockpile in an under-supplied market. Seized as part of a US-led anti-dumping investigation in 2019, the hoard's existence has become significant due to China's curbs on production to reduce emissions. The stockpile's value has risen 50% since its impoundment, and its release could erase a global deficit, but it remains unclear when or if it will be made available. Analysts predict the market's shift to scarcity, with other major industrial ports experiencing similar draws down in aluminium stockpiles.

site_title: US fund makes 'friendly' offer for Telecom Italia
summary: US private equity fund KKR has made a "friendly" non-binding offer to acquire Telecom Italia for around 10.8 billion euros, valuing the Italian operator at 0.505 euros per share. The proposal, which aims for the delisting of the company, is subject to due diligence and requires clearance by Italian government stakeholders. KKR already holds a 37.5% stake in a joint venture with TIM. The offer comes amid pressure from shareholders, including France's Vivendi, following disappointing recent results. TIM's board will discuss the proposal in an emergency meeting.

images.alt_text: Telecom Italia (TIM) confirmed on Sunday it had received a "friendly", non-binding expression of interest by US private equity fund KKR that values the Italian operator at around 10.8 billion euros (S$14.7 billion).

site_title: CEO boosts Q & M stake following Q3 earnings growth
summary: Singaporean CEO of Q & M Dental Group, Ng Chin Siau, increased his stake in the company after the group reported a 154% surge in 9-month net profit. The company's Q3 earnings growth was attributed to its corporate values and philosophy, which enables sustainable growth. Ng's ultimate parent company, Quan Min Holdings, acquired 7,584,300 shares of Q & M Dental, increasing his deemed interest from 51.6% to 52.4%. This acquisition followed Q & M's strong financial performance, including revenue growth of 58% and a 175% increase in Q3 net profit.

site_title: BOE divides Goldman Asset, State Street in bets on UK markets
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is expected to hike interest rates in 2022, but investors are divided on the extent of the hikes. Goldman Sachs Asset Management and Allianz Global Investors are betting against the pound, while State Street believes the currency is undervalued. The BOE's decision is complicated by Brexit trade concerns and labour shortages, as well as the evolving threat of Covid-19. Money markets are pricing a 90 basis point hike by September, with strategists predicting a range of 10-year gilt yields, from a drop to a surge.

site_title: Dining, social gathering rules relaxed to allow groups of 5 from Nov 22; JSS support tapered to 10%
summary: Singapore has relaxed dining and social gathering rules, allowing groups of up to 5 fully vaccinated people to dine out together, starting Nov 22. Unvaccinated children and medically ineligible individuals can also be included in these groups. However, the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) for the food and beverage (F&B) sector will be reduced to 10% from Nov 22 to Dec 19, causing concerns among industry leaders.

site_title: Boeing buyers' frustration builds as 787 disruptions pass 13-month mark
summary: Frustration is building among Boeing customers as the company's 787 Dreamliner deliveries have been halted for over 13 months due to regulatory and production issues. Despite the Covid-19 pandemic easing, airlines and lessors are uncertain about when the planes will arrive, contrary to Boeing's previous promise of this year's delivery. This delay is expected to impact the travel industry's ability to meet the expected rush of passengers as borders reopen.

site_title: Franchising and Licensing Asia event kicks off online on Thursday
summary: The Franchising & Licensing Asia (FLAsia) event will kick off online on November 25, featuring over 70 international brands and 3,000 participants. The 2-day event will cover franchising and licensing business models, market opportunities, and Covid-driven needs. Keynote speakers include the director of branding and market development at Ya Kun and co-founder of Inspire Brands Asia. The event aims to facilitate businesses looking to expand locally, regionally, and internationally in Asian markets.

site_title: Unleash The Roar! at full throttle to save Singapore football
summary: Singapore's Football Association has launched a new campaign, "Unleash The Roar!", aimed at revitalizing the country's football scene. The multi-stakeholder project, announced in March, includes partnerships with LaLiga and Borussia Dortmund to improve youth development, coach development, and sports science. The campaign has eight pillars, including increasing infrastructure and whole-of-society partnerships. To boost interest in the sport, the FAS plans to strengthen the Singapore Premier League, which has seen declining attendances. The campaign's success will depend on its ability to generate excitement and provide a stable, professional environment for Singaporean football talent.

site_title: Six daily flights from Chennai, Delhi and Mumbai to kick off Singapore-India VTL
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) announced that six daily flights from Chennai, Delhi, and Mumbai to Singapore will start on November 29 under the India Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL). Applications for vaccinated travel passes (VTP) for short-term and long-term visitors from India will begin on November 22. Airlines can also operate non-VTL flights, subject to public health requirements. This move aims to reopen Singapore's borders and restore its status as an aviation hub amid the pandemic.

site_title: BBSG to reach out to record number of beneficiaries
summary: The Boys' Brigade Share-a-Gift (BBSG) 2021 project, launched by Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, aims to reach 44,167 beneficiaries, the highest number on record. The project will also distribute face masks to beneficiaries in government-funded ComCare Programmes, following a poll indicating a majority of social workers believe the addition of facemasks would be beneficial. The initiative reflects the ongoing need for community support, particularly in the transition to endemic living due to COVID-19.

site_title: Dollar rises as pandemic concerns spark flight to safety
summary: The US dollar rose 0.489% to 96.029 against a basket of six major currencies, reaching a 16-month high, amid concerns over a potential full lockdown in Austria and rising Covid-19 infections in Europe. The euro fell to a 16-month low at 1.12895, while commodity-linked currencies declined. Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller urged the central bank to speed up interest rate hikes, and European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde maintained a cautious stance on policy tightening.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market closed with a +2,905 increase to $29,938, despite a generally underwhelming week. Rates are down week-over-week, oscillating in a trading range. The Transatlantic C8 and Transpacific C10 rates are at $33,500 and $31,562, respectively. Iron ore trades from Brazil to Asia are fixing for second-half December loading dates due to plummeting prices. The implications of sub $100 per mt iron ore prices on shipping are uncertain, with the China-Brazil Ballaster C14 route lagging at $24,582.

site_title: 11 hawker centres to allow groups of 5 from different households to dine in from Nov 23
summary: Eleven hawker centres and seven coffee shops in Singapore will allow groups of up to 5 vaccinated individuals from different households to dine in from November 23, following the government's decision to ease COVID-19 restrictions. The establishments must control access and conduct vaccination checks, while fully vaccinated patrons will receive a sticker for identification. Unvaccinated or partially vaccinated individuals can only purchase food to take away. The move comes as the COVID-19 situation in Singapore is deemed stable, with decreasing infection numbers.

site_title: CanningHill Piers' S$1.18b of sales in one weekend underscore hot demand for luxury condos
summary: In Singapore, luxury condo CanningHill Piers sold S$1.18 billion worth of units over a weekend, with 538 units sold at an average price of S$3,000 per square foot. The 99-year leasehold project, developed by City Developments Ltd and CapitaLand Development, saw 77% of units snapped up by Singaporeans, permanent residents, and foreigners. The project's penthouse unit sold for S$48 million, and its design by Bjarke Ingels Group was a major draw. This marks the best-selling project launch in the Central Area this year.

site_title: 1,670 new Covid cases, 8 deaths in Singapore on Sunday
summary: Singapore reported 1,670 new COVID-19 cases and 8 deaths on Sunday, November 21, with the weekly infection growth rate at 0.81. This marks 9 consecutive days of growth rates below 1, indicating declining cases. ICU utilization has also decreased, with 52.9% utilization on Sunday. The total number of fatalities in Singapore stands at 662, with 8 new deaths linked to COVID-19. The total number of cases now stands at 252,188.

site_title: El Salvador plans first 'Bitcoin City', backed by bitcoin bonds
summary: El Salvador plans to build the world's first "Bitcoin City", funded by bitcoin-backed bonds, with geothermal power from a volcano and no taxes except VAT. The city, in eastern La Union, will be circular with an airport, residential and commercial areas, and feature a central plaza designed like a bitcoin symbol. Half of the VAT will fund the bonds, which will be issued in 2022 and backed by a US$1 billion 10-year bond. The plan aims to harness bitcoin to fuel investment in the country, with the goal of making El Salvador the financial center of the world.

site_title: Should Ivanhoe Cambridge be allowed to vote on ARA Logos' merger with ESR-Reit?
summary: Ivanhoe Cambridge, with an 8.7% stake in ARA Logos, has provided an irrevocable undertaking to support the proposed merger with ESR-Reit. This could be crucial to the deal's success, as other unitholders have expressed concerns over the terms. Ivanhoe Cambridge also owns a stake in Logos, the sponsor group of ARA Logos, and will be paid handsomely for this stake. The move could further irritate minority investors, raising concerns about the fairness of the merger process.

site_title: S-Reits make maiden forays into new segments
summary: S-REITs have made significant asset acquisitions exceeding S$9 billion in total purchase consideration over the past 10 months of 2021, with most acquisitions in logistics and grocery-anchored retail assets. Notable acquisitions include CapitaLand China Trust's maiden entry into China's logistics sector, Ascendas Reit's first venture into the US logistics market, and Mapletree Logistics Trust's expansion in South Korea. United Hampshire US Reit also made its maiden acquisition, acquiring two dominant grocery-anchored retail assets in Pennsylvania and Virginia.

site_title: GM, Ford and Chrysler parent lag industry on fuel economy
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) reports that General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler parent Stellantis lag the industry in fuel economy performance, with projected 2021 fleet averages of 14.3, 22.7, and 21.6 miles per gallon respectively. Despite a 24% decrease in carbon dioxide emissions and a 32% improvement in fuel economy since 2004, only Tesla, Subaru, and Honda met emissions requirements without using credits. The EPA aims to boost efficiency 10% by 2023 and reach a fleet average of 52 mpg by 2026.

site_title: JPMorgan to pay S$60m to settle precious metals spoofing lawsuit
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has agreed to pay S$60 million to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging the bank manipulated prices of precious metals futures and options through spoofing. The settlement stems from US government investigations into a form of illegal trading in precious metals and US Treasury markets. The action resolves claims made by investors who claimed JPMorgan intentionally manipulated prices. The bank did not admit to any wrongdoing, and the settlement is part of a broader effort to resolve similar investigations.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co agreed to pay S$60 million to settle class-action litigation by investors who accused the largest US bank of intentionally manipulating prices of precious metals futures and options.

site_title: China fines Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu in latest antitrust investigation
summary: China's competition watchdog fined Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu a total of 21.5 million yuan (S$4.5 million) for 43 antitrust violations. Each company must pay 500,000 yuan. These penalties follow earlier fines on Alibaba ($2.8 billion) and Meituan ($533 million). The crackdown targets "platform" companies that accumulate data to create monopolies, as declared by President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Singapore reports 1,931 new Covid cases, 13 more deaths
summary: Singapore reported 1,931 new Covid-19 cases, exceeding Friday's count of 1,734, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.78. The ICU utilization rate declined to 56.8%, below 70.2% on Nov 4. Thirteen deaths linked to Covid-19 were reported, bringing the total to 654. The majority of new cases (1,867) were in the community, with 333 being seniors aged 60 and above.

site_title: Hong Kong authorises Sinovac vaccine for children aged 3-17
summary: Hong Kong has authorized the Sinovac vaccine for children aged 3-17, lowering the age limit from 18. The decision aims to encourage vaccination among its 7.5 million residents, with a focus on 12- to 17-year-olds receiving priority shots. The Secretary for Food and Health, Sophia Chan, deemed the benefits of the extension outweigh the risks. This move follows Beijing's lead in maintaining strict travel restrictions and comes as Hong Kong's vaccination campaign lags behind other developed economies.

site_title: Christmas trees light up Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade
summary: A row of 30 specially designed Christmas trees lit up Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade in Singapore, kicking off the 11th edition of the ChariTrees fundraiser. The event, themed "Tales of the Future," aims to bridge the digital divide, address mental wellness, and meet educational needs amid the current economic climate. Beneficiaries include the School of the Arts Endowment Fund and Samaritans of Singapore, with donations raised reaching S$315,000 as of November 19.

images.alt_text: (From left) Sota visual arts student Choi Minjoo who co-designed one of the trees with Tan Puay Kern, chairman of the ChariTrees 2021 Organising Committee and President Halimah Yacob.

site_title: China fines tech giants for failing to report 43 old deals
summary: China's market regulator fined tech giants Alibaba, Baidu, and JD.com for failing to report 43 deals dating back to 2012, violating anti-monopoly legislation. The companies, including Geely, were fined 500,000 yuan each, the maximum under China's 2008 Anti-Monopoly Law. The regulator stated that the deals did not eliminate or restrict competition, and the companies will be required to report past deals properly for antitrust reviews. This is the second time China has fined companies for failing to report deals, following a similar fine in December last year.

images.alt_text: China's market regulator on Saturday said it was fining companies including Alibaba, Baidu and JD.com for failing to declare 43 deals that date as far back as 2012 to authorities, saying that they violated anti-monopoly legislation.

site_title: Sonos case against Google gets closer scrutiny by ITC
summary: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) is reviewing a judge's finding that Google infringes five Sonos patents for home audio systems. The commission will consider whether to shut Google smart home devices, phones, and laptops out of the US market if it determines that products accused of infringing two patents are "articles that infringe at the time of importation." Sonos claims Google learned of its technology through a working partnership and used it in its products, while Google denies any wrongdoing. A final decision is scheduled for January 6.

site_title: No 'big bang' easing of Covid-19 restrictions in Singapore ahead of year-end festivities
summary: Singapore is exiting the Stabilisation Phase on Nov 21 and will not implement a "big bang" easing of Covid-19 restrictions, instead focusing on incremental measures such as raising group sizes for social gatherings and dine-in. The country is also accelerating its booster vaccination programme, standardizing shots to 5 months after the last vaccination. Measures such as the Jobs Support Scheme for F&B establishments will be extended, but at a lower level of support. The government will continue to monitor the situation and adjust its approach as needed, with the goal of avoiding a resurgence of cases.

site_title: ESG, US Embassy will facilitate collaborations in sustainability
summary: The US and Singapore are set to collaborate on sustainability through the US-Asean Climate Futures initiative and the US-Singapore Partnership for Growth and Innovation. The Biden Administration aims to increase global investments in clean energy and infrastructure, while Singapore charts green targets, including cleaner electricity imports and research in renewable energy. Opportunities exist in clean energy, urban solutions, and emerging sustainability solutions, with US companies seeking Singaporean businesses with capabilities in these areas. The US Embassy and Enterprise Singapore (ESG) will facilitate collaborations, offering support through webinars, virtual missions, and market access sessions.

site_title: US House passes Biden's US$1.75 trillion social spending bill, sending to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives passed President Joe Biden's $1.75 trillion social spending bill, sending it to the Senate. The bill, known as the Build Back Better Act, aims to bolster the social safety net and fight climate change. The House voted 220-213, with some Republicans calling for order after an angry speech. Biden expressed hope that the bill will pass in the Senate as soon as possible, allowing him to sign it into law. The Senate now faces a challenge in reaching agreement among divided moderates and liberals.

site_title: Fed's Clarida: global central banks should not coordinate policy
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Richard Clarida stated that global central banks should not coordinate policy explicitly, as it could erode credibility and public support for central bank independence. Instead, they can share analysis and adopt similar policies in response to common global shocks. Clarida's comments were made in remarks for the 2021 Asia Economic Policy Conference, but did not address the question of whether the Fed should raise interest rates to combat high inflation. Clarida's stance suggests a cautious approach to global monetary policy coordination.

site_title: The US$5 billion hoard of metal the world covets but can't have
summary: A massive aluminum stockpile worth approximately $5 billion in Vietnam has become the last remaining notable stockpile in the market, exacerbating a global deficit. Seized by US authorities in 2019, the 1.8 million-tonne hoard is unlikely to be released due to ongoing investigations and strict lockdowns in the region.
