The shortage has led to a 50% increase in aluminum prices, with the global market experiencing its deepest deficit in at least 20 years. The stockpile's disappearance underscores the turbulent aluminum market, where China's production cuts are driving a rapid drawdown of global reserves.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia land VTL could be launched by end-November: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore-Malaysia land VTL could be launched by the end of November, with Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong expressing optimism about the timeline. This comes as the air VTL between the two countries is set to launch on November 29. Gan stated that it's possible the land VTL could also start on the same day, bringing vaccinated travelers between the two countries closer together.

site_title: Cuscaden Peak gets regulatory approval from MAS, IMDA for SPH bid
summary: Cuscaden Peak, backed by Hotel Properties, Ong Beng Seng, and Temasek-linked units, has secured regulatory approvals from MAS and IMDA for its SPH bid, further solidifying its advantage in a bidding contest for SPH's property assets. The group remains on track for an indicative transaction completion by February 2022. In contrast, Keppel Corp, its rival, is refusing to budge on its offer, which has also obtained requisite regulatory approvals from Australia's FIRB and MAS. Cuscaden's offer is worth S$2.40 per share, surpassing Keppel's initial bid of S$2.099 per share.

site_title: Deutsche Bank board in weekend meet over chairman successor: source
summary: Deutsche Bank's supervisory board will meet over the weekend to discuss a successor to chairman Paul Achleitner, who plans to step down in May after 10 years. The European Central Bank has pressured the bank to name a candidate, but a current board member, Theodor Weimer, is ineligible due to his role as CEO of Deutsche Boerse. Weimer's contract runs to 2024, and a current board member may take the position, increasing the chances of an outsider being chosen.

site_title: Gold slips after comments from US Fed governor lift dollar
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low on Friday, dropping 0.6% to $1,848.05 per ounce, after US Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller called for early tapering of economic support to chart a tighter monetary policy. The dollar index rose 0.5%, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Analysts say gold is sensitive to rising US interest rates, and Waller's comments boosted the dollar. Despite this, some analysts believe inflation and Fed speak will support gold in the coming weeks.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, UBS set course for new era with new chairmen
summary: Deutsche Bank and UBS have appointed new chairmen, Alexander Wynaendts and Colm Kelleher, respectively, to lead the European banking giants into a new era. The appointments follow a decade of restructuring under the leadership of outgoing chairmen Axel Weber and Paul Achleitner. The new leaders, both with extensive experience in the US, aim to revamp digital platforms and improve regulatory relationships. UBS, which has returned to profitability, and Deutsche Bank, which recently posted its first profit in six years, enter the next phase from different starting points.

site_title: Oil dives 3% to below US$80 a barrel on resurgent pandemic in Europe
summary: Oil prices fell 3% to below $80 a barrel on Friday, with Brent futures dropping to $78.89 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling to $76.10 a barrel. The decline was driven by surging Covid-19 cases in Europe threatening to slow the economic recovery, and concerns over potential releases of crude reserves by major economies to cool prices. The European Union is considering full lockdowns, with Austria already reimposing a lockdown, and governments are weighing a potential release of oil from strategic petroleum reserves.

site_title: US lawsuit alleges 'rampant' sex harassment at Tesla factory
summary: A Tesla factory worker in California has filed a lawsuit alleging rampant sex harassment at the Fremont plant, with the victim claiming she was subjected to sexist language and behavior, including groping, by supervisors and managers. Despite her complaints, no action was taken, and she believes she was retaliated against. The worker is seeking compensation, punitive damages, and changes to Tesla's policies to prevent future harassment. This new suit comes weeks after a California jury ruled Tesla must pay $137 million in damages for racism at the same plant.

site_title: OCBC Bank studying crypto exchange: CEO Helen Wong
summary: OCBC Bank, Singapore's second-largest lender, is considering setting up a crypto exchange to address customer needs in a safe manner. CEO Helen Wong stated that the bank is studying crypto technology due to its potential to boost efficiency, but will not rush into the sector. OCBC aims to provide customers with a way to recognize and handle crypto investments, while prioritizing safety and responsibility. The bank's move comes as Singapore seeks to establish itself as a global crypto hub, with rival DBS Group Holdings planning to expand its digital exchange to retail individuals next year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slammed by lockdown fears, end 6-week rally
summary: European stocks ended the week in the red, marking their first weekly decline in seven weeks, due to concerns over fresh Covid-19 lockdowns in the region. Austria is set to reimpose a full lockdown, while Germany's Health Minister warned of possible restrictions for vaccinated individuals. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.3% and lost 0.1% for the week, with cyclical sectors like banks and automakers experiencing significant declines.

site_title: From mixing concrete to developing green property
summary: Arthur Aw, executive director of Kimen Group, has been driving the company's eco-friendly approach in property development. Founded in 1971, Kimen has been expanding its portfolio, including a co-owned boutique hotel in Singapore and a residential project in London. Aw aims to encourage residents to adopt an eco-conscious lifestyle through community gardens and workshops. He believes sustainable development will gain importance, especially among younger buyers. The company has launched a subsidiary, SEEDoE Ventures, to venture beyond Singapore and explore collaborations and partnerships.

site_title: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes takes stand to defend herself in fraud case
summary: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes took the stand to defend herself against charges of defrauding investors and patients. Holmes, 37, claimed her work at Theranos led her to believe in the company's technology, and she testified about early efforts to raise capital. Holmes met with Silicon Valley venture capitalist Don Lucas, who invested in Theranos and became chairman of its board. Her testimony aims to create reasonable doubt about her guilt, but prosecutors can cross-examine her to expose possible inconsistencies. Holmes has pleaded not guilty to nine counts of wire fraud and two counts of conspiracy.

site_title: Musk says he is checking Tesla app server outage
summary: Elon Musk confirmed an app server outage at Tesla, which prevented many owners from connecting to their cars via the iOS app. The outage, first reported by Electrek, affected around 500 users worldwide. Downdetector tracked the issue, with reports of a "500 server error" around 1640 ET (2140 GMT). Musk stated he was checking the issue and resolving it.

site_title: Blank-cheque book fuels global IPOs to new annual record of over US$600 billion
summary: Global initial public offerings (IPOs) reached a new annual record of over $600 billion in 2021, driven by a blank-check boom and high valuations. The surge in IPOs was fueled by record-high stock prices, economic recovery, and stimulus measures. However, regulatory scrutiny and concerns over a bubble have cooled the market, with many IPO stocks underperforming regional equity benchmarks. Experts warn that a correction in the market is possible if global growth slows sharply and monetary stimulus programs are scaled back.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends at new record as Dow retreats
summary: The Nasdaq index closed at a new record, reaching 16,057.44, while the Dow Jones fell 0.8% to 35,601.98. The mixed day was influenced by concerns about economic weakness due to the Covid-19 wave, with Austria announcing a national lockdown and Germany cancelling Christmas markets. The S&P 500 shed 0.1% to 4,697.96. Despite a strong week for the Nasdaq, investors remain cautious ahead of President Joe Biden's announcement on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's renomination.

site_title: Crypto in the classroom: Lucy Kellaway on the kids' new craze
summary: Teenage boys in the UK are investing in cryptocurrencies, despite some schools' inadequate teaching on personal finance. Boys in one school are making significant gains, but their teacher expresses concern about the risks, citing the Quran's stance on gambling. Many students, including a 15-year-old, are learning about cryptocurrencies through online tutorials and YouTube videos, often without proper guidance or understanding of the risks. Experts warn that financial illiteracy among young people is a growing concern, with many lacking knowledge of basic financial concepts, such as compound interest and risk management.

site_title: Gold rallies despite a strong dollar and high bond yields
summary: Gold prices have rallied 3.6% since the start of November, trading around $1,866 an ounce, despite a strong dollar and high bond yields. The metal broke through resistance at $1,840, a level it had tested four times this year, and has been driven by seasonality and inflation concerns. However, uncertainty over central bank moves and inflationary pressure from early holiday shopping may impact gold's performance, potentially leading to a range-bound market until the next Fed meeting in mid-December.

site_title: Move to tax foreign-sourced income in Malaysia not a surprise
summary: Malaysia has introduced a new tax policy that will subject foreign-sourced income (FSI) to taxation from January 1 next year. The move aims to comply with the OECD Forum on Harmful Tax Practices and potentially remove the country from the EU's grey list of tax havens. Certain types of FSI, such as foreign dividends, will continue to be exempt from taxation. The government hopes this policy will generate revenue and encourage the repatriation of FSI.

site_title: Malaysia says Singapore has returned US$16.3m in 1MDB funds
summary: Singapore has returned approximately US$16.3 million in 1MDB funds to Malaysia, according to the Malaysian Anti Corruption Commission. The funds were linked to a multibillion-dollar scandal at state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) between 2009 and 2014. The Malaysian government has recovered about RM20.5 billion (S$6.7 billion) in 1MDB assets so far, with efforts to recover more ongoing in countries including Switzerland and Hong Kong.

site_title: After long delay and cost overruns, Vietnam's first metro line begins service at last
summary: Vietnam's first metro line, the 13-kilometer Ha Dong line, began operations in Hanoi after an 8-year delay and significant cost overruns. The line runs from Ha Dong in Hanoi's southwest to Cat Linh, near the Temple of Literature and Hang Day Stadium. The project was initially planned but faced budget and construction issues, finally starting operations in November 2021. This is the first of nine planned metro lines for the Vietnamese capital.

site_title: Dyson moving into new global HQ at St James Power Station
summary: British technology company Dyson has completed the restoration of historic St James Power Station in Singapore and begun its move into the new global headquarters. The 110,000 sq ft waterfront site will house state-of-the-art research laboratories, doubling the company's research and engineering footprint. Dyson plans to hire 250 more engineers and scientists in Singapore over the next 5 years, as part of its £2.75 billion global investment plan. The company's CEO, Roland Krueger, said the move is "honoured" and will bring significant history to the building through scientific discoveries and technological developments.

site_title: Nat gas producers face billions in hedging losses for 2022: Rystad Energy
summary: US natural gas producers face billions of dollars in hedging losses for 2022 due to high gas prices. Global energy crunch boosts prices to multi-year highs, with US futures reaching a 12-year high in early October. Eleven operators analyzed by Rystad Energy stand to lose more than $5.2 billion if prices average at $4 per mmbtu, potentially doubling to $9.8 billion if prices average at $5 per mmbtu.

site_title: Enjoy your coffee, but watch how much you drink
summary: Moderate coffee consumption, defined as 3-5 cups per day or up to 400mg of caffeine, is not associated with a significant health risk in healthy adults, according to US dietary guidelines. However, observational studies suggest potential benefits, such as reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and certain cancers. Despite this, the lack of randomized controlled trials limits the understanding of causality. Pregnant women and those planning conception should limit their caffeine intake to 200mg per day, as high consumption is linked to increased risk of miscarriage, stillbirth, and low birth weight.

site_title: Booster shots standardised to 5 months after last shot for all age groups
summary: Singapore has standardized booster shots to 5 months after the last shot for all age groups, effective from Nov 24. This move follows the latest recommendation from the Expert Committee on Covid-19 Vaccination, citing the waning of antibodies occurring by around six months after the second dose. The government aims to administer 1.5 million boosters, increasing coverage from 21% to 50% of the population. Eligible individuals will receive SMS invitations for booster shots, with those who haven't received an invitation able to walk into vaccination centers without booking an appointment.

images.alt_text: Booster vaccinations for all in Singapore will from Nov 24 be standardised across the board at 5 months from the completion of the initial vaccination regime.

site_title: Manhattan's former Sony Building lands Chubb as anchor tenant
summary: Chubb has signed as anchor tenant at Manhattan's 550 Madison Avenue, leasing 240,000 square feet across 10 floors. The deal represents 30% of the 41-storey property's offices and will relocate Chubb's New York headquarters in 2022. The building, gut-renovated at a $300 million cost, features hospital-level filtration systems, a library, and a garden with 50 full-grown trees. The signing comes as the Manhattan office market recovers from the pandemic, with deals still below pre-pandemic averages.

site_title: I'm 87, triple vaxxed and living my life again
summary: An 87-year-old woman, triple vaccinated against Covid-19, is embracing life after a pandemic-induced pause. She's reacquainting herself with social activities, visiting grandchildren, and enjoying retirement community amenities. With a life expectancy of six more years, she's determined to make the most of her remaining time, despite lingering fears and caution. She finds solace in her resilience and optimism, encouraging others to prioritize relationships and living life to the fullest, rather than focusing solely on survival.

site_title: The importance of end-of-life planning
summary: A person's close relative was recently diagnosed with stage 4 cancer, leading to a rapid decline in their quality of life. The relative did not have end-of-life plans, including advanced care planning, lasting power of attorney, and advanced medical directives, causing stress and anxiety for the family. These plans are crucial in ensuring that an individual's wishes are respected, and their loved ones are not burdened with difficult decisions. Experts emphasize the importance of end-of-life planning, which can provide peace of mind and ensure that a person's legacy is respected.

site_title: HK bourse CEO says China expansion will bring 'big bang of finance'
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing CEO Nicolas Aguzin predicts China's capital market will triple over the next 10 years, positioning the country for the next "big bang of finance." China's expansion will lead to its emergence as the world's largest economy. Aguzin's statement came during the Bloomberg New Economy Forum in Singapore, where he emphasized the significance of China's outward investment.

site_title: Binance's US entity expects to close funding round in 'a month or two'
summary: Binance's US entity, Binance.US, is expected to close its funding round in about a month or two, raising around a couple hundred million dollars. Founder and CEO Zhao Changpeng mentioned that the company is following a "playbook" for an initial public offering (IPO) in the US, citing Coinbase's listing as a reference. The parent company, Binance, is not ruling out an IPO but will consider various factors, including regulations and market conditions.

site_title: Agritech startup Farmers Business Network raises US$300m from investors including Temasek
summary: Agritech startup Farmers Business Network (FBN) has raised US$300 million in a funding round led by Fidelity Management & Research Company, valuing the company at US$3.9 billion. The funding round also includes participation from Archer-Daniels-Midland, LN Mittal Family Office, and Tudor Investment Corp, among others. This investment is part of FBN's efforts to expand its agriculture technology services.

site_title: Austria imposes full lockdown, Germany may follow, as Covid grips Europe
summary: Austria has imposed a full Covid-19 lockdown, requiring the whole population to be vaccinated by February. The move follows a fourth wave of infections in Germany, which may also impose similar measures, sparking concerns about the economic fallout. Roughly two-thirds of Austria's population is fully vaccinated, one of the lowest rates in western Europe. The lockdown will start on Monday, with European stocks and government bond yields tumbling in response to the news.

site_title: TaFF Singapore's Leonard Choo dances away his stress
summary: TaFF Singapore's Leonard Choo, a ballet dancer, finds solace in the art form as a stress-reliever. He began taking ballet classes at 23 and continued to pursue it regularly, finding it to be an incredible experience that solidified it as a serious hobby. The classical ballet classes involve two parts: exercises at the barre and center exercises that test dynamism, muscular expression, and artistry.

site_title: Tiger Global's US$65b man shrugs off China crackdown threat
summary: Scott Shleifer, head of Tiger Global's venture-capital business, believes China's long-term future is bright despite a recent crackdown, which may impact investments in the country. Assets under his management have more than tripled to $65 billion, with a recent milestone reached in hitting a $10 billion target for its biggest venture fund. Shleifer downplays risks, saying China's long-term future is bright and Tiger's biggest wins are yet to come, with opportunities still existing on Hong Kong exchanges if companies can't go public in the US.

site_title: GSS Energy unit to buy Thai electric motorcycles firm for S$7.53m
summary: GSS Energy's subsidiary Giken Mobility has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 100% ownership of Thai electric motorcycles maker Edison Motors for S$7.53 million. The acquisition will be paid in a combination of shares and cash. Edison Motors, which provides design, technical, and engineering services, will become an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of GSS Energy. The deal is expected to enhance the group's e-mobility capabilities and provide patents, design, research, and development capabilities for electric scooters.

site_title: Singapore records 1,734 new Covid-19 cases; ICU utilisation rate at 57%
summary: Singapore reported 1,734 new Covid-19 cases, a decrease from the previous day's 2,038 cases. The weekly infection growth rate fell to 0.77, below 1 for seven consecutive days. ICU utilisation rate remains at 57%.

site_title: As Biden turns 79, potential successors watch from the wings
summary: US President Joe Biden is turning 79 on Saturday, sparking speculation about his potential re-election bid. With Biden's advanced age, Vice President Kamala Harris and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg are seen as potential successors. A recent poll found only 40% of voters believe Biden is in good health, raising concerns about his ability to run for re-election. Harris, who has struggled to make an impact, is seen as the frontrunner, while Buttigieg's popularity is rising due to his work on the infrastructure package. Other potential candidates, including California Governor Gavin Newsom and Minnesota's Amy Klobuchar, are also being considered.

site_title: Haruki Murakami unpacks his T-shirt collection
summary: Author Haruki Murakami has a vast collection of over 100 T-shirts, which he has accumulated over his lifetime of travel. In his new book, "Murakami T: The T-Shirts I Love," he shares memories and musings associated with each shirt, including those purchased at thrift stores and souvenir shops. The collection serves as a sartorial journey, exploring the connection between clothing and memory. Murakami values his comfortable and free lifestyle, symbolized by his T-shirt collection, and finds joy in describing characters' clothing in his novels.

images.alt_text: Murakami's T-shirts were collected over a lifetime of travel. The reclusive author has his fair share of kitschy T-shirts too, including one with the phrase "I put ketchup on my ketchup" emblazoned across the front.

site_title: More data needed before Singapore can decide on easing Covid measures: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's government needs more data before deciding to ease COVID-19 curbs, said Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong. The current Stabilisation Phase measures are set to lapse on Sunday, but officials require "a few more days" to assess the situation. Despite a decline in community cases and eased pressure on hospitals, the government is cautious in its decision-making, with Gan expressing optimism about the possibility of quarantine-free crossing at the land border with Malaysia by the end of November.

site_title: Investors hung their hats on Peloton and Zoom last year. What now?
summary: Peloton and Zoom Video, once darlings of the stock market for their role in the stay-at-home trade, have seen their stock prices collapse as investors shift their attention to other sectors. The economic reopening, aided by rising vaccination numbers and new treatments, has led to a decline in sales for Peloton and Zoom Video, wiping out billions of dollars in shareholder value. In contrast, cyclical stocks such as oil companies and financial firms have seen significant gains, driving the S&P 500 to a record high and on track for its best 3-year run since the late 1990s.

site_title: Ryanair drops London listing over Brexit compliance hassles
summary: Ryanair Holdings, the Irish discount carrier, will drop its London Stock Exchange listing, citing Brexit compliance headaches. The move confirms a plan set in motion due to the need for EU ownership and control, following Britain's exit from the EU. Ryanair has had to limit stock purchases and police investors to ensure compliance, resulting in dwindling trading volumes in London. The airline's shares are down 0.6% this year, and the decision is seen as an "inevitable consequence of Brexit."

site_title: Alvin Tan, WongPartnership's Ng Wai King appointed to MAS board
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has appointed Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry, and Ng Wai King, managing partner of WongPartnership, to its board of directors. Their 3-year terms began on November 22, 2021. Ng also serves on various other boards, including the National University of Singapore's board of trustees and the Singapore Institute of Directors.

site_title: Evergrande to be removed from Hang Seng China Enterprises Index
summary: China Evergrande Group will be removed from Hong Kong's Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, effective immediately, following the index provider's quarterly review. Evergrande's shares have declined over 80% year-to-date. The Hang Seng Indexes added technology firms JD.com and Netease to the benchmark to make it more reflective of Hong Kong-listed companies.

site_title: Australia house prices hugely outpace wage gains: CoreLogic
summary: Australian house prices have outpaced wage gains over the past two decades, driving up household debt and influencing the housing market's outlook. According to CoreLogic, the nation's debt to income ratio is among the highest in the developed world, making home owners vulnerable to rapid rate hikes. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is considering a potential rate increase in late 2023, driven by accelerating pay gains and inflation. Higher interest rates could exert downward pressure on housing prices, potentially making it easier for first-home buyers to enter the market.

images.alt_text: If the RBA begins its policy tightening cycle in earnest, this would exert downward pressure on housing prices, potentially making it easier for first-home buyers to get a foot on the property ladder.

site_title: Should I disclose my salary?
summary: Singaporeans debate whether disclosing salaries can address pay gaps and promote meritocracy. While some, like Gravity Payments CEO Dan Price, argue that transparency can lead to raises, HR professionals caution that it's not a solution to inequity. Organizations face challenges in implementing full disclosure, and market transparency may contribute to increased social mobility, but it's not a panacea. Experts suggest that employees should discuss their worth with superiors and that pay decisions are often influenced by various factors, including certifications, education, and work experience.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a 207.8 million yuan (S$44.2 million) deal to manage three wastewater treatment plants in China's Hebei province. GSS Energy's subsidiary Giken Mobility is set to acquire Edison Motors, a Thai electric motorcycles maker, for S$7.53 million. PSL Holdings has announced it will be de-listed from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading on Nov 30.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open after mixed Asia showing
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Friday, following a mixed Asian session. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.2% and 0.5%, respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. US stocks also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: As Elon Musk dumps more shares, Tesla remains bellwether of post-pandemic recovery
summary: Tesla's stock price has plummeted by over 20% from its peak in early November, dipping into bear-market territory, despite being a bellwether for the post-pandemic recovery. The company's volatility remains high, comparable to meme stocks like GameStop, with 21 moves of 5% or more this year. Elon Musk's recent dumping of shares, worth over $8.8 billion, has contributed to the sell-off, which was triggered by his stance on taxing the mega-rich. Analysts predict Tesla will remain a volatile stock amid the global energy crisis, but may outperform competitors in the electric vehicle industry.

site_title: China property risks to economy can be contained, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that China can contain the economic impact of real-estate developer financial strains, despite slowing growth. The IMF forecasts 8% growth in China this year and 5.6% in 2022, citing pandemic uncertainty and weak consumption as risks. However, the IMF believes policymakers have tools to limit the impact of property curbs on housing demand and investment. The IMF recommends a shift in fiscal policy to support social protection and green investment, and encourages China to distribute more domestically-made vaccines globally.

site_title: Protecting data as the new gold
summary: Companies are struggling to protect themselves against cyberattacks, with nearly 79,400 customers' data potentially accessed by hackers when MyRepublic's third-party servers were compromised in August. Experts point to the increased adoption of digital tools during the pandemic and sophisticated hacker gangs as the main causes of the rise in cases. The Cyber Security Agency of Singapore reported 89 cases of ransomware attacks last year, more than double the 35 reported in 2019. Fines for data breaches have fallen short of the S$1 million limit, with some companies receiving smaller penalties. Experts recommend that companies prioritize cybersecurity, consider the reputational impact of breaches, and invest in measures such as data protection officers and security reviews.

site_title: Thiam Siew Ave freehold sites sold for S$815m to JV between Hoi Hup Realty, Sunway Developments
summary: A joint venture between Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments has acquired two freehold development land parcels at Thiam Siew Avenue in Singapore for S$815 million. The 2.45-hectare sites have a plot ratio of 2.8 and could be developed into luxury high-rise condominiums with over 800 units, priced between S$2,400 and S$2,630 per square foot. The sale is the largest residential land sale since the July 2018 property cooling measures. Analysts estimate that construction costs will impact profit margins, but the sites' proximity to the Paya Lebar Central precinct and their potential for en bloc sales may drive demand.

images.alt_text: The deal of the Thiam Siew Avenue land parcels is the largest residential development land sale since the July 2018 round of property cooling measuress.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, up 1.75 points to 1,525.54. The index saw 474 gainers and 450 losers, with 2.669 billion lots traded worth RM2.013 billion.

site_title: China's Premier Li says economy facing new downward pressures
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country's economy is facing new downward pressures, with complex and severe situations at home and overseas. To alleviate the pressure, China will take measures to reduce commodity prices on small and medium-sized companies and maintain the yuan's exchange rate stability. The government will also study new measures to reduce tax and fee burdens on companies.

site_title: China cities ease land bidding rules as property stress spreads
summary: Chinese cities, including Shanghai and Nanjing, have relaxed land sale rules to ease cash flow pressure on developers amid a property slump. Several cities have lowered transaction requirements, such as reducing deposits and payment deadlines, and increased the number of plots available. This move aims to boost land sales and revenue for local governments, which rely on land sales for 40% of their revenue. The easing of rules is a response to a 27% unsold land parcel rate in September, the highest since 2018, and a 24% decline in land sales by value in October.

site_title: Hong Kong fines ICBC, UBS units, others US$5.7m for anti-money laundering breaches
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator fined four banks, including ICBC and UBS units, a combined $5.67 million for anti-money laundering breaches. The banks failed to carry out proper customer due diligence, with ICBC fined $20.7 million, UBS HK $9 million, China Construction Bank $8.5 million, and CTBC Bank $6 million. The regulator urged banks to review data quality and transaction monitoring systems following the cases, noting significant progress made since the identified deficiencies occurred in a less mature industry period.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower as Alibaba collapses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.07% on Friday, led by a 10.71% drop in Alibaba, which warned on revenue and reported a profit collapse in the second quarter. The Hang Seng Index fell to 25,049.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.13%. The decline was attributed to Alibaba's disappointing earnings report, which dragged down other market heavyweight stocks.

site_title: Alibaba shares tumble 11% after firm slashes sales outlook
summary: Alibaba shares plummeted 11% on Friday after the Chinese e-commerce giant slashed its annual revenue growth forecast due to increased competition and regulatory challenges. The company now expects revenue growth of 20-23%, a slowdown from its previous 29.5% forecast. This marks the slowest pace since its 2014 stock market debut. The company also missed earnings expectations for the second quarter.

site_title: Singapore needs more data before deciding on Covid easing: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore officials need "a few more days" to decide on easing Covid-19 restrictions, according to Trade Minister Gan Kim Yong, citing a stable decline in cases and easing pressure on hospitals. The city-state has seen a 15-day streak of community cases below 2,000 and 40% of public ICU beds vacant. Restrictions, which were set to lapse on November 21, may be extended or relaxed based on the week-over-week ratio of community cases and hospital capacity.

site_title: US: S&P, Dow under pressure from lockdown fears; Nasdaq gains
summary: The US stock market opened flat on Friday due to concerns over fresh lockdowns in Europe, affecting banking, energy, and airline stocks. However, technology stocks pushed the Nasdaq to a record high. The Dow Jones rose 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite reached a record high, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Paytm CEO's fixation on delivering a record IPO led to a first-day flop
summary: Paytm's record-breaking IPO turned into a first-day flop, with the stock's 27% plunge surprising even some pessimists. The company, backed by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, priced shares at the top end of its range, but failed to meet demand, leaving investors with heavy losses. Critics question Paytm's ability to live up to lofty promises, citing a "hyperbolic forecasts" and an underdeveloped business model. The company's founder, Vijay Shekhar Sharma, remains optimistic, but faces a quarter-by-quarter journey to prove its prospects to investors, with analysts predicting a "cash burning machine" with questionable corporate governance.

site_title: China's land sales slump for 4th month as property woes worsen
summary: China's land sales revenue declined 13.14% in October, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, as developers moved cautiously on land buying due to tighter regulatory curbs on borrowing. The value of government land sales dropped to 573.7 billion yuan, down from 662.8 billion yuan in the same period last year. This slump in land sales may constrain fiscal funding for infrastructure, leading regional and local governments to increase debt obligations and fund investments through bonds.

site_title: Telenor, CP Group discuss US$7.5b Thailand telecom merge
summary: Norway's Telenor and Thailand's CP Group are exploring a US$7.5 billion merger of their telecom units in Thailand, which would form a new market leader in the country. The deal would merge Telenor's Total Access Communication (Dtac) and CP Group's True Corporation, creating a combined entity with a 52% market share in Thailand. The transaction would be in line with Telenor's strategy of reducing risk and unlocking more value from its Asian business units. A final agreement is uncertain and subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Norway's Telenor and Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Group (CP Group) are exploring a merger of their telecom units in Thailand that could form a new market leader in the South-east Asian country.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Two freehold development land parcels in Singapore's Thiam Siew Avenue sold for S$815 million, the largest sale since 2018 cooling measures. PUB plans to spend S$1.4 billion on drainage improvement projects over the next five years. Xiaomi partners with foodpanda for 'quick commerce' of electronics in Singapore and Thailand. China Everbright Water clinches a Hebei wastewater treatment project worth 207.8 million yuan. Alvin Tan and Ng Wai King of WongPartnership appointed to the Monetary Authority of Singapore board for a three-year term. The Straits Times Index fell 0.14% on Friday.

site_title: Prime US Reit reaches agreement with WeWork to terminate lease agreement
summary: Prime US Reit has reached an agreement with WeWork to terminate its lease at Emeryville, a California office property. The Reit manager converted the security package into a termination fee, covering lease payments to early Q4 2022. The agreement comes after WeWork previously approached the Reit to restructure its lease, but Prime US Reit maintained its demand for rental payments. The lease termination is expected to have no material impact on the Reit's portfolio value or distribution per unit for the current financial year.

site_title: Xiaomi teams up with foodpanda to drive 'quick commerce' of electronics in Singapore, Thailand
summary: Xiaomi teams up with foodpanda to drive 'quick commerce' of electronics in Singapore and Thailand. The partnership allows users to shop for Xiaomi gadgets on the food delivery app and have them delivered within 30 minutes. Foodpanda's "foodpanda shops" will feature Xiaomi products, including smart devices, audio accessories, and household appliances. This collaboration marks Xiaomi's focus on "quick commerce" as it scales up outside of China, aiming to become the world's biggest smartphone maker in the next 3 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up, welcoming fresh Japan stimulus
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, Nov 19, 2021, as investors welcomed fresh Japan stimulus to shore up its pandemic recovery. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.50% to 29,745.87, and the Topix index rose 0.44% to 2,044.53. The stimulus aimed to boost economic growth and counteract the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: STI ends week 0.14% lower amid cautious trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.14% to 3,232.34 on Friday, marking its second narrowest weekly range in five years, amid inflationary pressures and supply chain disruptions. Decliners outpaced advancers 239 to 222, with the US inflation concerns and global fossil fuel price surge contributing to investor worries.

site_title: China Evergrande resumes construction on 63 projects in Pearl River delta
summary: China Evergrande has resumed construction on 63 projects in the Pearl River delta, spanning 15 sites in Guangzhou, Foshan, and surrounding areas. The real estate developer aims to "speed up and conquer difficulties" to deliver projects on time and meet quality standards. This move comes after the company faced financial difficulties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 2.64 points or 0.2% to 1,526.43. Volume was 254.7 million lots worth RM108.8 million, with gains outnumbering losses 190 to 171.

site_title: Philippines to reopen 'soon' to vaccinated foreign tourists
summary: The Philippines is set to reopen its borders to fully vaccinated foreign tourists "soon", following moves by other Southeast Asian countries to relax travel curbs. The tourism ministry approved the plan, which includes entry from countries with low Covid-19 cases, such as Japan, China, and India. This move aims to boost the country's tourism industry, which saw an 83% drop in foreign arrivals last year. Guidelines must be finalized before the reopening, which is expected to help the country's recovery efforts.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust to raise S$575.5m in IPO, selling units at S$0.80 each
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) will raise S$575.5 million in its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), offering units at S$0.80 each. The trust, sponsored by Daiwa House Industry Co (DHI), aims to capture growth opportunities in the Asian market, particularly in the Asean region. DHLT will purchase 14 logistics properties in Japan, with a potential pipeline of 42 assets in Japan, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia. The trust expects to repay a short-term loan after its listing and has a high aggregate leverage of 43.8% initially, but aims to reduce it to 36.9% after repayment.

site_title: US mulls diplomatic boycott of Beijing Olympics
summary: US President Joe Biden is considering a diplomatic boycott of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, amid pressure to address China's human rights abuses, particularly in the Xinjiang region. The move would impact government representatives attending the games, but not athletes. Biden's comments follow a video summit with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, who emphasized stability and preventing accidental conflicts. China's foreign ministry has dismissed human rights concerns as "inconsistent with the truth and completely groundless." A diplomatic boycott would be part of a complex balancing act for Biden, who aims to re-engage with Beijing while strengthening traditional alliances.

site_title: Thiam Siew Ave freehold sites sold for S$815m; it's biggest housing site sale since 2018 cooling measures
summary: A joint venture between Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments has purchased two freehold development land parcels at Thiam Siew Avenue in Singapore for S$815 million, marking the largest residential site sale since 2018 cooling measures. The 2.45 ha site has a plot ratio of 2.8 and translates to about S$1,488 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale price is expected to translate to luxury condominium prices between S$2,400 and S$2,630 per square foot, considering construction costs.

site_title: Japan unveils record US$490b stimulus to boost pandemic recovery
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has announced a record US$490 billion stimulus package to boost the country's pandemic recovery, the largest in Japanese history. The 56 trillion yen (S$665.1 billion) injection includes cash and coupon handouts, pay rises for nurses and careworkers, and is expected to be approved by the Cabinet. The move aims to provide a sense of safety and hope to the Japanese people, but analysts have raised doubts over its effectiveness and potential impact on Japan's already high public debt load.

site_title: PUB to spend S$1.4b more on drainage improvement projects in next 5 years
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) of Singapore plans to invest an additional S$1.4 billion in drainage improvement projects over the next 5 years to enhance the country's flood resilience. This is in addition to the S$2 billion already spent on similar projects. The PUB has also introduced new initiatives, including improved radar technology and expanded flood-monitoring capabilities, to prepare for the wetter weather expected during the North-east Monsoon season. The agency has also deployed new flood-response vehicles and automated flood barriers to help mitigate flood risks.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks deliver first weekly gain in 5
summary: South Korean stocks experienced their first weekly gain in 5, rising 0.075% to 2,971.02 as of Friday, November 19, 2021, amid investor optimism over pandemic recovery and inflation. The benchmark Kospi index gained 23.64 points, or 0.80%, from the previous week's decline. The Korean won weakened, while the bond yield rose, indicating a shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Indonesia swings to current account surplus in Q3
summary: Indonesia's current account surplus widened to $4.5 billion in Q3, driven by a boost in merchandise exports due to high commodity prices. This marks a significant improvement from a Q2 deficit of $2 billion. The country's balance of payments showed a surplus of $10.7 billion from July to September, compared to a Q2 deficit of $0.4 billion. The improvement is attributed to Indonesia's strong export performance, which helped to offset the impact of declining imports.

site_title: China's Weibo cleared for Hong Kong secondary listing: filings
summary: Weibo Corporation, China's largest microblogging platform, has been approved by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's listing committee to sell shares in the city, giving it a secondary listing alongside New York. The company did not specify the amount it is looking to raise or a timetable for the sale. This move follows regulatory filings published on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's website, indicating approval for the secondary listing.

site_title: Dyson delivers virtual reality in new twist to home shopping
summary: Dyson is launching a virtual reality showroom, allowing customers to test its hairdryers, straighteners, and stylers from home. The technology, developed by the company's engineers, will be available through Oculus headsets starting November 19. The move aims to improve customer understanding of Dyson products and will eventually incorporate e-commerce solutions and real salesperson interactions. Dyson's e-commerce director, Sean Newmarch, said the demonstration will be available for hair care products initially, with floor care range to follow.

site_title: Japan's consumer prices extend gains as fuel costs surge
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.1% year-on-year in October, driven by a 21.4% surge in fuel costs, the largest gain since August 2008. This is the second straight month of gains, despite weak wage growth limiting price hikes. The Bank of Japan will scrutinize this data in its policy meeting, with inflation expected to accelerate to around 1% in the first half of next year.

site_title: Tennis: WTA threatens to pull out of tournaments in China over Peng
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) threatens to pull out of tournaments in China due to the lack of response to Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai's sexual assault allegation. Peng claimed former vice-premier Zhang Gaoli coerced her into sex, but neither Zhang nor the Chinese government has commented on the matter. Peng's social media post was deleted, and the topic is blocked on China's censored internet. The WTA is prepared to withdraw from Chinese tournaments unless they are satisfied with the response to Peng's allegations.

images.alt_text: An outcry over the whereabouts of Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai escalated on Friday (Nov 19) as the Women's Tennis Association (WTA) said it was prepared to pull its tournaments out of China if they were not satisfied with the response to her sexual assault allegation.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH initiates 'buy' on Aoxin Q&M with S$0.37 target price
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on dental equipment and services provider Aoxin Q&M with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.37. Analyst John Cheong expects a strong turnaround in earnings due to the company's recent acquisition of Acumen Diagnostics and improved performance in its China dental business. Cheong estimates earnings growth of around 80% in FY2022, driven by contributions from Acumen and the expansion of its dental services industry in China.

site_title: China stocks in US slide as Alibaba adds to earnings woes
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks fell 3.2% on Thursday, adding to Wednesday's drop, due to poor earnings guidance from Alibaba Group Holding, which dropped 11% after revenue forecast fell short of analyst estimates. Other Chinese companies, such as Bilibili and Vipshop Holdings, also reported significant declines. The decline is attributed to a challenging operating environment in China, including a regulatory crackdown and a resurgence in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares dive at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.52% at the open on Friday, led by Alibaba's 10% decline after it announced a significant drop in quarterly profits and lowered its revenue outlook due to a government crackdown on tech firms and slowing economic growth. The Hang Seng Index fell 385.32 points to 24,934.40, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 1.43 points to 3,519.28.

site_title: Viking Offshore & Marine gets mandatory unconditional cash offer at S$0.01 per share
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine has received an unconditional cash offer of S$0.01 per share from a group of businessmen, acquiring about 87% of the company's issued shares. The offer is made solely to comply with acquisition code and does not indicate any major changes to the existing businesses. The board will appoint an independent financial adviser to advise on the offer, and shareholders will be notified within 14 days. Shares closed down 13.3% on the announcement date at S$0.078.

site_title: BT Explains: Can those who renounce their citizenship keep their GCB and CPF?
summary: Singaporeans who renounce their citizenship can keep their Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) and Central Provident Fund (CPF) accounts, but only if they sell the GCBs and withdraw all CPF cash balance within 2 years. CPF accounts can be transferred to a bank account abroad, but members are encouraged to close their accounts to avoid any potential issues. Foreigners can maintain their bank accounts, but rules vary among banks.

site_title: Binance US unit may raise 'couple hundred' million in funding
summary: Binance US, the American affiliate of Binance, is expected to raise a "couple hundred million" dollars in funding. The round, which is likely to close in 1-2 months, is part of a booming crypto fundraising trend. The company had initially sought at least $100 million in funding in August, following CEO Brian Brooks' resignation earlier that month. This funding round is the latest in a series of investments from reputable investors in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but Alibaba plunge hammers Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted 1.7% on Friday due to Alibaba's 11% drop in US shares, citing weaker earnings and regulatory concerns. Asia's markets were otherwise up, with Tokyo and Shanghai gaining, as the Japanese government announced plans to inject $500 billion into the economy. The US Federal Reserve faces pressure to raise interest rates, and inflation concerns persist globally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Modi U-turns on Indian farm laws after mass protests
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the repeal of three agricultural reform laws that sparked nearly a year of protests by farmers. The laws, passed in September 2020, aimed to deregulate farm produce markets, but protesters argued they would benefit big business at the expense of small farmers. Thousands of farmers camped out on the outskirts of New Delhi, leading to violent clashes with police. Modi's reversal came ahead of important elections in states where many farmers reside, and was welcomed by opposition leaders.

images.alt_text: India will scrap 3 agricultural reform laws that sparked almost a year of huge protests by farmers, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said Friday (Nov 19) in a stunning and rare U-turn by his Hindu nationalist government.

site_title: FountainVest to buy Papa John's Pizza China franchisee from EQT
summary: FountainVest Partners has agreed to purchase China F&B Group, the parent company of Papa John's Pizza and Dairy Queen outlets in China, from EQT AB for approximately US$160 million. China F&B, founded in 2003, operates the largest ice-cream restaurant chain and the second-largest pizza outlet chain in China. The deal is FountainVest's fourth acquisition in the Asia-Pacific region this year, with the firm investing at least US$2 billion in China.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher, post second straight weekly loss
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Friday, but marked a second straight weekly loss, closing at 7,396.5 points. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.23% despite a decline in financials, led by the "Big Four" banks, which fell 3.6% for the week. A revised takeover bid for Crown Resorts and modest recovery in financials were unable to counter the weekly slump.

site_title: Najib's US$24m request threatens Malaysia political stability
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's request for a $24 million land and house gift from the government is sparking controversy, potentially destabilizing the country's politics. The opposition, led by Anwar Ibrahim, is reconsidering a confidence and supply agreement with the government, which could lead to another round of instability. Najib's request is estimated to be worth $32.4 million, and his party is seeking to capitalize on the issue ahead of a crucial state election. The move is seen as an attempt to rehabilitate his image and regain power.

images.alt_text: Former premier Najib Razak was sentenced to 12 years in prison and a US$50 million fine last week after he was ruled guilty in a case linked to 1MDB. Malaysia struck a US$3.9 billion settlement with Goldman Sachs in July to resolve criminal charges against the US bank.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, November 19, 2021, as investors weighed the impact of fresh Japan stimulus to be announced later in the day. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.04% or 12.30 points to 29,610.96, while the Topix index increased 0.02% or 0.34 points to 2,035.86. The flat opening comes after a mixed Wall Street close.

site_title: Mizuho CEO to step down after system failures, reports say
summary: Mizuho Financial Group CEO Tatsufumi Sakai is planning to step down following multiple technical failures that disrupted services for customers. The failures, which included outages at ATMs and foreign-currency money transfers, drew criticism from the government and regulators. Japan's Financial Services Agency is preparing another business improvement order for the bank tied to the glitches. The decision comes amid increasing pressure on the bank's management to address a bloated cost structure and internal divisions stemming from a merger 20 years ago.

site_title: Partial lunar eclipse to be longest in nearly 600 years
summary: A rare partial lunar eclipse, visible for nearly 3 hours and 28 minutes, occurred on November 19, 2021, with the Moon appearing almost completely red as it moved behind the Earth. The longest partial lunar eclipse in nearly 600 years, it was visible for a big slice of humanity in North and South America, as well as parts of Asia and Polynesia. The phenomenon, caused by "Rayleigh scattering", made the Moon appear redder due to the Earth's atmosphere, with the most vivid coloring visible at peak eclipse 18 minutes later.

site_title: Indonesia's Cimory prices US$260m IPO near top end of range
summary: Indonesian dairy producer PT Cisarua Mountain Dairy, known as Cimory, priced its initial public offering (IPO) at 3,080 rupiah (29 Singapore cents) per share, near the top end of its marketed range, to raise approximately US$260 million. The IPO, scheduled for December 6, will be the nation's largest first-time share sale by a food company in over a decade, with 1.19 billion shares being offered. The proceeds will be used to expand production capacity.

site_title: China Everbright Water clinches Hebei wastewater treatment project worth 207.8m yuan
summary: China Everbright Water Limited has clinched a 207.8 million yuan (S$44.2 million) deal to manage three wastewater treatment plants in Hebei, China. The company will provide wastewater treatment services at Huanghua City, a northern Chinese province near Beijing. The project forms part of the southern canal system of the Haihe River Basin, serving as an important flood discharge and drainage channel.

site_title: Only 1.2% of world's top firms make substantial climate disclosures: Arabesque
summary: Only 1.2% of the world's top 5,000 firms, mostly large listed companies, made substantial climate disclosures, according to Arabesque's analysis. 54% of top firms made no disclosures, while industries like health and technology services were the worst offenders. The Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommends that companies disclose climate risks, but only about half of companies reported on some form of climate-related risks and opportunities. Regulators are increasing scrutiny, and investors are focusing on companies' exposure to climate change, with the TCFD framework being used as a basis for mandatory disclosures.

site_title: QT Vascular requisitioner withdraws notices; company issues clarification
summary: QT Vascular has withdrawn the requisitioning notices for extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) by shareholder Mission Well, which aimed to remove CEO Eitan Konstantino and other board members. The company claims Mission Well did not provide accurate information and made the requisition without explanation. QT Vascular has also clarified remuneration payments and new share issuances, refuting Mission Well's claims. The company's shares ended the week 10% lower after the announcements.

site_title: Towards impact-driven sustainability
summary: Companies must move beyond a superficial approach to sustainability, embedding environmental, economic, and social value into core business activities. To achieve this, they must review resource and capital allocation decisions with purpose, prioritizing ESG metrics and fostering stakeholder engagement. A fundamental shift is needed to recognize sustainability as a driving force, rather than just a peripheral obligation, and to unlock organizations to the circular economy and a better way of calibrating relationships between markets, customers, and natural resources.

images.alt_text: At week's end, global investors and policy makers will likely be given a stark reminder of the costs of a bitter Sino-US trade war, with a Reuters poll predicting that China's third-quarter growth will slow to its weakest pace since the global financial crisis.
Dr Jayanthi Desan helms Aubrens, a leading sustainability consultancy firm in Asia that helps organisations align their strategies and operations with global benchmarks and standards.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts gets A$8.5b offer from Blackstone
summary: Australia's Crown Resorts received a non-binding takeover proposal from Blackstone Inc, valuing it at A$8.46 billion (S$8.35 billion). The offer, from funds managed by Blackstone, is a 26.2% premium to the stock's last close, with A$12.50 in cash per share. The proposal is subject to shareholder approval and regulatory review.

site_title: Singapore business events bounce back post Covid-19, Hong Kong flounders
summary: Singapore is hosting top executives from global companies at various conferences, marking its return to normalcy after the COVID-19 pandemic. In contrast, Hong Kong remains under strict quarantine rules, which may impact its economic activity and talent retention. Despite daily COVID-19 cases and restrictions, Singapore is allowing quarantine-free travel to over a dozen countries, including the US, and is hosting events with hundreds of attendees. The city-state aims to open up more for business with 85% of its population vaccinated.

site_title: Ford Motor announces partnership to assure steady flow of US-made chips
summary: Ford Motor has partnered with GlobalFoundries to increase US-made chip production and improve its supply of critical parts. The non-binding agreement aims to foster innovation and ensure a long-term supply-demand balance. Ford CEO Jim Farley stated that the collaboration will help the company achieve greater independence in delivering technologies and features to customers. The companies plan to discuss specific ways to expand US chip production, but no investment in a new factory was announced. This collaboration comes as the auto industry faces ongoing chip shortages, with General Motors also exploring ways to secure enough chips.

site_title: Diet-related illness increases with availability of red meat: study
summary: A study published in the British Medical Journal found that the global trade in red and processed meats has led to a significant increase in diet-related non-communicable diseases, including colorectal cancer, type-2 diabetes, and coronary heart disease. Between 1993 and 2018, related deaths increased by nearly 75% worldwide, with a 55% rise in developed countries and a 157% rise in developing countries. The study suggests that international dialogue between health and trade bodies is needed to achieve healthier and more sustainable diets, particularly in developing countries that rely heavily on red and processed meat imports.

site_title: Agritech startup Farmers Business Network raises US$300m from investors including Temasek
summary: Farmers Business Network, an agritech startup, raised $300 million in funding from investors including Temasek, valuing the company at $3.9 billion. The funding round was led by Fidelity Management & Research Company and included participation from Archer-Daniels-Midland, LN Mittal Family Office, and others. The company plans to use the capital to fuel growth of its platforms and invest in technology and data science, with plans to hire 350 more employees over the next year. FBN has a data-driven platform that allows farmers to make decisions on seeds and agronomics.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up on financials, healthcare boost
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to 7,379.2 points, driven by gains in financials and healthcare stocks. Banking stocks rebounded after a three-day losing streak, while healthcare stocks added 0.7% for the third consecutive day. Gold stocks declined 1.8% due to bets on an earlier-than-expected US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The US Federal Reserve's decision on its nominee for the head of the central bank is expected to influence policy tightening and inflationary risks.

site_title: Seoul: Inflation, Covid-19 woes push stocks toward fifth weekly decline
summary: South Korean stocks are on track for a fifth weekly decline due to surging Covid-19 cases and inflationary risks. The Kospi index rose 0.11% to 2,950.69, but declined 0.7% for the week. Key players like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix were affected, with Samsung trading flat and SK Hynix rising 0.91%, while LG Chem and Naver fell 1.93% and 0.12%, respectively. The Korean won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield rose, indicating investor sentiment remains cautious.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Viking Offshore, QT Vascular, China Everbright, Straco, Ellipsiz
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine received a mandatory unconditional offer at S$0.01 per share, with its shares rising 18.4% prior to the announcement. QT Vascular's shareholder Mission Well withdrew its EGM notices without explanation, and the company refuted claims it was a long-term shareholder. Everbright Water secured a partnership project to build wastewater treatment plants in Hebei province, investing S$44.2 million. Straco Corp posted a net profit of S$4.4 million in Q3, while Ellipsiz announced plans to enter the agri-food industry through a conditional sale and purchase agreement.

site_title: Li Ka-shing-backed Dutch waste firm AVR in talks to buy AEB
summary: AVR, a Dutch waste processing company backed by Li Ka-shing's group, has emerged as the preferred bidder for Amsterdam's AEB, valued at over 400 million euros. AVR submitted the highest bid ahead of other parties, including financial investors. Discussions are ongoing, and the deal could fall apart or be sold to another bidder. AEB processes 1.4 million tonnes of waste annually and has a history dating back to the early 20th century. The sale is part of Amsterdam's municipal government's plan to sell the company, which started an auction in April.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall slightly at Friday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell slightly at Friday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% or 3.21 points to 3,233.81. Gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 61, despite 90.8 million securities changing hands. Top gainers included QT Vascular and Trans-China Automotive, while Singtel dropped 0.8% to S$2.50. The decline followed a mixed close on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising, while the Dow Jones Industrial average fell.

site_title: Japan eyes record stimulus package, bucking global tapering trend
summary: Japan is set to unveil a record $488 billion stimulus package to cushion the economic blow from the Covid-19 pandemic, bucking a global trend of withdrawing crisis-mode stimulus measures. The package, which includes funds for households and economic reflating, will likely lead to additional bond issuance this year. The massive spending will underscore Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's resolve to focus on economic growth and wealth redistribution. The package is expected to include record spending of around $661.8 billion and will be compiled with an extra budget to fund part of the cost.

site_title: Live Nation, Apple, Travis Scott sued for US$2b over Astroworld disaster
summary: Live Nation Entertainment, Apple, and US rapper Travis Scott have been sued for $2 billion by hundreds of people injured in the deadly Astroworld concert on November 5, in which 10 people were killed. The lawsuit alleges that the defendants "incited into a frenzy" a crowd of 50,000 people, and that Live Nation could have prevented the carnage if it had prepared properly. The case is the largest so far over the event, with 282 plaintiffs and another suit seeking over $750 million in damages.

site_title: Xbox chief evaluating console maker's relationship with embattled Activision
summary: Xbox chief Phil Spencer is evaluating the company's relationship with Microsoft-owned gaming console maker Activision Blizzard amid allegations of sexual misconduct and equal pay violations. Spencer expressed his team's "disturbance and deep concern" over the allegations, stating that the leadership at Xbox and Microsoft support their teams in building a safer environment. The allegations have led to launch delays and the exit of top executives, with employees staging a walkout following a report of the CEO's prior knowledge of the allegations. Activision is engaging with its partners, including Xbox.

site_title: Unilever sells tea arm, including Lipton, for 4.5b euros
summary: Unilever has agreed to sell its global tea business, including Lipton and PG Tips, to private equity group CVC Capital Partners for 4.5 billion euros. The sale comes as Unilever seeks higher growth opportunities elsewhere, with the ekaterra tea division generating 2 billion euros in revenue last year. The deal is set to complete in the second half of next year, subject to regulatory approvals, and excludes Unilever's tea business in India, Nepal, and Indonesia.

site_title: Oil hovers above 6-week low as China readies crude reserve release
summary: Oil prices rose slightly after falling to 6-week lows as investors awaited news on China's potential release of crude reserves. China's state reserve bureau confirmed it was working on a release, while the US requested cooperation from Japan and South Korea. The move is seen as a potential relief for markets, which have been pressured by high gasoline prices and inflation. Brent crude rose 1.2% to $81.24 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.8% to $79.01 a barrel.

site_title: Gold slips as US jobless claims data cements rate-hike bets
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.4% to $1,858.76 per ounce due to strong US jobless claims data, strengthening bets for an earlier-than-expected rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The data showed Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell close to pre-pandemic levels, reducing demand for safe-haven metal. This, combined with surging consumer prices, has bolstered bets for early interest rate hikes, making gold less attractive.

site_title: Lufthansa Technik Philippines shines with two big wins
summary: Lufthansa Technik Philippines (LTP) has won two prestigious awards at the Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES) 2021 for its leadership and sustainability efforts. The company, a top provider of maintenance, repair and overhaul services, received the Top Workplace in Asia award for its investment in employee welfare, despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. LTP's president and CEO, Elmar Lutter, was also recognized as one of the region's outstanding leaders.

site_title: AstraZeneca announces 'robust' results from anti-Covid drug trial
summary: AstraZeneca announced robust results from its anti-Covid drug trial, showing efficacy and long-term prevention. The AZD7442, a combination of two antibodies, has been undergoing final stage clinical trials. This follows US firms Merck and Pfizer's announcements of Covid-19 prevention drugs. The AstraZeneca drug is designed to be taken at the first sign of symptoms, offering a potential solution to severe forms of the disease. The results are seen as a significant development in the fight against Covid-19.

site_title: R.E. Lee International's CEO recognised as outstanding leader in Asia
summary: R.E. Lee International's CEO Calvin Lo has been recognized as one of Asia's outstanding leaders at the Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES) 2021. As CEO of the Hong Kong-based billionaire's company, Lo has successfully contributed to the company's substantial growth, including a 25% yearly growth despite the Covid-19 pandemic. He has also established R.E. Lee Capital, a Singapore-based asset management firm, and is known for his philanthropic efforts, including The 195 Project, which aims to address global issues through business discussions.

site_title: US pharmacy chain CVS to close about 10% of stores
summary: US pharmacy chain CVS plans to close approximately 900 stores, or about 10% of its locations, over the next three years. The closures will begin in the spring of 2022 and will focus on underperforming stores, with the company aiming to reduce store density. Despite the closures, CVS will remain the nation's largest drugstore chain with over 9,900 stores in the US, and will continue to invest in its digital presence and health care services.

site_title: MiRXES eyes fuss-free early cancer tests; road ahead not easy
summary: Singapore-based startup MiRXES aims to develop early-stage cancer tests that can be as simple as a blood test or Covid PCR test. The company has already developed a PCR-based blood test kit for gastric cancer, approved by Singapore's Health Sciences Authority, and plans to expand to other types of cancers. With a recent US$77 million funding round, MiRXES is doubling down on its acquisition strategy to improve accuracy and accessibility. However, the company faces challenges in bringing tests to homes or clinics and engaging patients, as well as regulatory and data security hurdles.

site_title: PBOC's support to focus on small firms, green energy
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), will focus on maintaining stable monetary policy, targeting support towards small businesses and environmentally-friendly projects. Governor Yi Gang stated that the PBOC will continue to provide support to small and medium enterprises and green finance, while phasing out temporary measures. The bank aims to achieve neutral carbon emissions and will use structural monetary policy tools to achieve this goal, balancing policy responses to support economic growth and address climate change concerns.

site_title: Soho House owner plots restaurant expansion to New York, Doha
summary: Soho House owner, Nick Jones, plans to open 12 new locations next year, including private clubs and restaurants, as the exclusive membership club recovers from the pandemic. The company reported a 57% revenue increase to $180 million in the third quarter, despite a net loss of $76 million. The wait list to join the Membership Collective's network grew to 66,800, and the group plans to open two new restaurants in 2022, including one in New York and another in Doha.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq end choppy session at records
summary: The US stock market closed at fresh records on Thursday, driven by gains in large technology equities such as Apple, Amazon, and Nvidia. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3% and 0.5% respectively, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2%. Analysts attributed lingering concerns over inflation and supply chain issues, but noted that strong earnings from companies like Macy's and Kohl's helped lift the markets. Despite this, Meta fell 0.6% after a US state probe into allegations of Instagram supplying the platform to children.

site_title: New US probe targets Instagram's impact on children
summary: A consortium of US states has launched a joint probe into Instagram's impact on children, targeting the social media giant Meta for allegedly promoting the app to minors despite knowing its potential harm. The probe follows a whistleblower's leak of internal documents showing executives were aware of the risks to teens' well-being. Massachusetts Attorney General Maura Healey criticized Meta, stating it has failed to protect young people and prioritized profits over their safety. The investigation marks a fresh regulatory push against Meta amid a reputational crisis.

site_title: Business leaders facilitating change through their formidable leadership
summary: Four prominent business leaders from Asia were recognized for their outstanding leadership at the 2021 Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES). The winners include Ms Cindy Vuu Le Quyen, CEO of Binh Tien Consumer Goods Manufacturing Limited Company (Biti's); Mr Gordon Lam Kwok Wai, president of Syniti Asia Pacific and Japan; Mr Hachi Yin, CEO of Utopia Corporation; and Mr Tran Hung Huy, chairman of Asia Commercial Bank. These leaders were praised for their ability to adapt to changing environments, empower their teams, and drive positive change and impact through their businesses.

site_title: Nvidia's strong report rekindles US$1t market-cap talk
summary: Nvidia Corp shares surged 8.3% after the company delivered estimate-beating results, with analysts praising its data centre business and expecting it to drive growth in the fourth quarter. The stock's market value increased by over $60 billion, bringing it close to a $1 trillion market capitalization. Analysts at Needham estimate that Nvidia's Omniverse software platform could represent a $100 billion market opportunity, further fueling optimism about the company's prospects. This is the latest catalyst for Nvidia's stock, which has risen over 60% since early October.

site_title: Members of the jury panel for the ACES Awards share what it takes to win
summary: The ACES Awards jury shares key takeaways on what it takes for companies to win, emphasizing the importance of perseverance, adaptability, and grit in the face of the Covid-19 pandemic. Industry experts highlight the need for businesses to innovate, prioritize sustainability and transparency, and foster a culture of active communication and collaboration. Companies that can adapt quickly and efficiently will thrive in the post-pandemic reality, where digital transformation and environmental concerns are becoming focal points. The jury also stresses the significance of business resilience, emphasizing the need for corporations to lean on partnerships and collaborations to navigate unexpected events.

images.alt_text: Members of the jury panel for the ACES Awards 2021.

site_title: Biden proposal would boost Detroit but anger trade allies
summary: President Biden's proposal to offer a bigger tax credit for union-built electric vehicles and phase out tax credits for imported EVs has won support from organized labor but drawn criticism from trade allies Mexico and Canada, who accuse the US of protectionism. The proposal, included in Biden's $1.75 trillion spending package, aims to boost the US automotive industry, particularly in Detroit. However, leading non-union carmakers like Toyota and Tesla have expressed opposition to the measure, citing concerns over unfair trade practices.

site_title: Equality, diversity and empowering communities is a major part of these ACES Awards winners' work
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES) 2021 recognized three companies for their commitment to corporate social responsibility (CSR) and sustainability. PT Bank Amar Indonesia won the Innovative Tech Companies of the Year award for its fintech innovations and CSR initiatives, including a collaboration with Habitat for Humanity. Johnson & Johnson was recognized as a top workplace in Asia for its staff welfare and health-focused initiatives. PT Citra Tubindo received the Community Initiative Award for its community development programs, including a vocational learning program and efforts to combat global warming.

site_title: Three ACES Awards winners recognised for setting exceptional standards in leadership and sustainability
summary: Three companies, CPC Corporation, Taiwan, PT Anugerah Pharmindo Lestari (APL), and Equinix Asia-Pacific and Hong Kong, have been recognized for their outstanding leadership and sustainability efforts at the Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES) 2021. CPC Corporation, Taiwan, received the Top Sustainability Advocates in Asia award, while APL received the Community Initiative Award. Equinix Asia-Pacific and Hong Kong won the Asia's Green Company of the Year award. The leaders of these companies, including CPC Corporation's acting chairman and president Shun-Chin Lee and APL's president director Christophe J. Piganiol, were also recognized for their exceptional leadership.

site_title: TOGL Technology named Asia's Most Promising SME
summary: Malaysian digitalisation specialist TOGL Technology Sdn Bhd has been recognized as one of Asia's Most Promising SMEs by the Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability Awards (ACES) 2021. Established in 2017, the company has created mobile apps for essential solutions and built websites for SMEs, including E-Booster and TogaGo.com. Its social messaging app Yippi, launched in 2019, has garnered industry accolades and serves over three million users across 15 countries. The award acknowledges TOGL's success despite the challenges posed by the global pandemic.

images.alt_text: TOGL Technology, which developed the social messaging app Yippi, was invited to showcase its offerings at the Mega Career Fair 2020, organised by Perkeso.

site_title: The ACES Awards recognises some of Asia's finest for the eighth year running
summary: The Asia Corporate Excellence and Sustainability (ACES) Awards, held virtually for the second consecutive year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, recognized successful companies and individuals in Asia for their leadership and sustainability achievements. The awards honored businesses that have risen above the challenges of the pandemic and made a positive impact on their communities.
