site_title: Renault Arkana Fastback review: Feeling all couped up
summary: The Renault Arkana Fastback is a stylish coupe-SUV with a curvilinear and muscular design, rivaling the Baywatch cast. It offers practical features like ample boot space and rear headroom, but its cabin feels humdrum and lacks refinement. The hybrid drivetrain, though efficient, is marred by noticeable clunks and a laggy infotainment system. Performance is acceptable but unexciting, and the car's handling is uninspiring. With few rivals, the Arkana may appeal to those prioritizing aesthetics, but it falls short in other areas, making it a less desirable alternative to the Mazda CX-30 or Toyota Harrier.

site_title: Hong Kong gay dating show aims to break down LGBT+ barriers
summary: A reality TV series in Hong Kong, "Boyscation," aims to break down LGBT+ barriers by portraying the complexities of being gay in Chinese society. The 20-episode series, featuring 10 men from different backgrounds, will follow their daily lives, relationships, and interactions with family and friends. The show's producer, actor Vinci Wong, hopes to change traditional attitudes towards sexuality and promote acceptance. The series is set to air on Hong Kong's TVB television network in late 2021 or early 2022.

site_title: Still picking stocks?
summary: Asian investors are increasingly adopting passive investments via Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs), shifting away from stock picking. The universe of ETFs has grown to over $7.7 trillion, offering diversified portfolios and minimizing the risk of concentrated losses. Research shows that only 14% of stocks outperform an index by more than 10% per year, while 18% consistently underperform by over 30% annually. A recent portfolio of US and emerging market ETFs demonstrated that ETFs can outperform actively managed funds, with returns comparable to those of individual stock picks.

site_title: Security officers in Singapore to see wages rise over 6 years from 2023
summary: Security officers in Singapore will see their wages rise over 6 years, from 2023 to 2028, with a monthly wage increase of 6.6% on average. The lowest-ranked security officers' monthly wage will more than double from S$1,650 to S$3,530, while senior supervisors' wages will rise from S$2,240 to S$4,430. The government has accepted proposals from a tripartite committee to address the industry's manpower crunch and improve wages and working conditions.

site_title: Golden Gate Ventures' Michael Lints digs deep to do better
summary: Michael Lints, partner at Golden Gate Ventures, credits running as a source of focus, rebalance, and personal growth. He approaches running similarly to his professional life, emphasizing the importance of slowing down to build endurance and perseverance. Lints attributes improved mental and physical well-being to running, which also translates to his work and daily life. His experiences, including participating in Ironman 70.3, have taught him the value of discipline, determination, and self-awareness, allowing him to stay calm under pressure and maintain a routine despite demanding work schedules.

site_title: Singapore firms help develop smart mobility solution in Indonesia's BSD City
summary: Mitbana, a joint venture between Mitsubishi Corporation and Surbana Jurong, is introducing a smart mobility solution in Indonesia's BSD City, a metropolitan region of 300,000 people. This project, one of the first in the country, uses real-time technology to manage bus networks. The initiative aims to improve transportation efficiency and quality of life in the area, with Mitbana working with Indonesian partner Sinar Mas Land to implement the solution.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.37 points to 1,531.22 on Friday, with 521 gainers and 414 losers. The index closed at RM2.617 billion in volume.

site_title: Thailand to lag in tourism recovery despite border reopening: Nomura report
summary: Thailand's tourism sector is expected to lag in recovery despite its border reopening, according to a Nomura report. The country's Tourism Recovery from Inbound International Passengers Tracker (TRIPTracker) score is forecasted to reach 4.9% by year-end, from 4% on November 1. This is attributed to a relatively low full-vaccination rate and stringent quarantine requirements imposed on visitors from certain countries. In comparison, Singapore's score is expected to be 6.3% by end-2021, driven by its higher vaccination rates and more aggressive reopening strategy.

site_title: A coming-out party for the NFT community
summary: The NFT community gathered for NFT.NYC, a conference and party in New York, marking a coming-out party for the NFT community. The event, attended by 5,000 people and a 3,000-person waitlist, featured panels and parties, including a yacht party and a reception on the roof of the Edison Hotel. The conference showcased the crossover appeal of NFTs, which have turned a thing people didn't understand into something they do. Many attendees saw NFTs as part of a larger vision of "Web3," a decentralized internet service that runs on public blockchains. The event marked a shift towards mainstream acceptance of crypto, with many young entrepreneurs salivating over the promise of a new, blank canvas.

images.alt_text: An NFT collector named Seedphrase, who appeared on stage in a light-up CryptoPunk helmet, was the DJ for a set at VR World in Manhattan on Nov 1.

A participant getting a taste of a crypto-filled future. Many of today's young crypto entrepreneurs are itching to tear down the entire technological edifice of the modern world and rebuild it, piece by piece, on the blockchain.

site_title: South-east Asia retailers need to take a leaf from China's playbook
summary: China's retail market is the world's largest, valued at US$5.072 trillion in 2020, with a diversified market share of 6.3% among the top 100 companies. In contrast, Singapore's retail market is valued at US$2.53 billion. To reach China's level, South-east Asia and Singapore retailers must adopt innovative strategies, as seen in China's playbook. Despite growing wealth and infrastructure, changes are needed to achieve this goal. The article suggests that China's retail market is a benchmark for smaller players in the region, offering a case study for growth.

site_title: Prince Charles' charity boss quits after cash-for-honours claims
summary: Prince Charles's charity boss, Michael Fawcett, permanently resigned amid an internal investigation into an alleged cash-for-honours scandal. Fawcett, a former valet to Prince Charles, had initially suspended his duties weeks earlier. He is accused of coordinating work to grant a royal honour and UK citizenship for a Saudi businessman, Mahfouz Marei Mubarak bin Mahfouz, in exchange for large donations to restoration projects of interest to Charles. The resignation comes after newspaper revelations about Fawcett's links to the businessman.

site_title: Japan plans stimulus of US$350b to ease pain of Covid-19, oil costs
summary: Japan plans a US$350 billion economic stimulus package to ease the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and rising oil costs, with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida aiming to compile the plan by November 19. The package is expected to finance new debt, adding to Japan's already heavy public debt, as Kishida prioritizes recovery over fiscal reform. The stimulus is part of efforts to spur the world's third-largest economy, which is struggling to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Xi urges investment in economic and technical cooperation in Apec address
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged fellow Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) leaders to invest in economic and technological cooperation, calling it crucial for the bloc. Xi also pledged to expand China's opening up to the world and share its development opportunities. The Apec summit comes amid heightened regional tensions, particularly between China and the US, ahead of a high-stakes online meeting between Xi and US President Joe Biden on Monday. The US aims to prevent growing tensions from escalating into conflict, while China seeks to avoid confrontation and focus on cooperation on issues like climate change and the pandemic.

site_title: UMS Holdings Q3 net profit rises 17% amid 'explosion' in global chip demand
summary: UMS Holdings reported a 17% increase in Q3 net profit to S$15.1 million, driven by strong global semiconductor industry growth and the consolidation of JEP Holdings. The company's mandatory unconditional cash offer for JEP was closed at a final offer price of S$0.20 per share, with 71.66% of JEP's shares accepted. This follows the company's consolidation of JEP Holdings, with the deal aimed at expanding its presence in the global semiconductor market.

site_title: Shares of embattled China Evergrande Group rise to 6-week high
summary: Shares of China Evergrande Group surged to a 6-week high, rising 12.25% to HK$2.84, after the company made a last-minute bond payment, averting a default. This marks the third time in a month the company has paid up close to a deadline. Evergrande's cash-strapped status has led to a 80% loss this year, with over US$300 billion in liabilities. Analysts say Beijing will maintain policies to curb excess borrowing by property developers, despite making financing tweaks amid an industry liquidity crunch.

site_title: Japan's SMFG, Mizuho post surge in H1 profit as credit costs ease
summary: Japan's SMFG and Mizuho Financial Group reported a surge in first-half profit, with SMFG's net profit jumping 69% to 456 billion yen and Mizuho's earnings rising 79% to 385.7 billion yen. The banks' credit costs eased due to government support, but overseas lending margins may be squeezed as the Federal Reserve tapers its financial easing. SMFG and Mizuho lifted full-year profit forecasts and plan to expand overseas operations. Despite challenges, the banks' profitability is expected to improve due to lower credit costs and higher profits from aircraft leasing and other businesses.

site_title: China's real estate slump likely to be significant but contained, say economists
summary: China's real estate slowdown is expected to be significant but contained, according to Oxford Economics. The slowdown is forecast to extend into the first half of 2022, with a recovery later in the year. Investment in private dwellings is expected to grow around 3% between 2021 and 2030, down from 7.6% in the previous decade. Two scenarios suggest a more severe downturn, with China's GDP growth potentially dropping to 3% in 2022 and global metal prices falling heavily.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on J&J, big tech gains
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Friday, driven by gains from Johnson & Johnson and big technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 42.55 points, or 0.12%, to 35,963.78. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 gaining 5.97 points, or 0.13%, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 48.34 points, or 0.31%. The gains came despite concerns over prolonged inflation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private home sales rebounded in October with a 8.3% year-on-year increase. A data breach at RedDoorz affected 6 million customers, with the hospitality platform fined S$74,000. Strong business travel demand was reported on VTLs, and Singapore aims to import 1.2 GW of low-carbon electricity by 2035. The government will continue investing in talent for advanced manufacturing.

site_title: Bumitama Agri hits record Q3 net profit as palm oil price rallies
summary: Bumitama Agri, a palm oil producer, has recorded its highest-ever Q3 net profit of 588.7 billion rupiah, driven by a 27% increase in the average selling price of its crude palm oil to 10,000 rupiah per kg. Revenue for the first 9 months of 2021 increased 40% to 8,496.8 billion rupiah, and net profit rose 70% to 1,072.8 billion rupiah. The company is optimistic about meeting its internal growth guidance for fresh fruit bunches and expects CPO prices to remain high due to global inventory tightness.

site_title: Of good schools and level fields
summary: Singapore's revised primary school registration rules prioritize proximity to schools, potentially favoring affluent families. The Ministry of Education aims to improve access and inclusivity, but critics argue that this may exacerbate existing inequalities. Some popular schools are concentrated in affluent neighborhoods, leading to higher property prices. The revised rules may benefit some families, but others may struggle to access these schools. Experts suggest that alternative solutions, such as providing choice schools in every town, could help achieve a more level playing field.

site_title: A funny little French car auction started last week
summary: A French car auction, hosted by Artcurial, is set to feature 37 iconic French vehicles, including 5 Citroen DS models, 24 Peugeots, and 13 Renaults. The collection, curated by French entrepreneur Richard Romagny, is a tribute to French marques and engineering. Notable lots include a 1989 Peugeot 205 GTI and a 1985 Renault Super 5 GT Turbo, both estimated at over 25,000 euros. Bidding for the auction, which starts on November 4, will conclude on November 22.

site_title: Boustead Singapore H1 profit dips 2%, revenue up as real estate business recovers
summary: Boustead Singapore posted a 2% drop in net profit to S$21.3 million for the half-year ended September, driven by improved revenue recognition in its real estate unit. Revenue rose 17% to S$340.3 million, led by Boustead Projects, with a S$179.1 million topline. The healthcare segment reported a loss, while the geospatial division maintained steady revenue. The company has a net cash position of S$362.8 million and is in a stable position to weather the challenging global landscape.

site_title: Silverlake Axis posts 7% increase in Q1 profit after tax
summary: Silverlake Axis posted a 7% increase in profit after tax for its Q1 2022, reaching RM35.2 million, driven by 18% growth in software project services and 7% growth in maintenance revenue. Revenue rose 3% year-on-year to RM152.5 million. The company remains cautiously optimistic despite a 33% decline in software licensing revenue due to administrative delays. It aims to continue deal signings with its modernised solutions and cloud-based services.

site_title: APAC Realty's 9M net profit more than doubles on new home sales
summary: APAC Realty's net profit more than doubled to S$26.1 million in the first 9 months of 2021, driven by strong sales of new homes, with brokerage revenue increasing 177% year-on-year to S$211.3 million. The company's 9M revenue also more than doubled to S$543.8 million. APAC Realty plans to continue its regional expansion despite the impact of COVID-19 on regional real estate markets, with growth expected in Indonesia and cautious optimism in Thailand. The company anticipates "even stronger growth" in 2022.

site_title: Pressure mounts as UN climate negotiations enter final day
summary: Negotiators at the UN climate conference in Glasgow face a final day of bargaining to agree on a deal to stop global warming from becoming catastrophic. Despite nearly two weeks of talks, countries remain at odds over issues like emissions pledges and climate finance. A new draft weakened language on phasing out fossil fuels, sparking concerns. Countries are attempting to impose new requirements, including annual reviews of climate targets, to keep the 1.5 degree Celsius goal within reach, but a final deal requires the unanimous consent of nearly 200 countries.

site_title: All Cheers, Fairprice Xpress outlets to charge for plastic bags next year
summary: All 167 Cheers and Fairprice Xpress outlets in Singapore will start charging for plastic bags at 10 cents and 20 cents per transaction, respectively, from next year. This expansion of the No Plastic Bag initiative aims to curb excessive plastic bag use and encourage behavioral change. Since its introduction in 2019, the program has saved 30 million plastic bags and gained the support of 7 out of 10 customers. Revenue from the initiative will support green initiatives, including the National Parks Board's OneMillionTrees movement.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Stamford Land's net profit surged to S$16.3 million for the half-year ended September, driven by recovery in its hotel business. Revenue more than doubled to S$83 million, with hotel owning and management contributing S$67.6 million. In contrast, Chip Eng Seng posted a net loss of S$9.6 million for its first quarter, citing pandemic-impacted recruitment and retention of foreign students. Meanwhile, Raffles Education reported a wider net loss, while Chip Eng Seng expects to incur a net loss for FY2021 due to construction delays and supply-chain disruptions.

site_title: Keppel T&T to fully divest its 50% stake in Wuhu Sanshan Port for 170m yuan
summary: Keppel T&T is divesting its 50% stake in Wuhu Sanshan Port for 170 million yuan (S$36 million) to Chinese logistics company Sinotrans. The sale is expected to be completed in Q4, with 34 million yuan paid by Dec 2 and the remainder upon completion. This divestment is not expected to have a material financial impact for the current financial year. The sale price represents a significant decrease from the port's unaudited net asset value of 97 million yuan as of end-July.

site_title: ST Engineering bags 5-year maintenance contract from Virgin Australia Airlines
summary: ST Engineering secured a 5-year component maintenance-by-the-hour contract from Virgin Australia Airlines, starting this month. The contract includes comprehensive component maintenance, repair, and overhaul services for the airline's Boeing B737NG fleet. This adds to ST Engineering's existing airframe heavy maintenance services for Virgin Australia Airlines at its Singapore facility. The contract supports ST Engineering's business recovery and leverages its life cycle nose-to-tail support capabilities.

images.alt_text: In a press statement on Friday (Nov 12), ST Engineering said that under the contract, it will provide full, integrated component support to the growing fleet of Virgin Australia Airlines' Boeing B737NG from this month.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish the week on a positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.32% to 25,327.97. The move followed easing concerns over troubled developer Evergrande, which paid interest on its bonds ahead of a deadline. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index adding 0.18% to 3,539.10. The positive sentiment boosted the market, which had been uncertain due to Evergrande's financial struggles and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end the day higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.13% on Friday, driven by overnight gains in US tech shares, which boosted investor optimism. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 29,609.97, while the Topix index added 1.31% to 2,040.60. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong corporate earnings report.

site_title: EMA seeks proposals to import, sell 1.2 GW of low-carbon electricity into Singapore
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has issued a request for proposal (RFP) to import and sell 1.2 GW of low-carbon electricity, with plans to reach 4 GW by 2035. The first RFP is open until April 1, 2022, for proposals that exclude coal-fired generation technologies. The EMA aims to diversify energy sources, support regional decarbonisation efforts, and improve energy security through these imports.

site_title: Hong Kong economy grows 5.4% yoy in Q3, government upgrades 2021 forecast
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 5.4% in the third quarter of 2021, surpassing the government's revised forecast of 6.4%. This growth reversed the 5.5-6.5% forecasted range. The economy expanded 0.1% on a quarterly basis, improving from a 0.9% contraction in the previous quarter. The government also revised down its full-year underlying CPI forecast to 0.7% from 1%.

site_title: ISDN Holdings Q3 net profit surges by 57% to S$8.6 million
summary: ISDN Holdings, a mainboard-listed engineering solutions provider, reported a 57% surge in its third-quarter net profit to S$8.6 million, its highest quarterly profit in history. The company attributed the increase to diversification into growth industries, including semiconductors and aerospace, with profit margins improving to 11.3% from 7.1% last year. Revenue rose 10.2% to S$106.7 million, driven by the successful commissioning of hydropower plans and expansion of its solutions portfolio.

site_title: China's top chipmaker SMIC says top executive, board members quit
summary: China's Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) announced that its vice-chairman, Chiang Shang-Yi, and three other board members have resigned, including co-CEO Liang Mong Song. Chiang cited family reasons, while Liang's departure was previously threatened. The resignations do not impact SMIC's operations, according to the company. This follows the recent resignation of SMIC's chairman, Zhou Zixue, due to health reasons. SMIC, China's largest chipmaker, is expanding its chip-making capacity with a $8.87 billion deal to build a plant in Shanghai.

site_title: Australia PM Morrison denies lying, rejects French accusation
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison denied lying in public life, saying "I don't believe I have" when asked if he had ever told a lie. Morrison rejected French President Emmanuel Macron's accusation that he lied to him about a multi-billion-dollar submarine contract. Macron had accused Morrison of outright lying, but Morrison said he had the "thick skin" to deal with such allegations. Morrison's denial comes after Macron's accusation, which was made earlier this month.

site_title: Singapore to continue investing in talent to benefit from opportunities in advanced manufacturing
summary: Singapore will continue investing in talent development to support workers in the advanced manufacturing sector, Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong said. This effort aims to equip workers with the necessary skills to harness new technologies. However, the government emphasizes the need for collaboration with businesses to ensure relevant training programs. The move comes after the unveiling of the revamped Siemens Advance Manufacturing Transformation Centre (AMTC) in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (left) and Siemens Asean chief executive Thai-Lai Pham unveiling a plaque at the opening of the expanded Siemens Advance Manufacturing Transformation Centre in Tuas on Friday.

site_title: FW de Klerk, Mandela's partner in ending apartheid, dies at 85
summary: Former South African President Frederik Willem de Klerk, who played a key role in ending apartheid alongside Nelson Mandela, has died at 85. De Klerk, 85, died at his home in Cape Town after being diagnosed with lung cancer in March 2021. He was awarded the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating a smooth transition to democracy in South Africa. De Klerk had previously been a proponent of apartheid, but later admitted to the "terrible wrong" it had done to the country and people.

site_title: Japan prepares beds, booster shots in Covid-19 lull before winter
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has outlined a plan to increase hospital beds and medical resources in preparation for a possible Covid-19 resurgence this winter. The government aims to boost hospital bed capacity by 30% and collect data to predict which hospitals will come under pressure. Booster shots are set to start next month, and the government considers expanding inoculations to children as young as 5. Japan has weathered the pandemic relatively well, but experts warn of a possible sixth wave and urge caution.

site_title: Unvaccinated may face Covid medical bills of S$25,000
summary: Singapore's government plans to start charging unvaccinated Covid-19 patients with medical bills of approximately S$25,000, effective Dec 8. This move aims to encourage vaccination among the 15% of the population that remains unvaccinated. Patients may be eligible for subsidies and a national health insurance plan to lower their fees. The government hopes to reduce the financial burden on hospitals and urge everyone to get vaccinated if eligible.

images.alt_text: Covid-19 patients who are unvaccinated by choice will have to foot their own medical bills from Dec 8, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung at a multi-ministry taskforce briefing on Nov 8.

site_title: Malaysia's GDP shrinks 4.5% in Q3, recovery seen as pandemic's impact fades
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted 4.5% in Q3, worse than forecast, due to pandemic-induced slump and Covid-19 restrictions. However, the central bank expects a quick recovery as restrictions ease and vaccination rates increase. Growth is expected to accelerate to 5.5-6.5% in 2022, driven by reopening of sectors and higher commodity prices. The bank remains vigilant against financial imbalances and price instability.

site_title: STI caps choppy week, ending lower by 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week lower by 0.3%, retreating 9.62 points to 3,228.45. The index declined 13.89 points week-over-week, bucking regional gains. Key drivers include overnight mixed US indices, inflation narratives, and corporate earnings. Despite this, the STI's medium-term view remains bullish, with a "limited rise" over the short term. Gainers outpaced losers, with Maybank Kim Eng's AWX reaching an all-time high of S$4.78.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log fourth weekly decline on inflation risks
summary: South Korean stocks rose on Friday, but logged a fourth weekly decline due to growing inflation risks and supply chain issues. The Kospi index rose 1.50% to 2,968.80, with Samsung Electronics and LG Chem gaining, while SK Hynix fell. The decline marks the fourth weekly drop in four weeks, as investors become increasingly cautious about inflation and its impact on the global economy.

site_title: Australia: Miners help shares back to gains
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.83% on Friday, cutting weekly losses to 0.2%, after miners rebounded on relief over China Evergrande's averted default and a weaker-than-expected US inflation print. Iron ore prices surged, boosting miners like BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue. The S&P/ASX 200 index added 5.2% for the week, with tech stocks also contributing to the gains.

site_title: SoftBank looks to buy stake in software maker Icertis at US$5b valuation: sources
summary: SoftBank Group is reportedly nearing a deal to buy a stake in software maker Icertis, valuing the company at approximately US$5 billion. SoftBank will pay about US$80 million for the stake owned by Fidelity-backed Eight Roads Ventures. Icertis is planning a potential initial public offering in the US as early as next year, with a valuation of US$2.8 billion in March. Deliberations are ongoing, and there's no certainty the transaction will go through.

site_title: HSBC Singapore teams up with Saxo Bank for enhanced digital investment offerings
summary: HSBC Singapore has partnered with Saxo Bank to enhance its digital investment offerings in Singapore by incorporating Saxo's trading infrastructure into its platform. The agreement involves HSBC adopting Saxo's self-directed trading infrastructure for equities investments, aiming to provide users with more advanced digital trading capabilities. This partnership is expected to strengthen HSBC's digital presence in the region and improve its competitiveness in the market.

images.alt_text: HSBC Singapore has entered into an agreement with investment bank Saxo Bank to enhance the former's digital investment offerings in Singapore.

site_title: Toshiba plans to split into 3 firms
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to split into three independent companies, separating its energy and infrastructure business from its device and storage business. The spin-off is aimed at encouraging activist shareholders to exit and is part of a five-month strategic review following a corporate governance scandal. After the split, Toshiba will retain a 40.6% stake in memory chipmaker Kioxia and other assets.

site_title: Impressionist painting sells for record US$53m at NY auction
summary: The Getty Museum purchased Gustave Caillebotte's painting "Young Man at His Window" for a record US$53 million at a Christie's auction in New York, surpassing Caillebotte's previous record of US$22 million. The auction also featured works by Vincent van Gogh, Paul Cezanne, and Claude Monet, generating a total of US$332 million. The sale marked a significant milestone in Impressionist art, with more than 20 pieces selling for a combined US$332 million, including Caillebotte's 19th-century masterpiece of modern urban realism.

site_title: Tencent buys game studio behind hit Nintendo Switch titles: sources
summary: Tencent Holdings has acquired a 90% stake in Wake Up Interactive, a Japanese creative studio behind Nintendo Switch titles such as Ninjala and Travis Strikes Again: No More Heroes, for over $59.3 million. This deal is part of Tencent's talent acquisition spree in Japan, where it aims to secure valuable intellectual property in anime and video games. The acquisition is unusual for Tencent, which has made smaller investments in Japan and mainly focused on securing international publishing rights. The move is seen as a strategic move to diversify its revenue streams and reduce dependence on the Chinese market.

site_title: KPMG sued for US$600m over alleged sloppy auditing in Dubai's Abraaj scandal
summary: KPMG LLP has been sued for at least US$600 million over its alleged role in the insolvency of Dubai private-equity firm Abraaj Group. The lawsuit claims KPMG failed to maintain independence and professional skepticism while auditing the firm, leading to the identification of "irregularities" in its financial statements. This is the latest in a string of complaints against KPMG over poor auditing work, following a similar lawsuit filed by Malaysian authorities and 1MDB for their role in auditing the state investment fund.

site_title: Employers can opt to share SHN, Covid-19 test costs for transfer workers under new MOM guidelines
summary: Employers of non-Malaysian work permit holders being transferred to a new workplace can now share the costs of Stay-home Notices and related Covid-19 tests with subsequent employers. The Ministry of Manpower recommends employers bear costs proportionate to the worker's duration of employment within a 12-month period. Employers can also divide costs among themselves by mutual agreement, as long as they meet certain criteria, including a written agreement retained for a year. This allows for cost sharing within 12 months of the Stay-home Notice completion.

site_title: Gold set for best week in 6 months on inflation woes
summary: Gold prices rose on Friday, set for its biggest weekly gain in 6 months, amid high US consumer prices and inflation concerns. Spot gold was steady at $1,860.81 per ounce, with US gold futures edging down 0.1%. The metal's appeal as an inflation hedge has increased, driven by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike expectations. Silver, platinum, and palladium also saw gains, with platinum on track for its biggest weekly rise in a month.

site_title: AirAsia X receives over 90% support from creditors for debt restructure: source
summary: AirAsia X, a Malaysian long-haul airline, has received over 90% support from creditors for its debt restructuring proposal, according to a source. The airline needs at least 75% support from each class of creditors to proceed. Airbus has agreed to reduce AirAsia X's existing aircraft orders as part of the deal. The creditor agreement will allow the airline to start with a clean slate, betting that financials will improve as countries reopen borders to travel.

site_title: Biden, Xi to address Asia-Pacific leaders on trade, Covid recovery
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are set to address Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec meeting, amid heightened regional trade and geopolitical tensions. Xi warned the region against returning to Cold War-era tensions, while Biden will discuss the Covid-19 pandemic and global economic recovery. The meeting comes ahead of a virtual summit between the two leaders on November 15, as they aim to prevent growing tensions between the world's two biggest economies from escalating into conflict.

site_title: Golden Agri swings into the black with US$115m profit for Q3
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$115 million for its third quarter, reversing a net loss of US$5 million a year ago, driven by higher average selling prices and an increase in sales volume. Revenue rose 76% to US$2.83 billion and Ebitda increased 145% to US$305 million. The company's palm product output grew 5% and downstream sales volume increased 12% year-over-year. Net profit for the 9-month period was US$268 million, reversing a net loss of US$162 million in the same period in 2020.

site_title: SIA reports strong business travel demand on VTL flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reports strong demand for vaccinated travel lane (VTL) flights, particularly in premium cabins, driven by quarantine-free travel arrangements with various countries since September. The airline has seen a 7-fold increase in bookings for VTL flights, with new bookings for the next three months reaching 140,000. Despite EU recommendations, SIA remains optimistic, citing its "agile and nimble" response to border restrictions. The airline's hedging gains are attributed to managing fuel cost volatility, with gains of US$352 million locked in for future periods.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,242.24 at 9:01 am on Friday, November 12, driven by tech shares gaining on Wall Street overnight. Medtech firm QT Vascular was the top gainer, rising 20% to S$0.012 after 35.8 million shares traded. Meanwhile, European stocks closed at a record high, while Tokyo stocks opened higher following overnight US tech gains.

site_title: Vietnam looks to raise public debt ceiling to spur growth
summary: Vietnam is considering raising its public debt ceiling to 70% of GDP to stimulate growth amid a 6.17% contraction in the third quarter of 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic. Investment Minister Nguyen Chi Dung stated that not increasing the ceiling would limit resources for growth. This move comes as the country seeks to recover from the economic downturn caused by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore new private home sales rebound in October, up 8.3%
summary: Singapore's new private home sales rebounded in October, with 903 units sold, up 8.3% from September and 38.1% from October 2020. The near sell-out of Jervois Mansion and the absence of new executive condominiums boosted buying momentum. The top-selling project was Jervois Mansion, followed by Parc Greenwich. The most expensive transaction was a S$75 million penthouse unit at Les Maisons Nassim. The proportion of new sales priced at S$2 million and above increased to 39% in October, with the core central region accounting for 30.8% of the volume. Analysts predict a strong primary market in Q4 2021 due to the launch of new projects and potential delays in overseas travel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.09% at the open on Friday, driven by Alibaba's strong revenue report for its annual Singles Day shopping event in China. The Hang Seng Index rose to 25,522.83, while Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The gains were attributed to positive sentiment in the tech sector and traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares firm in early trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, Nov 12, 2021, following overnight gains in US technology shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.51% to 29,426.32 and the Topix index added 0.71% to 2,028.55.

site_title: Data breach at RedDoorz hit 6m customers; hospitality platform fined S$74,000
summary: A data breach at hospitality platform RedDoorz compromised 5.9 million customer records, including names, contact numbers, and booking information. The breach, discovered in September 2020, was caused by an Android application package (APK) containing an access key that was left unsecured. RedDoorz was fined S$74,000 by the Personal Data Protection Commission for failing to prevent the breach. The company has since amended its policies and upgraded its infrastructure to improve security.

site_title: Asia: Shares advance as inflation worries fade to background
summary: Asian share prices rose 0.7-1.1% on Friday, driven by a decline in inflation worries and strong US earnings. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index reached its highest level in two weeks, with Japan's Nikkei leading the gain. US stock futures were up 0.3% after a mixed session, while tech-heavy Nasdaq rose 0.52%. Investors are now hopeful that the worst price hikes could be over, with the S&P 500 ending 0.06% higher on Thursday.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink enters voluntary administration
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary Basslink has entered voluntary administration due to ongoing disputes with Hydro Tasmania and an unsuccessful sale process with APA. Ernst & Young has been appointed voluntary administrators for Basslink, which owns and operates a high-voltage direct current interconnector connecting Tasmania to the national electricity market. The move is expected to have a minimal impact on KIT's distribution per unit for the current financial year. Basslink's administration aims to effect change while protecting all stakeholders.

site_title: Biden, China's Xi expected to meet virtually on Monday: sources
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are expected to hold a virtual summit on Monday, amid tensions over trade, human rights, and military activities. The meeting aims to prevent a deterioration in the relationship between the world's two largest economies from spiraling toward conflict. Beijing is keen to focus on "positive competition" and cooperation on climate issues, while Washington seeks to address concerns on human rights and the pandemic. The virtual summit is seen as a direct engagement with Xi to prevent escalation.

site_title: Inflation is hurting 80% of British businesses: survey
summary: A survey by the British Chambers of Commerce found that 80% of UK businesses are experiencing higher prices and shortages, with 40% citing significant price increases. Rising costs of fuel, shipping, electricity, and natural gas are the main burdens. Steel costs were also cited by half of manufacturers. The findings add to concerns about inflation, which may lead to higher interest rates. The survey's director general described the picture as "deeply worrying" for businesses.

site_title: Insurer AIA's third-quarter new business value rebounds from pandemic slump
summary: Asia-focused insurer AIA Group reported a 4% increase in its quarterly value of new business (VONB) to US$735 million in the third quarter, rebounding from the pandemic slump. The Hong Kong-based insurer's VONB rose due to strong growth in its mainland China business, while its Hong Kong business also showed "strong" growth. China and Hong Kong, which account for half of the company's VONB globally, contributed to the recovery. AIA warned of disruption from pandemic restrictions and increased claims in some markets.

site_title: Alibaba's Singles Day sales grow just 8.5%, slowest pace ever
summary: Alibaba's Singles Day sales grew 8.5% to 540.3 billion yuan (S$114.4 billion), the slowest pace ever, due to strong regulatory and supply chain headwinds in China. The event, which Alibaba once aggressively promoted, saw a muted version of sales, with analysts expecting only minor growth. The e-commerce giant played down its sales figures and focused on social welfare initiatives, shifting its tone amid regulatory tightening from Chinese authorities. Despite this, the event remains a top draw for merchants and shoppers, with nearly 400 brands generating over US$15 million in sales each.

site_title: Toshiba set to announce split into 3 firms, shareholder reaction in focus: sources
summary: Toshiba plans to split into three listed companies: one focused on infrastructure, one on devices, and one on memory chips. The move aims to improve shareholder value and encourage activist shareholders to exit. The review, following a corporate governance scandal, calls for a nuclear power and infrastructure-related division to be housed under one company, while power chips and hard disk drive divisions would form the backbone of another. The third company will own Toshiba's 40.6% stake in unlisted memory chipmaker Kioxia. Shareholder reaction is mixed, with some investors skeptical that the break-up would create value.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.69 points, or 0.2%, to 1,521.54 at 9:15 am on Friday, November 12, 2021. Volume was 101.9 million lots worth RM40.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 141 to 71.

site_title: Oil bounces around, settles up despite strong dollar, near US$83/barrel
summary: Oil prices settled slightly higher on Thursday, with Brent crude futures rising to $82.87 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures reaching $81.59 a barrel. The increase came despite a stronger US dollar and concerns over increasing US inflation. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) cut its 2021 oil demand forecast due to high prices, citing a slowdown in the pace of recovery in the fourth quarter of 2021.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SATS, Frasers Property, Keppel Infra Trust, Golden Agri, Sasseur Reit, SIA, Singtel
summary: Key stocks to watch on Friday include SATS, which reported a H1 FY2021-2022 profit of S$13.2 million, reversing a year-ago loss of S$76.9 million. Frasers Property reversed into the black for the second half of the fiscal year, driven by strong contributions from industrial and logistics. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Australian subsidiary Basslink has entered voluntary administration. Golden Agri-Resources reversed into the black in its third quarter, driven by higher average selling prices and sales volume.

site_title: Frasers Property back in the black for H2; capital, liquidity management remain top priorities: CEO
summary: Frasers Property, a global property developer, has swung back into the black for the second half of its fiscal year with a net profit of S$528.4 million, driven by stronger contributions from its industrial and logistics segments. The company's CEO, Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, emphasized the importance of capital and liquidity management as the sector faces uncertainties due to the pandemic. Frasers Property plans to focus on investment discipline, portfolio value enhancements, and proactive capital structure optimization to remain agile and well-positioned for growth.

site_title: Sasseur Reit Q3 DPU rises 3.8% to S$0.01831
summary: Sasseur Reit, a real estate investment trust, reported a 3.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01831 for the third quarter ended Sep 30, driven by lower interest expenses and a favourable exchange rate. Rental income rose 3.9% to S$31.4 million, and distributable income increased 9.4% to S$23.2 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rate rose to 93.7% and total sales grew 12% quarter-over-quarter.

site_title: Brazil clears GMO wheat flour from Argentina in global first, but sales may be slow
summary: Brazil has become the first country to allow imports of genetically modified (GMO) wheat flour, a decision made by its biosecurity agency CTNBio. The approval applies only to wheat flour, but opposition from Brazilian millers and global consumers is expected to slow sales. The move may lead to a broader global discussion about GMO wheat, with prices rising and concerns about severe weather threatening food security. The decision was met with resistance from Argentine grains exporters, who threaten to boycott Brazilian imports if the GMO wheat is sold.

site_title: Sembcorp to acquire 658MW of wind, solar assets in China for 3.3b yuan
summary: Sembcorp Industries has agreed to acquire 98% interest in a 658MW wind and solar portfolio in China for 3.3 billion yuan (S$700 million). The assets, located in Hebei, Henan, and Shandong provinces, will double Sembcorp's renewables portfolio in China to 1,400MW. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first half of 2022, subject to regulatory approvals, and is not expected to have a material impact on Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset value.

site_title: The legendary Black Bay
summary: The Tudor Black Bay watch celebrates 60 years of diving watches with its iconic design, including a domed dial, "big crown" and angular "snowflake" hands. Launched in 2012, it features a high-performance mechanical movement with a 70-hour power reserve and is certified by the Swiss Official Chronometer Testing Institute. The watch is available in three variants, each with its own unique personality, and is powered by the MT5602 movement. The Black Bay's stainless steel case is waterproof to 200m and features a signature Jacquard leather strap made in traditional French methods.

site_title: Elon Musk sells US$5b in Tesla shares after Twitter poll
summary: Elon Musk sold approximately $5 billion in Tesla shares, including nearly 3.6 million shares worth $4 billion and another 934,000 shares worth $1.1 billion, following a Twitter poll on selling 10% of his stake. The sales helped recover Tesla's stock price after a 12% drop on Tuesday. The move, which equates to about 3% of Musk's total Tesla holdings, may have a minimal impact on the company's outlook, with retail investors continuing to buy the stock.

site_title: Dollar jumps to 16-month highs on hot US inflation data
summary: The US dollar surged to 16-month highs against the euro and other currencies due to hot US inflation data, with the euro falling to its lowest level since July 2020. The dollar's rise is attributed to traders' expectations of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, which may surpass those in Europe and Japan. This led to a decline in other major currencies, including sterling and the yen, with the yen falling close to its 4-year low.

site_title: Hot stock: VCPlus shares jump 14.3% on plans to raise funds via security token offering
summary: VCPlus shares jumped 14.3% on Friday after announcing plans to raise funds via a security token offering in Singapore. The company's counter rose to a high of S$0.024, up S$0.003, before closing flat at S$0.021 after 128.3 million shares changed hands. This follows an announcement on Thursday that VCPlus was chosen as the blockchain adviser for a security token project between Tree Roots Entertainment and ECXX Global in Singapore.

site_title: A few cheers for the American economy
summary: The US economy is experiencing a boost, with rising wages and a potential infrastructure spending spree. However, policy trade-offs are expected. This positive trend is attributed to the country's affluent urban consumers, who prioritize organic and high-end products, resulting in a smoother shopping experience at Whole Foods.

site_title: Spotify expands in audiobooks with purchase of Findaway
summary: Spotify has agreed to acquire Findaway, an audiobook company, expanding its offerings beyond music and podcasts. The deal will allow Spotify to sell individual audiobooks to its nearly 400 million users, with authors and publishers sharing revenue. Findaway will maintain its headquarters and continue to serve its existing clients. The purchase marks Spotify's most significant investment in audiobooks, aiming to become the default service for audio content. The deal is expected to close this year, with Spotify planning to add more audiobooks to its service.

images.alt_text: Spotify Technology agreed to acquire Findaway, an audiobook company that gives the Swedish streaming giant additional products to market alongside music and podcasts.

site_title: Non-Swiss brands win big at watch Oscars
summary: Non-Swiss brands won two of the top three awards at the 2021 Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Genève, including Grand Seiko of Japan's Men's Watch Prize and Bulgari's Ladies' Watch Prize. Despite Swiss brands dominating the competition, the event marked a step towards international recognition, with Grand Seiko's win being its third GPHG award. Bulgari's Octo Finissimo watch was praised for its innovative design and precision.

images.alt_text: (From left) Winner of GPHG _Aiguille d'Or_ Grand Prix - Bulgari's Octo Finissimo; Winner of GPHG Ladies' Watch Category - Piaget's Limelight Gala Precious Rainbow; Winner of GPHG Men's Watch Category - Grand Seiko's Hi-Beat 36000 80 Hours Caliber 9SA5.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark new highs as mining stocks rally
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 closed at a new peak of 485.29 points, up 0.3% on Thursday, driven by relief around China's Evergrande Group and strong earnings season. Mining stocks rallied 3.7% in their best day in 4 months, with diversified miner Anglo American PLC and BHP Group jumping 5.9% and 3.9% respectively. Despite concerns over rising global inflation, higher commodity prices boosted the broader mining sector. Profits of Stoxx 600 companies are expected to jump 60.7% in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: European stocks ended at a record high on Thursday (Nov 11) after relief around property developer China Evergrande benefited China-focussed mining stocks, while a strong earnings season buoyed broader sentiment.

site_title: The chip that could transform computing
summary: Apple's new custom-designed processors, the M1 Pro and M1 Max, have revolutionized laptop performance, rivaling those of high-end desktops. The chips, built for power efficiency rather than raw speed, have been a game-changer, with experts predicting a future saturated with computing power in various devices. This innovation has disrupted Intel's dominance, with the company investing heavily to catch up. The M1 chips' success has also sparked a new chip-making race, with other manufacturers like Samsung and TSMC investing billions to increase capacity.

site_title: Biden pushes tax breaks for electric vehicles
summary: US President Joe Biden will visit a Michigan General Motors electric vehicle plant on November 17, as the White House pushes for tax incentives for zero-emission vehicles. The visit comes as Biden discusses $7.5 billion in funding for EV charging stations and the benefits of EVs in reducing emissions and creating jobs. A proposed social spending and climate bill includes an EV tax credit of up to $12,500, with some provisions sparking opposition from Democratic Senator Joe Manchin.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden will visit a Michigan General Motors electric vehicle plant next week as the White House pushes Congress to approve big tax incentives for zero-emission vehicles.

site_title: No takers for Malaysia's 5G plan as major telcos balk over pricing, transparency
summary: Malaysia's major mobile carriers have refused to use the government's 5G network due to concerns over pricing and transparency. Despite a planned rollout in three urban centers, state-owned Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB) hopes to launch 5G services in 3 urban areas. Industry executives and carriers have expressed concerns that the single shared network could result in a nationalized monopoly, hurting their business and limiting access to future technology.

site_title: US: S&P closes little changed as chips boost Nasdaq in subdued holiday trading
summary: The S&P 500 closed little changed on Thursday, with chipmakers driving the Nasdaq higher. The session was subdued due to the holiday trading period and lack of economic data. Walt Disney fell after a disappointing earnings report, while the Dow declined. The bond market was closed in observance of Veterans Day. Despite some fluctuations, the Nasdaq edged closer to a record high.

site_title: Of good schools and level playing fields
summary: Singapore's primary school registration rules prioritize proximity to schools over alumni links, potentially widening the gap between the haves and have-nots. This trend exacerbates existing issues with higher home prices near desirable schools.

site_title: Goldman readies US$30b for alternative investments in Asia
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to invest at least $30 billion in Asian alternative assets over the next five years, doubling its current investments to $60 billion. The bank aims to overtake rivals like KKR & Co and Blackstone by betting on technology startups, real estate, consumer, and renewable energy. However, challenges arise from cashed-up rivals bidding up valuations and China's crackdowns.

site_title: Brands rake in millions at Alibaba's toned-down Singles' Day event
summary: Alibaba's toned-down Singles' Day event saw nearly 400 brands, including Apple and L'Oreal, rake in over $15 million in sales each. The e-commerce giant prioritized sustainable growth over real-time sales data, citing regulatory scrutiny. Despite the toned-down marketing hype, the event remains a top draw for merchants and shoppers, with sales reaching $15.7 billion. JD.com also reported $65.9 billion in sales during the same period, with Alibaba's focus on quality growth amid regulatory tightening.

site_title: PM Lee urges Apec to help firms embrace digital trade
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) bloc to extend its scope to cover the digital economy, warning that smaller companies risk falling behind the rest of the world. Lee emphasized the need for countries to invest in digital frameworks and identify common development goals for global cooperation.

site_title: Watch the countdown to Christmas on Orchard Road
summary: Tudor, a Swiss luxury watch brand, is celebrating the year-end festive season in Singapore with a large-scale countdown display on Orchard Road, dubbed "Christmas on a Great Street 2021". The project features festive glass panels, projection mapping displays, and a countdown sequence on the Mandarin Orchard Hotel's facade, accompanied by local singer Yung Raj. The event aims to spread festive cheer and is seen as a marketing push to draw shoppers to Orchard Road, with Tudor showcasing its iconic Black Bay watches and partnering with The Hour Glass and the Orchard Road Business Association.

site_title: Performance reviews need a brand new P&L
summary: Performance reviews are in need of an overhaul, with a 2019 Gallup poll showing only 14% of employees are inspired by their reviews. Companies can balance performance reviews by incorporating complementary criteria, such as legacy, latitude/altitude, lifestyle, and leverage. This approach, exemplified by Google's bi-annual performance cycles, considers the individual's personal values and needs, and can help identify alignment and talent retention. By incorporating these criteria, companies can create a more holistic evaluation process that fosters growth and well-being, rather than solely focusing on business performance.

site_title: Japan's wholesale inflation hits 40-year high as fuel costs spike
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation surged to a 40-year high in October, reaching 8% year-over-year, driven by supply bottlenecks, rising commodity costs, and a weak yen. Fuel costs spiked 44.5% and timber goods prices rose 57%. The Bank of Japan data exceeded market expectations, adding to concerns for the world's third-largest economy. Corporate profits may be negatively impacted, but some firms plan to pass on costs to consumers. This inflationary pressure is part of a global trend, with China's factory gate inflation hitting a 26-year high and the US seeing its biggest consumer price rise in 31 years.

site_title: UK house prices soar again, fuelled by dearth of sellers: survey
summary: UK house prices rose again, driven by a shortage of sellers, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey. A net balance of 70% of members reported an increase in house prices in October, up from 69% in September. This marks the first increase in the house price balance since May. The lack of supply, coupled with the expiration of the year-long stamp duty tax exemption, is expected to lead to further price rises, with the RICS chief economist attributing the trend to "historic lows" in inventory.

site_title: If you sell 'Oaxaca in a bottle', what happens to Oaxaca?
summary: Mexico's mezcal production has surged, with over $413 million worth produced last year, a 17% increase from 2019. The drink's international popularity is driven by its authenticity, with many consumers seeking out traditional, small-batch producers. However, this surge has also led to concerns about the drink's sudden popularity and the homogenization of its unique flavors. Investors, including celebrities like George Clooney and LeBron James, are backing mezcal startups, but some producers, like Bricia Lopez, worry that the industry's focus on "discovering" the spirit is eroding its authenticity.

site_title: Cutting emissions isn't enough; the world needs to move to a circular economy
summary: COP26, the delayed United Nations climate summit, has seen governments, corporations, and community groups pledge to cut greenhouse gas emissions, but experts argue that a circular economy model is needed for a more complete transformation. A circular economy aims to reduce waste and re-use resources, moving away from the traditional "take-make-waste" model. While emissions cuts are a step in the right direction, a more significant shift in the economy is required to address the climate crisis. The summit's outcome highlights the need for a more holistic approach to reducing global warming.

site_title: Prime public housing model may include areas beyond waterfront, city centre: Indranee
summary: Singapore's new prime location public housing (PLH) model will initially focus on areas like the Greater Southern Waterfront, city centre, and surrounding HDB estates, which are easily recognizable as prime locations. The government aims to make public housing affordable, accessible, and inclusive for Singaporeans. Under the new model, public rental flats will be built in these areas, and owners will be required to occupy the flats for at least 10 years before selling, with subsidies clawed back by the government. This approach aims to reduce speculative buying and promote home ownership.

site_title: Goldman launches 3 more thematic ETFs as it bets on disruption
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched three new actively managed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to profit from companies that will disrupt industries. The funds focus on future consumer, healthcare, and real estate and infrastructure, with each charging a 0.75 percentage point expense ratio. The move aims to help clients position their portfolios on the right side of disruption, with the goal of generating higher returns. The launch follows the introduction of two other ETFs this year targeting disruption in tech and planet-focused sectors.

site_title: Didi prepares to relaunch apps in China: sources
summary: Didi Chuxing is preparing to relaunch its ride-hailing and other apps in China by the end of the year, anticipating a resolution to a cybersecurity investigation by the Cyberspace Administration of China. The company has set aside 10 billion yuan (S$2.1 billion) for a potential fine. Didi had previously stopped registering new users and made changes to its apps to comply with China's Personal Information Protection Law. The relaunch is expected to address issues stemming from the company's New York listing and its collection of personal data.

site_title: Can the march to gender equality survive the pandemic?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the gender equality issue in Singapore, with women disproportionately affected in the workforce. Despite equal opportunities in education and careers, women occupy only 30% of senior management roles and 17.6% of board positions. Changing mindsets and cultural norms are key to progress, but putting pejorative labels on differences deepens the divide. The community must work to scrub out unconscious sexist biases and unseat long-held gender stereotypes, rather than relying on government and business initiatives alone.

site_title: All ECB bond purchases could end by next September: official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may end its bond purchase program as early as September if inflation returns to its target of 2%, according to Governing Council member Robert Holzmann. The program, introduced in 2015, aims to achieve this inflation goal. Holzmann opposes changes to the program, citing low lending effects, and expects price growth to stay above 2% in 2022. This would be sooner than anticipated by economists, who foresee the program staying in operation until at least 2023.

site_title: SATS posts H1 FY2021-22 profit of S$13.2m on higher cargo volume, ship calls
summary: SATS reported a H1 FY2021-22 profit of S$13.2 million, reversing a loss of S$76.9 million in the previous year. Revenue grew 29.3% to S$569.5 million, driven by higher cargo volume, non-travel revenue, and resumption of ship calls. Gateway services revenue jumped 61.4% and food solutions revenue increased 12.6%. The company's operating profit was S$4 million, up from an operating loss of S$36 million.

site_title: Huge Kaws sculpture 'sun-bathing' in Marina
summary: A 42-metre Kaws sculpture, "Companion" holding a miniature version of itself, has been installed at The Float @ Marina Bay in Singapore as part of the artist's Holiday project. This is the seventh installation, made possible with support from the Singapore Tourism Board and AllRightsReserved. Kaws aims to make his artwork accessible to the public, and the location offers a unique urban context. Limited-edition merchandise will be available online, and the installation will run from Nov 13 to 21, with free admission.

site_title: Evergrande dodges default again but sector debt concerns remain
summary: China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted developer, avoided a default for the third time in a month after several bondholders received overdue coupon payments. The payments were made at the end of a 30-day grace period, averting a formal default that could have triggered a debt crisis. Despite this near-term fix, concerns about the sector's debt remain, with Evergrande facing over $300 billion in liabilities and other cash-strapped developers, such as Kaisa Group, facing short-term debt obligations.

site_title: Might VTL countries tighten curbs on arrivals from Singapore?
summary: Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) countries may tighten restrictions on arrivals from Singapore after the European Union removed the country from its whitelist. Currently, fully vaccinated travelers from Singapore can enter these countries without quarantine. However, this may not be the case for all VTL countries, and the decision to impose restrictions will depend on individual country policies. Denmark has already introduced a quarantine requirement for travelers from Singapore.

site_title: Best World Intl posts 11.1% decline in Q3 profit; mulling over a delisting
summary: Best World Intl reported a 11.1% year-on-year decline in Q3 profit to S$25.1 million, driven by lower revenue from its direct selling segment. The company attributed the decline to the effects of second pandemic waves in key markets, including Taiwan and Malaysia. Shares are suspended from trading, and Best World is considering a delisting due to regulatory concerns and the need for external financing. The company will explore options to provide liquidity to shareholders, including an off-market share buyback scheme.

site_title: Singapore's Q Investment Partners gets set for Japan housing foray
summary: Singapore-based private equity real estate firm Q Investment Partners (QIP) plans to enter Japan's residential market next year, focusing on multi-family housing and student accommodation. The firm aims to double down on its existing markets of UK purpose-built student accommodation and US co-living properties. QIP's CEO, Peter Young, made the announcement, marking the company's expansion into the Japanese market.

site_title: Apec charts the pathway from pandemic
summary: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) leadership session, chaired by New Zealand, will focus on charting a path to recovery from the pandemic, the biggest economic and political shock since World War II. The meeting, attended by US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, aims to promote an inclusive, sustainable, and resilient recovery amidst new waves of infections. After preliminary Apec meetings, progress has been made, and the session will seek to address the economic and health impacts of the pandemic on the 3 billion population of the Pacific rim.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound with consumer prices in focus
summary: US stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, rebounding from the previous day's slump, as investors assessed the impact of higher-than-expected consumer prices on inflation and monetary policy. The S&P 500 and European Stoxx 600 Index rose, while Chinese equities rallied on speculation of government measures to ease the cash crunch. Investors are bracing for tighter monetary policy, with the European Central Bank potentially stopping bond purchases as early as next September if inflation returns to target.

site_title: Frencken Q3 earnings up 10.7% as revenue rises
summary: Frencken Group reported a 10.7% year-on-year increase in earnings to S$14.77 million in Q3, driven by 18.7% revenue growth to S$196.46 million. Gross profit rose 15% to S$33.5 million, despite a half-point decrease in gross profit margin due to higher material and freight costs. The company expects stable revenue in H2 2021, with stable revenue in its semiconductor segment and growth in its medical and analytical segments.

site_title: Embroiled in 'Sleazegate', Johnson's government at risk of losing next UK general election
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government is at risk of losing the next UK general election due to the mounting "Sleazegate" scandal, with a new poll showing 55% of respondents believe he is a poor leader. The scandal involves lawmakers getting paid for external jobs, with some earning £82,000 a year plus living allowances and expense claims. The UK's economic growth is sliding, inflation is accelerating, and Covid-19 cases are rising, further eroding public trust in Johnson's government.

site_title: Waste not, want not
summary: A new exhibition, "The Waste Refinery," showcases designers transforming waste into useful items, challenging the perception of waste as unwanted material. The exhibition features upcycled products, art pieces, and designs made from waste materials such as recycled plastic, industrial residues, and seashells. The aim is to inspire a mindset change towards sustainability and encourage people to see waste as a resource, rather than something to be discarded. The exhibition runs until January 16, 2022, at the National Design Centre in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore reports 2,396 new Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate at 0.87
summary: Singapore reported 2,396 new Covid-19 cases on November 11, down from 3,481 the previous day, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.87. This marks the ninth consecutive day the rate has been below 1. Eight people aged 74-100 died of Covid-19 complications, bringing the total fatalities to 548. The new cases included 2,243 community cases, 136 in migrant worker dormitories, and 17 imported cases.

site_title: Philippines 'First Daughter' joins new party ahead of presidential poll cutoff
summary: Philippines' "First Daughter" Sara Duterte joined the Lakas-Christian Muslim Democrats party, fuelling speculation she will run for president in the upcoming election. Her sudden withdrawal from the mayoral contest and desire to give her supporters what they want have led to speculation that she will succeed her father, President Rodrigo Duterte. Sara Duterte would join a crowded field of candidates, including her father's son and namesake, Manny Pacquiao, and Vice-President Leni Robredo. Analysts expect she will be a more moderate version of her father, with the potential to protect him from criminal charges.

site_title: Grab's Q3 net loss widens to almost US$1 billion, revenue slips ahead of US listing as pandemic hits ride-hailing
summary: Grab's Q3 net loss widened to almost US$1 billion due to a 9% revenue drop to US$157 million, largely attributed to the impact of pandemic restrictions on its ride-hailing business. Despite a 32% growth in gross merchandise value (GMV), the company's adjusted Ebitda loss deepened 66% to US$212 million. However, deliveries showed strong revenue growth, with a 58% increase to US$49 million. Grab remains cautious, with a focus on investments to capture a greater share of emerging opportunities, particularly in the grocery delivery market.

site_title: Opec cuts world oil demand forecast
summary: Opec has cut its world oil demand forecast for the last quarter of 2021, citing high energy prices that are delaying the recovery from Covid-19. The forecast now expects oil demand to average 99.49 million barrels per day in the fourth quarter, down 330,000 barrels per day from the previous forecast. The year's demand growth forecast was also trimmed by 160,000 barrels per day to 5.65 million barrels per day. This move may pose a challenge to Opec's efforts to balance the market, as it also raised its supply forecast from US shale producers next year.

site_title: Holiday house hunting
summary: Singaporeans are investing in holiday homes, particularly resort properties in the mountains and by the coast, as a result of the pandemic. Developers report high demand for such properties, with 95% of units in Andermatt Swiss Alps' Koya collection reserved within two weeks of launch. The pandemic has led to a shift in buyers' priorities, with a focus on outdoor activities, proximity to nature, and wellness. Beach resorts in Tioman Island and Lombok are also gaining popularity, with luxury developers like Selo Group and Finns Lifestyle Village seeing strong interest from Singaporean buyers.

site_title: European stock market rally is far from over, says Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a 13% total return for the Stoxx Europe 600 Index in 2022, driven by low interest rates, resilient earnings recovery, and cheap valuations. Despite record highs, European equities are undervalued compared to the US market, with a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 16. The strategist recommends a "barbell" strategy, focusing on cyclical industries like banks, energy, and industrials, while favouring healthcare as a defensive play. This would bring the Stoxx Europe 600 to a target price of 530 by the end of 2022.

site_title: Old Chang Kee posts net profit decline of 45.1% on scaling back of foreign worker packed meals
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Catalist-listed food retailer, reported a 45.1% decline in net profit to S$3.4 million for the first half of its financial year ended Sep 30, 2021. The decline was mainly due to the absence of economies of scale savings from catering meals for foreign workers. Revenue remained steady at S$38.5 million, with retail outlet revenue increasing by 28.4% and non-outlet sales declining. The company has diversified into meal kit home deliveries and plans to reduce operating costs and improve operational efficiencies.

site_title: Zillow agrees to sell 2,000 homes to Pretium as flipping business ends
summary: Zillow agrees to sell approximately 2,000 homes to Pretium Partners, marking the end of the company's home-flipping business. The deal comes after Zillow's tech-powered flipping operation failed to achieve its ambitious goals, resulting in a potential writedown of up to $569 million and a 25% workforce reduction. Pretium, the second-largest single-family landlord in the US, will purchase the homes at a time when rents on single-family properties are surging.

images.alt_text: The decision to abandon home-flipping come as Zillow's Q3 results show it lost more than US$380 million in the operation, called Zillow Offers.

site_title: Regional rebound could boost Singtel's FY2022 dividends by 20%; analysts mixed on its Singapore mobile prospects
summary: Singtel's net profit grew 104.7% year-over-year to S$954 million in the first half, driven by a rebound in associate Bharti Airtel's profits. The company's underlying net profit rose 17% to S$983 million. Analysts predict a 20% increase in full-year dividends, with DBS analyst Sachin Mittal estimating a 76% payout ratio. However, Citi analyst Arthur Pineda notes that Singtel is comfortably positioned to pay at the top range of its guidance, allowing for a 4-5% yield.

site_title: Burberry to expand new store format to gain higher-spending clients
summary: Burberry shares fell 10% as the company's plan to shift to a higher-spending client base lost momentum. The UK trenchcoat maker reported a slowdown in full-priced sales growth to 10% in the 3 months to September. Burberry aims to exit markdowns by the end of its fiscal year in March, but the delay dashes hopes of a turnaround before new CEO Jonathan Akeroyd's arrival in April.

site_title: Life insurance sales in Singapore up 38% in first 9 months of 2021
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 38% increase in weighted new business premiums to S$4.11 billion in the first 9 months of 2021, with single-premium products accounting for 84% of sales. New policies purchased online rose 207% to 371,000, while integrated shield plans covered 25,000 more Singaporeans and Permanent Residents. Total in-force annual premiums for group insurance increased by 21% to S$1.79 billion.

site_title: Denmark imposes quarantine for travellers from Singapore
summary: Denmark has imposed a quarantine requirement for travelers from Singapore, with a minimum stay of four days, due to Singapore being considered a high-risk country for travel to Europe. This decision was made despite Singapore's Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme, which allows for quarantine-free travel to Singapore. The Danish Embassy stated that Singapore's vaccination certificate is not recognized in Denmark, leading to this quarantine requirement.

site_title: UK economy grows less than forecast, consumer spending shows signs of weakening
summary: The UK economy grew 1.3% in the third quarter, below the Bank of England's forecast of 1.5%. Consumer spending showed signs of weakening due to accelerating inflation eroding living standards. A December interest rate hike is now uncertain, with policymakers waiting for Labour market data to assess the impact of furloughed workers' wage cuts on inflation. Economists warn of a tougher recovery phase due to supply chain disruptions and inflation, which may slow the economy in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Indonesian Islamic body forbids crypto as currency
summary: The Indonesian Ulema Council (MUI) has ruled that using cryptocurrencies as a means of payment is unlawful in Islam due to elements of uncertainty and harm. However, trading of digital assets is allowed in the commodities and futures market, with over 6.5 million traders and a total value of $35.1 billion in cryptocurrency trading this year. The MUI also allows trading of cryptocurrencies that meet Islamic rules, including those with an underlying asset and clear benefits. The decree, not legally binding, may influence investment decisions among some Muslims.

site_title: Halcyon Agri sees 22 % fall in Q3 Ebitda despite surge in revenue
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a 21.8% decline in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) to US$9.7 million in Q3 2021, despite a 51.9% surge in revenue to US$602.1 million. The company attributed the revenue growth to robust downstream demand, higher average selling prices, and improved sales volume. However, the Ebitda decline was primarily due to lower margins at its tyre grade rubber division. Shares fell 2% following the business update.

site_title: Top China chipmaker SMIC's vice-chairman leaves abruptly
summary: SMIC's vice-chairman Chiang Shang-Yi resigned abruptly, citing a desire to spend more time with his family. This departure follows the resignation of chairman Zhou Zixue in September and comes after co-CEO Liang Mong Song threatened to quit in 2020. SMIC reported a 31% revenue increase to $1.42 billion in the 3 months ending in September, beating analyst forecasts. The company is expanding its capacity to satisfy China's demand for home-made chips, but faces challenges in acquiring key machinery from overseas suppliers due to US sanctions.

site_title: Elon Musk sells US$5 billion of Tesla stock
summary: Elon Musk sold approximately $5 billion of Tesla stock, largely due to a Twitter poll where he asked if he should sell 10% of his stake. The poll resulted in a majority vote for his sale, causing Tesla shares to decline 16% in the first two days of the week. Musk had previously exercised equity options, which also led to a $1.1 billion sale. The sales were made in two tranches, with the majority occurring after the Twitter poll.

site_title: Malaysia's healthcare expenditure to 'increase considerably' in short term despite reforms: report
summary: Malaysia's public healthcare expenditure is expected to increase significantly in the short term, reaching RM 69.2 billion (S$22.4 billion) this year, with a 5-year compound annual growth rate of 7.6% in local currency terms. Despite government reforms aiming to secure financial sustainability, analysts from Fitch Solutions express skepticism about the progress of these reforms and the funding structure of the healthcare system. They predict that cost-containment measures will be introduced to maintain sustainable levels of funding, potentially hindering drugmaker revenue earning opportunities.

site_title: China's 'Single's Day' shopping fest subdued by tech crackdown
summary: China's annual "Single's Day" shopping festival saw subdued sales and a lower profile this year due to a government crackdown on e-commerce platforms, particularly those operated by Alibaba. The event, which normally boasts aggressive promotions and breathless hourly updates, was marked by a lack of rolling sales figures and triumphant comments from executives. The government's scrutiny of online giants for alleged abuse of user data and monopolistic business practices has led to a shift towards a more consumer-driven economy, with "Single's Day" sales figures potentially becoming less of a benchmark for the country's economy.

site_title: China ruling party leaders pass historic Xi resolution
summary: China's ruling Communist Party leaders passed a historic resolution on the country's past, cementing President Xi Jinping's grip on power.
