The resolution, passed by 350 members of the Central Committee, praises Xi's leadership and vision, and is seen as a key step towards his potential third term in office. The document downplays the violence of the Cultural Revolution and emphasizes Xi's role in shaping China's future, with analysts predicting an even greater taboo on criticism of his rule. The move is expected to solidify Xi's position as China's most powerful leader since Mao Zedong.

images.alt_text: Analysts say the resolution will help Xi shore up his grip on power by setting in stone his vision.

site_title: Global luxury sales set to outpace pre-Covid levels this year, Bain says
summary: Global luxury sales are projected to surpass pre-Covid levels this year, with Bain estimating a 4% increase to 283 billion euros (S$439.5 billion). The US and China drive the growth, with US sales boosted by early vaccination campaigns and local consumption, while China's strong demand despite lockdowns in some areas. European sales are still recovering, expected to reach pre-Covid levels by 2024. Luxury brands have attracted new customers through domestic marketing and online campaigns, with 60% of luxury purchases expected to be made by those under 40 by 2025.

site_title: Trans-China Automotive ends first day trading at 6.5% above IPO price
summary: Trans-China Automotive Holdings (TCA) listed on the Catalist board in Singapore, with its shares opening at S$0.245 and ending the first day at S$0.245, 6.5% above its IPO price of S$0.23. The company's market capitalization is approximately S$134.4 million, and it plans to use most of its S$16.3 million net proceeds from the IPO to expand its dealerships and service centers in China, driven by the country's growing affluence and robust economic performance.

site_title: Singapore trusts market growing, but governance standards stagnating: 2021 index
summary: A Singapore-listed trusts index, Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT), found that the market has grown, but governance standards have stagnated or declined. The index, produced by Mak Yuen Teen and Chew Yi Hong, examined 45 listed trusts and found that corporate governance and business-risk performance have not improved. This is the fifth edition of the GIFT, which aims to promote better governance standards in the Reits sector. The findings highlight a need for improvement in the governance of Singapore-listed trusts.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q3 Patmi up over 19%
summary: ComfortDelGro reported a Q3 profit after tax and minority interests (PATMI) of S$25.8 million, up 19.4% year-on-year, driven by 7.4% higher revenue. Public transport services revenue rose 10.3% to S$710.6 million, while operating profit declined 8% to S$40.3 million due to higher costs. Government relief fell 55% to S$19.8 million. The company's shares closed at S$1.56, shedding 3.11%.

site_title: Winning trio of MAS' retail CBDC competition unveiled
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced the winners of its Global CBDC Challenge, a competition to develop central bank digital currencies (CBDCs). Three winners were selected: Giesecke+Devrient advance52, CBDCgo, and Atomic CBDC Solution. These solutions aim to enable secure, private, and transparent transactions using smartphones and blockchain technology. The winners received S$50,000 in cash and will help inform the development of a retail CBDC system in Singapore. The MAS will now embark on Project Orchid to establish the technology infrastructure and capabilities to build a retail CBDC system.

site_title: South Africa's de Klerk dies
summary: South Africa's former President FW de Klerk, who played a pivotal role in dismantling apartheid, has died at 85. De Klerk, a key figure in the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe, initially served as a servant of apartheid but later became its wrecking ball. He shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Nelson Mandela in 1993 and negotiated a peaceful transition to democracy. Despite facing criticism from many blacks and right-wing Afrikaners, de Klerk's legacy is marked by a historic shift towards non-racial democracy in South Africa, paving the way for Mandela's presidency in 1994.

site_title: World past tipping point of renewable energy transformation, says Tesla's Denholm
summary: The world has surpassed the tipping point for a renewable energy transformation, according to Tesla's chair, Robyn Denholm. In her keynote address, Denholm emphasized the need to accelerate the deployment of renewable energy technologies at an incredible pace. Tesla aims to produce 20 million electric vehicles annually by 2030 and plans to expand into new markets. This marks a significant shift in the global energy landscape, with Denholm urging the need for swift action to meet the renewable energy transformation.

site_title: SIA cuts Q2 loss to S$428m as VTLs help double revenue to S$1.5b; H1 cash burn down to just $106m
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a smaller net loss of S$427.6 million for the second quarter to September, thanks to a surge in passenger traffic amid the launch of vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs). Revenue doubled to S$1.5 billion, while cash burn rate narrowed to S$106 million for the first half of FY2022. The carrier's fuel hedging trades also generated gains, offsetting higher fuel costs. SIA expects passenger capacity to reach 43% of pre-pandemic levels by December.

images.alt_text: SIA's cash burn rate has narrowed to S$106 million in the first half of FY 2022 as operating performance improved, down from S$1.7 billion in H1 FY2021.

site_title: Boustead Projects back in the black on resumption of E&C projects
summary: Boustead Projects has posted a net profit of S$5.9 million for the first half of its financial year, reversing a S$2.2 million loss in the same period last year. Revenue surged 104% to S$179.1 million, driven by normalised revenue recognition on Engineering & Construction (E&C) projects. E&C revenues rose 144% to S$172.8 million. The company expects the E&C business segment to progressively improve as it completes pre-pandemic projects and sees better business development opportunities.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts remain optimistic of PropNex after its Q3 results
summary: Analysts at UOB Kay Hian, DBS Group Research, and CGS-CIMB have maintained their positive outlook on PropNex's prospects after the company's Q3 2021 financial results. UOB Kay Hian raised its target price to S$2.17, while DBS maintained its "hold" call with a target price of S$1.84. The analysts attribute the upgrades to PropNex's strong momentum in the Singapore property market and its high cash pile. However, DBS warned that property cooling measures could impact the company's earnings.

images.alt_text: UOBKH believes that PropNex's S$4.4 billion worth of en bloc projects at hand could add S$13 million to S$18 million to the company's earnings over the next 12 to 18 months, assuming a 0.3 to 0.4 per cent commission.

site_title: SBST's Downtown Line to shift to version 2 of rail financing framework
summary: SBS Transit's Downtown Line (DTL) will transition to the new rail financing framework Version 2, reducing commercial volatility and sharing revenue risk with the Land Transport Authority (LTA). The new framework caps earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) at 5% and shares revenue risk in fare revenue shortfalls. The LTA will issue a consolidated rail licence to SBST's wholly-owned unit, SBST Rail, for 11 years starting January 1, 2022. The agreement also includes an extension of five existing bus contracts by an average of three years.

site_title: Pound, euro's woes are back on speculation Fed will hike rates
summary: The British pound and euro have declined due to speculation that the US Federal Reserve may raise interest rates to combat runaway US inflation. The euro has reached levels near US$1.1450, its highest in 16 months, while the pound has dropped 1.4% to break below US$1.34, its weakest since December. Investors are positioning for further losses in both currencies, with the US dollar rallying to its highest level since November 2020. Experts predict US inflation will remain sticky, weighing on the euro and pound.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.89 points lower at 1,518.85 on Thursday. The market saw 3.020 billion lots worth RM2.241 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 499 to 447. This comes amidst global market trends, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Chinese property, tech stocks jump on hope of softer regulations
summary: Chinese property and tech stocks surged on hopes of softer regulations. Shares in property developers, including Evergrande, rose 12% over two days, their best gain in six years, as investors speculated Beijing may ease restrictions. The rally was fueled by positive news, including a potential relaxation of funding rules and a positive outlook for Didi Global's re-introduction of its apps in China. Analysts warn that if the regulations are not implemented, the risk of a hard landing for China's property market could be avoided, but the rally could reverse if no policy catalysts are announced.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Temasek's unit Heliconia invested US$10 million in Carousell, a classifieds platform, at a US$1.1 billion valuation. GoTo, Indonesia's largest tech group, raised US$1.3 billion from investors ahead of its planned IPO, pushing its valuation to US$28 billion. Ant Group plans to expand Alipay+ services in South-east Asian e-wallets and buy now, pay later. Doctor Anywhere acquired Thailand-based telemedicine platform Doctor Raksa. South Korea demonstrated a system for controlling air taxis.

images.alt_text: Heliconia has purchased over 577,000 shares of Carousell for US$17.30 each via its vehicle Orchid 3 Investments VCC.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip for second day on US inflation woes
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.18% to 2,924.92 on Thursday, tracking US inflation woes and overnight Wall Street weakness. The Korean won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. The decline follows a similar drop on the previous day.

site_title: Evergrande makes overdue interest payments: report
summary: Evergrande, a Chinese developer heavily indebted with over $300 billion liabilities, made overdue interest payments on three US-dollar bonds before their 30-day grace periods ended, averting a potential default. The payment, totaling $148 million, triggered a 8.4% rally in the company's shares in Hong Kong. This move follows previous interest payments made in October to offshore bond-holders. The payment signals a temporary reprieve for the company, but its liquidity crunch continues to impact investor sentiment and the Chinese real estate market.

site_title: Nets makes 2 board appointments from OCBC
summary: Nets appoints Sunny Quek and Melvyn Low to its board of directors, effective November 1. Quek, OCBC's head of consumer financial services, succeeds Ching Wei Hong, while Low, OCBC's head of global transaction banking, replaces Neo Bock Cheng. The appointments mark a transition for OCBC, following the retirement of Ching and Helen Wong, who will step down as OCBC CEO and be succeeded by Tan Teck Long.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend slump as inflation fears weigh
summary: Australian shares slumped 0.57% to 7,381.9, extending losses for the fourth consecutive session, amid concerns over inflation and the potential for the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy sooner than expected. The surprise drop in October employment data, coupled with growing US inflation risks, led to a decline in financials and energy stocks, while miners and gold miners were the sole upward movers. The Australian dollar fell to its lowest in over a month, further exacerbating market volatility.

site_title: South Korea tests system for controlling air taxis
summary: South Korea demonstrated a system for controlling urban air mobility vehicles (UAM) on Thursday, with the aim of cutting travel time by two-thirds. The transport ministry estimates UAM services could reduce travel time between 30-50km from an hour to 20 minutes by air. A pilot flew a two-seat model at Seoul's Gimpo Airport to test and demonstrate its control and coordination. The system, which can be piloted or operate autonomously, is expected to start commercial flights between major airports and downtown Seoul by 2025, with a cost of around 20,000 won per trip.

site_title: STI snaps 2-day losing streak, posts marginal 0.21% gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed marginally above water, up 6.75 points or 0.21% to 3,238.07, snapping a two-day losing streak. Key regional peers closed mixed, with Japan, Hong Kong, and China posting gains. The US consumer price index for October exceeded expectations, fueling inflation concerns. The STI is up nearly 14% in the year to date. Gainers outpaced losers, with 263 counters up and 194 down, driven by trading interest in SPH and Keppel Corp amid Keppel's privatisation offer for SPH.

site_title: SBS Transit Q3 profit-after-tax down 28%
summary: SBS Transit's Q3 profit-after-tax fell 28% to S$13.86 million, driven by a 28% decline in operating profit and a 41% decrease in government relief. Revenue rose 10.9% to S$334.85 million, with higher revenues from public transport services. The company warned of a slow rail ridership recovery due to current restrictions.

site_title: ADDX to work with Tokai Tokyo on security token issuances by Japanese companies
summary: DIGITAL securities exchange ADDX is partnering with Japanese financial services company Tokai Tokyo to issue security tokens by Japanese real estate companies and banks. The tokens will be tokenized on ADDX's platform and distributed to Japanese investors, who can also trade them on the ADDX secondary exchange through Tokai Tokyo. The partnership is expected to yield multiple deals over the next few quarters and bring a significant increase in revenue for ADDX. Japanese regulators have been forward-thinking on digital securities, making this partnership a promising opportunity for investors.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as inflation remains in focus
summary: Asian markets experienced mixed trading on Thursday as inflation fears persisted, despite a report that Chinese property giant Evergrande had avoided a default by meeting bond-payment deadlines. The dollar surged and US interest rates are expected to rise, while bitcoin reached a record high. Inflation reports showed producer prices accelerating and a 31-year high in the consumer price index. Analysts warn that the pain from inflation could continue for some time, with labor costs and rents rising, and investors are seeking inflation-hedging assets like bitcoin.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on bargain hunt, cost worries hurt risk appetite
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.59% to close at 29,277.86 on Thursday, driven by investors seeking undervalued stocks. Despite concerns over rising costs and inflation, shares like Toppan Printing and Showa Denko surged, while others like Shiseido and Asahi Group Holdings fell after cutting profit outlooks. The broader Topix rose 0.32% to 2,014.30, as investors maintained a cautious risk appetite.

site_title: ITAP to return to Singapore Expo from Nov 22-24, expecting 5,000 physical attendees
summary: The Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) will return as a hybrid event in Singapore from November 22-24, featuring 100 booths and a digital event. The event is expected to attract around 5,000 physical attendees, with 300 overseas attendees allowed due to pilot business event restrictions. Local manufacturing companies, including JM Vistec and Rim Polymers Industries, will showcase their Industry 4.0 products and solutions. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat will deliver an opening address on November 22.

site_title: China developers' shares surge higher on easing news, Evergrande payment
summary: Chinese property developers' shares surged 5.5% on Thursday, marking their best 2-day gain in 6 years, amid hopes that Beijing may ease property curbs and as embattled Evergrande Group paid overdue dollar bond interests. The CSI 300 Index rose, with developers such as Gemdale and Jinke Properties Group Co among top performers. Analysts say easing rules could help avoid a hard landing for the property market in China.

site_title: Indonesian tech group GoTo wraps up US$1.3b round ahead of Indonesia IPO
summary: Indonesian tech group GoTo has raised $1.3 billion from investors, including Abu Dhabi Investment Authority and Google, valuing the company at nearly $28 billion ahead of its planned public listing by year-end. The funding round comes as GoTo seeks to secure institutional backing to build favor among retail investors and avoid the pitfalls of its peer Bukalapak, whose share price has fallen by over 30% since its IPO. GoTo plans to use the funds to grow its customer base, expand its financial services, and strengthen its position in the region.

site_title: Temasek's Heliconia invests US$10m in Carousell
summary: Temasek's Heliconia unit has invested US$10 million in classifieds platform Carousell at a valuation of US$1.1 billion, following a US$100 million fundraise in September. Heliconia purchased over 577,000 shares, and Carousell aims to provide investors with an exit by 2024 at a valuation of at least US$1.13 billion, with plans to consider a public listing in the US through a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end well up
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.01% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 25,247.99, following reports that China Evergrande met a deadline to pay interest on offshore bonds. Alibaba also saw gains as it held its Singles Day online shopping event. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Cortina's H1 net profit surges 74% on easing Covid-19 curbs, Sincere Watch acquisition
summary: Cortina Holdings' first-half net profit surged 74% to S$25.4 million due to easing Covid-19 curbs and additional revenue from Sincere Watch acquisition. Revenue rose 87% to S$324.6 million, with sales margins improving to 30%. However, operating expenses increased 81.6% due to the acquired company. The group has drawn down S$50 million in bank borrowings to strengthen working capital, expecting to remain profitable despite uncertainties. No dividend was declared for this period.

site_title: Didi plans to relaunch apps as probe nears end
summary: Didi Global plans to relaunch its apps in China by the end of the year as regulators near the end of their investigation. The company has set aside 10 billion yuan for a potential fine, which is expected to be finalized by December. The Cyberspace Administration of China ordered Didi to remove its services from Chinese app stores in July after concerns over data safety. The company went public in the US despite regulatory concerns, leading to potential unprecedented penalties. Didi is cooperating with the cybersecurity review and has not commented on the accuracy of the reported fine amount.

site_title: Japan's new foreign minister says important to build constructive ties with China
summary: Japan's new foreign minister, Yoshimasa Hayashi, emphasized building constructive and stable ties with China while requesting responsible behavior from the giant neighbor. Hayashi announced his decision to step down as head of the Japan-China Parliamentarians' Friendship League to avoid unnecessary misunderstandings. This move comes amid doubts among conservative lawmakers in Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party about Hayashi's ability to take a firm stance against China.

site_title: A round-up of the construction industry pandemic woes so far
summary: The construction industry has faced significant challenges due to the pandemic, including supply chain and shipping disruptions, which have driven up raw material prices. Companies are exploring alternative solutions, such as building site dorms to limit worker exposure. However, the industry's recovery remains uneven due to manpower and supply constraints. The collapse of contractor Greatearth Corporation has raised concerns about the financial stability of other construction firms, with lawyers warning of increased costs and potential for more contractors to follow suit.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB downgrades Riverstone to 'sell' on risks to future earnings
summary: RHB has downgraded its call on Riverstone Holdings from "neutral" to "sell" due to risks to future earnings from sub-optimal utilisation rates of its plants, currently operating at 75% capacity. The brokerage lowered its price target to S$0.65 from S$0.95, citing erosion of average selling prices (ASPs) and revised earnings projections. Despite this, DBS maintains a "buy" rating, expecting a bumper final dividend and a long-term recovery due to Riverstone's exposure to the cleanroom glove segment.

site_title: Ant seeks to grow Alipay+ use in South-east Asian e-wallets, Buy Now Pay Later
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese payments company, plans to expand its Alipay+ cross-border payments solution in South-east Asia, adding more e-wallets and buy now, pay later services. The move aims to capitalize on the region's booming mobile payment market and facilitate cross-border e-commerce. Alipay+ already partners with e-wallets such as EZ-Link Wallet and Touch 'n Go, and plans to integrate other services, including banks and BNPL players, to serve small and medium-sized enterprises in the region.

site_title: Boeing to compensate families of victims of Ethiopia 737 MAX crash
summary: Boeing has reached an agreement with families of 157 victims of the 2019 Ethiopia 737 MAX crash, admitting responsibility and committing to ensure full and fair compensation. The agreement, filed in a Chicago court, allows families to focus on determining compensation amounts, with jurors assessing damages based on evidence. The settlement is seen as a "historic" milestone for families seeking justice against Boeing, which has made significant changes to the 737 MAX design to prevent future accidents.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro down as much as 3.7% after scrapping subsidiary IPO plans
summary: ComfortDelGro shares plummeted 3.7% after the company scrapped plans for an initial public offering (IPO) for its Australian subsidiary, ComfortDelGro Corporation Australia. The IPO was shelved due to challenging market conditions in Australia. The decision was met with a significant decline in shares, trading at S$1.55, down from S$0.06. Analysts had predicted a potential special dividend and re-rating of ComfortDelGro's shares. The company cited "other strategic options" emerging but did not provide further details.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% at the opening on Thursday, November 11, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,218.17. This comes after Wall Street ended with sharp losses overnight due to consumer inflation hitting a 30-year high. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 57, with Geo Energy Resources RE4 and Keppel Reit actively traded. The decline in Singapore stocks follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while the US and European markets also experienced losses.

site_title: Sony cuts PlayStation 5 production outlook due to component snag
summary: Sony has reduced its PlayStation 5 production outlook to 15 million units for the fiscal year due to component and logistics constraints. The company had previously targeted 16 million units. The move comes amid a global semiconductor shortage, which has impacted companies including Sony. The company is also partnering with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co to build a $7 billion chip plant in Japan, expected to begin production in 2024. This is the second time Sony has adjusted its PS5 production target this year, following a reduction in October.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE downgrades Valuetronics to 'sell' due to near-term headwinds
summary: Maybank KE downgraded its call on Valuetronics to "sell" from "hold" due to near-term headwinds, including cost pressures and lower-than-historical margins. The brokerage lowered its target price to S$0.50 from S$0.60, citing a multiple pegged at 10.6 times FY2023 P/E, which is in line with global peers. Analysts at Maybank KE and CGS-CIMB expect sustained near-term weakness and uncertainties, making the stock attractive for longer-term investors.

images.alt_text: Maybank KE is expecting Valuetronics to face multiple headwinds including cost pressures.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses for fourth day on US inflation threat
summary: Australian shares declined 0.6% on the fourth consecutive day, driven by concerns over US inflation and potential policy normalisation by the Federal Reserve. Healthcare stocks, such as CSL and Ramsay Health Care, led the losses, while energy sector stocks, including Woodside Petroleum and Santos, fell 2.4%. Oil prices dropped overnight due to a surge in the US dollar. Despite this, some miners, such as BHP Group, recovered from a previous drop.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere acquires Thailand-based telemedicine platform
summary: Doctor Anywhere, a healthcare startup, has acquired Thailand-based telemedicine platform Doctor Raksa for an undisclosed amount. Doctor Raksa offers online consultations, electronic prescriptions, and other telehealth services. The acquisition is a strategic move to meet growing demand for telehealth in Thailand, combining Doctor Anywhere's strengths with Doctor Raksa's established brand.

site_title: Japan's Subaru unveils first all-electric car, developed with Toyota
summary: Subaru unveiled its first all-electric vehicle, the Solterra, in a joint development project with Toyota. The sports utility vehicle (SUV) has a 530 km cruising range and is set to compete with Toyota's battery electric vehicle (BEV) models. Subaru's vehicle sales are less than a tenth of Toyota's, but the technological shift towards EVs offers opportunities for smaller carmakers to draw larger rivals closer. Toyota plans to have 15 BEV models by 2025 and is spending $13.5 billion to expand auto battery production capacity.

images.alt_text: Japan's Subaru Corp on Thursday unveiled it first all-electric vehicle (EV), the Solterra, the result of a two-year joint development project with its biggest shareholder Toyota Motor Corp.

site_title: TreeDots raises US$11m to tackle food waste
summary: Singapore-based startup TreeDots has raised US$11 million in Series A funding to tackle food waste. The company, which helps redistribute unsold food inventory from suppliers to businesses, aims to reduce the emission of greenhouse gas methane from discarded food. With this funding, TreeDots plans to expand its services and increase access to the venture capital industry for women and minorities. The startup has already expanded to Malaysia and has a social commerce platform that allows consumers to buy discounted products.

site_title: SpaceX launching 4 astronauts to ISS
summary: SpaceX is set to launch four astronauts, including US Air Force Colonel Raja Chari, NASA astronauts Kayla Barron and Tom Marshburn, and German astronaut Matthias Maurer, to the International Space Station on the "Crew-3" mission. The launch, initially postponed due to weather and a medical issue, is now scheduled for Wednesday night from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The crew will spend six months on the ISS, conducting research and testing experiments, including growing plants in space and building optical fibers.

site_title: Kimly shuffles board, management following resignation of directors charged under SFA
summary: Kimly, a Singapore-based coffee shop and food court operator, announced changes to its board and management following the resignation of two directors charged under the Securities and Futures Act. Former executive chairman Lim Hee Liat and executive director Chia Cher Khiang resigned after being charged for failing to disclose an interested person transaction and failing to disclose ASC's beneficial ownership. Lau Chin Huat was redesignated as non-executive independent chairman, and Wong Kok Yoong Karen was appointed as executive director and finance director. Kimly also made changes to its management team, including appointing Lin Meiqi as financial controller and Tan Chong Sing Roy as director of business development.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to concerns about US inflation prompting aggressive central bank policies. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.21% to 29,044.24, while the Topix index declined 0.10% to 2,005.88.

site_title: Australia court gives CBA investor confidential records to test greenwashing concerns
summary: An Australian court has granted a shareholder access to confidential documents from Commonwealth Bank of Australia to verify compliance with its climate change policy on lending to oil and gas projects. This is the first time an Australian court has allowed access to internal documentation for this purpose. The documents pertain to seven oil and gas projects. The move aims to scrutinize the bank's adherence to its net-zero climate change policy.

site_title: Tesla's Musk exercises options, sells some shares to cover tax bill
summary: Elon Musk sold some shares of Tesla to cover tax obligations related to exercising stock options, which helped the company's stock rise 2% after the bell. Musk initially polled Twitter users about selling 10% of his stake, but the company recovered 4.3% in trading. Despite a $150 billion market loss, retail investors have been net buyers of the stock, with $157 million in purchases on Monday and Tuesday. Tesla's stock is up 51% in 2021, driven by an October rally fueled by an agreement to sell 100,000 vehicles to Hertz.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at start of business
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Thursday with losses, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to concerns over US inflation and potential Federal Reserve policy tightening. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.56% to 24,856.11, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The losses were attributed to the surge in US inflation, which may prompt the Fed to raise interest rates sooner than expected.

site_title: Gold consolidates as US inflation surges
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,850 per ounce, following a surge to a 5-month peak the previous day due to US inflation concerns. US consumer prices rose 0.2% in October, the largest annual gain in 31 years, fueling inflation worries. Despite a stronger dollar, gold prices held firm, with other precious metals also rising. The Federal Reserve Bank President Mary Daly expressed caution on raising interest rates, citing the need for moderate inflation to recede once COVID-19 is controlled.

site_title: Hot stocks: SPH, SPH Reit, Keppel, Keppel Reit see active trading after Keppel's counter offer for SPH
summary: Shares of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), Keppel Corp, and units of SPH Reit and Keppel Reit were actively traded after Keppel raised its privatisation offer for SPH to S$2.351 per share, a 6.9% increase. The revised offer includes cash, Keppel Reit units, and SPH Reit units, reflecting improved financial performance and economic conditions. A consortium has also offered S$2.10 per SPH share in cash, but Keppel's offer is considered more compelling due to regulatory approvals and a higher valuation.

site_title: China's Singles' Day shopping fest subdued by tech crackdown
summary: China's annual Singles' Day shopping festival saw a subdued version of the event, with major e-commerce platforms like Alibaba not releasing sales figures due to government scrutiny targeting alleged abuse of user data and monopolistic business practices. The crackdown, part of the ruling Communist Party's efforts to diversify China's economy, has rattled tech giants but is unlikely to significantly hobble e-commerce. Combined sales of Alibaba and JD.com platforms reached $115 billion last year, but this year's sales figures remain unclear.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Sembmarine, FLCT, Q&M, ComfortDelGro, StarHub, Geo Energy
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies reported significant developments in their earnings and operations. Singtel posted a 104.7% jump in H1 earnings to S$954 million, while Q&M Dental saw a 69% rise in net profit. Geo Energy Resources reported record profits and revenue in its third quarter. Meanwhile, ComfortDelGro announced it would no longer pursue an IPO for its Australian subsidiary. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Sembmarine posts S$1.42b order book at end-Q3
summary: SembCorp Marine posted an order book of over S$1.42 billion at the end of Q3 2021, including S$180 million for repairs and upgrades by 2022. However, the company faces Covid-19 supply chain constraints and skilled worker shortages, delaying project completions. This may result in material cost overruns, leading to significant losses in H2 2021. Despite challenges, Sembmarine expects growth in renewable and clean energy segments over the next decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.90 points or 0.06% to 1,521.64. The market saw 276.70 million lots traded worth RM138.13 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 230 to 149. This follows a broader regional trend, with Singapore stocks rallying for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Q&M Dental Q3 net profit surges 69% on medical equipment and supplies segment
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 69% surge in net profit for its third quarter, driven by strong contributions from its medical laboratory and dental equipment and supplies segment. The segment saw a 932% increase to S$18.4 million, compared to S$1.8 million previously. Net profit rose to S$9.5 million, with revenue increasing by 48% to S$57.7 million. The company also expanded its dental clinics to 90 in Singapore and 38 in Malaysia, and increased its total number of dentists to 270.

site_title: Biden says prices are too high in trip touting efforts to combat inflation
summary: US President Joe Biden said US consumer prices remain too high, with a 6.2% annual increase in October, the largest in three decades. This comes as inflation-taming efforts are highlighted during a visit to Baltimore's Port of Baltimore, a major US port. The port's congestion has been a source of supply shortfalls, but is set to benefit from a $17 billion infrastructure package. Biden's administration has also worked to relieve congestion at other ports, including those in Long Beach and Los Angeles.

site_title: Trans-China Automotive debuts on Catalist board at S$0.245, 6.5% above IPO price
summary: Trans-China Automotive Holdings made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.245, 6.5% above its IPO price of S$0.23. The company's shares were subscribed 1.2 times and its market capitalisation is approximately S$134.4 million. TCA plans to use the majority of the IPO proceeds to expand its dealerships and service centres, while also growing its dealership network to new regions.

images.alt_text: Trans-China Automotive was founded in 2009 by executive chairman and chief executive officer Francis Tjia who has more than 20 years of industry experience.

site_title: Nordic Group looking to make offer for Starburst Holdings at S$0.238 per share
summary: Nordic Group is set to make a voluntary conditional offer for Starburst Holdings at S$0.238 per share in cash. The offer is contingent on the approval of resolutions at Nordic Group's general meeting by February 10, 2022. Starburst's chairman and managing director have already irrevocably committed to accepting the offer, holding 69.7% of the shares. The offer price represents a 5.78% premium over the last trading day's price, and if successful, Nordic Group may consider delisting the company from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Singtel H1 profit jumps 104.7% to S$954m; JVs, associates back to black with S$770m contribution
summary: Singtel reported a 104.7% jump in earnings to S$954m in the first half of its financial year, driven by improved results from associates and joint ventures. Underlying net profit rose 17% to S$983m, excluding exceptional losses. The company approved an interim dividend of S$0.045 per share, lower than last year's S$0.051 cents, but expects full-year dividends to be at the upper half of its 60-80% range. Operating revenue edged up 3.1% to S$7.7 billion, driven by the Australia consumer business.

images.alt_text: Singtel on Thursday reported a 104.7 per cent jump in earnings to S$954 million from S$466.1 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Disney+ streaming subscriber growth slows
summary: Disney's streaming service, Disney+, grew to 118 million subscribers worldwide, but at a slower rate than expected. The company's share price dropped after the earnings call. CEO Bob Chapek attributed the slow growth to the need for great content to attract new subscribers. Despite this, Disney plans to nearly double its content offerings and is promoting Disney+ with a major offer. The company's overall earnings fell short of expectations, with revenue less than analysts anticipated.

site_title: US Trade Rep calls for 'bold' efforts to reform WTO
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai urged officials at the upcoming WTO ministerial conference to be "bold" in reforming the global trade body. She emphasized the need for energy, dynamism, and vision to adapt to the changing economy. Tai encouraged officials to share their grievances and disappointments, and be honest about the changes needed. The ministerial conference is set to start on November 30 in Geneva, marking a critical moment for the WTO's reform efforts.

site_title: US prosecutors seek 4 years' jail for Capitol riot 'shaman'
summary: US prosecutors are seeking 51 months in jail for Jacob Chansley, also known as the "QAnon shaman," who participated in the January 6 Capitol riot. Chansley pleaded guilty to unlawful trespassing and violent conduct in September and faces up to 20 years in prison. His conviction comes after he wore a horned buffalo headdress during the riot in an attempt to stop the election results from being validated.

site_title: Oil prices plunge into close, roiled by inflation fears
summary: Oil prices plummeted on Thursday, falling 2.5% to $82.64 a barrel for Brent crude and 3.3% to $81.34 a barrel for US crude, amid inflation fears and a surge in the dollar. US President Joe Biden's comments on reducing energy costs and curbing inflation led to a market sell-off, while consumer inflation data showed a 6.2% year-over-year rate, its fastest in three decades. The dollar's rally, driven by expectations of a rate increase, further weighed on oil prices, with traders expecting prices to continue rising in the coming months.

site_title: US rejects request to consider tariffs on solar panels from Vietnam, Malaysia and Thailand
summary: US trade officials rejected a request to consider tariffs on solar panels from Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand, according to a Commerce Department letter. The request was made by the American Solar Manufacturers Against Chinese Circumvention, a group of domestic solar panel manufacturers. The decision comes after US President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canadian goods and threatened tariffs on other countries. This move may help stabilize global solar panel prices, but its impact on the US solar industry remains unclear. The decision does not address the concerns of the requesting group.

site_title: Apple loses bid to stall apps bypassing pay system in Epic Games case
summary: A US judge rejected Apple's request to delay implementing a ruling allowing app developers to bypass the App Store's payment system, as ordered by the court in a case brought by Epic Games. The judge, Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers, said Apple had 30 days to comply, despite Apple's appeal of the ruling. The order, made in September, permanently barred Apple from prohibiting developers from including external links to payment methods in their apps, but allowed Apple to mandate its payment systems for in-app transactions.

site_title: In search of vacation homes
summary: Singaporeans' desire to travel has shifted from planning to buying vacation homes due to the pandemic. Overseas property developers are experiencing healthy sales of resort properties, especially in hotspots like the Swiss Alps and Hokkaido ski resorts. Buyers are prioritizing second homes for escape from city life and a safe quarantine location. This trend is a significant shift from pre-Covid, where buyers focused on financial returns.

site_title: Expanding VTLs: reconnecting Singapore with the rest of the world
summary: Singapore is expanding its network of Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) with new connections to Malaysia, Finland, and Sweden, and several Asean countries, including Cambodia, Indonesia, and Vietnam, are moving to Category 2. The expansion aims to reconnect Singapore with the rest of the world, promote regional commerce, and restore ties with other nations. The move is seen as a step towards living with Covid-19 and recognizing the interconnectedness of the region, despite potential limitations on travel and economic activities.

site_title: US and China unveil emissions deal in bid to save UN climate talks
summary: The US and China have unveiled a deal to increase cooperation on climate change, including reducing methane emissions, phasing out coal consumption, and protecting forests. The agreement, announced at the UN climate conference in Scotland, aims to boost efforts to combat global warming. US climate envoy John Kerry and his Chinese counterpart Xie Zhenhua billed the deal as a key step towards success, despite UN head Alok Sharma warning that current commitments would not be enough to tackle climate change.

site_title: Alternative assets post strong 2020 growth in Singapore asset management industry: MAS
summary: Singapore's asset management industry saw strong growth in 2020, with alternative assets posting a 54% increase in assets under management (AUM) to S$391 billion, driven by investors' appetite for yield and uncorrelated assets. The industry's overall AUM expanded by 17% to S$4.7 trillion, with discretionary and alternative assets accounting for 51% of the total. Private equity and venture capital managers reported significant dry powder, with private credit also gaining attention as a source of funding for businesses.

site_title: China's Xi warns of 'Cold War-era' tensions in Asia-Pacific
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned against a return to Cold War-era tensions in the Asia-Pacific, urging greater cooperation on pandemic recovery and climate change. He called for joint efforts to close the "immunisation gap" by making Covid-19 vaccines more accessible to developing nations. China reached a surprise deal with the US on climate change, and Xi expressed support for "green, low-carbon sustainable development." The warning comes amid rising tensions with the US over Taiwan, with Beijing ramping up military activities near the island.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end at record high on robust earnings
summary: European stocks closed at a record high on Wednesday, driven by strong earnings from media and energy sectors. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% to 483.76 points, with media stocks like ITV and Siemens Energy advancing 15.1% and 3.5%, respectively. Despite a 1.3% decline in technology stocks, the overall market remained strong, with profits expected to jump 60.7% in the third quarter. Investors are optimistic despite concerns over inflation and the impact of US interest rate decisions on the market.

site_title: Bond market flashes mixed messages as real yields plunge
summary: US Treasury bond market shows mixed signals as real yields plummet to record lows, with 30-year inflation-protected securities reaching minus 0.60%. Despite expectations of economic growth, traders are pricing in higher inflation risk, driven by rising inflation expectations and concerns of ingrained inflation. Strategists attribute the downward trend to factors such as traders re-positioning portfolios and concerns about the long-term impact of high inflation.

site_title: US consumer prices surge at fastest pace in 30 years
summary: US consumer prices surged 0.9% in October, the largest annual gain since 1990, driven by rising petrol and food costs. The 6.2% year-on-year increase in the consumer price index (CPI) was the largest since November 1990, amid snarled global supply chains and labour shortages. Excluding volatile food and energy components, the core CPI rose 4.6% on a year-on-year basis, the largest increase since August 1991. Economists warn that inflation could remain high due to pandemic relief fueling demand and supply bottlenecks persisting.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends sharply lower after inflation hit 30-year high
summary: US shares plummeted 0.7-0.8% on Wednesday, ending the day at 36,079.94 and 4,646.71 respectively, after inflation hit a 30-year high of 6.2% in October, driven by rising oil, auto, and housing prices. This decline comes after a streak of gains over the past few weeks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7% and the S&P 500 fell 0.8% amidst investor concerns about the impact of high inflation on the economy.

site_title: FLCT posts 6.3% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.0388
summary: FRASERS Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a 6.3% increase in its half-yearly distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0388, driven by 11.4% growth in gross revenue to S$237.6 million. Net property income (NPI) and distributable income also rose 12.3% and 11.8% respectively. The trust's portfolio occupancy rate was 96.2% as of Sep 30, with a weighted average lease expiry of 4.8 years. FLCT's valuation increased to S$7.3 billion, with net asset value per unit rising 12.7%.

images.alt_text: Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust's distribution per unit rose by 6.3 per cent to 3.88 Singapore cents for its second half ended Sep 30, from 3.65 cents a year ago.

site_title: China property stocks rally on hopes of potential easing of refinancing
summary: Chinese property stocks rallied on Nov 10, 2021, as the National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors hosted a meeting with developers in Beijing to discuss financing issues. Analysts believe that Beijing may ease refinancing policies for developers to prevent a hard landing in the property market. Shares of Poly Developments, China Merchants Shekou, China Aoyuan Group, and Shimao Group surged, while experts expect new policies to be introduced in the fourth quarter to create a better business environment for real estate companies.

site_title: Rivian raises US$11.9b in Wall Street debut
summary: Rivian, an electric vehicle manufacturer, raised $11.9 billion in its Wall Street debut, valuing the company at $67.9 billion. The IPO price was set at $78 per share, with 153 million new shares being issued due to high demand. The company, backed by Amazon and Ford, plans to deliver 55,400 electric trucks and SUVs by the end of 2023 and 100,000 vans to Amazon by 2030. Rivian's valuation surpasses that of Ford, with the company entering the market at a time of growing enthusiasm for electric vehicles.

site_title: China shuts Myanmar tin ore crossing amid virus fears
summary: China has closed its border crossing with Myanmar due to concerns over the spread of the coronavirus, further disrupting tin concentrate imports. The closure affects 94% of China's tin concentrate imports, which were already impacted by pandemic-related disruptions. Tin prices have risen 83% year-to-date, reaching a record high, due to shortages and low stocks. China's zero-COVID strategy and porous border with Myanmar have led to repeated lockdown restrictions and disruptions to the tin trade.

site_title: China tightens oversight of 23.9t yuan mutual fund market
summary: China's securities regulators have tightened oversight of the 23.9 trillion yuan mutual fund market, banning unlicensed firms and individuals from giving fund recommendations or publishing performance numbers. The China Securities Regulatory Commission's (CSRC) Beijing bureau issued the notice to strengthen market supervision. This move aims to improve market transparency and protect investors. The ban affects those without an advisory license, which will now be required to provide fund recommendations.

site_title: Squid Game director predicts second season of megahit
summary: Squid Game director Hwang Dong-hyuk expressed confidence that the show will return for a second season, stating they are in talks for the project. The director mentioned having a basic storyline and broad plan in place, but declined to provide a release date. The show's success has been praised, with Hwang describing it as "surreal" and Lee Jung-Jae expressing gratitude for the show's impact. The series' themes of class inequality and social commentary have resonated with audiences, echoing the success of 2020 Oscar winner Parasite.

site_title: Six major carmakers and 31 countries say they will phase out sales of petrol cars
summary: Major carmakers and 31 countries pledge to phase out sales of new petrol and diesel-powered vehicles by 2040 and 2035 in leading markets. However, Toyota, Volkswagen, and the Nissan-Renault alliance did not join the non-legally binding pledge. The move aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and transition to cleaner transportation.

site_title: As China's property crisis spreads, Beijing says there's nothing to see
summary: China's property crisis deepens, with developers facing financial strain and widespread defaults. Despite Beijing's assurances that the situation is under control, Evergrande's financial woes have sparked panic, contributing to a wave of defaults among other developers. The company's unpaid debts total over $300 billion, and its recent payments on multimillion-dollar bonds have raised concerns about its ability to meet future obligations. Experts warn that the crisis has already had a spillover effect on the US economy, with the US Federal Reserve flagging it as a potential risk.

site_title: Look beyond reported rates to get true picture of rental market for CBD offices
summary: Singapore's central business district (CBD) office market is shifting, with demand trends indicating a more sustainable picture of rental rates. Despite a 2.2% decline in average signing rent for the first nine months of 2021, property groups and Reits with high exposure to the market should monitor the situation closely. Occupancy rates slipped to 91.7% at CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, while the Urban Redevelopment Authority's office rental index posted a 3.5% quarterly drop. Experts attribute the decline to rental weakness at older, poorer-quality office buildings, with some landlords agreeing to lower rental rates to support occupancy.

site_title: World Bank report shows 'massive gaps' in systems to track poor countries' debts
summary: The World Bank released a report revealing "massive gaps" in tracking sovereign debts of poor countries, with estimates potentially off by 30% of a country's GDP. The report found 40% of low-income countries had published no data on their sovereign debt in over two years, and 12% are already in debt distress. World Bank chief economist Carmen Reinhart warned that actual debt levels could be "markedly higher" and called for reforms to ensure better debt statistics and coordinated data collection.

site_title: Branagh draws on 'other lockdown' of Troubles for Oscar frontrunner Belfast
summary: Kenneth Branagh's Oscar frontrunner "Belfast" was inspired by the "other lockdown" of Northern Ireland's Troubles, his childhood experiences in the region. Filmed during the pandemic, the black-and-white drama premiered in Los Angeles, where it is expected to have a lengthy award season campaign. Branagh, who drew from his own experiences, says the film provides an emotional release for those who have been through trauma, and he hopes it will help reconnect audiences with their roots.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents and leasing volumes rise in Oct as Singapore eases border measures
summary: Singapore's rental markets for HDB flats and private apartments saw a rise in volumes and rents in October, driven by the easing of border measures and the opening of more Vaccinated Travel Lanes. Condo rents increased by 1.3% and 9.1% year-over-year, while HDB rents rose 0.2% and 8.3% year-over-year. Rental demand is expected to increase in the coming months as more foreign workers and expatriates return to the country, with experts predicting a 6-10% increase in rents over the next 12 months.

site_title: Paytm IPO, India's biggest share sale, fully sold on final day
summary: Paytm's $2.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) was fully subscribed on its final day, with bids for 1.2 times the number of shares offered. The sale, considered India's biggest share sale, was slower than expected due to concerns about the firm's profitability. Analysts had raised doubts about Paytm's ability to turn a profit, but the strong demand for the shares suggests investor confidence in the company's potential.

site_title: Marie Antoinette's bracelets dazzle at auction
summary: Marie Antoinette's two diamond bracelets, valued at $2-4 million, sold for $11 million at Christie's Geneva auction on November 9. The 112 old-cut diamonds adorned 18.7 cm long bracelets, which have been part of the royal family's heritage since 1776. The sale marks the first time the bracelets have gone under the hammer, with the first bid reaching $5 million. The sale achieved an astonishing price for a "really, really great jewel," according to Christie's, with the royal provenance and historic significance of the bracelets adding to their value.

site_title: With falling cases and higher vaccination rates, Vietnam is ready to reopen to foreigners
summary: Vietnam is set to reopen its borders to fully vaccinated foreign tourists starting November 20 on the resort island of Phu Quoc. The move aims to boost the country's struggling tourism sector, which plummeted by nearly 80% last year due to the pandemic. With falling Covid-19 cases and higher vaccination rates, Vietnam hopes to attract international visitors and revive its tourism industry, which accounted for 9% of the country's GDP in 2019.

images.alt_text: All eyes are on Phu Quoc, an island in the Gulf of Thailand about 10 km off the coast of Cambodia, as it prepares for the first batch of international arrivals.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as surging consumer prices fan inflation fears
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday as consumer prices surged, fueling inflation fears. The Dow Jones fell 0.06% to 36,299.25, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.32% to 4,670.26, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.84% to 15,753.84. The surge in consumer prices deepened concerns about high inflation, which has been a major focus for investors and policymakers.

site_title: US dollar ticks up ahead of US inflation data
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major peers on Wednesday ahead of US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The US consumer price index is predicted to come in at 4.3% annualized, surpassing the Fed's 2% target. This data will be crucial in determining the pace of interest rate hikes in 2022, with investors taking little risk. The US dollar index rose 0.19% to 94.146, while the euro fell 0.23% to $1.1569.

site_title: Moving from rhetoric to action on inclusive business
summary: Businesses must shift from sole focus on profitability to inclusive business practices to achieve long-term sustainability and competitiveness. The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the social aspect of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, and digital technologies have enabled businesses to address concerns. Companies in South-east Asia, with a population of over 600 million, are encouraged to adopt an inclusive business model to achieve greater ESG impact. This requires a rethink of purpose and mindsets, and understanding of how to build or shift towards an inclusive business model.

site_title: Peter Jackson sells special effects firm in US$1.6b 'metaverse' deal
summary: New Zealand film director Peter Jackson has sold his Oscar-winning special effects firm Weta Digital to US software firm Unity Software in a US$1.6 billion deal. The acquisition will help Unity develop the metaverse, a virtual reality version of the Internet, and provide artists with ultra-realistic tools. Jackson retains majority ownership of a standalone film effects company, WetaFX. The deal aims to democratize Weta's industry-leading tools, allowing artists from various industries to create immersive virtual worlds.

site_title: Wealth Pulse - Financial Planning
summary: DBS Bank predicts 7 industries to outperform in the coming years, including healthcare, education, and technology. The bank's pick is based on its analysis of market trends and economic conditions. The industries are expected to drive growth and create new opportunities for investors. The bank's revised estimates also suggest that the pandemic's impact on the economy will be similar to the 2009 global financial crisis.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust seeks SGX listing
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust, a Reit investing in logistics and industrial real estate assets across Asia, is seeking a listing on the Singapore Exchange. The trust will offer nearly 244.44 million units at S$0.80 per unit as part of an offering including a placement tranche and a public offer. The move aims to raise funds for its investment activities.

site_title: Literary star Viet Thanh Nguyen on the roots of identity politics
summary: Viet Thanh Nguyen, a Pulitzer-winning author, discusses the roots of identity politics, emphasizing that it oversimplifies the complexities of US and French imperialism. Nguyen argues that colonialism and conquest are the underlying causes of identity crises, rather than symptoms. He notes that France and the US have a hard time dealing with their imperial past, particularly in relation to Vietnam, Algeria, and Indo-China. Nguyen's experiences as a Vietnamese-American writer, including being separated from his parents at a refugee center, have shaped his perspective on the importance of acknowledging and addressing historical injustices.

site_title: 3,481 new Covid-19 cases and 17 deaths; weekly infection growth rate at 0.88
summary: Singapore reported 3,481 new Covid-19 cases and 17 deaths on Nov 10, with a weekly infection growth rate of 0.88. This marks the eighth consecutive day with a growth rate below one. The total number of cases in Singapore stands at 227,681, with 540 deaths. The majority of new cases (3,244) were in the community, while 299 were in migrant worker dormitories and eight were imported.

site_title: Beauty startup IPO mints India's 7th woman billionaire
summary: Falguni Nayar, 58, becomes India's 7th woman billionaire after Nykaa's market debut, tripling her net worth to $7 billion. The beauty startup's parent company FSN floated on the Mumbai stock exchange, hitting a valuation of $18.1 billion. Nykaa, founded by Nayar in 2012, has become popular among young Indians for its wide selection of global brands and has a growing high street presence with 80 stores across 40 cities. The company expects India's beauty market to nearly double in size from 2020 to 2025.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust seeks listing on SGX
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) is seeking a listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to invest in logistics and industrial real-estate assets across Asia. The trust plans to raise approximately S$575.5 million through a public offering, with a preliminary prospectus lodged with the Monetary Authority of Singapore. DHLT's initial portfolio consists of 14 logistics properties in Japan, with a total net lettable area of 423,920 square meters. Trading in the units is expected to commence on or about November 26.

site_title: Wealth Pulse - Sustainability
summary: A recent article from Wealth Pulse discusses market trends in 2022, highlighting seven key points to consider from Budget 2022. The article also touches on various other topics including sustainability, longevity, and financial planning. Notably, DBS has identified industries that are expected to outperform in the coming years. However, the article also mentions fears of a worsening pandemic in Asia, which may impact market trends. Overall, the article provides insights into the current market landscape and potential future growth areas.

site_title: Draft deal looks beyond UN conference for real climate advances
summary: The UK hosts of the UN climate conference have released a draft deal calling on countries to increase their greenhouse gas emissions reductions by next year to meet the 1.5°C Paris Agreement goal. The draft asks countries to "revisit and strengthen" their 2030 targets, with a goal of limiting warming to well below 2°C. The proposal also urges countries to phase out fossil fuel subsidies and speed up efforts to stop burning coal. While the draft is seen as a step forward, critics say it falls short of what is needed to avert climate catastrophe, and a final agreement is unlikely to be reached this week.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida vows wide-ranging payouts in planned stimulus package
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has pledged a pandemic-relief stimulus package worth "several tens of trillion yen" by the end of next week, including cash payouts to households hit by the coronavirus crisis. The package includes 100,000 yen payouts to students, temporary workers, and low-income households, as well as aid to agriculture and fishery industries. The government aims to compile an extra budget by the end of the month to deliver the payouts at the earliest date possible, amid a post-election boost in government support ratings.

site_title: Elton John receives elite royal honour from Prince Charles
summary: Elton John, 74, was appointed to the Order of the Companions of Honour, a rare royal honour, by Prince Charles in recognition of his 50+ year music career and charity work, particularly in AIDS research. The musician joins notable figures such as David Hockney, Judi Dench, and Paul McCartney in the prestigious order.

site_title: Singapore Airshow to go ahead in 2022 from Feb 15 to 18; not open to public
summary: The Singapore Airshow 2022 will take place from February 15 to 18 at the Changi Exhibition Centre, despite the cancellation of public days due to COVID-19 precautions. Foreign participants must be fully vaccinated, and pre-event testing and capacity limits will be implemented. The event is expected to attract around 10,000 trade attendees, down from 30,000 in 2020. Organisers aim to ensure the highest levels of safety for all attendees, with the event serving as a signal for Singapore's return as a global aviation and aerospace hub.

site_title: GE kicks off US$23b bond tender offer to cut debt load
summary: General Electric has launched a US$23 billion bond tender offer to reduce its debt load. The offer, which expires on December 9, targets bonds maturing through 2050. As part of its plan, GE aims to cut its borrowings by over US$75 billion in the next three years through operational changes. The company's debt reduction strategy is expected to boost cash flow and profit margins.

site_title: Progress but no victory at COP26
summary: The COP26 climate summit in Glasgow saw significant financial commitments, with over 450 financial firms joining the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, totaling $130 trillion in assets under management. However, concerns remain about the lack of progress and the potential for "greenwashing" due to the alliance's open-door policy. Despite this, the financial sector is increasingly recognizing the risks of inaction and the economic opportunities of transitioning to a net-zero economy. Pledges made at the summit provide a basis for holding those who have made them accountable, and efforts should focus on making the financial sector work to its full potential.

site_title: Google wins UK legal case over iPhone tracking
summary: The UK's Supreme Court has unanimously dismissed a $4 billion class action against Google, which claimed the company secretly tracked iPhone users' internet activity. The "Google You Owe Us" association, representing 4.4 million people, sought compensation for alleged unauthorized tracking. The court's decision blocks the legal action, allowing Google to avoid the massive payout.

site_title: Trans-China Automotive IPO 1.2 times subscribed
summary: Trans-China Automotive Holdings' shares were subscribed 1.2 times for its initial public offering (IPO), with 2.9 million shares by public offer and 82.1 million shares by placement. The company plans to use the $16.3 million in net proceeds to expand its dealerships and grow its network, with the remaining funds allocated to working capital and new regions. The shares will start trading on the Catalist-board of the Singapore Exchange on November 11.

site_title: NetEase's answer to Fortnite clocks up 6 million in sales
summary: NetEase's battle royale game Naraka: Bladepoint has sold over 6 million copies globally, making it one of the fastest-selling Chinese PC games and a rare example of a non-smartphone title from China gaining global success. The game, launched in August, has grossed at least $240 million through in-game purchases, with top international markets including the US, Japan, and Vietnam. NetEase is now pushing for overseas growth, with plans for a console version, mobile game, and e-sports league, as the company aims to expand its global presence and counter scrutiny from local regulators.

site_title: AEM Holdings posts 4% fall in Q3 net profit
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 4.3% fall in net profit to S$23.3 million for its Q3, down from S$24.3 million last year. Revenue fell 9.7% to S$146.2 million, despite higher sequential quarter revenue. The company expects demand to rise in the next few quarters due to growing demand for semiconductor chips and advanced packaging. AEM has engaged with top 20 semiconductor companies and expects initial orders to contribute to revenue in the second half of 2022.

site_title: Inflation in US builds with biggest gain in prices since 1990
summary: The US consumer price index (CPI) rose 6.2% from October 2020, the largest gain since 1990, with energy, shelter, food, and vehicle prices driving the increase. Core inflation, excluding food and energy, rose 4.2% from a year earlier, and shelter costs increased 0.5% for the first time in four months. The report suggests higher inflation will be longer-lasting, putting pressure on the Federal Reserve to end near-zero interest rates sooner, and threatening to exacerbate political challenges for President Biden and Democrats.

site_title: Technology lends a hand to green e-commerce
summary: The Asia-Pacific region has witnessed a surge in e-commerce growth, with the online retail market predicted to reach $2.8 trillion by 2025. However, this growth comes with a significant environmental impact, including increased packaging waste and transportation emissions. To mitigate these effects, major e-commerce players are partnering with logistics service providers to adopt sustainable practices. Technology is playing a key role in reducing waste and emissions, with innovations such as AI-powered packaging, autonomous vehicles, and smart logistics robots. By leveraging technology, industry leaders can reduce their carbon footprint and set a sustainable tone for the industry.

site_title: Crypto exchange Huobi Global to close Singapore accounts by end-March 2022
summary: Huobi Global will close the accounts of all its Singapore-based users by March 31, 2022, due to compliance with Singaporean laws. The exchange advises Singapore-based users to close their active positions and withdraw digital assets by the deadline. This move restricts Huobi Global's services to Singapore-based users, citing the need to include the country as a restricted jurisdiction.

site_title: Thailand defends its strict royal insults law at UN rights review
summary: Thailand defended its strict royal insults law at a UN rights review, with officials arguing it protects the monarch and national security. The law, which carries jail terms of up to 15 years for criticizing King Maha Vajiralongkorn, has been criticized by UN member states for restricting freedom of expression. At least 156 people, including 13 minors, have been charged with lese majeste since student protests began last year, with some calling for the law to be amended or reviewed. The US expressed concern over the law's impact on freedom of expression.

site_title: China's credit stabilises as PBOC encourages banks to lend
summary: China's credit stabilised in October with aggregate financing reaching 1.59 trillion yuan, down from 2.9 trillion yuan in September. The central bank encouraged banks to lend to the property sector amid a downturn in the economy. Credit growth remains steady at 10% year-over-year, and mortgage lending posted relatively stable gains. Long-term loans extended to households reached 422.1 billion yuan, higher than a year earlier, as the People's Bank of China steps up targeted lending support to the economy.

site_title: Wealth Pulse - Longevity
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The article from Wealth Pulse covers various topics related to finance, sustainability, and longevity. It includes updates on market trends for 2022, key points from Budget 2022, and predictions for industries set to outperform in the coming years. DBS's predictions for outperforming industries were revised, maintaining the same final position. Additionally, the article touches on concerns about a worsening pandemic in Asia. Overall, the content provides insights into the current state of the economy, sustainability, and financial planning. It offers a snapshot of market trends and predictions for the future.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical Group posts 10% rise in Q3 net profit
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group, a C8R-listed company, reported a 10% rise in net profit to RMB56.9 million (S$12 million) in its third quarter ended September 30. Revenue increased by 56% to RMB416.7 million due to higher average sales prices of dimethylformamide (DMF) and methylamine. However, sales volume for DMF and methylamine fell due to severe flooding in Henan province. The company attributed the higher prices to increased raw material costs and strong demand from downstream customers.

site_title: Xi says China is ready to work with US to manage differences
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping stated that China is prepared to work with the US to manage their differences. This comes after a letter was read by China's US ambassador, Qin Gang, in which Xi emphasized the need for enhanced exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: SPH open to considering all offers that are better than Keppel's: CEO
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) CEO Ng Yat Chung is open to considering all offers that surpass Keppel Corp's S$2.351 per share bid for the company. SPH will hold a scheme meeting by Dec 8 to vote on Keppel's offer, while also allowing for another agreement with a competing party until Nov 16. A rival offer from Cuscaden Peak has been made, but its feasibility and timing are uncertain due to regulatory requirements. The Keppel offer provides a cash component and shares of Keppel Reit and SPH Reit units, while Cuscaden's offer is all-cash.

site_title: China developers jump on possible easing of bond issue rules
summary: Chinese developers' bonds and stocks surged after reports that authorities are likely to loosen controls on real estate companies' local-currency note issuance. The easing is expected to center on the interbank bond market, which has seen issuance from developers fall in the past year. Analysts say the move could calm stressed markets and boost sentiment, but may only benefit higher-quality developers. Authorities sent the policy signal at a meeting between developers and the National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors, which oversees corporate bond issuance.

site_title: Geo Energy Resources sees record quarterly results on historically high coal prices
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported record quarterly results, posting a net profit from operations of US$45.5 million and revenue of US$153.6 million in Q3 FY2021, driven by historically high coal prices. The company delivered 2.6 million tonnes of coal, exceeding the previous year's amount, and expects another record-breaking fourth quarter. Geo Energy also declared an interim dividend of S$0.03 per share and expects strong coal prices to remain around US$90 per tonne for the rest of the year, despite a cap on domestic sales.

site_title: China's gaming crackdown pushes Tencent to slowest profit growth in 2 years
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest gaming and social media company, reported its slowest quarterly profit growth in two years due to a gaming crackdown. Net profit rose 3% to 39.5 billion yuan, beating analyst expectations, while revenue climbed 13% to 142.4 billion yuan, the slowest quarterly growth since 2004. The company attributed the decline to regulatory and macroeconomic factors, including new limits on video game time for minors and a curbed appetite for advertising from industries such as tutoring and beauty.

site_title: Evergrande teeters on edge of default as US$148m payment falls due
summary: China Evergrande Group teeters on the edge of default as it faces a final deadline to make an offshore bond coupon payment of US$148 million, ending a 30-day grace period. The company, struggling with over US$300 billion in liabilities, has not defaulted on any offshore debt obligations but a failure to pay would trigger cross-default provisions and exacerbate China's debt crisis. The deadline comes as concerns about the property sector's liquidity squeeze and global risks spread, with the US Federal Reserve warning of potential fallout.

site_title: Labcorp launches bioanalytical lab in Singapore, expands headcount by 25%
summary: Labcorp, an American biotech company, has launched a new laboratory in Singapore, expanding its team by 25% with 90 new jobs. The lab will provide bioanalytical testing services, including testing for biologics and vaccines, and will help strengthen Singapore's biomedical ecosystem. Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong stated that Labcorp's expansion will support the development of healthcare technologies and make Singapore a more compelling regional biomedical hub, attracting leading-edge investments.

site_title: StarHub revenue grows on cybersecurity services gains, improved broadband ARPU
summary: StarHub's third-quarter revenue rose 5.6% to S$517.2 million, driven by a 17.3% increase in enterprise business segment revenue, primarily from cybersecurity services. Net profits fell 9.5% to S$40.2 million, excluding Jobs Support Scheme wage subsidies. The company raised its full-year service earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) guidance to "at least 26%". Broadband revenue grew 9.5% to S$49.8 million, despite a decline in subscribers to 485,000.

site_title: DoorDash takes aim at Europe with purchase of Wolt
summary: DoorDash has acquired Wolt, a Finland-based food delivery firm, in an all-stock deal valued at $8.1 billion, expanding its presence in Europe. The deal follows DoorDash's 45% revenue growth to $1.3 billion in the recently ended quarter, despite a doubling of its loss to $101 million. The combined company aims to accelerate product development, improve focus on markets, and enhance value for consumers, merchants, and delivery personnel globally. Wolt's 4,000-employee operation spans 23 countries, and the deal is expected to boost DoorDash's international growth.

site_title: Malaysia tipped to enter technical recession in Q3: analysts
summary: Malaysia is likely to enter a technical recession in the third quarter of 2021, with a 0.6% quarter-on-quarter decline in GDP, according to a Bloomberg poll. The economy contracted 1.9% on a yearly basis, with all sectors expected to see contractions. However, economists believe the economy could make a turnaround in the fourth quarter due to the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions and improved vaccine coverage. Despite this, technical recession forecasts range from a 6% contraction to 1% growth, highlighting widespread uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.29 points to 1,520.74. Losers outnumbered gainers 502 to 428, and volume reached 3.432 billion lots worth RM2.315 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SPH CEO Ng Yat Chung stated the company is open to considering better offers than Keppel's for a potential sale. The digital economy in South-east Asia is expected to reach $175 billion in 2021, with a projected value of $1 trillion by 2030. Asean fintech funding reached a record high of $3.5 billion in the 9 months of 2021. Singapore-based startups raised $11.2 billion in the 9 months of 2021, more than double the amount in 2020. Crypto exchange Huobi Global plans to close Singapore accounts by March 2022.

site_title: Freehold Cairnhill 16 to launch for sale, prices start at S$2,789 psf
summary: CAIRNHILL 16, a luxury freehold development in Singapore's District 9, is set to launch for sale on Nov 27 with prices starting at S$2,789 psf. The 15-storey tower features 39 units, ranging from 775 to 1,744 sq ft, with indicative prices starting at S$2.2 million for a two-bedroom unit. The project aims for Green Mark GoldPlus certification and is near key MRT stations, schools, and amenities. Developers expect demand for luxury properties to increase as Singapore transitions to endemic living.

site_title: Asset managers flock to Singapore's new corporate structure: MAS
summary: More than 400 variable capital companies (VCCs) have been set up or re-domiciled in Singapore since the new corporate structure was launched in 2020, cementing the city-state's position as a financial hub. The framework has attracted over 300 Singapore-based global and regional asset managers, with assets under management in Singapore rising 17% in 2020 to S$4.7 trillion. The VCC structure has proven popular across various asset managers, including family offices, hedge funds, and private equity, amid growing political uncertainty in rival hub Hong Kong.

site_title: Indonesia, Malaysia to start phased travel corridor
