summary: Malaysia and Indonesia plan to establish a phased travel corridor, allowing fully-vaccinated travelers to fly between Kuala Lumpur International Airport and Jakarta and Bali, starting early next year. The arrangement prioritizes travelers for official, business, medical, or humanitarian reasons. This move aims to balance economic revival with public health safety, following similar agreements in other Southeast Asian countries, including Singapore and Thailand.

site_title: BOT holds policy rate, says economy in recovery
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, left its key interest rate unchanged at 0.50% for a 12th straight meeting, as the country tries to revive its tourism sector. The decision was made in an effort to restart tourism, which reopened to vaccinated visitors without quarantine requirements on November 1. The unanimous vote was expected by economists, who polled 21 economists by Reuters. The decision aims to stimulate the economy, which is in recovery.

site_title: Five challenges for Singapore's continued economic recovery
summary: Singapore's economic recovery is expected to continue in 2022, but challenges remain, including inflationary pressures, a labour market divergence, and ongoing Covid-19 flare-ups. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned of potential disruptions to supply chains and border reopening efforts due to global health concerns. Geopolitical risks, such as the ongoing trade war between the US and China, also pose a threat to business confidence. To address these challenges, the MAS is working to ensure a smooth transition to a more sustainable and inclusive economy.

site_title: STI extends losses, falls 0.37% as it takes cue from Wall Street's overnight losses
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.37% on Nov 10, extending losses for the second straight day, as regional bourses were weighed down by Wall Street's overnight losses and China's crisis-hit real estate sector. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,231.32, with key gauges in Japan, China, South Korea, Australia, and Malaysia closing in negative territory. China's elevated consumer inflation and factory gate prices for October, as well as concerns over US consumer price index data, also contributed to the market's decline, with analysts citing China's property sector as the main driver of Asian sentiment.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall for third day as miners drag on China worries
summary: Australian shares fell for a third consecutive day, down 0.14% at 7,423.9, due to mining stocks being dragged by iron ore price plunges amid China's worsening liquidity crisis. The Australian metals and mining index shed 1.9%, with BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue also declining. Energy stocks tumbled 1.1%, while the financials sector edged up 0.7%. National Australia Bank led gains, soaring 4.4% after brokerages raised their price targets.

site_title: Xi to participate in Apec meetings via video link
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will participate in and speak at a video link meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) leaders on Friday, focusing on regional economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The meeting, hosted by New Zealand, will emphasize supply chain support and decarbonizing economies. Additionally, Xi will deliver a keynote address to an Apec business leaders meeting on November 11.

site_title: Singapore to host Apec Business Advisory Council meeting in February
summary: Singapore will host the first 2022 meeting of the Apec Business Advisory Council (Abac) in February, marking a return to in-person meetings after two years of virtual sessions. The meeting will bring together business leaders and officials from 21 Apec economies to discuss regional economic integration, sustainability, and digital issues. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend the virtual Apec CEO Summit and deliver a keynote speech on digital disruption. The Abac Report presented at the meeting includes 43 recommendations for Apec leaders, focusing on border reopening, travel regimes, and knowledge sharing.

site_title: Oil drillers Noble and Maersk in US$3.4b merger
summary: Noble Corporation and Maersk Drilling are merging in a $3.4 billion deal to form one of the world's largest offshore oil drilling rig companies. The combined entity will be headquartered in Houston, Texas, with ownership split 50-50 between the two companies' existing shareholders. Annual cost savings of $125 million are expected, and Noble CEO Robert Eifler will become the CEO of the merged business. The merger will lead to job losses to deliver cost cuts, but also create a larger and stronger company with future growth opportunities.

site_title: Temasek-backed PharmEasy's owner files for 62.5b rupee India IPO
summary: API Holdings, owner of India's largest online pharmacy PharmEasy, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise up to 62.5 billion rupees (S$1.1 billion). The company, backed by TPG and Temasek Holdings, joins a record year for first-time share sales in India, with $12.3 billion raised so far. This marks the latest listing in a market rally, where the benchmark index has more than doubled since 2020.

site_title: ComfortDelGro ditches IPO plans for Australian unit
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport operator, is abandoning its initial public offering (IPO) plans for its Australian subsidiary ComfortDelGro Corporation Australia. The decision comes due to challenging market conditions and a shift in strategic priorities. The company had initially planned to list ComfortDelGro Australia by the end of the year, but will instead focus on growing its business through mergers and acquisitions, contract renewals, and new contract tenders. The withdrawal of the IPO is not expected to have a material impact on the company's operations or financials.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.74% on Wednesday, driven by a rally in tech firms, reversing morning losses. The Hang Seng Index ended at 24,996.14, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices eased. This follows a broader market trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: A Singapore-based retail trader reportedly amassed a US$7 billion position in Tesla without much attention, sparking questions about how this occurred. The outcome of International Plaza's CBD Incentive Scheme bid has implications for a S$2.7 billion collective sale tender. Proposed changes to CPF top-up and payout procedures will automatically disburse savings to members whose Retirement Account savings run dry. In other news, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower for fourth day
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed lower for a fourth straight session, down 0.61% or 178.68 points to 29,106.78, amid US shares dropping on inflation worries. The broader Topix index slid 0.54% or 10.81 points to 2,007.96. This follows a global market trend, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: China property stocks rally on hopes of potential easing of refinancing
summary: China's property stocks rallied on Nov 10, driven by hopes that Beijing may ease refinancing for developers to prevent a property market hard landing. The National Association of Financial Market Institutional Investors (NAFMII) hosted a meeting with developers to discuss financing issues, signaling potential policy changes. Analysts expect new policies in Q4 this year and Q1 next year to create a better business environment for real estate companies. Shares of developers such as Aoyuan, Agile, and Shimao rose 8-18% in mainland and Hong Kong trading, with analysts predicting benefits for firms with high-quality properties.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain at open as investors track inflation data
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose slightly at the start of trading on Wednesday, driven by investors tracking inflation data. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2% to 7,289.60 points, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose 0.1% each. Global inflation is surging, with China's factory-gate inflation hitting a 26-year high in October and the US revealing high wholesale prices. Economies reopening following pandemic lockdowns are contributing to the inflation surge.

site_title: BT Explains: Keppel's counter offer for SPH
summary: Keppel Corp has raised its offer for Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to S$2.351 per share, comprising S$0.868 cash, 0.596 Keppel Reit units, and 0.782 SPH Reit units. The revised offer is in response to a rival bid from a consortium of companies, including Hotel Properties and Temasek-linked entities, which offered S$2.10 per share. SPH's CEO Ng Yat Chung stated that Keppel's final offer is currently the best on the table, but the company will consider superior offers until November 16.

site_title: Bookings for Singapore-KL flights spike despite lack of VTL flight details
summary: Bookings for flights between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur have surged after the announcement of the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme, with a 17-fold increase in search volumes for flights on Expedia, and a double-digit percentage growth in bookings on Traveloka. The VTL will feature 6 daily flights between Changi Airport and Kuala Lumpur International Airport, with talks ongoing to extend the scheme to land checkpoints. Malaysians in Singapore are hopeful that the eased border restrictions will be extended, with some expressing concern over expensive ticket prices and others welcoming the opportunity for families to reunite.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li's FWD considers shifting US IPO to Hong Kong: sources
summary: Asian insurer FWD Group, controlled by Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li, is considering shifting its planned US$2-3 billion initial public offering (IPO) from the US to Hong Kong due to delays by US regulators and lackluster investor interest. The company has faced questions from the Securities and Exchange Commission on its mainland China ties, prompting it to reconsider its market debut. The decision comes as FWD awaits approval from US regulators, which has been delayed, and amid concerns that approval may not be granted before the end of the year.

site_title: TPG-backed Nykaa soars in India market debut to 954.4b rupee valuation
summary: Nykaa, a fashion e-commerce platform backed by TPG, made its India market debut, listing at a 79.4% premium to its offer price. The company, valued at 954.37 billion rupees (S$17.33 billion), saw its shares open at 2018 rupees, drawing bids worth US$32.55 billion. The strong investor demand signals a profitable startup with a broad appeal among Indian consumers, run by famous celebrities like Alia Bhatt and Katrina Kaif.

site_title: Australia to set up A$1b fund to develop low-emissions technology
summary: Australia plans to establish a A$1 billion fund to invest in low-emissions technology, aiming to cut carbon emissions and meet net-zero targets by 2050. The federal government will commit A$500 million, matched by private investors, to support early-stage companies in carbon capture and storage technologies. The move has been met with opposition from Labor, which opposes diverting renewable energy funding to CCS. Industry bodies have also expressed concerns that the fund will hinder the development of more effective low-emissions solutions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 1-month low as tech shares, China data weigh
summary: South Korean shares fell to a 1-month low on November 10, closing down 1.09% at 2,930.17. The decline was driven by tech shares, including a sharp drop in Tesla, and concerns over China's inflation data and potential US interest rate hikes. Foreign investors sold 20.7 billion won worth of shares, while the won weakened and bond yields fell. The benchmark Kospi has now fallen for three consecutive days.

site_title: Gold eases off 2-month peak as US dollar rises
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to US$1,827.05 per ounce, easing off a 2-month peak, as the US dollar rose. The dollar index edged up 0.1%, increasing gold's cost to buyers holding other currencies. US producer prices increased in October, suggesting high inflation could persist. Euro zone inflation is expected to fall below 2% late next year, prompting the European Central Bank to prepare for a less benign scenario.

site_title: Singapore-based startups raise S$11.2b in 9M 2021, more than double the whole of 2020
summary: Singapore's startups raised S$11.2 billion in the first 9 months of 2021, more than doubling the S$5.5 billion raised in 2020. This marks a healthy sign of recovery, with the city-state remaining the top destination for startup investments in South-east Asia. The growth is attributed to the booming South-east Asian market driven by increasing internet usage and a growing middle class. Enterprise Singapore plans to strengthen international connections and talent pool to support the growth of tech unicorns, including Ninja Van, PatSnap, and Nium, which have benefited from the region's fast-growing digital economy.

site_title: Singles' Day, housing policies and other ways to recognise contributions of singles
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) have released the PLH model, aiming to keep public housing in prime locations affordable and inclusive for Singaporeans. Singles, who must be at least 35 years old and have a household income of S$7,000 or less, can buy three-room and larger flats directly from HDB. However, resale of PLH flats is ring-fenced for eligible buyers, excluding singles. The government has assured single Singaporeans that they care about their housing needs, but critics argue that the policy may exacerbate oversubscription and price escalation of resale units.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents and leasing volumes rise in Oct as Singapore eases border measures
summary: Singapore's rental markets for HDB flats and private apartments saw a rise in rents and leasing volumes in October, driven by the easing of border measures and the expansion of Vaccinated Travel Lanes. Condo rents increased by 1.3% and 9.1% year-over-year, while HDB flat rents rose 0.2% and 8.3% year-over-year. Leasing volumes for condos and HDB flats increased by 10.1% and 8.2% respectively, with the suburbs accounting for 36.5% of total rental volume. Experts predict further increases in rents for both segments over the next 12 months.

site_title: Pfizer applies for Covid-19 vaccine approval for 5-11 year olds in Japan
summary: Pfizer has applied for approval to use its Covid-19 vaccine, Comirnaty, on children aged 5-11 in Japan, marking the first time the vaccine will be administered to children under 11. This follows the vaccine's approval for the general public in February. With about 74% of Japan's population fully vaccinated, the government is expected to start administering booster shots by year-end. Approval would make Pfizer's vaccine the first to be given to children under 11 in Japan, pending health ministry approval.

site_title: China should advance property tax legislation: think tank
summary: China's state think tank, the Development Research Center, urges the government to advance legislation for a proposed property tax, aiming to deter speculators and curb surging home prices. The pilot real estate tax will be rolled out in some regions, with the goal of raising the cost of holding property and slowing purchases. This move is seen as a key step to tame the once-unruly property market, which has created an affordability crisis. The think tank's head, Ma Jiantang, emphasizes that homes should be for living in, not for speculation.

site_title: South-east Asia's digital economy to top US$175b in 2021 despite pandemic: report
summary: South-east Asia's digital economy is projected to reach US$175 billion in 2021, exceeding the initial 2020 target of US$115 billion, driven by the pandemic and a growing population of smartphone users. By 2025, the region's online transactions are expected to reach US$360 billion and US$1 trillion by 2030. The number of online users in South-east Asia has surpassed 440 million, with 60 million people driven online during the pandemic, creating opportunities for startups in the digital economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets down as inflation concerns return to the fore
summary: Asian equities fell on Wednesday as inflation concerns resurfaced, with prices in the US and China surging. China's factory gate prices jumped 13.5% in October, the highest in over two decades, while US wholesale prices remained elevated. The news led to a hawkish stance from central banks, raising interest rates and paring financial support measures. Markets in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Tokyo were among the worst performers, with investors keeping an eye on the China Evergrande saga, which faces a deadline to pay interest on three bonds worth $148 million.

site_title: SATS commits over S$3m to invest in food startups and projects
summary: SATS has committed over S$3 million to invest in food startups and projects through its corporate venturing arm, with support from the Singapore Economic Development Board. This initiative aims to grow the company's non-travel food business, ideating, incubating, and growing innovative new business models. Projects with growth potential will become independent startups or be incorporated into SATS' main operations.

images.alt_text: Through corporate venturing, SATS will ideate, incubate and grow innovative new business models.

site_title: Hot stock: SingHaiyi hits 3.5-year high after Tangs' privatisation offer
summary: SingHaiyi shares hit a 3.5-year high after resuming trading, reaching S$0.118, a 9.3% increase from the previous day's close. The company received a voluntary conditional offer from investment holding company owners Gordon Tang and Celine Tang, offering S$0.117 per share in cash with a 21.8% discount to its net asset value. The offer aims to privatize the company, which reported a H1 FY2022 earnings of S$12.5 million, reversing a loss in the same period last year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts positive on Genting Singapore's FY2022 recovery as tourism opens up
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research, UOB Kay Hian, and RHB have expressed optimism on Genting Singapore's FY2022 recovery, despite the company's underperforming Q3 2021 financial results. The easing of travel restrictions and anticipation of returning international visitors are seen as positives. Analysts maintained their "buy" calls, with target prices remaining unchanged, while RHB lowered its target price to S$0.90. They expect Genting Singapore's Ebitda to recover to close to pre-crisis levels in FY2023, driven by a strong FY2022 recovery.

site_title: China factory-gate inflation hits record again
summary: China's factory-gate inflation reached a 26-year high in October, rising 13.5% year-over-year, according to official figures. This is the fourth consecutive month of rising factory-gate inflation, driven by high commodity prices and supply struggles due to China's environmental targets and the reopening from lockdowns. The producer price index (PPI) also hit a record high in September. Consumer inflation rose 1.5% year-over-year, driven by energy price increases and supply chain disruptions. The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the inflation to "imported global factors" and "tight supply of major domestic energy and raw materials."

site_title: Peter Jackson sells Weta Digital in US$1.6b 'metaverse' deal
summary: New Zealand film director Peter Jackson sold his Oscar-winning Weta Digital special effects business to Unity Software for US$1.6 billion. The acquisition aims to develop the virtual-reality "metaverse," a 3D version of the internet that will transform online interactions. Weta's technology, used in films like The Lord of the Rings and Avatar, will allow Unity Software subscribers to create ultra-realistic virtual worlds. The deal is seen as a significant step in shaping the future of the metaverse.

site_title: Hot stock: Cordlife jumps 25.9% on married deals
summary: Cordlife shares surged 25.9% to a high of S$0.535 on Wednesday, driven by three married deals at S$0.52 each. The deals were recorded at 10:10 am, 10:17 am, and 10:37 am. This is the first reported married deal for the company, according to ShareInvestor data.

images.alt_text: SHARES of Cordlife surged in early trade on Wednesday (Nov 10).

site_title: General Electric to split into 3 companies in latest restructuring
summary: General Electric (GE) announced it will split into three separate companies: GE Healthcare, which will be spun off in early 2023, and a new aviation-focused company, which will be spun off in early 2024. The remaining core of the company will focus on aviation, with GE retaining a 19.9% stake in GE Healthcare. The split aims to create three independently run businesses better positioned for long-term growth and value creation.

site_title: Singapore launches market access programme with South Korea for bilateral business partnerships
summary: Singapore has launched a market access programme with South Korea, Rainmaking Expand Korea, allowing Singapore startups and SMEs to tap into Korean government programmes and partnerships to expand. The programme, announced by Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng, aims to facilitate cross-border partnerships and strengthen Singapore's position as a hub in Southeast Asia. This complements existing efforts, such as the K-Startup Centre, and is seen as a step to invigorate the ecosystems in both countries.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened lower on Wednesday, dropping 0.20% to 29,227.27, following US shares' decline due to inflation worries. The broader Topix index eased 0.01% to 2,018.62.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off with a loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.10% loss, dipping 25.69 points to 24,787.44, following a retreat in New York and concerns over the Evergrande crisis. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, easing 0.23% and 0.30% respectively. Investors are keeping tabs on the Evergrande crisis, which has a fresh interest payment deadline looming.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares began with small losses on Wednesday (Nov 10) following a retreat in New York while investors were keeping tabs on developments in the Evergrande crisis with the troubled property giant facing a fresh interest payment deadline.

site_title: China Evergrande's EV unit plans HK$500m share sale for vehicles production
summary: China Evergrande's electric vehicle unit, China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group, plans to sell HK$500 million worth of shares to fund new energy car production. The sale involves 174.83 million new shares, representing 1.76% of the enlarged share capital, at HK$2.86 per share. The funds will support the production of vehicles, including those made by its Hengchi brand. This move aims to support the company's expansion in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Wednesday, down 0.83 points or 0.05% to 1,523.20. The index saw a significant volume of 363.13 million lots worth RM177.62 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 227 to 177.

site_title: Facebook parent to take politics, race out of ad targeting
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, will stop allowing ads to be targeted at users based on sensitive topics such as race, religion, or politics, starting January 19. The change aims to prevent advertisers from abusing targeting options and comes amid concerns about abuse and the company's response to allegations of discriminatory practices. The move may negatively impact some businesses and organizations, but Meta says it is necessary to address feedback from civil rights experts and policymakers.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars lean on chart support after another setback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars faced setbacks, with the Aussie at US$0.7370 and the kiwi at US$0.7120, after failing to hold gains and testing chart supports. The Aussie dropped 0.6% to test US$0.7360, while the kiwi fell 0.5% after failing at US$0.7365. These movements leave the currencies vulnerable to further declines, with the Aussie potentially breaching support at US$0.7360 and the kiwi facing a retreat to US$0.7320.

site_title: Valuetronics H1 profit drops 38.1% to HK$56.6m amid global electronic components shortage
summary: Valuetronics reported a 38.1% drop in net profit to HK$56.6 million for the first half of 2021 due to a severe global electronic components shortage. Revenue declined 7.3% to HK$1 billion, with the consumer electronics segment falling 12.5% year-over-year. The company expects the shortage to affect its near-term performance but remains optimistic about its expansion plan in Vietnam, which is on track for mass production by end-FY2022.

site_title: Hatten Land enters JV to manage solar panel facilities in Malaysia
summary: Hatten Land is forming a joint venture with Nestcon to manage solar panel facilities in Malaysia, including the installation of 6,000 solar panels on the roof of Dataran Pahlawan Melaka Megamall. The JV aims to generate 3,900 megawatt-hours per year, equivalent to powering 1,100 3-room flats. The agreement is part of Hatten Land's strategy to repurpose malls for digital and blockchain activities, including cryptocurrency mining enabled by renewable energy.

site_title: Unity to buy Lord of the Rings VFX studio Weta Digital in US$1.63b deal
summary: Unity Software agreed to buy Weta Digital, a visual effects studio known for its work in movies such as Godzilla vs Kong and Avatar, in a US$1.63 billion cash-and-stock deal. The acquisition will help Unity tap into Weta Digital's technology and talent to develop VFX tools and focus on metaverse opportunities. Weta Digital, founded by film director Peter Jackson, has won several Academy and Bafta Awards and is known for its animated characters such as Gollum and Caesar. The deal aims to expand Unity's capabilities in VFX and metaverse development.

site_title: US sets goal of net-zero aviation emissions by 2050
summary: The US has set a goal to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions from the aviation sector by 2050, with Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg announcing the plan. This aligns with President Joe Biden's target of making the US net carbon neutral by 2050. The plan includes the use of sustainable aviation fuel, new aircraft technologies, and increasing operations efficiency to reduce emissions. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) supports the goal, and Airlines for America has committed to working with the government to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment edges up in Nov, jobs outlook brightens
summary: Australian consumer sentiment rose 0.6% in November, surpassing worries about personal finances, as optimism on the economy improved. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index showed a shift in employment expectations to historic highs, with confidence levels at record levels. The economic outlook for the next 12 months and five years also improved, while family finances fell 4.5% and the index of buying major household items declined 7.8%. Consumers remain cautious about spending, but determined to maintain spending levels, with 26% expecting to spend less and 10% planning to spend more during the Christmas season.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Valuetronics, PropNex, Hatten Land, Genting Singapore
summary: ST Engineering reported S$1.8 billion in new contracts for Q3 FY2021, bringing its order book to over S$18 billion. Valuetronics Holdings saw a 38.1% drop in net profit to HK$56.6 million (S$9.8 million) due to electronic component shortages. PropNex reported a 113.2% improvement in bottom line and a doubling of revenue for its fiscal third quarter. Genting Singapore's net profit grew 11% to S$60.7 million for the third quarter.

site_title: Macron says France to relaunch construction of nuclear reactors
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that France will relaunch the construction of nuclear reactors to meet growing energy and environmental challenges. Macron stated that the goal is to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and ensure energy independence. France currently has one new third-generation EPR nuclear reactor under construction, but Macron vowed to continue developing renewable energy. The government will also invest in carbon-free energy production on French soil.

site_title: US judge denies Trump bid to block Jan 6 select committee investigation
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that the House of Representatives' Jan 6 select committee can access some of former President Donald Trump's White House records, rejecting Trump's argument that telephone records and documents are protected by executive privilege. The committee sought documents related to the January 6 attack on the US Capitol. The judge's decision allows the committee to access some of the requested materials, but the outcome of the investigation remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the opening of Wednesday, Nov 10, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 3.73 points to 3,239.69. The decline followed Wall Street's pullback overnight, ending a streak of record-setting sessions. HGH Holding rose 9.4% after entering a non-binding memorandum of understanding with AAEX, while Hatten Land rose 3.2% after forming a joint venture with Nestcon. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC were also affected, with DBS and UOB slipping, while OCBC climbed 0.4%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip from record highs after 8-day bull run
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2% lower, retreating from record highs after an 8-day bull run. Insurers and bank stocks declined, while basic resources stocks fell 1.1%. Renault rose 3.8% after Nissan's quarterly profit and full-year forecast hike. Investors await economic data, including inflation and industrial production data, for fresh cues. Despite concerns, profit margins are expected to remain elevated, supporting the bull market.

site_title: White House channels infrastructure funds to snarled ports
summary: The White House is redirecting $4 billion from the recently passed $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill to alleviate congestion at US ports, which have been causing delays and shortages of goods amid the global supply chain snarls. The funds will be allocated to modernize port and inland waterway projects within the next 60 days, and the government will also invest $240 million in improving capacity nationwide. The move aims to address the issues ahead of the Christmas shopping season, with President Biden's approval ratings facing challenges due to rising inflation.

site_title: Oil rises on higher demand forecasts, tight supplies
summary: Oil prices rose to a two-week high on Tuesday, driven by higher demand forecasts and tight supplies. The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) projected retail gasoline prices would decline over the next several months, prompting the Biden administration to consider releasing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Brent futures rose 1.6% to $84.78 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose 2.7% to $84.15. Despite tight global supplies, analysts forecast US crude inventories to rise, potentially capping further price gains.

site_title: US: Wall Street pulls back, ending record streak
summary: US stocks ended a record-breaking streak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, Nasdaq Composite Index, and S&P 500 declining 0.3%, 0.6%, and 0.4%, respectively. The drop was attributed to traders digesting high US inflation, which remains a concern for investors. Analysts expect the market to experience a technical correction due to being overbought. The producer price index rose 8.6% in October, fueling inflation concerns.

site_title: Governments in Asia can help digitalisation and decarbonisation flourish together
summary: Governments in Asia-Pacific and Japan are collaborating with the private sector to accelerate digitalization and decarbonization, with a focus on sustainable IT, renewable energy, and green business opportunities. Net-zero carbon goals are being set ahead of the 2050 Paris Agreement target, with countries like Australia, Japan, and South Korea making declarations. Governments are providing incentives, funding, and investments in green skills and research and development to support sustainable innovation. Companies like Amazon are also investing in low-carbon solutions and partnering with startups to drive climate action, with over 200 signatories to the Climate Pledge committing to net-zero carbon by 2040.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood falls to 7-month low in November: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japanese manufacturers' business confidence fell to a 7-month low in November due to ongoing supply shortages, with the sentiment index among manufacturers dropping to 13 from 16 in October. However, sentiment in the services sector improved, rising to a 3-month high of 1, driven by easing coronavirus curbs. Despite concerns about supply issues and commodity inflation, manufacturers became more optimistic about their outlook, with the three-month forward-looking reading rising to 19. The services sector also showed improved sentiment, with a 3-month outlook also rising to 15.

site_title: Pelosi, AOC tell COP26 'America is back' on climate
summary: US congressional Democrats, led by Nancy Pelosi and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, told COP26 that "America is back" on climate action, vowing to lead on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The statement comes as the US seeks to repair its damaged credibility after withdrawing from the Paris Agreement under Donald Trump. Pelosi and Ocasio-Cortez emphasized the importance of passing the Build Back Better bill, which includes billions for climate resilience measures, to restore US credibility and meet the moment to address climate change.

site_title: Sheraton Towers Singapore Hotel donates S$15,000 to BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: Sheraton Towers Singapore Hotel has donated S$15,000 to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF), a programme supporting beneficiaries from The Little Arts Academy and 10 Square Youth to showcase their work and talent. This donation marks the hotel's collaboration with BT BAF since 2019. The Budding Artists Fund, initiated in 2004, aims to provide arts opportunities to children with limited financial resources. The donation will support the development of beneficiaries' talents through various projects, including music performances.

site_title: Duterte's daughter quits mayor's race as Philippine election deadline looms
summary: Sara Duterte-Carpio, the daughter of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, has withdrawn from the mayoral race in Davao City, just days before the election deadline. She cited no reason for her decision, but announced her brother Sebastian will run instead. This move comes despite her popularity and her father's influence in the region. The deadline to change candidates for the presidential election in May 2022 expires on November 15. Duterte-Carpio had previously expressed interest in forging an alliance with Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr. for the presidential election.

site_title: Nasa pushes back crewed Moon landing to 2025 or later
summary: NASA has pushed back its crewed Moon landing to 2025 or later, citing development delays and a court case with Blue Origin. The original target of 2024 was set by the Trump administration, but the Artemis programme has faced numerous delays. The agency is now targeting a first uncrewed mission in February 2022, followed by a crewed mission in 2024. NASA expects to require more funding from Congress to meet the new timelines, amid competition with China's rapidly advancing space programme.

site_title: Biden-Xi virtual meeting planned for as soon as next week: source
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are set to hold a virtual meeting as soon as next week, according to a source. The meeting aims to prevent the relationship between the two biggest economies from spiraling toward conflict. The US and China have agreed in principle to hold the meeting, with working-level discussions underway to confirm details. Experts expect the two sides to work toward agreements on visa relaxation and reopening of consulates, although these are not being discussed ahead of the meeting.

site_title: IPOs: SPACs are fine, but keep attracting local home-grown firms
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced new listing rules to allow special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) in the local market, amid a global increase in SPACs over the past 2 years. This move aims to attract more capital for local companies, following a disappointing 2021 with only 4 new IPOs of home-grown firms. SGX officials acknowledge the challenges of competing with international peers, but emphasize the need to balance the entry of SPACs with the capital raising needs of local small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Open collaboration, non-dilutive funding can nurture more homegrown biotechs
summary: Singapore's biotech industry has gained global recognition due to increased open collaboration and sharing of information, particularly during the pandemic. This collaboration has enabled researchers to access critical data points, such as genomic sequencing data, to develop in-vitro diagnostics and vaccines. However, biotech startups in Singapore still require more non-dilutive funding support to commercialize their discoveries and overcome the "valley of death" between lab bench and market. Experts, including Professor Jackie Ying and Thomas Coffman, emphasized the need for sufficient funding and support structures to enable startups to succeed.

site_title: Marie Antoinette's bracelets dazzle at auction
summary: Marie Antoinette's 112 old-cut diamond bracelets sold for over US$8 million at a Christie's auction in Geneva, exceeding their estimated value of 2-4 million Swiss francs. The bracelets, made in 1776, feature her "glamour, glory and drama" and have a "unique aesthetics of Versailles: opulent and regal, yet youthful and romantic." The royal provenance is impeccable, with a line of heritage unbroken and traceable from 1776 onwards. The sale marks a significant milestone for collectors, with the first bid reaching five million francs, a testament to the historical significance and value of the iconic pieces.

site_title: OK Lim's wife claiming half-share of S$33.4m GCB sale proceeds
summary: Tan Sook Eng, the wife of Lim Oon Kuin, is suing the liquidators of Hin Leong Trading, claiming a 50% interest in a S$33.39 million Good Class Bungalow sale proceeds. She filed an originating summons on Oct 20, naming the firm and its liquidators as defendants. This comes after Lim's death in 2020, amidst a scandal surrounding the oil trader.

site_title: PropNex net profit rises 113.2% in Q3
summary: PropNex, a real estate agency, reported a 113.2% increase in net profit to S$14.4 million in its fiscal third quarter, up from S$6.8 million in the same period last year. Revenue also doubled to S$29.3 million. The company's earnings per share rose to S$0.0389, up from S$0.0183 in the year-ago period.

images.alt_text: PropNex reported a 113.2 per cent improvement in its bottom line for its fiscal third quarter together with a doubling of its revenue, it said in an exchange filing on Wednesday morning.

site_title: China's self-isolation is a global concern
summary: China's president Xi Jinping has been criticized for his self-imposed isolation following the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to strict border controls and quarantines. The country has become increasingly anomalous, affecting international business and global cooperation. Experts argue that China's zero-COVID policies risk becoming a trap, and the country's isolation may have long-term effects on the Chinese people and the global economy. With China's leadership potentially welcoming this trend, the world may encounter a significantly changed country when it eventually opens up.

site_title: Accounting for a hopeful world
summary: World leaders at the 2021 UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) are working towards a comprehensive global baseline for sustainability disclosures, aiming to keep the 1.5 degrees Celsius goal alive. The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB), part of the IFRS Foundation, will develop these standards, which will include disclosure requirements on companies' impacts on sustainability matters. The ISSB has received endorsements from G20 leaders and the Financial Stability Board, and has published prototype climate and general disclosure requirements. This move aims to provide a unified framework for sustainability reporting, building on the success of the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) in standard-setting.

site_title: The dogs of the stock market
summary: The article discusses the importance of focusing on the underlying businesses (the "lady") in the stock market, rather than just the stock prices (the "dog"). It cites examples of successful investors, such as Warren Buffett and Ralph Wagner, who have consistently outperformed the market by investing in businesses that are growing and thriving despite various economic challenges. The article concludes that investors should focus on the long-term progress and resilience of humanity, rather than getting caught up in short-term market fluctuations, and that this approach can lead to sustained investment success.

site_title: Apec ministers pledge recovery support, seek to curb fishing, farm subsidies
summary: APEC ministers pledged to sustain economic recovery from the pandemic while pursuing talks to curb fisheries and agriculture subsidies at the WTO. They committed to maintaining policy support measures, preserving financial stability, and reducing vaccine costs. The ministers also agreed to facilitate trade in medical supplies, ensure safe travel, and work towards a favorable trade environment. They will engage constructively at the WTO's 12th ministerial meeting to modernize trade rules and deliver concrete results, including curbs on harmful fisheries subsidies and substantial reductions in agricultural support and protection.

site_title: As we live longer, yield-fixated investors need to watch out for inflation
summary: Singaporeans living longer face a challenge of sufficient passive income to fund their lifestyle. With low interest rates, fixed deposits may earn less than 1% annual interest. To hedge against inflation, investors should consider balancing yield with growth. As Singapore's population ages, the need for diversified investments and income streams becomes increasingly important.

site_title: ST Engineering secures over S$1.8b in new contracts for Q3
summary: ST Engineering secured over S$1.8 billion in new contracts for Q3 FY2021, bringing its order book to over S$18 billion. The company reported a 27% increase in revenue for its commercial aerospace business to S$607 million, driven by international flights and maintenance, repair, and overhaul recovery. ST Engineering expects to deliver S$1.9 billion worth of orders in the remaining months of 2021, on track to achieve its S$180 million cost savings target.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering expects S$1.9 billion worth of orders to be delivered in the remaining months of 2021.

site_title: HSBC exceeds hiring targets for China retail wealth business
summary: HSBC has exceeded its hiring targets for its Chinese retail wealth management business and is exploring re-entering India's private banking market. The bank plans to boost its mobile wealth planning service in China and increase its presence in Asia, with a focus on Singapore and South-east Asia. As part of its strategy to become Asia's top wealth manager by 2025, HSBC is investing US$3.5 billion in its wealth and personal banking business.

site_title: Why the inflation outlook matters
summary: Investors are concerned about inflation's impact on equity markets, as it can lead to different outcomes and reduce the status of government bonds as safe-havens. The US and UK are currently experiencing high inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to unwind pandemic-era stimulus. Three scenarios are possible: inflation subsiding gradually, the Fed hiking rates aggressively, or inflation remaining high, leading to significant interest rate hikes and recession. To diversify, investors may consider alternatives like gold, commodities, private credit, and private real estate assets, as traditional government bonds become less attractive due to low yields.

images.alt_text: We balance an overweight allocation to equities with an increased allocation to alternative assets, such as gold, commodities, private credit and private real estate, to capture different sources of return.

site_title: PBOC gives banks cheaper funding for loans to green firms
summary: China's central bank, the PBOC, has announced a new policy to offer cheaper funding to banks that lend to green firms, aiming to support companies in clean energy, energy-saving, and environment-friendly sectors. The PBOC will lend 60% of required funds at 1.75% interest, with banks using the money to provide loans at a higher rate. The move is part of China's efforts to reduce carbon emissions and meet President Xi Jinping's pledge to make China carbon neutral by 2060.

site_title: China tightens use of property proceeds as Fed sees risks
summary: China has tightened oversight of property proceeds, deepening a cash crunch for developers. Major cities such as Beijing, Tianjin, and Shijiazhuang, as well as smaller municipalities, have issued rules requiring developers to deposit presale proceeds into government-supervised bank accounts before accessing them. This move aims to ensure timely project completion and delivery, but may worsen cash shortages and debt repayment challenges for developers. The measures follow a nationwide government crackdown on speculation and leverage in China's property industry, which has been suffering from a severe downturn.

images.alt_text: Cities including Beijing (above) have issued rules aimed at ensuring timely completion of developments amid a severe downturn in the nation's real estate market.

site_title: Can we research our way to zero carbon?
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) is urging governments to approve a $5 billion research and development (R&D) fund to accelerate the development of zero-emission technologies for the shipping industry. The fund, paid for by shipowners through a levy on bunker purchases, is necessary to meet the industry's 2050 net-zero carbon target. Industry leaders have showcased initiatives to reduce reliance on carbon-heavy fuels, but concerns about scalability and the need for a global solution remain. Some experts, including ABS' chairman, have expressed skepticism about the need for the fund, citing the potential for carbon capture technology to significantly reduce emissions.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng wins S$320m contract to build Aviation Park MRT station, tunnels
summary: Hock Lian Seng Holdings won a S$320 million contract from the Land Transport Authority to design and construct the Aviation Park MRT station and tunnels in Changi, Singapore. Work on the project starts immediately. The contract is not expected to impact the group's financials for the 2021 financial year.

site_title: Why all the inflation worries?
summary: The US labor market is experiencing a "high-pressure" economy with a tight labor market, as indicated by a 3.7% increase in the Employment Cost Index (ECI) in the year to September. However, the ECI-basis real wage has fallen by 1.7% over the past year due to a 5.4% increase in consumer prices. This suggests that workers do not have enough bargaining power to secure real wage increases, contradicting the notion of a tight labor market.

site_title: How to think about the Covid recession
summary: The US is struggling to predict the end of the COVID-19 recession, with many economists turning to past recessions for guidance. However, the pandemic-induced economic collapse was unlike any previous recession, with unusual demand for physical goods and services, and a significant reversal of long-standing economic trends. The National Bureau of Economic Research declared a 2-month recession in 2020, but past business cycles do not provide useful lessons for the current situation. The recovery will depend on controlling the spread of the virus and the progress made against it, with significant implications for inflation, shortages, and long-term economic trends.

site_title: More young investors turning to SRS for retirement needs
summary: Young investors in Singapore are increasingly turning to the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) to build their retirement nest eggs. The share of 18- to 35-year-olds with SRS accounts has risen from 11% in 2015 to 19% in 2020. SRS accounts offer tax relief and can provide a steady income stream. Investors can contribute up to S$15,300 for Singaporeans and PRs, and S$35,700 for foreigners, with every dollar tax-deductible up to the annual tax relief cap of S$80,000. This trend highlights the growing importance of retirement planning among young Singaporeans.

site_title: Euro/US dollar treads water as traders wait for more clues
summary: The euro remained steady against the US dollar on Tuesday, trading at US$1.1587, as traders awaited US inflation data and central bank governors' speeches for clues on interest rate direction. The US dollar index also remained little moved at 94.001. Analyst Adam Cole expects the US dollar to gain traction as rate expectations converge, but notes that inflation data due out Wednesday will provide better direction. Meanwhile, the yen rose to a one-month high versus the US dollar, while sterling and the New Zealand dollar steadied despite rate hike concerns.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed after inflation data, GE surges on split
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened mixed on Tuesday after data showed a solid rise in producer prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.08%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, reaching fresh records. General Electric surged on its plan to split into three public companies.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: CapitaLand Investment Limited has established a S$6 billion Euro Medium Term Note Programme for refinancing and general corporate purposes. Econ Healthcare Group reported a 56% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$1.61 million for the six months ended Sept 30, 2021, despite a 1.6% increase in revenue. Shares in Econ Healthcare closed unchanged at 31 Singapore cents.

site_title: Barca's La Masia academy finally opens its doors to women
summary: Barcelona's La Masia football academy has finally opened its doors to female players, marking a significant milestone for women's football. The academy, renowned for producing talent such as Lionel Messi and Andres Iniesta, had previously only accepted male players. This season, 9 female players, including 18-year-old Claudia Riumallo Pineda, became the first female residents at La Masia. The move comes as the women's team, Barcelona Femeni, continues to achieve success, with captain Alexia Putellas nominated for the Women's Ballon d'Or.

site_title: Deutsche Bank gets another credit rating upgrade
summary: Deutsche Bank has received another credit rating upgrade from Standard & Poor's, upgrading its long-term issuer credit and senior preferred debt ratings to "A-" from "BBB+". The bank's restructuring efforts, which include closing businesses and shedding staff, have led to its first full-year profit since 2014. This upgrade follows similar upgrades from Moody's and Fitch. The bank's CEO, Christian Sewing, stated that the recognition of its transformation progress by a leading rating agency is "very encouraging." The upgrade is expected to help Deutsche return to more sustainable profitability.

site_title: More can be done to elicit detailed director remuneration disclosures
summary: A Singapore Institute of Directors' (SID) report found that only 38% of listed companies disclosed detailed director remuneration, with 54% providing only band-based disclosure. The study also noted that smaller companies, particularly Catalist-listed companies, were less likely to provide detailed disclosures. The report suggests that regulators and investors should push for better disclosures, considering the need for added transparency to reduce perceptions of conflicts of interest and the lack of effectiveness in deterring executive movements.

site_title: A primer on sustainable funds: Approaches vary
summary: Sustainable investing has become mainstream in Singapore, with investors seeking to align portfolios with their values and mitigate climate risk. Various approaches exist, including exclusionary, norms-based, portfolio tilting, thematic ESG, impact investments, ESG integration, and engagement and shareholder action. However, distinguishing between genuine sustainability efforts and greenwashing remains a challenge. Regulators in Europe and Singapore have taken steps to increase transparency, and asset managers are being asked to provide more information to support their ESG claims. Despite the challenges, sustainable investing is expected to continue growing, with US$25.2 trillion in assets committed to ESG integration globally.

site_title: Bitcoin, Ether hit new highs amid ongoing rally
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time record of US$68,513, with Ether also hitting a new high at US$4,840. The total value of digital tokens tracked by CoinGecko reached US$3.1 trillion. Analysts attribute the rally to the search for investments to hedge against inflation and record-low real yields. The cryptocurrency market has been volatile, with Bitcoin plummeting below US$30,000 in June and recovering since China's crackdown. Experts predict further gains for Bitcoin and other altcoins in the coming weeks, with some forecasting a "final push-up" before consolidation in the new year.

site_title: French retailer Carrefour steps up digital push
summary: French supermarket group Carrefour has pledged a 3-billion-euro investment between 2022 and 2026 to expand its digital commerce, aiming to triple its e-commerce gross merchandise value to 10 billion euros by 2026. The investment represents a 50% increase from previous years and will focus on express delivery, data, retail media, and digitalizing financial services to retain an edge over Amazon in the grocery market. The move is part of Chairman and CEO Alexandre Bompard's new strategy plan, aiming to transform Carrefour into a digital retail company.

site_title: China conducts combat readiness patrol as US lawmakers visit Taiwan
summary: China conducted a combat readiness patrol near the Taiwan Strait in response to a US Congressional delegation's visit to Taiwan. The patrol aimed to address "seriously wrong" words and actions regarding the Taiwan issue and pro-independence forces. This move follows recent rising tensions between China and Taiwan, with China claiming the self-ruled island as its own.

site_title: China developer Kaisa pleads for help, 'patience' as sector's debt woes mount
summary: China's 25th largest developer, Kaisa Group Holdings, is pleading for help to pay investors, workers, and suppliers due to mounting debt woes in the sector. The developer cited a deteriorating liquidity situation and urged state companies to help private firms improve liquidity through project acquisitions and strategic purchases. Kaisa attended a meeting with government think-tank, banks, and property firms, where it requested more breathing space and "patience" from investors. The developer's offshore debt exceeds Evergrande's, with Fitch downgrading Kaisa on Tuesday, citing liquidity concerns.

site_title: 3,397 new Covid-19 cases and 12 deaths; weekly infection growth rate at 0.82
summary: Singapore reported 3,397 new Covid-19 cases, with 12 deaths, on November 9, 2021. The weekly infection growth rate decreased to 0.82, down from 0.84 on Monday. The majority of new cases were in the community (3,222), with 513 cases above 60 years old. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 224,200. The death toll has reached 523, with underlying medical conditions being a factor in most cases.

site_title: Keppel raises SPH bid to S$2.351 a share, cash component up by 20 cents; says price is final
summary: Keppel Corp has raised its offer to privatize Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to S$2.351 per share, including an additional cash component of S$0.20 per share. This surpasses the rival bid from Cuscaden Peak at S$2.10 per share. The revised offer includes 0.596 Keppel Reit units and 0.782 SPH Reit units per share, valued at S$3.8 billion. SPH shareholders can expect to receive the final consideration by mid-January 2022, subject to regulatory approvals and shareholder approvals.

site_title: Integrated Shield: Dispute platform set up, insurers' doctor panels widened
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) have expanded their doctor panels to 500-600 private specialists by year-end, addressing a clash between doctors and insurers over IP coverage changes. A disputes platform, the Clinical Claims Resolution Process (CCRP), has been established to resolve clinically related claim disputes, including unfair rejection of claims and over-charging. The CCRP will handle an estimated 60-70 cases a year, with costs ranging from S$200,000 to S$400,000. Insurers have committed to ensuring their panels reach 500 specialists by end-2021, with 80-90% of claims to come from panelled providers.

site_title: Fed's Powell touts benefits of maximum employment
summary: Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the importance of maximum employment, stating that the US economy is healthier and stronger when as many people as possible are able to work. He noted that the Federal Reserve assesses maximum employment through a wide range of indicators, including labor market disparities, rather than just headline numbers. Powell's comments highlight the Fed's focus on achieving full employment, which benefits the overall economy and society.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as financials slide on National Australia Bank warning
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, down 0.24% at 7,434.2, due to a warning from National Australia Bank on margins, causing a 1% fall in bank stocks. Energy stocks slid 1% and mining stocks rose 1.4% on strong copper prices, while gold stocks climbed 0.7% after bullion prices reached a 2-month high.

site_title: Porsche 9-month profit jumps to low end of 2021 target thanks to Volkswagen
summary: Porsche reported a 9-month net income of 3.3 billion euros, exceeding last year's result by almost seven times, thanks to Volkswagen's profits. This surpasses the company's full-year guidance of 3.4-4.9 billion euros, bringing it to the lower end of the target range. The result is attributed to Volkswagen's recovery from a pandemic-related slump last year, with Porsche holding a 53.3% stake in the German automaker.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.38 points to 1,524.03. Volume was 3.105 billion lots worth RM2.392 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 653 to 311.

site_title: US wholesale prices may be accelerating again
summary: US wholesale prices rose 0.6% seasonally in October, accelerating from September's 0.1% increase, according to the Labor Department. This marks the same rate of increase as October 2020. Rising inflation is fueled by shortages of workers and components, with energy prices increasing 4.8% and transportation and warehousing prices rising 1.7%. Economists expect price pressures to peak in the fourth quarter before moderating in 2022, with the possibility of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates to contain inflation.

site_title: Stricter border restrictions for Singaporeans travelling to the EU
summary: The Council of the European Union has removed Singapore and Ukraine from a list of countries for which travel curbs should be lifted, effective immediately. This decision may lead to stricter border restrictions for Singaporeans traveling to the EU. Singapore had previously announced Vaccinated Travel Lanes with 10 EU countries, allowing for quarantine-free travel for fully vaccinated travelers. The EU's decision is based on the epidemiological situation, response to Covid-19, and data reliability, with the 27 EU countries responsible for implementing the new restrictions.

site_title: Snarled supply chain worsens US warehouse shortage
summary: The US warehouse shortage worsens due to a snarled global supply chain crisis, with record numbers of cargo ships waiting to unload at Southern California ports. The shortage forces logistics managers to scramble for space, with some companies building holiday displays in parking lots. The crisis is attributed to severe labor shortages, antiquated infrastructure, and free-spending US shoppers spurring an import surge. Warehouse owners are benefiting from skyrocketing rents, with rents increasing over 30% in some hot US markets, and companies are building new space to meet demand, with 800 million square feet needed for backup inventory.

site_title: WHO warns of shortage of 1-2 billion Covid vaccine syringes
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns of a potential shortage of 1-2 billion Covid-19 vaccine syringes in 2022, which could impact routine immunizations and undermine needle safety. The shortage, resulting from the high demand for vaccinations, may lead to delays in routine vaccinations, especially for children, and encourage the reuse of syringes and needles in poorer countries. WHO expert Lisa Hedman advises national health authorities to plan ahead to avoid "hoarding and panic buying" and to consider shifting production capacity to specialized immunization syringes.

site_title: Far East Orchard posts bigger net loss of S$12.6m for 9M FY21
summary: Far East Orchard reported a net loss of S$12.6 million for the 9M FY21, widening from S$6.3 million a year ago. Revenue declined 10.2% to S$75.4 million due to the pandemic's impact on its hospitality business in Australia. However, the company's PBSA business and government grants partially offset the losses. The group has a cash position of S$261.6 million and is targeting 25,000 rooms by 2025. Shares closed at S$1.12, up 0.9% on the day.

site_title: Riverstone Holdings reports 49 per cent rise in net profit for Q3FY21
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 49% year-over-year increase in net profit to RM266.4 million (S$86.4 million) for Q3FY21, driven by demand for its healthcare and high-tech cleanroom gloves. Revenue rose 35% to RM652.8 million, with a blended gross profit margin of 54.7%. The company has cash reserves of RM1.76 billion and is preparing for Phase 8 expansion plans, which will increase production capacity to 13.5 billion gloves by FY2022/2023. Despite near-term challenges, the CEO is optimistic about longer-term prospects for sustainable growth.

site_title: Oxley's exec director invests in co-living startup The Assembly Place
summary: Oxley Holding's executive director Eric Low See Ching led a S$5.5 million seed round investment in Singapore-based co-living startup The Assembly Place. Other investors included M+S CEO Kemmy Tan and angel investors. This funding round aims to support the growth of TAP, a co-living startup in the competitive Singapore market.

site_title: Chasen posts H1 earnings up 53% to S$1.6 million on higher revenue
summary: Chasen Holdings, a logistics group, posted earnings of S$1.6 million for the first half of 2021, a 53% increase from the same period last year. Revenue jumped 44% to S$84 million, driven by business recovery from the pandemic across all three business segments. The group secured several fresh contracts worth S$19.9 million and expects robust revenue from its 3PL segment. Despite a 2.7% decline in shares, managing director and CEO Low Weng Fatt expressed optimism for the coming quarters.

site_title: Food Empire's net profit halved to US$3.1m in Q3 on higher commodity, freight costs
summary: Food Empire's net profit for Q3 2021 fell 50.6% to US$3.1 million, despite an 8.8% increase in revenue to US$76.4 million. Higher commodity and freight costs, supply chain delays, and COVID-19 infections in Russia and Vietnam impacted the company's performance. Despite this, the group remains optimistic about its longer-term prospects and expects to fulfill its obligations.

site_title: OK Lim's wife claiming half-share of S$33.4m GCB sale proceeds
summary: OK Lim's wife, Tan Sook Eng, has taken legal action against the liquidators of Hin Leong Trading, claiming a 50% interest in a S$33.4 million GCB sold in October. She seeks 50% of the sale proceeds, arguing she's the owner of the property. The case is set to be heard on November 11, amidst the Hin Leong empire's liquidation due to a US$3.5 billion debt. Lim faces 130 charges of alleged fraudulent loans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close higher as healthcare stocks rebound
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.2% to 24,813.13, driven by a rebound in healthcare stocks that surged 5% after a sharp drop in the previous session. Analysts attribute the sector's recovery to adjustments, making it a buy opportunity. The Hang Seng index and China Enterprises Index also gained 0.1% each.

site_title: ExxonMobil announces FID for mega China petchem project
summary: ExxonMobil has made a final investment decision (FID) to build a multi-billion dollar petrochemical complex in south China's Guangdong province. The project, valued at an unspecified amount, will produce performance polymers used in various industries. Construction is underway, with a steam cracker expected to have a nameplate capacity of 1.6 million tonnes per year. The project is part of an initial agreement signed by ExxonMobil with China in 2018, and is the company's first wholly-owned petrochemical complex in China.

site_title: Valuers who fall short will continue to be taken to task: SGX Regco chief
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (RegCo) chief Tan Boon Gin stated that valuers who fall short will continue to be referred to their respective disciplinary bodies. This follows the enhancement of requirements on valuers in January, which aimed to raise the standard of property valuers and property valuations. Tan emphasized the need for improved communication, especially in virtual unitholder meetings, and highlighted the importance of disclosing letters of demand for substantial sums of money that could impact listed companies.

site_title: Europe: Equities subdued at open
summary: Europe's stock markets opened subdued on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index edging 0.1% lower to 7,296.11 points. The eurozone's Paris CAC 40 index reversed 0.3% to 7,025.31, while Frankfurt's DAX was almost flat. Despite gains elsewhere, traders paused ahead of key US inflation data, which has fueled fears.

site_title: India sparkles amid reforms and China's painful crackdown
summary: India's equity market has gained significant attention amid Chinese regulatory uncertainties and US-China tensions. The MSCI India Index has risen nearly 30% year-to-date, while the MSCI China Index has fallen 14%. India's strong performance is attributed to a recovery in earnings growth and strong growth in manufactured exports, particularly in the automotive sector. The country's IPO market has been particularly robust, with $10 billion raised this year, and an estimated 150 companies with $550 billion valuation potential awaiting listing. India's market capitalization is expected to increase to over $5 trillion by 2024, making it the 5th largest market by capitalization.

site_title: Hu An Cable says liquidation process hindered by insufficient funds
summary: Hu An Cable Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, is struggling to liquidate due to insufficient funds. The company, which had trading suspended since 2018, is considering raising funds to cover professional fees and other costs associated with the liquidation process. The board aims to appoint liquidation professionals by December 31, pending fund-raising efforts. This delay is partly due to the impending delisting of the company, which further complicates the process.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Integrated Shield insurers have committed to expanding their doctor panels to 500-600 private specialists by year-end. COE prices are expected to remain tight in 2022, with only 14,000 cars available for the 9-10 age group. October condo resale prices surged for the 15th consecutive month, with increases of 8.6% in the core central region and 9.4% in the out of central region. Mastercard launched a commercial Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) card for SMEs in Asia. Genting Singapore reported an 11% Q3 net profit despite lower revenue.

site_title: STI snaps 2-day winning streak, falls 0.63%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 20.48 points or 0.63% to 3,243.42 on Tuesday, snapping a two-day winning streak. The decline was attributed to profit-taking and lingering caution despite a record overnight close on Wall Street, driven by optimism over economic recovery and US President Biden's infrastructure spending. The STI had gained 3.6% in October, with shares of HGH Holdings and Prime US Reit making significant gains.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end little changed, US inflation data in focus
summary: South Korean stocks ended flat on Tuesday, despite record closing highs on Wall Street, as traders awaited US inflation data. The benchmark Kospi rose 2.26 points or 0.08% to 2,962.46. The won strengthened, while bond yields fell. Foreigners were net sellers of 137.8 billion won worth of shares. A dire shortage of urea solution threatened commercial transport and industries.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends down for third straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index fell for a third consecutive session on Nov 9, down 0.75% or 221.59 points to close at 29,285.46, due to a strong yen prompting profit-taking.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma to acquire Novem companies for S$16.3 million
summary: Hyphens Pharma has agreed to acquire Novem companies for S$16.3 million, adding over 40 brand principals and 1,000 active customers in Europe and Asia. Novem's product portfolio consists of over 150 generic medications and health supplements, covering diseases like cardiology, ophthalmology, and general surgery. The acquisition aims to augment Hyphens Pharma's current healthcare products and services.

images.alt_text: In a bourse filing on Tuesday (Nov 9), the pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare company announced a sale and purchase agreement that will add over 40 brand principals across Europe and Asia and over 1,000 active customers such as hospitals, general practitioners and specialists with the acquisition.

site_title: EC World Reit posts 19.7% increase in Q3 DPU to S$0.01662
summary: EC World Reit reported a 19.7% increase in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01662, up from S$1.388 cents in the year-ago period. Gross revenue rose 10.9% to S$31.6 million, while net property income (NPI) increased 9.4% to S$28.6 million. The Reit manager attributed the growth to positive straight-line adjustments and a strengthening Chinese renminbi. The total amount available for distribution was 15.2% higher at S$14.1 million, with a 20.3% increase in distribution to unitholders.

site_title: Citigroup raises record US$40b for ESG financing in Asia
summary: Citigroup raised a record US$40 billion for Asia-Pacific clients to finance sustainability projects in 2021, a sixfold increase from 2020. The bank aims to meet its global targets and help firms lower emissions. This surge in green financing is driven by increasing demand for environmental, social, and governance investing. Citigroup has committed to reducing its environmental footprint and offers benchmark indices to help investors transition portfolios towards ESG. The bank's efforts align with its US$1 trillion sustainable finance goal by 2030.

site_title: Taiwan says China can blockade its key harbours, warns of 'grave' threat
summary: Taiwan's defense ministry warns that China's armed forces can blockade the island's key harbors and airports, posing a "grave" military threat. China has been increasing military activity around Taiwan, including flying war planes into the island's air defense zone. In the past year, 554 Chinese war planes have made unauthorized intrusions into Taiwan's south-western theatre of air defense identification zone. The report highlights China's use of "gray zone" warfare, a strategy that falls short of a full-scale invasion but still poses a significant threat to Taiwan's security.

site_title: Duterte's daughter quits mayor race as Philippine election deadline looms
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's daughter, Sara Duterte-Carpio, has withdrawn from the mayoral race in Davao City, just days before the deadline to change candidates for the 2022 presidential election. She cited no reason for her decision, but announced her brother Sebastian will run instead. The 43-year-old has been a top contender for president, but has repeatedly stated she does not want the job. Her decision comes as she considers forging an alliance with presidential candidate Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr., who has urged her to be his running mate.

site_title: China property stress spurs Fed warning as bond losses widen
summary: The US Federal Reserve warned that China's property industry crisis could impact global financial markets and threaten world economic growth. A bond selloff has spread to China's entire real estate sector and beyond, echoing concerns about a potential Lehman moment. Regulators in Beijing had previously downplayed the crisis, but the Fed's explicit link to global markets highlights the growing risk. The US central bank's warning comes as China's property sector faces significant stress, with losses widening and concerns about the potential for a broader economic impact.

site_title: UOB customers can soon track their carbon footprint via new digital tool
summary: UOB is launching a digital tool to track customers' carbon footprints, providing personalized data based on spending and saving behavior. The feature, set to be made available to select customers in Singapore next year, will automatically calculate and benchmark a customer's carbon footprint using international benchmarks and locally adapted emission standards. The tool aims to educate customers on their impact and encourage sustainable lifestyle changes, complementing UOB's existing sustainable products.

site_title: SoftBank shares jump 11% on 1 trillion yen share buyback
summary: SoftBank Group announced a share buyback plan worth up to 1 trillion yen (S$11.9 billion), jumping 10.5% in its first trading session after the announcement. The move comes amid a decline in portfolio company shares and a regulatory crackdown in China, resulting in a 40% fall from its peak in May. SoftBank's net assets fell to US$187 billion, with a repurchase period set to run until November 8 next year. Analysts predict the buyback could provide support but also pose material downside risks if broader tech falters.

site_title: Ho Bee Land names new CEO, redesignates Chua Thian Poh as executive chairman
summary: Ho Bee Land appoints Nicholas Chua as its new CEO, effective January 2022, succeeding his father Chua Thian Poh, who will be redesignated as executive chairman. Nicholas Chua, current deputy CEO, will implement overall strategies and manage the group's development and investment portfolio. The company also announced the retirement of Desmond Woon as executive director, who will become a senior advisor. Chua's appointment is seen as part of the group's leadership succession planning, following his successful tenure as deputy CEO.

site_title: Chinese city offers cash for clues in Covid 'people's war'
summary: China's northern city of Heihe is offering 100,000 yuan (S$20,900) for clues in tracing the source of its latest Covid-19 outbreak, part of a "people's war" to combat the Delta-driven surge. The city has reported 43 local cases, linked to smuggling, hunting, and cross-border fishing, with millions under lockdown and domestic travel rules tightened. Critics of China's zero-Covid strategy, including virologist Guan Yi, are calling for better data and vaccine efficacy updates.

site_title: Temasek's Affinidi launches unit to increase Web 3.0 tech adoption among individuals, SMEs
summary: Temasek-founded Affinidi has launched a new business unit, Finnovate, to increase Web 3.0 technology adoption among underbanked individuals and under-served SMEs in Asean. The unit aims to provide decentralized financial services using protocols and verifiable credentials (VCs), enabling faster and more personalized financial transactions. Affinidi's technology will help address the lack of documentation as a key barrier to access banking, with the goal of creating a more inclusive financial ecosystem.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore blockchain plays to watch on SGX
summary: Singapore-listed companies are leveraging blockchain technology to diversify returns and achieve long-term growth. Recent moves include Joyas International Holdings' NFT market entry, Intraco's investment in MHC Digital Co, and HGH Holdings' exploration of a blockchain platform with AAEX. Other companies, such as Hatten Land, VCPlus, and Alset International, are also exploring blockchain opportunities. The Singapore government's recognition of blockchain's potential benefits and the growing popularity of NFTs and cryptocurrency are driving these investments.

images.alt_text: A few public-listed entities are linking up with the relevant technology players to extract value for both their companies and shareholders.

site_title: Netflix to roll out TikTok-like short clip feature aimed at kids
summary: Netflix is launching a TikTok-like feature called "Kids Clips" aimed at kids, with short videos from existing children's programs and movies. The feature, available on the iOS app, will show 10-20 clips daily and will begin rolling out in the US, Latin America, Canada, Australia, and Ireland. The move is part of Netflix's effort to attract younger viewers and expose them to more titles in its catalog. The feature will be tested and may be expanded based on user feedback.

site_title: Oceanus sets up unit to start warehouse service, distribution of frozen food
