summary: Oceanus Group, a food technology company, has set up a new wholly-owned subsidiary, Oceanus Tradelog, to expand into warehousing and logistics solutions. The unit aims to manage around 600,000 square feet of warehousing facilities and distribute frozen food products. Oceanus has secured distribution deals for frozen meat exports and a contract with Country Foods for warehousing and logistics services, expected to improve its financial performance over the next few years.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise after Wall Street record
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday after Wall Street hit a record, driven by optimism over the recovery outlook despite long-running inflation fears. The Fed's plan to withdraw financial support and cautiously raise interest rates boosted traders' mood. However, the Fed warned that a Covid surge or stalled recovery could reverse the market rally. Analysts also raised concerns about China's property crisis. Despite this, markets remain buoyant, with predictions of further gains.

site_title: MAS unveils 3 winners of global challenge to promote AI adoption in financial sector
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced the winners of its Global Veritas Challenge, a global competition to promote AI adoption in the financial sector. Three winning projects, backed by Visa, Cylynx, and TruEra and Demyst, received a cash prize of S$50,000 each. The projects focus on responsible AI, including a toolkit to improve marketing fairness, an open-source governance framework for machine learning models, and a solution to mitigate credit scoring biases. The MAS emphasized the importance of "responsible AI" in fostering trust among stakeholders and preventing systematic disadvantage.

site_title: New platforms to tackle ESG data gaps in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and industry partners are launching four interoperable platforms to address data gaps in green finance. The Project Greenprint initiative aims to simplify ESG disclosure and provide accessible data for international investors and financial institutions. The platforms include a common disclosure portal, data orchestrator, blockchain-based ESG registry, and Greenprint Marketplace, which will facilitate partnership, innovation, and investments in green technology. The pilots are expected to be completed in the second half of 2022.

site_title: US eyes January roll-out of first projects to counter China's Belt and Road: official
summary: The US plans to invest in 5-10 large infrastructure projects globally in January as part of the Group of Seven's "Build Back Better World" initiative to counter China's Belt and Road Initiative. US officials have identified 10 promising projects in Senegal and Ghana, and plans could be finalized during a G-7 meeting in December. The initiative aims to promote US-led infrastructure development and counter China's growing influence in global projects.

site_title: Singapore chocolate maker seeks sweet spot in global market
summary: Aalst Chocolate, a Singapore-based chocolate manufacturer, aims to become Asia's leading manufacturer of quality chocolates, exporting 98% of its products to over 55 countries. Founded in 2003, the company has grown significantly despite being a newcomer to the industry. With a focus on quality, Aalst Chocolate invests in research and development, importing European technology and best practices. The company has received international recognition, including the Monde Selection Gold Award, and is seeking to expand into India and Indonesia, aiming to increase its annual revenue five-fold.

site_title: APAC aviation markets to account for half of global air traffic by 2040: Boeing
summary: Boeing forecasts that air travel within Asia-Pacific markets will account for nearly half of global air traffic by 2040, driving demand for over 17,000 new planes valued at US$3.1 trillion. The region's carriers will require after-market services valued at US$3.7 trillion to support commercial aviation. South-east Asia is expected to need 4,465 new airplanes, while North-east Asia will require 1,385 new planes. Single-aisle jets will dominate demand, with 13,500 deliveries expected, while widebody jets will total nearly 3,800 airplanes.

site_title: Genting Singapore posts 11% rise in Q3 net profit on one-off gain, despite lower revenue
summary: Genting Singapore reported an 11% net profit rise to S$60.7 million in Q3, driven by a one-off gain of S$45.9 million related to its Yokohama IR bid. However, adjusted Ebitda fell 31% to S$102.5 million and total revenue dropped 16% to S$251.5 million due to enhanced safe-management measures and lower gaming revenue. The company expects minimal increase in overseas visitors and potential impact on visitorship from local population demand for international travel.

site_title: Singhaiyi owners offer to privatise company at significant discount to NAV
summary: SingHaiyi Group has received a voluntary conditional cash offer from Gordon Tang and his wife Celine Tang to privatize the company at S$0.117 per share, a 21.8% discount to its net asset value (NAV) per share of S$0.1496. The offer represents a premium of 19.4% over the 12-month volume weighted average price (VWAP) and a premium of 8.3% over the closing price on November 8. The offer price also exceeds the highest closing price of the offer shares in the 3-year period prior to and including November 8.

site_title: Hot stock: HGH hits 2.5-year high after announcing blockchain platform tie-up
summary: HGH Holdings, a Singapore-listed concrete manufacturer, reached a 2.5-year high after announcing a tie-up with AAEX to develop a blockchain platform. The company surged 26.7% to S$0.019 after the market opened, with 56.9 million shares changing hands. The proposed collaboration aims to integrate computing power, financial, and information services, and is part of HGH's strategy to diversify returns and achieve long-term growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced a 0.76% gain, rising 189.05 points to 24,952.82, following a rebound in tech firms and another record performance on Wall Street. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also saw gains, adding 0.24% and 0.20% respectively. This rally comes amidst global market stability despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia bumps up investment in EV chargers, shuns sales targets
summary: The Australian government has pledged A$178 million to increase the rollout of hydrogen refuelling and charging stations for electric vehicles, but has decided not to offer EV rebates or set targets to phase out petrol cars. Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that the country will focus on lowering transport emissions without forcing Australians out of their preferred vehicles or penalizing those who can least afford it.

site_title: Singapore startups and SMEs can now tap onto Russia through ESG's network
summary: Singapore startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can now tap into the Russian market through Enterprise Singapore's (ESG) Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) network, which will expand to over 16 cities globally. ESG plans to establish 25 nodes in cities globally over the next 5 years. This expansion aims to provide local startups with more opportunities to access the innovation ecosystem of partner cities and tap into new markets.

site_title: Mastercard launches commercial BNPL card for SMEs in Asia
summary: Mastercard has launched the Pay & Split card, a commercial buy now, pay later (BNPL) card for small businesses in Asia-Pacific. The card allows users to convert purchases into monthly or periodic instalments, providing flexible financing options and better cash flow management. With interest in commercial BNPL products high in India and Singapore, the card is expected to benefit 80 million merchants worldwide where Mastercard is accepted. This move aims to address challenges faced by small businesses during the pandemic, such as accessing credit and building a credit history.

images.alt_text: Businesses can easily make instalment finance purchases from suppliers around the globe and better manage cash flow, while eliminating the hassle of managing fragmented payment plans.

site_title: Integrated Shield coverage: Disputes platform set up, insurers' panel of doctors widened
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan (IP) has committed to expanding its doctor panels to 500-600 specialists by year-end, following a clash with doctors over co-payment plans. A disputes platform, the Clinical Claims Resolution Process (CCRP), has been established to resolve conflicts. The platform aims to provide a fair and objective resolution to disputes, with an estimated 60-70 cases per year. Insurers will pay an administrative fee for each dispute, with policyholders, doctors, and medical institutions required to pay varying amounts. The CCRP is a voluntary process and parties must mutually agree to participate.

images.alt_text: Visitors at a clinic in Tampines on 11 October 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, following gains on Wall Street after the US$1.2 trillion infrastructure bill was passed by Congress. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.2 points to 3,268.10, with Prime US Reit and Genting Singapore among the top gainers. In contrast, OCBC slipped 0.1% and HGH jumped 20%. The US stock market also closed at new all-time highs, driven by the infrastructure bill and robust employment data.

site_title: Oracle launches cloud region in Singapore, invests US$3m in startup credits
summary: Oracle has launched a new cloud region in Singapore to cater to growing demand for enterprise cloud services in South-east Asia. The company is offering $30,000 in Oracle Cloud credits to 100 startups over two years, along with free training and certifications. Oracle aims to expand its cloud presence to 44 regions globally by the end of 2022. This move follows other cloud infrastructure companies like Tencent Cloud and Alibaba Cloud, which are also expanding their presence in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 3.32 points or 0.22% to 1,532.09. Losers outnumbered gainers 176 to 153, with a trading volume of 309.15 million lots worth RM136.47 million.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades SIAEC to 'buy' on launch of more Vaccinated Travel Lanes
summary: DBS Group Research upgraded SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) to a "buy" rating, citing the potential benefits of Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) on the company's stock. The research team expects positive market sentiment and normalizing earnings to lead to a re-rating, with a target price of S$2.65. SIAEC's core profitability is still expected to be a while off, but the company's potential acquisition of SR Technics Malaysia and its growth in the narrowbody aircraft component MRO space are seen as positives.

site_title: SGInnovate and SingHealth ink 3-year partnership to advance healthcare AI
summary: DEEP tech investor SGInnovate and healthcare group SingHealth have entered a 3-year partnership to collaborate on health science innovations, focusing on healthcare AI. The collaboration aims to combine SingHealth's clinical research capabilities with SGInnovate's tech-intensive applications, promoting the adoption of AI systems in healthcare and regulations. The partnership will organize knowledge-sharing events, build Communities of Practice, and provide resources to startups to grow, including connections to investors and support in developing business plans.

site_title: Boeing US worker vaccine exemption requests top 11,000: sources
summary: Boeing Co employees have submitted over 11,000 vaccine exemption requests, accounting for nearly 9% of its US workforce, exceeding initial estimates. This has left executives scrambling to balance employee safety and compliance with the US vaccine mandate. The company is facing industrial and certification challenges, as well as supply-chain shortages, amidst depressed demand. The vaccine exemption requests have raised concerns about the impact on engineering and factory labor, potentially affecting the company's operations.

site_title: Six-storey boutique hotel at Hongkong Street up for sale with S$25m guide price
summary: A six-storey boutique hotel in Singapore's Hongkong Street is up for sale with a guide price of S$25 million. The hotel, completed in 2016, has 27 rooms and a gross plot ratio of 4.2, zoned for hotel use. The land plot is located near nightlife destinations and tourist attractions, with a 99-year leasehold title. Foreigners are eligible to purchase, and there is no buyer's stamp duty. The expression of interest exercise will close on Dec 21, offering a timely opportunity for investors or operators to acquire the asset.

site_title: Alpha JWC Ventures raises US$433 million for Fund III, investors include World Bank's IFC
summary: Alpha JWC Ventures has raised US$433 million for its third fund, with investors including World Bank's International Finance Corporation and Morgan Stanley Alternative Investment Partners. The Indonesia-focused venture capital firm now has about US$630 million in assets under management. Fund III will focus on Indonesian startups, but also support regional expansion. The VC has already deployed funds into 7 companies in fintech, B2B, and SME solutions in Indonesia, Singapore, and Vietnam. The fund aims to increase investment size to up to US$60 million across different stages of funding.

site_title: UK shoppers shrug off inflation worries to pick up their spending
summary: British shoppers continued to boost spending in October, despite inflation concerns, with retail sales rising 1.3% compared to the same period last year, according to the British Retail Consortium. This recovery follows a slowdown in September due to panic buying of fuel. A separate survey by Barclaycard found consumers increased spending by 14.2% compared to 2019, driven by increases in entertainment, digital subscriptions, and travel. Experts attribute the continued spending to consumers being "happy to carry on shopping" despite rising prices.

site_title: Australian businesses see rapid recovery as consumers ache to spend
summary: Australian businesses experienced a sharp rebound in sales and profits in October, driven by a lifting of coronavirus restrictions and consumers' desire to spend on travel and entertainment. A National Australia Bank survey found business conditions rose 6 points to +11, while confidence climbed 11 points to +21. A separate report from Commonwealth Bank of Australia showed households are eager to spend, with spending intentions surging 53% for travel and 15% for entertainment. The rebound is seen as a sign of a rapid economic recovery from a lockdown-induced contraction.

site_title: October condo resale prices surge for 15th straight month; volumes fall further: 99.co, SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 0.7% month-on-month and 9% year-on-year in October, with the highest growth in the Outside of Central Region (OCR) at 9.4%. Despite a 6.3% decline in resale volume, year-on-year volumes are up 9%. The decline in volume is attributed to a decrease in resale units offered for sale, with some owners preparing for collective sales. The market is expected to remain steady, with sales potentially picking up in January after the holiday break, and developers turning to government land sales and private enbloc markets to replenish inventories.

site_title: Bitcoin hits new record as crypto market cap exceeds US$3t
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$67,700, surpassing the US$3 trillion market capitalization of the cryptocurrency market. Ether also hit a record peak at US$4,800, with both assets more than doubling since June and nearly 70% against the dollar since October. The surge in cryptocurrency values is attributed to increased adoption and concerns about inflation.

site_title: Kaisa says trying to solve liquidity issues, pleads for 'more time and patience'
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, is facing liquidity issues and has suspended shares of itself and three units from trading. The company is accelerating asset disposals and sales of existing properties to repay debts. Kaisa has the most offshore debt due over the next year of any Chinese developer, totaling more than $300 billion. The company is pleading for "more time and patience" from investors as it seeks to solve its liquidity issues amid China's snowballing property debt crisis.

site_title: Can former 5-year extensions save us from soaring COE prices in 2022?
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices continue to rise, with Category A and B certificates reaching record highs of S$53,709 and S$82,801, respectively. The tight supply of COEs, due to a shrinking number of cars on the road between 9-10 years old, is expected to ease pressure on prices by 2023, when a larger quota is anticipated. However, car dealers are cautiously pessimistic, predicting no significant decrease in COE prices in 2022, and some even believe Tesla's presence in the market may contribute to higher prices.

site_title: MAS neutral to a digital Singdollar for now, but prepping for future potential
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that it is neutral to the idea of a retail central bank digital currency (CBDC) for now, citing a lack of strong reasons for or against it. However, the MAS is preparing for the potential future issuance of a digital Singapore dollar by launching Project Orchid, a partnership with the private sector to build tech infrastructure and competencies. In contrast, the MAS sees potential benefits in wholesale CBDCs, which could "radically transform" cross-border payments. Menon also highlighted the need for caution and careful consideration of the potential risks and benefits of digital currencies and stablecoins.

site_title: Original Apple built by Jobs and Wozniak auctioned
summary: An original Apple computer, handbuilt by Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak 45 years ago, is up for auction in California. The Apple-1, one of only 200 made, is expected to fetch up to $600,000. Encased in koa wood, a rare feature among the original 200, the computer comes with a 1986 Panasonic video monitor. The device has only had two owners and is considered the "holy grail" for vintage electronics collectors.

site_title: China's state council held meeting with property developers, banks: source
summary: China's state council held a meeting with major property developers and banks in Shenzhen, addressing concerns over a liquidity crisis in the sector. The meeting participants included China Vanke, Kaisa Group, and several major banks. The crisis has been fueled by offshore debt defaults, credit rating downgrades, and sell-offs in developers' shares and bonds. The meeting aims to stabilize the market and prevent further declines.

site_title: Federal Reserve flags potential risk from China's Evergrande
summary: The Federal Reserve has raised concerns about the potential impact of China's struggling real estate sector, particularly Evergrande, on the US financial system. The central bank's Financial Stability Report notes that high debt levels and inflated real estate values could lead to a sudden correction in prices, affecting China's financial system and potentially straining global markets. The report highlights the interconnectedness of China's economy and the US, citing extensive trade linkages and the potential to impact global consumer confidence.

site_title: Gold steadies as soft dollar offsets stable US bond yields
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Tuesday, holding near a 2-month high, as a weak US dollar offset firm US bond yields. The dollar steadied close to its previous session's lows, reducing gold's cost for buyers holding other currencies. The benchmark US 10-year yield was little changed, dimming gold's appeal. US Federal Reserve officials are debating interest rate hikes, but Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans said rates may not be raised until 2023.

site_title: Oil lifted by US spending as supply concerns weigh
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude up 71 cents to $83.44 a barrel and US oil gaining 68 cents to $81.95 a barrel. The increase was supported by positive signs for global economic growth and the US's decision to weigh options to address high prices. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) also decided not to speed up their planned production increases, contributing to the price boost.

site_title: Roblox bookings beat expectations as gaming boom persists; shares surge
summary: Roblox exceeded market estimates for quarterly bookings, with bookings surging 28% to $637.8 million. The company's daily active users grew 31% to 47.3 million, and gamers spent 11.2 billion hours on the platform. This growth is attributed to the company's video games, social media element, and metaverse platform. Despite a loss of $0.13 per share on an adjusted basis, Roblox's shares surged nearly 33% in extended trading, driven by the gaming boom's persistence.

site_title: Hacker steals investment app Robinhood users' details
summary: A hacker gained unauthorized access to Robinhood's customer support system, stealing millions of user email addresses through a social engineering tactic. The hacker called Robinhood's customer support, pretending to be an authorized party, and duped an employee into providing access to the system. The company alerted police and notified users about the breach, opting not to pay the hacker's demands.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sri Trang Gloves, OKP, SIIC, Ban Leong, Unusual, Yongmao
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday, Nov 9, 2021, include Sri Trang Gloves with a net profit of 4.53 billion baht for the third quarter, OKP Holdings securing a contract worth S$39.9 million, and Ban Leong Technologies' net profit rising 64.9% to S$3.9 million for the half year. Other notable announcements include SIIC Environment's revenue increase and Unusual Limited's narrowed net loss.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up to record high on commodity gains
summary: European stocks reached a record high close on Monday, driven by gains in commodity-linked sectors. The Stoxx 600 rose marginally to 483.61 points, led by basic resources and energy stocks. Oil and base metal prices rose on increased demand prospects after the US passed a massive infrastructure bill. Investor morale in the euro zone also improved, with supply bottlenecks and higher prices expected to hold back the economy temporarily.

site_title: US ex-diplomat says Myanmar junta 'open' for progress
summary: US ex-diplomat Bill Richardson believes Myanmar's junta is open to working with the world on humanitarian relief and possibly more after a rare visit. Richardson, a former US ambassador to the UN, met with military leader Min Aung Hlaing, who was snubbed at a recent Asean summit. Richardson hopes progress was made on addressing the severe Covid-19 outbreak in Myanmar. He rejected criticism from rights advocates, saying he made progress in his efforts, including addressing the pandemic.

site_title: NAB's annual profit beats estimates on provisions release
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) reported a 76.8% jump in annual profit, beating estimates, driven by a reversal in provisions for pandemic losses and growth in home lending. The bank's cash profit rose to A$6.56 billion, with a dividend of 67 Australian cents a share. NAB's optimism about the future is reflected in its decision to limit direct funding to fossil fuel projects outside Australia. The bank's CEO, Ross McEwan, stated that NAB is well-positioned for the expected economic rebound in Australia and New Zealand, despite some uncertainties in the outlook.

site_title: ISOTeam to develop autonomous drones to paint building facades
summary: ISOTeam, a building maintenance company, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Acclivis Technologies and Solutions and Nippon Paint (Singapore) to develop autonomous painting drones for building facades. The collaboration aims to improve productivity and reduce manpower costs through the use of technology. The autonomous drones will be safer, more environmentally-friendly, and require less equipment and labor, resulting in significant cost and time savings. ISOTeam expects the use of these drones to improve efficiency in repairs and redecoration operations, with no expected impact on earnings per share.

site_title: SoftBank launches buyback of up to 1 trillion yen after US$10b Vision Fund loss
summary: SoftBank Group reported a quarterly loss of 398 billion yen due to a US$10 billion loss by its Vision Fund unit, primarily caused by declines in portfolio company shares, including Alibaba and Coupang. Despite this, CEO Masayoshi Son announced a buyback of up to 1 trillion yen (S$11.9 billion) to address the undervalued stock, citing the company's "true strength". The move aims to boost returns and potentially pave the way for a management buyout.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following the rally on Wall Street, where investors celebrated the passage of a US infrastructure overhaul. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 29,552.82, while the Topix index gained 0.23% to 2,039.98.

site_title: Euronext to ditch London Stock Exchange for clearing by 2024
summary: Euronext, a pan-European exchange, plans to clear all trades on its Italian platform by 2024, reducing its reliance on the London Stock Exchange (LSE) for core financial activities post-Brexit. The move aims to increase Euronext's control over clearing and generate more income. The company will pay a break-up fee to the LSE, which is currently handling most Euronext clearing. This decision is seen as a step towards building up the European Union's capital market autonomy and reducing its reliance on the City of London.

site_title: Britain commits £210m to Rolls-Royce for small nuclear reactors
summary: Britain has committed £210 million to help Rolls-Royce build the country's first small modular nuclear reactor, aiming to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The funding will enable the technology to progress through the nuclear regulatory process and identify potential deployment sites. The project, led by Rolls-Royce, could create up to 40,000 jobs in the UK and abroad, according to CEO Warren East. The move is part of Britain's drive to increase low-carbon power generation and reduce reliance on fossil fuels amid rising gas prices.

site_title: Tears, relief, long lines as US reopens borders after 20 months
summary: The US has reopened its borders to vaccinated visitors after 20 months of Covid-19 restrictions, marking a significant step towards normalcy. Travelers from over 30 countries, including Canada and Mexico, are now allowed to enter the US without restrictions, but must present negative Covid tests and proof of vaccination. Reunions have been emotional, with many families separated for extended periods, and airlines have increased transatlantic flights to cope with demand. However, some restrictions remain, including requirements for PCR tests and vaccination for non-essential trips.

site_title: Pandemic fallout blunts textbook policy of raising land supply to curb rising home prices
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 1.1% in Q3 2021, driven by strong demand, low interest rates, and economic recovery. However, the pandemic has limited the increase in land supply, as construction costs are rising due to manpower shortages and supply chain constraints. The government's Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme, which offers land for private homes, may need to adjust its supply to meet demand. With a low inventory of unsold uncompleted homes, more residential land may be needed to cater to the growing demand.

site_title: Germany eyes tougher curbs as infection rate soars
summary: Germany's incoming coalition government has proposed fresh measures to combat the country's Covid resurgence, with a focus on protecting vulnerable populations. The plan includes stricter prevention measures in the workplace, mandatory testing, and the option to exclude unvaccinated individuals from indoor events. Despite a record-high incidence rate of 201.1 new cases per 100,000 people, mandatory jabs or nationwide lockdowns have been ruled out. The proposals aim to mitigate the impact of the fourth wave of the pandemic and will take effect from the end of November.

site_title: What Europe's energy crunch reveals
summary: Europe's energy crisis highlights the challenges of the green transition. Rising gas and oil prices, driven by years of low prices and regulatory pressure, have made renewable energy more competitive but also led to consumer resistance. To address this, governments must gradually raise energy prices and provide income support to those in need. The quality of governance plays a significant role in a country's energy efficiency improvement. Implementing a balanced approach is crucial to avoid building vulnerabilities in the energy sector, as seen in Spain's failure to adjust to higher electricity prices.

site_title: Factories of the future will be powered by innovative digital solutions
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the transition to Industry 4.0, a technological transformation integrating physical production and digital technologies to create "smart factories." Manufacturers have had to adapt to supply chain and manpower disruptions, leading to a surge in demand for digital solutions. Industry experts say the main hurdles to implementing Industry 4.0 solutions are cost and talent availability. To overcome these challenges, companies are investing in innovative digital manufacturing solutions, such as artificial intelligence and the Industrial Internet of Things. The Singapore government is also supporting Industry 4.0 innovation through initiatives like the Smart Industry Readiness Index and the Innovation Factory.

site_title: Open Labs launches US$100m fund to grow high-potential SMEs in Indonesia
summary: Open Labs, an Indonesian brand aggregator, has launched a US$100 million fund to invest in high-potential small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with a strong online presence. The fund aims to acquire at least a 51% stake in these companies, providing operational support to help them scale their operations. Indonesia's e-commerce market is expected to grow, with the government estimating 30 million micro SMEs to make the digital transformation in the coming years. This investment is seen as a strategic move to support the country's economic growth and the development of its e-commerce sector.

site_title: BOJ board stresses need to keep easy policy on weak inflation
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) policymakers emphasized the need to maintain ultra-easy monetary policy due to modestly rising inflation and weak wage growth. Despite rising global commodity costs, inflation remains below the 2% target in Japan. The BOJ also expressed optimism about recent yen declines, attributing them to differing inflation and monetary policy stances with other countries. The BOJ retained its view that the economy is headed for a moderate recovery as the COVID-19 pandemic impact subsides.

site_title: Marvels' Eternals makes US$161.7m debut at global box office
summary: Marvel's Eternals made its global box office debut with $161.7 million, scoring the fourth-best opening weekend in the pandemic era. Despite this, the film fell short of expectations, earning $71 million in the US and $90.7 million overseas. The film's poor reviews and lukewarm audience reception may have contributed to the lower-than-expected results, with only 49% of reviews marked as positive on Rotten Tomatoes. The film's director, Chloe Zhao, is also fresh off the Oscar-winning Nomadland.

site_title: Japan PM calls for IPO rethink in new capitalism drive
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has called for a revision of the initial public offering (IPO) process to better serve startups, as part of a new capitalism drive. A 21-page document released by a panel ahead of a stimulus package proposed measures to address this issue, among others, in an effort to boost Japan's economy.

site_title: China's Communist Party leaders begin top meeting expected to boost President Xi
summary: China's top Communist Party leaders began a four-day meeting on Monday, expected to strengthen President Xi Jinping's grip on power. The meeting, held behind closed doors, brings together around 400 members of the party's Central Committee. This pivotal gathering is seen as a key event in Xi's consolidation of power and could have significant implications for China's economic and political landscape.

site_title: Climate change threatens wine, and a way of life, in Jura
summary: Climate change is devastating the Jura wine region in eastern France, threatening the livelihoods of local winegrowers. Record crop losses due to frost, hail, and warmer temperatures have led to despair and suicides among wine enthusiasts. Despite its small size, Jura produces high-quality wines, but the region's economy is heavily reliant on winemaking. The unpredictable weather conditions, exacerbated by global warming, are putting immense pressure on winegrowers to sustain production, with some struggling to stay afloat. Experts warn that the impact of climate change will only worsen unless drastic measures are taken to adapt to changing weather patterns.

site_title: Ecosystem pathways for smart construction
summary: A smart construction ecosystem is formed when different entities co-innovate around common problems, prioritizing solutions that benefit multiple participants. To achieve this, ecosystems must be built on interoperability, facilitated by Application Programming Interfaces. Four primary ecosystems in smart construction include job site, supply chain, customer, and talent ecosystems. E&C companies can adopt an ecosystem approach by setting up an executive team, building a connected construction platform, adopting a strategic approach for participants, and determining which capabilities to cultivate in-house. However, challenges such as coordination efforts, data protection, and intellectual property theft must be mitigated to unlock the full benefits of an ecosystem approach.

site_title: US: Main indices open higher on passage of infrastructure bill
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Dow hitting a record high, driven by the passage of a $1 trillion infrastructure bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 88.51 points, or 0.24%, to 36,416.46. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 3.95 points, or 0.08%, and the Nasdaq up 24.13 points, or 0.15%. The infrastructure bill supported big industrial firms, contributing to the market's upward momentum.

site_title: US dollar steady; Kiwi up 0.2%
summary: The US dollar remained steady on Monday, holding below its 15-month high, as investors awaited US CPI data for inflation projections. The New Zealand dollar rose 0.2% following Prime Minister Jacinda Arden's announcement to ease lockdown measures. The euro was also higher, while the Australian dollar declined 0.1%. Meanwhile, China's export growth beat forecasts, but its yuan was steady against the US dollar. Investors are awaiting Chinese producer and consumer price data due on Wednesday, which could impact global supply chains.

site_title: Most countries 'failed' on Paris climate pledges, says Obama
summary: Former US President Barack Obama stated that "most countries have failed" to meet their Paris climate deal pledges, emphasizing the need for increased emissions-cutting efforts to limit global temperature rises. Despite the landmark accord's success in some measures, Obama noted that the world has not done enough to address the climate crisis. He urged countries, particularly advanced economies like the US and Europe, China, and India, to step up their commitments. The US has set a goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, but Obama warned that the world is at a critical moment for international cooperation on climate change.

site_title: Singapore in talks to 'reconnect' with more Asean countries
summary: Singapore is in talks to "reconnect" with more ASEAN countries, upgrading the travel risk classification system for 8 countries, including Cambodia, Indonesia, and Vietnam. From November 11, these countries will move from Category 4 to Category 2 or 3, easing some requirements for business travel and paving the way for regional tourism. The upgrades also include Finland and Sweden, with Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) to be launched on November 29.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: London's Heathrow Airport is considering increasing fees for its £10 billion upgrade, with potential charges ranging from £10 to £20 per passenger. Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in connection with a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran, replacing outgoing CEO Helen Wong. Singapore's MAS and PBOC are strengthening green and transition finance cooperation. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, leading to a downgrade to 'hold' by CGSI.

site_title: Credit Suisse agrees to refer prime services clients to BNP
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to refer its prime services clients to BNP Paribas after exiting the business. The Swiss firm will recommend its hedge fund clients move to the French bank as part of a strategic plan to move capital into its wealth management business. This move comes after Credit Suisse lost billions in the collapse of Archegos Capital Management. BNP Paribas is already taking on Deutsche Bank's prime brokerage business, and the agreement shows Credit Suisse's efforts to remain a player in the buying and selling of stocks and derivatives.

site_title: Can Washington ever end its political bickering and return to normalcy?
summary: US President Joe Biden's efforts to bring normalcy to Washington have stalled, with Democrats failing to pass major spending bills and suffering losses in recent elections, blamed on his performance. Opinion polls show that more Americans disapprove of his conduct in office, and pundits predict the "demise" of his presidency before his first year is over. The lack of progress in Washington threatens to exacerbate US policy paralysis, particularly in foreign policy, and raises concerns about the country's ability to effectively exert influence abroad without addressing its domestic issues.

site_title: Rappers Travis Scott, Drake sued over deadly Texas concert crush
summary: Rappers Travis Scott and Drake have been sued over a deadly Texas concert crush that killed 8 people and injured dozens. The 23-year-old concertgoer Kristian Paredes filed a lawsuit claiming Scott "incited mayhem" and "had prior conduct" that led to the chaotic scenes. Drake is also accused of contributing to the surge towards the stage. The lawsuit is one of the first filed in the Travis Scott Astroworld Festival tragedy. High-profile attorney Ben Crump has also filed a separate suit against Scott and Astroworld organizers.

site_title: McAfee to be taken private in US$14b deal including debt
summary: An investor group led by Advent International Corp and Permira Advisers has agreed to take cybersecurity software maker McAfee Corp private in a deal valued at over $14 billion, including debt. The private equity consortium will pay $26 per share in cash, representing a 23% premium over McAfee's closing share price of $21.21 on November 4. McAfee has total debt of approximately $4 billion and was previously acquired by Intel Corp in 2010. The company is allowed to solicit alternative offers for 45 days.

site_title: Smart manufacturing and its implications for Singapore's SMEs
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are embracing smart manufacturing, driven by "Industry 4.0" (I4.0) technologies such as Industrial Internet-of-Things (IIoT), machine learning, and automation. A study found that I4.0's impact on business models is critical for long-term competitiveness, with key drivers including government support and funding, and low barriers to entry. However, significant challenges remain, including ROI concerns, capability and mindset issues, and ecosystem limitations. SMEs are adopting a phased and incremental approach to I4.0, leveraging technologies such as visual computing, data analytics, and robotics to enhance productivity and efficiency.

site_title: More women appointed to top posts in Nigerian banks that favour male clients
summary: Nigeria's commercial banks have appointed nearly one-third of their CEOs as women, a significant increase from 2015. Women now occupy top positions at major banks, including Unity Bank, Fidelity Bank, and Guaranty Trust Bank. This shift aims to expand the lenders' customer base, particularly women, who face limited financial access. According to McKinsey, achieving full gender equity in Nigeria could bolster its GDP by $229 billion by 2025. Despite progress, banks still need to bring more people into the financial system, with women facing 40% exclusion compared to 32% for men.

site_title: HK's Link to buy retail properties in Sydney for A$538m
summary: Link Real Estate Investment Trust has agreed to buy 50% interests in three retail properties in downtown Sydney for A$538.2 million. The properties include Queen Victoria Building, The Galeries, and The Strand Arcade. The acquisition is expected to complete in the first half of 2022 and will increase Link's debt to total assets ratio to 21.4%. This is Link's first purchase outside of Hong Kong and mainland China, following its earlier purchase of a US$470 million office tower in Sydney in 2019.

site_title: 5 people from same household can dine out together from Nov 10
summary: Singapore relaxes dining-in measures, allowing up to 5 people from the same household to dine out together starting Nov 10, up from the current limit of 2. The move aims to support the food and beverage industry, with the multi-ministry taskforce also planning to relax safe-management measures at large-scale events and workplace activities. However, the limit of 2 vaccinated diners from different households remains in place, and hawker centres and coffee shops are excluded from the easing.

site_title: 55 years of US-Singapore relations in photos
summary: The US Embassy in Singapore has launched a virtual photo exhibition, "From Sea to Shining Sea," to commemorate 55 years of diplomatic relations between the US and Singapore. The exhibition features 55 photos showcasing friendship, cooperation, and partnership between the two countries since 1966. The photos include historic moments, such as US President Ronald Reagan meeting Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew, and US Vice-President Kamala Harris's visit to Singapore this year. The exhibition is free to view at www.ussg55inphotos.com.

site_title: Vividthree posts widening losses despite surging revenue
summary: Vividthree, a CATALIST-listed virtual reality and visual effects studio, reported a widened net loss of S$1.8 million for the six months ended Sep 30, 2021, despite a 297.5% surge in revenue to S$1.2 million. The company's post-production segment drove revenue growth, while its content production segment was impacted by Covid-19 restrictions. Vividthree is cautiously optimistic about its recovery and exploring opportunities in the gaming sector to increase future revenue streams.

site_title: Facebook defends Meta rebrand ahead of whistle-blower hearing
summary: Facebook's vice-president of content policy, Monika Bickert, has defended the company's rebranding as Meta Platforms Inc, stating it was a long-term effort not in response to recent criticism. Whistle-blower Frances Haugen is set to testify in the European Parliament, where legislators are drafting strict new rules to rein in technology platforms, citing concerns over content moderation and profit prioritization. Bickert said the company will focus on both safety and new platforms, and supports user transparency and control over algorithms.

site_title: SingPost's e-commerce, logistics units show promise, but challenges remain
summary: SingPost's e-commerce and logistics units have shown strong growth amid the pandemic, with logistics revenue increasing 29.6% year-over-year to S$379.5 million. The business segment now contributes the largest share to the company's top line, overtaking its post and parcel business. E-commerce logistics, which accounted for 40% of domestic post and parcel revenue, has been growing fast and now accounts for 55% of total revenue. Despite a decline in net profit, SingPost's earnings appear to have stabilized, with a 13.3% year-over-year increase to S$35 million. The company is expanding its presence in Australia and considering acquiring Freight Management Holdings to further capitalize on the e-commerce boom.

site_title: TSMC says it did not reveal client data in response to US request
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) has denied disclosing detailed client information in response to a US request for data on the global chip shortage. The company, the world's largest contract chipmaker, stated it remains committed to protecting customer confidentiality and will not reveal any customer-specific information. TSMC has pledged to spend $100 billion over three years to expand chip capacity, aiming to resolve the shortage. The US request has sparked industry concerns over trade secrets, with South Korean firms Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also planning to leave out detailed information.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker, said on Monday it had not disclosed detailed information on clients in its response to a chip data request from the United States.

site_title: Relatives of MH17 victims call for clarity on Russia's role in crash
summary: Relatives of MH17 victims urge Dutch judges to clarify Russia's role in the 2014 plane crash that killed 298 people. The victims' families demand to know who was responsible, from the person who launched the missile to those in the Kremlin. Russia denies involvement, but three Russians and a Ukrainian national remain at large. The trial is set to continue in December, with a verdict expected next year. The families have faced intimidation and misinformation, and the prosecution's closing statements are expected to shed more light on the incident.

site_title: Tackling an uneven recovery in Singapore's labour market, post-Covid
summary: Singapore's labour market has shown a slow recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic, with employment falling at a record pace in 2020 and remaining weak in 2021. The government's efforts, including the Jobs Growth Incentive scheme, have helped stabilize and boost the recovery. However, challenges remain, including skill mismatches, foreign manpower bottlenecks, outsourcing of jobs, and unequal access to training opportunities for non-professionals and professionals. To address these issues, the government, businesses, and workers must work together to strengthen reskilling and upskilling initiatives, support employers in job redesign, and ensure sufficient foreign manpower.

site_title: Tesla shares fall after Twitter users vote for Musk to sell stock
summary: Tesla shares fell 5.4% in pre-market trading after Elon Musk proposed selling 10% of his holdings in the electric-car maker, following a Twitter poll in which 57.9% of users voted "Yes". Musk plans to sell the stock to free up funds for taxes, which he would otherwise pay personally by selling his shares. The move could wipe off about $66 billion from Tesla's market value, and market participants expect speculators to try to front-run his selling.

site_title: Australia says it will sell coal 'for decades into the future'
summary: Australia has announced it will continue to sell coal for "decades into the future" despite over 40 countries pledging to phase out the polluting fossil fuel to combat climate change. Minister for Resources Keith Pitt defended Australia's decision, citing its high-quality coal and the potential for the country to maintain its market share. The announcement comes despite Australia's 2050 net-zero emissions target and the coal industry's efforts to reduce its environmental impact, with major mining groups such as BHP exiting polluting fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: The Collinsville coal mine in Queensland. Australia has spurned a pact to phase out the polluting fossil fuel to halt catastrophic climate change.

site_title: League of Legends and Twitch streamers fuel latest Netflix hit
summary: Tencent Holdings' League of Legends franchise achieved success with a record-breaking e-sports tournament and the debut of the anime series Arcane on Netflix, drawing 130 million views in China within hours. The show became the most searched item on Tencent's streaming site and is also available on Amazon's Twitch. Arcane's global streaming performance marked a significant milestone for the franchise, further solidifying its presence in the gaming and entertainment industries.

site_title: Singapore reports 2,470 new Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate at 0.84
summary: Singapore reported 2,470 new Covid-19 cases, down from 2,553 the previous day, with 2,307 in the community and 156 in migrant worker dormitories. The weekly infection growth rate was 0.84, marking the sixth consecutive day below one. The total number of cases stands at 220,803, with 511 fatalities, and the ICU utilisation rate decreased to 68.5%.

site_title: US could be ready for rate hike by end of 2022, says Fed's vice-chair
summary: US Federal Reserve vice-chair Richard Clarida suggests the US economy may be ready for a benchmark borrowing rate hike by the end of 2022, signaling a potential shift in monetary policy to combat inflation. Clarida believes necessary conditions for a rate hike will be met by year-end 2022, with forecasts indicating a key inflation measure will fall to 2% next year. The economy is also expected to recover from pandemic-related job losses, with unemployment projected to drop to 3.8% by the end of 2022.

site_title: Will COP complicate soft power deficit problem for China?
summary: China's absence from the COP26 summit has raised concerns about its commitment to the climate change agenda. Critics, including the US, argue that China is a "significant outlier" among countries that have made commitments to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Centigrade. China's failure to show up has also led to criticism from climate ambassadors, such as Tina Stege of the Marshall Islands. However, some argue that China's diplomats can deliver funding to developing nations, which may influence their willingness to criticize China publicly. China can potentially address this issue through enhanced global public diplomacy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.68 points to 1,535.41 on Monday, closing higher. The index saw 3.102 billion lots traded worth RM2.132 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 571 to 415.

site_title: Seeking paradise, US buyers forking out big bucks for Hawaii oceanfront homes
summary: US buyers are driving the surge in luxury sales in Hawaii, with the influx of buyers from Silicon Valley contributing to the market's rapid growth. The pandemic has led people to realize they can work remotely, making Hawaii's oceanfront properties, particularly in communities like Hokuli'a and Kohanaiki, highly sought after. Prices have skyrocketed, with oceanfront lots starting at $7.5 million and luxury homes fetching over $5 million. The scarcity of inventory and local resources are driving up prices, with some properties offering customisation options and resort-like amenities, making paradise even more exclusive.

images.alt_text: A residence at Timbers Kauai in Hawaii. Oceanfront property, in particular in Hawaii, is experiencing a surge in sales and prices, with bungalows and luxury dwellings fetching over US$5 million.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: King Wan Corporation secured S$29.6 million in new M&E projects, bringing its order book to S$154.5 million. OUE Limited appointed Lee Wee Tat as its new CFO. Sri Trang Agro-Industry reported a 55% rise in net profit to 3.23 billion baht, driven by higher average selling prices and sales volume.

site_title: China's central bank rolls out lending tool for carbon-emission cuts
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has introduced a lending tool to support firms in cutting carbon emissions. The tool will provide low-cost loans, 60% of which will be used for carbon emission reductions. Financial institutions can apply for these loans, and the PBOC will require them to disclose information on carbon-emission reduction loans and cuts financed by such loans. This move aims to support China's goal of achieving carbon neutrality by 2060 and peak emissions before 2030.

site_title: Quest for the perfect measure of human progress
summary: US congresswoman Ilhan Omar is pushing to supplement GDP with a broader measure of human progress, citing concerns that the current metric does not reflect a society's wellbeing. Researchers have proposed alternatives such as gross national happiness and the genuine progress indicator, but disagree on the factors. However, experts suggest that replacing GDP with per capita GDP could provide a more accurate measure of progress, as it captures social welfare indicators and population decline. Nations with higher per capita GDP tend to have higher life expectancy, social support, and lower poverty levels, making it a strong predictor of life satisfaction.

site_title: Indian star Kamal Haasan to launch metaverse avatar
summary: Indian film superstar Kamal Haasan is set to launch a metaverse avatar, becoming the first Indian actor to do so. Haasan plans to auction virtual memorabilia as non-fungible tokens (NFTs) and create a metaverse game where fans can interact with his digital avatars. The announcement follows a similar move by Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan, who raised nearly $1 million from an NFT auction last week. This marks a growing trend of celebrities exploring the virtual world to expand their fan base, with tech giant Facebook envisioning the metaverse as the future of the internet.

site_title: Collaboration on digitalisation, sustainability key to Singapore, China's future
summary: Singapore and China should collaborate on digitalisation and sustainability to bounce back stronger from the pandemic, said Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. The digital economy in South-east Asia is projected to grow by 3 times by 2025, driven by accelerated digitalisation. A partnership between the two countries could leverage their strengths in technology and innovation to drive growth and address sustainability challenges. The collaboration aims to create a future beyond the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves sees tepid net profit growth amid increased supply
summary: Sri Trang Gloves Thailand reported a 3% year-over-year net profit of 4.53 billion baht for the third quarter, driven by 32.6% revenue growth to 10.86 billion baht. However, the company's export sales volume declined due to global container shortages, and revenue fell 16.2% quarter-over-quarter. The company aims to expand capacity to 80 billion pieces by 2024, improve production efficiency, and increase market share to 190 countries within three years.

site_title: Credit Suisse's decision-making power for Asia-Pacific to stay in the region after overhaul
summary: Credit Suisse has decided to keep its key decision-making power for Asia-Pacific within the region, despite integrating its wealth management and investment banking units into the global divisions. The move has alleviated concerns from local bankers that it may lead to a loss of autonomy and contribute to the bank's declining market share in Asia. Despite this, Credit Suisse's Asia-Pacific chief executive, Helman Sitohang, assured that the region will continue to work closely with global colleagues and maintain its speed of decision-making.

site_title: Europe: Shares struggle for direction after record run
summary: European shares opened flat on Monday, offsetting optimism about a strong earnings season and the European Central Bank's temporary inflation outlook. Asian markets were directionless due to US inflation data concerns. Oil stocks rose 0.6% as crude prices firmed, while Richemont advanced 3.8% after a stake was built in the luxury goods firm. Henkel fell 5.8% after trimming its full-year outlook, and Tesla dropped 7.3% after a Twitter poll favored a 10% stake sale by CEO Elon Musk.

site_title: OKP secures S$39.9 million PUB contract for drainage improvement works
summary: OKP Holdings secured a S$39.9 million contract from PUB for drainage improvement works at the Benoi Road outlet drain. The project, expected to be completed in 3 years, includes the construction of reinforced U-drains, outfall structure, and replacement of a footbridge. The contract brings OKP's current net construction order book to S$360.8 million, with contracts until 2025. Group Managing Director Or Toh Wat expressed confidence in the company's drainage/sewage expertise and commitment to project delivery.

site_title: Superyachts enjoy pandemic tailwind as rich seek zen at sea
summary: The superyacht industry is experiencing a significant rebound after the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 200 new vessels launched in the first nine months of 2021, a 25% increase from 2019. Billionaires, seeking a luxury escape from crowds, are driving the demand, with sales of luxury vessels over 8% higher than the pre-pandemic period. The industry's recovery is expected to continue, with over 330 new yachts ordered to be ready before 2023, and Italian yacht builders Ferretti and Azimut Benetti experiencing a surge in orders.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What happened today
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will launch a vaccinated travel lane (VTL) between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur on Nov 29, allowing travel without quarantine. Thomson View Condominium has been put up for collective sale with a S$950m reserve price. Nets will adopt Alipay+ payments solution, and Singapore has set aside an additional S$180m for AI research. SIA Engineering is exploring the market for stripping retired aircraft, and Singapore's financial watchdog aims to curb greenwashing via stress tests and technology. Singapore shares extended gains, up 0.7% on the day.

site_title: Covid-19 patients unvaccinated by choice to pay their own medical bills from Dec 8
summary: Singapore will require unvaccinated COVID-19 patients admitted on or after Dec 8 to pay their own medical bills, with medically ineligible individuals fully covered by the government. Those partially vaccinated will not be charged until Dec 31 to allow time for full vaccination. From Jan 1, only fully vaccinated citizens, PRs, and long-term pass holders will have their COVID-19 medical bills fully paid for by the government.

site_title: China's Xiaohongshu raises US$500m, valuation hits US$20b
summary: China's social e-commerce app Xiaohongshu has raised US$500 million in a new round of financing from existing investors, valuing the company at up to US$20 billion. The round was led by investors including Temasek Holdings, Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group, Genesis Capital, and Tiantu Capital. Xiaohongshu allows users to post product reviews and share shopping experiences. The company had previously faced scrutiny over excessive personal information collection, but the fundraising is seen as a sign of the company's continued growth and support from major investors.

site_title: COP26 talks wade into climate finance as poor nations count cost
summary: Governments at COP26 climate talks are pushing for agreement on climate finance to help the most vulnerable nations deal with global warming and compensate for damage already done. Rich nations have pledged billions in funding, but developing countries want more money to adapt to higher temperatures and rising sea levels. The talks aim to keep global warming below 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, with the expected cost of loss and damage estimated at $400 billion to $1.8 trillion by 2030 and 2050.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at near 1-month low as biopharma shares slump
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a near 1-month low on Monday, down 9.07 points or 0.31% at 2,960.20, driven by losses from biopharmaceutical firms following positive COVID-19 data from Pfizer. Chip heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose, while foreigners sold 124.3 billion won worth of shares. The won edged higher, and the benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: Cadillac thins out US dealers to get fit for the Tesla challenge
summary: Cadillac, a General Motors Co brand, is restructuring its US dealer network to prepare for an all-electric vehicle lineup by 2030. The brand now has approximately 560 US dealers, down from 920 in 2018, with costs totaling US$274 million. Despite this, Cadillac still has more US dealers than established luxury brands. The brand plans to launch its first electric vehicle, the Lyriq, next summer and has received interest from 216,000 people. Sales in China, Cadillac's largest market, increased 20% in the first 9 months of the year.

site_title: Airwallex gains MAS licence, to launch services in Singapore next year
summary: Airwallex, a fintech startup, has secured a Major Payment Institution Licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). This licence will enable the company to launch its services in Singapore next year, offering financial services such as account issuance, money transfer, and e-money issuance. Airwallex CEO Jack Zhang stated that the regulatory approval marks steady progress in Southeast Asia, as the company continues to scale its payment offerings and solutions.

site_title: Up to 5 people from same household can dine out together from Nov 10
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has announced "calibrated adjustments" to ease social restrictions, allowing up to 5 people from the same household to dine out together starting November 10. Fully vaccinated individuals can also attend large-scale gatherings, such as sports events and conferences, with on-site Covid-19 testing. Exemptions will be given to medically ineligible individuals, and a rapid-test protocol will be piloted for higher-risk activities like team sports and mass events.

site_title: Crypto rally lifts Ether to new record, Bitcoin to near 3-week high
summary: Bitcoin surged to a near 3-week high, reaching a record $66,170, while ether climbed to a fresh record at $4,768.07. The rally is driven by investor enthusiasm for the asset class as a hedge against inflation, with falling real yields and positive regulatory signals. The momentum is fueled by the launch of a US futures-based bitcoin exchange-traded fund and the growing interest from financial institutions and regulators. The sector is expected to become increasingly integrated into the financial system.

site_title: Japan cuts economic view after key indicator falls to lowest in a year
summary: Japan's Cabinet Office lowered its assessment of the coincident indicator index, showing current economic conditions, to "weakening" from "improving" for the first time in over 2 years. The index fell 3.8 points to 87.5, its lowest in a year, marking the third consecutive month of decline. This is the largest drop since May 2020, indicating a weakening economy.

site_title: Economists expect Singapore to make strong recovery in 2021/22 despite pandemic resurgence risks
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to recover strongly this year and next, driven by robust employment, domestic spending, and external demand, according to economists from the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro). The country's GDP is forecast to expand by 6.5% this year and 4% in 2022. However, the outlook is tempered by risks including supply-chain disruptions, inflation, and the risk of a resurgence in Covid-19 cases, which could impede the recovery in high-contact services sectors and have a negative impact on non-performing loans at local banks.

site_title: Global Covid-19 cases hit 250 million, eastern Europe infections at record levels
summary: Global Covid-19 cases surpassed 250 million, with the daily average number of cases falling by 36% over the past three months. Eastern Europe, particularly Russia, Ukraine, and Greece, are experiencing record outbreaks, with over half of new infections reported from European countries. Health experts are optimistic that many nations have overcome the worst of the pandemic, but warn of potential increases in cases due to colder weather and holiday gatherings. Despite this, vaccination efforts are ongoing, with over 70% of Japan's population vaccinated and a US$23.4 billion plan to bring Covid-19 vaccines to poorer countries in the next 12 months being proposed.

site_title: Easier Covid tests for Category 2, 3 countries; 8 Asean countries upgraded
summary: Singapore has upgraded the risk classifications of several ASEAN countries due to the pandemic's stabilization in the region. Starting November 11, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam will be categorized as Category 2, while Laos, Myanmar, the Philippines, and Thailand will be categorized as Category 3. This change reflects the improving pandemic situation, allowing for easier COVID-19 testing for residents of these countries.

site_title: Unusual posts net loss for H1 FY2021 amid pandemic disruption
summary: UnUsUal Limited, the events-production unit of mm2 Asia, reported a net loss of S$1.6 million in the half-year ended Sep 30, 2021, narrowing by 54.1% from S$3.4 million in the previous year. Revenue declined 60.8% to S$426,346 due to lower promotion revenue and a 67% decrease in completed projects. Despite this, the company saw an increase in completed projects for production and others segments in H1 FY2022. No dividend was declared, and the group intends to conserve cash for potential upcoming projects.

site_title: A HK$150m IPO heralds Hong Kong bourse's new transparency rules
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission and Hong Kong stock exchange have implemented new transparency rules for initial public offerings (IPOs). Better Home Group Holdings, a Chinese drying rack manufacturer, is the first company to publicly disclose conditions it must meet before its Nov 12 listing, including information on broker fees, IPO pricing, and share allocation. The move aims to curb "ramp-and-dump" situations, where post-listing stock volatility causes losses to retail investors. The regulations set a precedent for increased transparency in IPOs, following a joint statement by regulators in May outlining suspicious activity indicators.

site_title: US reopening hands British Airways a US$1b lifeline
summary: British Airways has reopened its US$1 billion annual revenue-generating route between London Heathrow and New York John F. Kennedy International Airport, marking a major step in the return of long-haul travel. The corridor reopened to Europeans, allowing the airline to revive its BA001 flight moniker, previously used for supersonic Concorde trips. This milestone comes more than 18 months after the aviation crisis caused by Covid-19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.43% due to a sell-off in tech firms, despite a rally in tourism-linked companies. The decline was influenced by hopes for a quicker pace of reopening after Pfizer's successful Covid treatment trial. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.20% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.48%.

site_title: Yongmao posts 78.8% increase in net profit amid construction recovery
summary: Yongmao Holdings, a crane builder, reported a 78.8% increase in net profit to RMB44.5 million for the half-year ended Sep 30, 2021, driven by a low base due to the pandemic. Revenue rose 57.3% to RMB631.4 million, with China's operations rebounding the most. However, the company warned that the operating environment remains challenging due to power shortages, supply chain bottlenecks, and COVID-19 outbreaks, which may impact production activities in China.

site_title: Credit Suisse agrees to direct its hedge fund clients to BNP
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to direct its hedge fund clients to BNP Paribas, citing the need to exit its prime brokerage unit after losing billions in the Archegos Capital Management collapse. The Swiss bank is shifting capital to its wealth-management business as part of a new strategic plan. BNP Paribas is already taking on Deutsche Bank's prime brokerage business, and the agreement is seen as a significant move in the prime brokerage market, which generates around $15 billion in revenue annually.

site_title: All banks will think about crypto trading, says Vikram Pandit
summary: Former Citigroup CEO Vikram Pandit predicts that all major financial institutions will consider trading cryptocurrencies within one to three years. This shift comes as demand for cryptocurrencies grows, with banks like JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America hiring for crypto positions. Central banks are also exploring digital currencies, with El Salvador adopting Bitcoin as legal tender. Pandit envisions a future where central bank digital currencies are available to retail participants worldwide, potentially creating efficiencies and reducing costs. This trend is expected to have a significant impact on the global financial landscape.

site_title: Singapore shares extend gains, up 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% on Monday, closing at 3,263.90, led by gains in banking stocks DBS, UOB, and Singapore Airlines. The benchmark STI reached a post-pandemic high of 3,2425 last Friday. The rally follows better-than-expected earnings from Singapore's banking trio and easing of border restrictions. The Straits Times Index (STI) finished 0.66% higher, with 246 counters up and 216 down, amidst extended optimism.

site_title: Sydney Airport poised to sell for US$17b
summary: Sydney Airport has agreed to a US$17 billion takeover bid by the Sydney Aviation Alliance, a consortium of infrastructure investors and Australian pension funds. The airport's board unanimously approved the sale, recommending shareholders vote in favor of the offer of A$8.75 per share. The deal comes just days after the airport reopened to international travel. The sale price is A$23.6 billion (US$17.5 billion), surpassing the alliance's earlier offers.

site_title: SIA Engineering looking at market for stripping retired aircraft
summary: SIA Engineering is exploring the market for stripping retired aircraft, a segment that could meet growing demand in the region. The company, which helps remove variable components from aircraft for its parent Singapore Airlines, saw a net profit of $10.5 million in the second quarter. Flight activities have picked up amid international borders reopening, but the pace of recovery remains slow. SIA Engineering has rolled back manpower management measures and expects costs to decrease as it improves operating performance through reduced costs and better utilization.

site_title: Chinese developer part-owned by government is latest to see bonds plunge
summary: Chinese developer Sino Ocean Group Holding, part-owned by the finance ministry, has seen its bonds slump to a record 800 basis points over comparable Treasuries. Its 4.75% note due 2030 fell to 73.48 cents on the dollar, despite being rated investment-grade and holding significant cash reserves. The decline is attributed to stress in the market for Chinese property bonds due to soaring borrowing costs and a slowing housing market. This is the latest in a series of declines for Chinese developers, with Sino Ocean's shares rebounding 3.5% on the news.

site_title: Ban Leong Technologies net profit surges by 64.9% on pandemic-driven demand for IT products
summary: Ban Leong Technologies reported a 64.9% surge in net profit to S$3.9 million for the half-year ended Sep 30, 2021, driven by a 29.8% increase in IT accessories revenue. The tech distributor's gross profit rose 40.9% to S$11.1 million, attributed to consumers' willingness to pay more for quality products. Revenue for the half-year rose 24.9% to S$108.8 million, with an interim dividend of S$0.0125 declared. The company expects demand for IT and consumer electronics products to remain strong due to pandemic-driven changes in the working environment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Nov 8, 2021, as investors focused on corporate earnings reports. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.35% to 29,507.05, while the Topix index slipped 0.30% to 2,035.22.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia VTL starts Nov 29; businesses look to reopening of land links
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have announced a vaccinated travel lane (VTL) starting November 29, allowing fully vaccinated travelers to fly quarantine-free between Changi Airport and Kuala Lumpur International Airport. The VTL scheme will enable travel between the two countries, with applications starting on November 22. Businesses are eager to see the resumption of land links, which are seen as crucial for regularizing the flow of workers, goods, and materials. The Singaporean government plans to extend the VTL scheme to include Sweden and Finland from November 29, with a daily quota of 6,000 vaccinated travelers.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment to buy industrial building for S$6.1m
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment has exercised its option to purchase a 3-storey industrial building in Henderson Industrial Park for S$6.1 million. The property, spanning 788 square meters, will be used to house the company's consolidated business operations. The acquisition is expected to enhance management and oversight, increase operational synergies, and facilitate staff interaction. The company intends to finance the remainder of the consideration through internally-generated funds and bank borrowings, without affecting its earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower as healthcare, tech stocks drag
summary: Australia's shares closed 0.06% lower on Monday, snapping a 3-session winning streak, due to losses in healthcare and tech stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 7,452.2, with healthcare stocks losing 1.24% and tech stocks falling 1.72%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's cautious tone on rate hikes contributed to the market's volatility. In contrast, the mining sector advanced 0.72% and energy stocks rose 1.95%.

site_title: Australia vows to sell coal 'for decades'
summary: Australia has vowed to sell coal "for decades into the future," defying global calls to phase out the polluting fossil fuel to combat climate change. The country, along with China and the US, did not sign the COP26 pact to eliminate coal use. Australia's Minister for Resources, Keith Pitt, defended the decision, citing the country's high-quality coal and its importance to Australian jobs and the economy. The move comes despite Australia's 2050 net zero emissions target, which has been criticized for lacking detail.

site_title: SoftBank records 397b yen quarterly loss, dragged by falling Vision Fund valuations
summary: SoftBank Group reported a 397 billion yen (S$4.7 billion) net loss for the July-September quarter, driven by a US$10 billion investment loss at its Vision Fund unit due to falling tech valuations. CEO Masayoshi Son's "golden eggs" strategy, referencing startups' market performance, has not worked this year. Depressed valuations in SoftBank's China portfolio, including a stake in ride-hailer Didi, continue to drag the group down. Bright spots include the India portfolio, which is targeting listings.

site_title: Inequitable vaccine distribution, climate change and inflation possible growth risks for Asia Pacific's economic recovery: Report
summary: Asia-Pacific economies are expected to recover from the pandemic at a faster pace, with a 6.3% growth rate in 2021 for those with vaccination rates above 30%, compared to 5.4% for those below 30%. However, stakeholders are concerned about the impact of fragmented travel rules on the recovery, with climate change and inflation identified as top risks to growth. Climate change is a top priority for APEC leaders' discussions, with almost half of respondents selecting it as a top five growth risk, and 60% calling for immediate and drastic action to address it.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.17 points or 0.21% to 1,534.90 at 9:15 am on Monday, with 321.73 million lots traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 254 to 216. The market's gains come as global stocks continue their rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Customers from 8 major banks can now set up GIRO payments online within minutes
summary: Singapore's 8 major banks have introduced an electronic GIRO (eGIRO) service, allowing customers to set up recurring bill payments in real-time. The service, which typically took 3-4 weeks to complete, now takes mere minutes for consumers and less than 48 hours for corporations. The new system aims to reduce paper-based documentation by 2 million sheets per year, minimize errors, and promote digital payments. The service is available to 13 pilot billing organizations and is expected to increase usage and onboard more banks and organizations in subsequent phases.

site_title: Thomson View up for collective sale again with S$950m reserve price
summary: Thomson View Condominium, a 99-year leasehold property, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$950 million. The site, occupying 50,197 square meters, could yield up to 1,240 new units, subject to approval. The tender will open on Nov 9 and close on Jan 13, 2022. The site's land rate translates to S$1,293 per square foot per plot ratio, making it the largest residential site by price quantum to be launched for collective sale this year.

site_title: Lagging business travel takes shine off transatlantic restart
summary: Airlines are set to resume transatlantic flights after 19 months of restrictions, a welcome boost for carriers. However, the return of corporate travel budgets is uncertain, with experts predicting a lag in recovery. Leisure travel is expected to fill the gap, with airlines focusing on premium economy and business class sales. The US has reopened to fully-vaccinated Britons and Europeans, and demand for premium travel is strong, with some carriers reporting double-digit growth in corporate bookings. The full transatlantic restart may not be as lucrative as hoped, with some airlines relying heavily on transatlantic revenues.
