The Manchester United vs Manchester City match is expected to be a high-scoring, intense battle, while Bayern Munich's victory will likely be their 10th consecutive title win. The AC Milan vs Inter-Milan match will be a crucial test of the two Milan teams' title credentials, with AC Milan seeking to maintain their unbeaten record.

site_title: UOB to launch gig employment model for retired employees
summary: UOB is launching a gig employment model for retired employees, allowing them to work on a flexible basis in areas such as customer service and project advisory. The model will offer healthcare benefits and insurance coverage, and will be tested for feasibility with future plans to expand. The initiative aims to create flexible work opportunities for retirees, leveraging their valuable skills and experience, and promoting a vibrant society in Singapore.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit launches S$750 million multicurrency perpetual securities programme
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has launched a S$750 million multicurrency perpetual securities programme, allowing it to issue securities in various currencies with flexible terms. The programme enables the trust to issue perpetual securities with no fixed maturity dates, bearing fixed or floating rates of distribution, and can be dual-currency. The move aims to provide investors with more flexibility and opportunities.

site_title: What to watch out for after Covid-19 infection
summary: Long Covid, a condition where patients experience persistent symptoms after recovering from Covid-19 infection, affects an estimated 10-20% of infected individuals. Symptoms include extreme tiredness, shortness of breath, heart palpitations, and brain fog. The risk of long Covid increases with age, and women are twice as likely as men to develop the condition. Current research suggests that rogue immune system elements contribute to the persistence of symptoms. Vaccination appears to improve symptoms, with 16.6% of patients experiencing remission after 120 days. Prevention through vaccination is considered the best treatment for long Covid.

site_title: IReit Global tenant to vacate property accounting for 11% of total gross rental income when lease expires in 2022
summary: IReit Global's tenant, GMG Generalmietgesellschaft, a unit of Deutsche Telekom AG, will vacate a property in Darmstadt, Germany, accounting for 11% of IReit's total gross rental income when the lease expires on November 29, 2022. This move is part of IReit's strategy to diversify its portfolio and tenant base, and the company expects no material impact on its distribution per unit. IReit's manager will continue to focus on lease management and acquisitions to strengthen its lease profile.

site_title: US: Wall St opens at record high on strong jobs report, Pfizer Covid-19 pill cheer
summary: US stocks opened at record highs on Friday, driven by strong jobs growth and positive earnings, with the Dow Jones rising 144.52 points, the S&P 500 gaining 19.20 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 63.25 points. The news also boosted Pfizer's Covid-19 pill update, further fueling economic growth sentiment.

site_title: Dutch court scraps record US$50b payout to Yukos shareholders
summary: The Dutch Supreme Court has scrapped a record $50 billion arbitration award to Yukos shareholders, ordering the case back for appeal and potentially years of additional litigation. The ruling came after seven years of legal wrangling, following a 2014 tribunal finding that Russia violated its international obligations by taking actions to bankrupt Yukos, formerly Russia's largest oil company. The award was initially dismissed in 2016 but reinstated on appeal. The Supreme Court accepted one of Russia's grounds of appeal, dismissing the shareholders' fraud allegations, and referred the case back to the Amsterdam Court of Appeal.

site_title: Pfizer says Covid pill 89% effective against severe disease
summary: Pfizer's Covid-19 pill, Paxlovid, has shown an 89% reduction in hospitalization or death risk among high-risk patients in a clinical trial. The company will stop recruiting new participants and submit the data to the FDA for Emergency Use Authorization. CEO Albert Bourla described the results as a "game-changer" in the global fight against the pandemic, citing the potential to save lives and reduce hospitalizations. The pill is a protease inhibitor that targets the virus's replication machinery, but its effectiveness may be limited to early stages of infection.

site_title: Japan's economy likely shrank in Q3 on weak consumption, output: poll
summary: Japan's economy likely contracted in the third quarter, with analysts expecting a 0.8% annualized decline due to weak consumption and output. The contraction, largely driven by a 0.5% slump in consumption, would reinforce expectations that Japan will lag other countries in withdrawing crisis-mode stimulus steps. External demand did not contribute to GDP growth, and capital expenditure shrank 0.6% from the previous quarter, indicating a potential loss of momentum in corporate activity. The government will release preliminary third-quarter GDP data on November 15.

site_title: F&N net profit down 21.4% in second half as input, freight costs rise
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported a 21.4% decline in net profit to $61.8 million for the 6 months ended Sep 30, despite a 3.1% rise in revenue. The decline was attributed to unfavorable foreign currency translation, higher input and freight costs, and lower profit share from Vietnam Dairy Products Joint Stock Company. Full-year net profit was down 3.4% at $145.2 million, with revenue up 2.5% at $1.88 billion.

site_title: Experts cautiously optimistic as Covid-19 infection growth rate dips below 1
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 infection growth rate has dropped below 1 for the second consecutive day, with experts expressing cautious optimism about the easing of safe management curbs. However, they do not expect immediate relaxation of restrictions, which were initially set to end on November 21. The Ministry of Health will reassess the situation and make further decisions based on the trend.

site_title: Falling in love in a Covidean world
summary: In a pandemic-affected world, love has the potential to unite humans against death and disease, elevating the human capacity to imagine its immortality. French philosopher Alain Badiou and novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez argue that love transforms chance into destiny, giving birth to oneself and a shared world. As the COVID-19 pandemic sharpens the sense of a global, common erotic habitat, love can unite people against infectious death, marking a transition from chance to destiny. Love is a virtue in the best of times and a necessity in the worst, offering a unique trust in the metamorphosis of passing events into lasting personal being.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam expects mainland China border to reopen in Feb: broadcaster
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam expects the border with mainland China to reopen in February next year, following Beijing's zero Covid-19 policies. Despite low local cases, Hong Kong has tightened quarantine and discharge rules to convince Beijing. The move is seen as a priority by Lam, but international business groups warn Hong Kong risks losing talent and investment if restrictions are not relaxed. A video call between health experts and officials from Hong Kong and mainland China was deemed "constructive" in resuming quarantine-free travel in a "gradual" manner.

site_title: Penthouse at Les Maisons Nassim sells for S$75 million
summary: A penthouse unit at the ultra-luxury freehold condominium Les Maisons Nassim in Singapore sold for S$75 million, or S$6,210 per square foot, in late October. This price beats previous records, including the S$73.8 million paid for a super penthouse at Wallich Residence in 2019. The sale marks the priciest penthouse ever sold in Singapore, according to Sotheby's International Realty executive director Lewis Cha.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open mixed ahead of US jobs data
summary: Europe's stock markets opened mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.3% to 7,299.41 points, and the Paris CAC 40 also gaining 0.3% to breach the 7,000-point level. Frankfurt's DAX index fell fractionally. The mixed trend comes ahead of key US jobs data and amid global interest rate speculation. This follows a healthy run-up in equities on Thursday after the Federal Reserve announced its plan for tapering its bond-buying program.

site_title: Honda reports lower Q2 operating profit
summary: Honda Motor reported a lower Q2 operating profit of 198.9 billion yen, down from 282.9 billion yen a year earlier, due to a global chip shortage that forced it to cut vehicle output. The company also lowered its full-year profit forecast to 660 billion yen, lower than forecast. Despite exceeding analyst estimates, the result was still a disappointment, highlighting the challenges faced by the automotive industry due to supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Chinese banks quicken home loan disbursement but caution prevails
summary: Chinese banks have increased home loan disbursements in some cities to alleviate cash-strapped developers' concerns, despite regulatory caution. The move follows criticism from the People's Bank of China, which aims to prevent debt bubbles and ensure genuine buyers access the market. Loan issuance has picked up, with some banks accelerating mortgage approvals to three to four months, down from six months previously. Authorities remain strict on illegal lending, but the increased disbursements aim to support the property sector's health and the economy.

site_title: US job growth picks up in October; unemployment rate falls to 4.6%
summary: US employment increased by 531,000 jobs in October, exceeding expectations, as the COVID-19 surge subsided. The unemployment rate fell to 4.6%, with worker shortages persisting despite the end of federal unemployment benefits. The revised September data showed 312,000 jobs created, higher than the initial 194,000. This marks evidence of economic activity regaining momentum in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end week with further losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended a tough week with a sharp decline, closing 1.41% lower on Friday. The Hang Seng Index fell 354.68 points to 24,870.51. Investors brushed off another record on Wall Street due to concerns over US jobs data and Evergrande's bond payment deadline. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also fell, with the Shanghai Index down 1.00% and the Shenzhen Index down 0.77%. The declines mark a challenging week for Hong Kong's markets amidst global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Japan eases border rules for business travellers, students
summary: Japan has eased border rules for business travellers and foreign students, allowing them to enter the country with reduced quarantine requirements. From Monday, fully vaccinated business visitors will only need to quarantine for 3 days, down from 10 days. Daily cases have plummeted to 200, and 73% of the population is fully inoculated. However, tourists remain barred under pandemic restrictions, with around 370,000 visa holders waiting to enter. The government has promised to make COVID-19 a top priority under new Prime Minister Fumio Kishida.

site_title: Shiba wallet with billions is scrutinised as coin tumbles
summary: Shiba Inu, a cryptocurrency inspired by the Dogecoin meme, has seen its value tumble after a recent surge, with its price falling 30% in the last 24 hours. The coin's value was temporarily among the top cryptocurrencies, but concerns have been raised about the anonymity of its largest holder, a "whale" wallet controlling billions of dollars worth of the token. The wallet's recent transactions have raised speculation that the holder may be selling, and experts point to the lack of regulation and transparency in the cryptocurrency market as contributing to the issue.

site_title: How to make live-work-play work
summary: Singapore is embracing the "live-work-play" concept, with large-scale mixed-use projects offering a premium to pricing and recurrent income. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's master plan aims to create a more polycentric urban structure with business hubs in various regions. This approach has led to the development of attractive blended precincts with a variety of LWP options, promoting self-sufficiency in each region. The URA's strategy is part of its efforts to revitalize the Central Area and create a more dynamic urban landscape.

images.alt_text: Louis Lim, CEO of Keppel Land, says "people like to have the flexibility and the convenience of working and living in places with close proximity", which drives private home projects such as Reflections at Keppel Bay.

Lee Nai Jia of the National University of Singapore Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies, notes that many residents are loath to live downtown, while suburbs lack a concentration of major employers.

"As long as the parameters are set clearly... that's fine. Most of us would know how to price that in, in terms of the development, and incorporate it," says Low Chee Wah, Frasers Property Retail CEO.

"What the URA can do, if they really want LWP to have concrete results, is release more parcels of land in Geylang, Paya Lebar, Tampines," says Harvey Neo of Singapore University of Technology and Design.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 7.13 points or 0.47% to 1,538.46. The market saw a significant volume of 231.96 million lots worth RM124.75 million. The gain was attributed to a 0.4% increase in the STI on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore banks face uneven recovery in near term, beat Q3 estimates
summary: Singapore banks reported better-than-expected Q3 results despite a mixed outlook for the short term. OCBC's net profit rose 19% to S$1.22 billion, while UOB's net profit increased 57% to S$1.05 billion. DBS reported a 31% rise in net profit to S$1.7 billion. Analysts warn of an uneven recovery due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and economic uncertainty in the region. Despite this, banks remain optimistic about 2022's recovery, with UOB's CFO predicting a stronger economic environment.

site_title: Nintendo says chip shortage hitting hardware development
summary: Nintendo has confirmed a global chip shortage is impacting its hardware development, forcing the company to scale back expectations for Switch device sales. The shortage is affecting the console business, which is heavily reliant on Nintendo, as rivals like Microsoft expand subscription and cloud gaming services. Nintendo is exploring alternatives, such as substituting components and tweaking designs, to minimize the impact. The company has cut its full-year Switch sales forecast and refers to an "integrated hardware-software next gaming system" in upcoming plans.

site_title: UK house prices hit record US$365,000 after 8.1% surge in a year
summary: The UK housing market has reached a record high, with the average home price increasing 8.1% to $365,000, its fastest annual gain since June. A shortage of homes for sale and a strong labour market are driving the surge, despite soaring inflation and higher interest rates. Demand for property remains buoyant, with values expected to continue to rise as consumers search for larger homes away from urban centers.

site_title: Visibility deteriorates as pollution cloaks China's capital
summary: China's capital, Beijing, experienced severely limited visibility due to heavy pollution, forcing highway closures and suspending outdoor activities. The city issued its first heavy pollution alert for the fall and winter, requiring the suspension of construction and factory operations. Visibility was so poor that the tops of buildings vanished in the haze, posing a significant challenge to daily life in the city.

site_title: Indonesia GDP growth slows to 3.51% in Q3 on virus curbs, below expectations
summary: Indonesia's GDP growth slowed to 3.51% in Q3 due to strict Covid-19 virus containment measures, missing expectations of 3.76%. The country's economy grew 1.55% on a quarterly basis, down from a 3.31% rise in Q2. The slower growth was attributed to reduced business activity and spending caused by the restrictions.

site_title: Indonesia takes over land controlled by Suharto son's firm
summary: Indonesia's government has taken over land assets linked to PT Timor Putra Nasional, an automaker company controlled by Suharto's youngest son Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Putra. The move is part of efforts to recover $7.7 billion in unpaid loans from the 1997-1998 financial crisis. The company owes the state $180.87 million after defaulting on loans, and the government had previously issued letters to seize the assets. Authorities sealed four plots of land in West Java with a total size of 1.2 million sqm after overcoming obstacles on the ground.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore banks face uneven recovery, with concerns due to the region's wobbly economy amid the ongoing Covid-19 spread. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) ended the week up 0.7% at 3,242.34. Retail sales rose 6.6% in September, reversing a dip in August. The Jobs Transformation Map was launched for the wholesale trade sector, which is expected to undergo significant changes. A new global body for climate and sustainability disclosures was also launched to provide investors with comprehensive information. DBS reported a 31% increase in Q3 profit.

site_title: In 'toxic' workplaces, the rot starts at the top
summary: A senior executive recounts a pivotal moment when her boss addressed a toxic work environment by acting promptly, speaking explicitly and transparently about unacceptable behaviors, and emphasizing the organization's values and culture. The boss sat down the team, including the complainant and the manager, to discuss boundaries and respect for personal time. This approach transformed the workplace, setting a standard for kindness and decency. The author emphasizes that leaders must be aware of their own blind spots and take responsibility for creating a healthy work environment, and that everyone, regardless of position, holds power and influence over others.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop at opening bell on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 1.09% at the opening bell on Friday, following a rally in Asia the previous day. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,950.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The market is awaiting the release of US jobs data later in the day.

site_title: China's Oct exports likely remain strong on robust global demand, imports surge: poll
summary: China's export growth likely moderated slightly in October but remained strong due to robust global demand, easing global supply chain disruptions and a mitigating power crunch. Exports are expected to have risen 24.5% in October, while imports likely rose 25% from a year ago, driven by energy demand and coal imports. Despite a slight easing in export growth, China's economy is still facing challenges, including slower industrial growth and persistently soft consumption.

site_title: New global standards-setting body for climate, sustainability-related disclosures launched
summary: A new International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) has been launched to set global standards for climate and sustainability-related disclosures. The ISSB aims to provide investors with information on companies' sustainability-related risks and opportunities, helping them make informed decisions. The board will develop global baseline standards, compatible with existing financial reporting standards, and will sit alongside the International Accounting Standards Board. The launch comes as global leaders gather for the United Nations' climate conference, COP26, to address the urgent issue of climate change.

site_title: SIA Engineering posts Q2 net profit of S$10.5m, reversing from year-ago loss
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) posted a group net profit of S$10.5 million for the second quarter, reversing from a year-ago loss. The company's basic earnings per share rose to 0.94 Singapore cents, and revenue increased 32.2% to S$138.2 million. Despite a slow and gradual flight recovery, SIAEC's outlook remains uncertain. The company will not declare an interim dividend due to loss-making performance, but is preparing to scale up and meet changing demand for maintenance services.

site_title: Singapore retail sales rise 6.6% in September, reversing dip in August
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.6% year-over-year in September, reversing the 2.8% decline in August. The computer and telecommunications industry drove the growth, with mobile phone sales contributing to the 66.1% year-over-year increase. Online sales accounted for 53.7% of the industry's total sales. Retail sales value remained below pre-Covid-19 levels at S$3.4 billion in September. The growth exceeded forecasts, with economists attributing it to improved labour market conditions and a shift to an endemic Covid environment.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle to track Wall Street rally, eyes on US jobs
summary: Asian markets struggled to follow Wall Street's rally on Friday, with investors waiting for US jobs data and assessing central bank monetary policy amid surging inflation. Despite the US Federal Reserve's plan to taper its bond-buying program, Asian markets were mixed, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Hong Kong falling, while Sydney, Singapore, and Wellington gained. Oil prices surged after OPEC producers stuck to their output plan, despite calls to increase supply. The Bank of England's decision not to lift interest rates shocked traders, fueling uncertainty about future policy.

site_title: Australia: Shares notch best week in a month as RBA boosts 2022 growth forecast
summary: Australian shares ended the week 1.8% higher, their best performance in a month, after the Reserve Bank of Australia boosted its 2022 growth forecast to 5.5% and remained dovish on interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,456.90, up 0.4% on Friday. Shares of Link Administration surged to a two-month high following a buyout offer.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to profit-taking ahead of key US payroll data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.61% to 29,611.57, while the Topix index slipped 0.69% to 2,041.42. The move follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US. The decline in Tokyo stocks was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the US jobs data, which is expected to be released later in the day.

site_title: Prime US Reit gets a boost in Q3 from new acquisitions as leasing activity gains momentum
summary: Prime US Reit reported a significant boost in Q3 leasing activity, with 187,076 square feet of leases executed, a 256% increase from the previous quarter. The Reit's weighted average lease expiry extended to 4.5 years, driven by new acquisitions and long-term lease decisions. Gross revenue rose 10.1% and net property income increased 10.7% year-over-year, with distributable income jumping 11.3%. The Reit's gearing ratio stood at 38.4%, and interest coverage was 5.5 times. Analysts remain optimistic, with a "buy" recommendation and unchanged target price of US$1.10.

site_title: US lawmakers to vote Friday on giant twin bills at centre of Biden agenda
summary: US lawmakers will vote on Friday on twin bills centered around President Joe Biden's agenda, including a $3 trillion transportation and welfare plan and a $1.2 trillion infrastructure package. The House will convene at 8am for legislative business and vote on the Senate Amendment to the infrastructure package and the Build Back Better Act. The votes come after delays due to outstanding differences among lawmakers.

site_title: Chinese developer Kaisa halts trading as property woes grow
summary: Chinese developer Kaisa Group halted trading of its shares in Hong Kong due to concerns over its cash flow and China's key property sector. The halt comes amid reports of unpaid wealth management products and "unprecedented pressure on its liquidity." Ratings agencies Fitch and S&P downgraded Kaisa last week, citing refinancing risks. The move follows a liquidity crisis at Evergrande, another major property developer, which has rattled investors and fueled fears of wider economic fallout.

site_title: Jobs Transformation Map launched for wholesale trade sector
summary: The Jobs Transformation Map (JTM) for the wholesale trade sector was launched in Singapore, aiming to prepare employers and workers for sector transformation. Eight in 10 jobs in the sector are expected to undergo significant change, with new roles emerging in areas like digital strategies, data analytics, and sustainability. The JTM will provide a compass for employers and workers to seize new opportunities, with a focus on enhancing enterprise and workforce capabilities. The sector, contributing 16.8% to Singapore's GDP, is expected to see a growth in demand linked to the green economy.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia lifts growth, inflation forecasts for 2022
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has revised its economic forecasts, lifting its 2022 growth forecast to 5.5% and inflation expectations to 2.25% by the end of 2022 and 2.5% by late 2023. The RBA trimmed its 2022 GDP forecast to 3% due to a deeper-than-expected pandemic-induced contraction in the previous quarter. The revised forecasts reflect increased global supply pressures.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain, set for best week in over five months
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Friday, setting for their best week in over five months, driven by gains in heavyweight miners and a takeover bid from US private-equity firm Carlyle. Link Administration jumped 12.5% on a potential bid, while Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources also surged. Energy stocks fell due to lower oil prices, but technology stocks were on track for a weekly gain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, November 5, 2021, ahead of US payrolls data, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.12% and the Topix index down 0.22%.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE downgrades Venture to 'hold' as chip shortage persists
summary: Maybank Kim Eng downgraded Venture Corporation to "hold" from "buy" due to persistent chip shortages limiting earnings recovery. Analyst Lai Gene Lih cut earnings per share estimates by 9-18% and slashed the target price estimate from S$25.13 to S$19.18. Despite leading margins and a diverse customer base, Lai cites supply chain risks, inflation, and diminishing demand as concerns.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS says Yangzijiang 'unwarrantedly undervalued', reiterates 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has reiterated a "buy" rating on Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, citing its undervalued share price and potential upside of 48.9%. The company's recent 20.8% drop in third-quarter gross profit is seen as a buying opportunity, despite higher raw material costs squeezing margins. Analyst Ho Pei Hwa notes the stock is trading at 0.7 times its book value and 8 times estimated earnings, with a 10% return on equity and 18% three-year earnings growth rate. The research team also expects Yangzijiang to benefit from a sustained newbuild supercycle.

site_title: Boeing shareholders reach settlement in 737 MAX board oversight suit: WSJ
summary: Boeing's current and former directors have agreed to a $225 million settlement to resolve a shareholder lawsuit claiming the company's board failed to oversee safety matters related to the 737 MAX. As part of the agreement, Boeing will hire an ombudsman and appoint a board member with aviation safety experience. The settlement, expected to be filed in Delaware's Court of Chancery, does not require an admission of wrongdoing by directors, including CEO David Calhoun. The deal comes after a Delaware judge ruled that Boeing's board must face the lawsuit over two fatal 737 MAX crashes.

site_title: Airbnb profit soars on Pandemic-era lifestyles
summary: Airbnb reported record-high profit in the recently ended quarter, with bookings surpassing pre-pandemic numbers. The surge in bookings is attributed to remote work trends, with users spending nearly US$12 billion on overnight stays and associated experiences. Airbnb stated that a "something bigger than a travel rebound is happening."

site_title: Japan PM Kishida to meet Biden in US before end of month: Jiji
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to visit the US for talks with President Joe Biden before the end of November, following a brief meeting at the UN climate summit. The meeting aims to discuss issues such as China relations and maintaining a "free and open Indo-Pacific." Kishida's visit coincides with a packed schedule, including budget deliberations and an extraordinary parliament session, making it an ideal time for the talks.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit posts portfolio occupancy of 99.8% for Q1; raises stake in Jem
summary: Lendlease Global Reit posted a portfolio occupancy rate of 99.8% for Q1, driven by strong tenant retention and new leasing strategies. The Reit also completed an acquisition of an additional stake in Jem, a suburban mall in Jurong East, increasing its exposure to the resilient retail segment. Occupancy rates for 313@somerset were 98.9%, with a 90% tenant retention rate, and tenant sales improved 14.1% year-over-year. The Reit has a gearing ratio of 34.3% and undrawn debt facilities of S$137.2 million-equivalent multicurrency.

site_title: ISOTeam to divest stake in Sunseap Group for S$12.2m
summary: ISOTEAM 5WF agreed to divest its 1.18% stake in Sunseap Group for S$12.2 million, with the shares being sold to EDP Renewables for S$270 per share. The transaction values Sunseap at S$1.1 billion. The deal is subject to approvals and expected to be completed in Q1 2022.

site_title: AT&T, Verizon to delay 5G due to air safety concerns: US regulators
summary: US telecom giants AT&T and Verizon agreed to delay the deployment of a new 5G frequency band due to air safety concerns. The Federal Aviation Administration and Federal Communications Commission recommended assessing potential interference with flight safety equipment. The two companies, which had planned to begin using the 5G network on December 5, will now push back deployment to January 5 to address these concerns. This decision aims to ensure safe deployment of next-generation communications technologies without undue delay.

site_title: SIA Engineering to provide component support coverage to Thai VietJet
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has signed a 6-year inventory technical management programme with Thai VietJet, a low-cost carrier, to provide component support coverage for its Airbus A320 fleet. The agreement includes pooling, repair, and overhaul services, as well as on-site stock in Bangkok. SIAEC does not expect the transaction to impact its net tangible assets or earnings per share. The move is expected to support Thai VietJet's growth in the Asia-Pacific region, with SIAEC citing its strong technical capabilities and experience in providing engineering support to airline customers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Venture Corp, ESR-Reit, ARA Logos, Parkway Life Reit
summary: DBS reported a 31% growth in Q3 FY2021 net profit to S$1.7 billion, with an interim dividend of S$0.33 per share. Venture Corporation's net profit increased to S$77 million for the third quarter. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,230.29 at 9 am, following overnight gains on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 70, with International Cement and Trendlines being top gainers. The US stock market also saw record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. European shares reached record highs, while Tokyo stocks opened lower ahead of US jobs data.

site_title: CO2 rebound as climate summit sees emissions pledges
summary: Global CO2 emissions are expected to rebound to pre-pandemic levels in 2022 due to moderate progress at the COP26 summit in Glasgow. Despite pledges from 20 countries and finance institutions to end new direct public support for fossil fuel projects by 2022, China's emissions will account for 31% of global emissions this year. The COP26 summit also saw agreements to slash methane emissions by 30% and phase out coal use within decades, but critics say more needs to be done to address climate change.

site_title: Public officers who choose not to take Covid-19 jabs may be put on no-pay leave as a last resort
summary: Singapore public officers who refuse Covid-19 vaccination may face no-pay leave or contract non-renewal as a last resort. The Public Service Division has stated it will allow unvaccinated staff to work from home starting January 1, 2022, if the job can be done remotely. Officers who remain unvaccinated may be allowed to return to work on-site with on-site testing at their own cost.

site_title: US offers US$10m bounty for DarkSide hackers
summary: The US government has announced a $10 million reward for information leading to the arrest or conviction of DarkSide hackers, a Russia-based ransomware gang responsible for the shutdown of the largest US oil pipeline in May. The reward is part of a broader effort to combat rising cyber-extortion attacks. However, cybersecurity experts question the effectiveness of the reward, citing the difficulty of tracking hackers across international borders. This move comes as ransomware-related payments reached $590 million in the first half of 2021, with experts warning of a potentially billions-dollar cost to companies and institutions.

site_title: Keppel partners Temasek, Incitec Pivot to explore ammonia supply from Australia; for use as direct fuel, hydrogen carrier
summary: Keppel, Temasek, and Incitec Pivot have signed a memorandum of understanding to explore producing green ammonia in Australia for export as a direct fuel or hydrogen carrier. The ammonia will be produced from 100% renewable energy and can decarbonize the maritime industry. The companies plan to produce the ammonia in Queensland and New South Wales, with Temasek funding part of the feasibility study. This collaboration aims to support Keppel's Vision 2030 and deepen its involvement in renewables and low-carbon solutions.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Infrastructure - through its wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel New Energy - has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Temasek and Australia's Incitec Pivot, a fertiliser manufacturer, to look into producing green ammonia in Australia for export globally.

site_title: Dathena v Justco: Does the Unfair Contract Terms Act apply to you?
summary: A recent court judgment may impact commercial bargains under the Unfair Contract Terms Act. A multi-national cybersecurity business leased a large office space from a co-working operator in Singapore. The business, with significant financial resources, was found not to have tailored the lease agreement to its unique needs, despite having the means to hire lawyers. This judgment may have far-reaching consequences on the certainty of various commercial bargains, as the court's interpretation of the Unfair Contract Terms Act may be applied to a wide range of commercial agreements.

images.alt_text: A recent court judgment may have far-reaching consequences on the certainty of a wide variety of commercial bargains.

site_title: Bank of England confounds markets, keeps rates on hold
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates on hold, defying market expectations, as seven of its nine policymakers voted to keep rates unchanged. The decision came despite forecasts of inflation reaching almost 5% in April and a slowdown in consumer demand. Governor Andrew Bailey said the BoE would likely raise rates "over coming months" if the economy performed as expected, but the announcement sent shockwaves through markets, with sterling falling to its biggest drop since the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore banks beat estimates in Q3
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, posted better-than-expected results for the third quarter, beating estimates. Analysts attribute the strong performance to revenue growth and improved asset quality. DBS closed the reporting season with a bottom-line beat, while OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, is set to take the reins after Helen Wong's retirement. The banks' steady growth outlook is expected to continue if credit costs remain low.

images.alt_text: All three Singapore banks posted better-than-expected results for the third quarter, with DBS closing the results season on Friday.

site_title: Qantas reports surge in domestic bookings as state borders open
summary: Qantas reports a surge in domestic bookings, with nearly 500,000 bookings in the past two weeks as Australian state borders reopen. This marks a significant increase from August, when around 20,000 bookings were made. The airline attributes the growth to high travel demand and confidence levels. Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce expects the Melbourne-Sydney route to ramp up and most states to open their borders before Christmas, a busy travel time. The airline is on track to return to work its idled staff by early December and remains on track to choose suppliers for a new domestic fleet by the end of the year.

site_title: Move of Indonesia's capital city, new infrastructure projects boost Jakarta-listed construction stocks
summary: Indonesia's construction sector is gaining momentum, driven by government projects, including the new capital city, which is expected to be operational in 2024. Stocks of companies like Pembangunan Persero and Wijaya Karya have surged 31.9% and 32.3% respectively, with analysts citing potential benefits from infrastructure projects, including roads and bridges. However, investors should note several risks, including the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, strict social restrictions, and a slower-than-expected economic recovery, which may affect short-term sales forecasts.

site_title: Jack Ma, Trump and Xi: How Chinese billionaire flew close to the sun
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma is taking steps to re-emerge on the global stage after a year of relative isolation following a crackdown by Beijing on his business empire. Ma's trip to Europe, where he has been cultivating hobbies like horticulture, has seen Alibaba gain $42 billion in value. The billionaire's fall from favor is seen as a sign of how rapidly China has transformed under Xi Jinping, who is nearing a potential third term as leader. Ma had previously met with President-elect Donald Trump in 2017, which was met with disapproval from the Chinese government, and has since sought to reconnect with Xi, offering to devote his life to rural education.

site_title: US to sell advanced air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia
summary: The US State Department approved the sale of $650 million worth of advanced air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia to help protect against drone attacks. The missiles, worth up to 280 AIM-120C, will be used to intercept unmanned aircraft threatening both Saudi and US forces in Yemen. The sale is part of a cautious approach by the Biden administration to support the Saudis while addressing human rights concerns and the conflict with Iranian-backed Houthi rebels. The missiles cannot be used against ground targets, and the sale is seen as consistent with the administration's pledge to lead with diplomacy.

site_title: Uber ride share business regains traction in quarter
summary: Uber's ride share and food delivery businesses regained traction in the recently-ended quarter, with revenue growing 72% to $4.8 billion and gross bookings increasing 57% to $23.1 billion. Despite a net loss of $2.4 billion, the company reported a profitable core restaurant delivery business and 39% growth in trips, averaging 18 million per day. The recovery is attributed to drivers and riders returning to the platform, with the company's early investments in driver growth paying off.

site_title: US: Bullish sentiment pushes Nasdaq, S&P 500 to records
summary: US stocks reached new records on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index climbing 0.4% and 0.8% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.1% as Verizon Communications fell 2.1% due to air safety concerns. The rally was driven by positive sentiment over the Federal Reserve's decision to taper bond purchases and ease money policies. Investors welcomed the slow approach to raising interest rates, with many sectors benefiting from the low-rate environment. The S&P 500 closed at a record 4,680.06, while the Nasdaq reached a record 15,940.30.

site_title: The accidental wine educator
summary: Craig Claiborne, the restaurant critic of The New York Times, stopped at Depuy Canal House Tavern in 1970, awarding it four stars and sparking business explosion. Kevin Zraly, a 19-year-old waiter, responded to a customer's wine inquiry, leading to his discovery of wine education. Zraly taught wine courses, ran the wine program at Windows on the World, and wrote the best-selling wine book "Windows on the World Complete Wine Course." He revolutionized America's food-and-wine culture, teaching thousands of consumers and influencing a generation of American wine professionals.

site_title: China's wind giants hatch plans to muscle in on US and Europe
summary: Chinese wind turbine giants, including Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology, Envision Group, and Ming Yang Smart Energy Group, plan to expand their overseas market share by investing in factories abroad and competing with European and American rivals. The companies have already shown they can compete on size and price, with Ming Yang's 16-megawatt turbine surpassing Vestas' earlier record. China's turbine prices are 40% cheaper than overseas, and domestic producers are trying to undercut each other, spurring them to look abroad.

site_title: Singapore's SME recovery on track, but further resilience will be key
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are recovering from the pandemic, with some experiencing unexpected growth. The number of small retailers in the Asia-Pacific region increased by 35% in 2020, outperforming the global average. Despite challenges, some SMEs, such as those in residential areas and the lodging industry, have seen healthy growth. To ensure longer-term viability, the government could provide greater access to low-interest loans and extended grace periods for businesses, particularly those struggling with working capital issues. A flexible online/offline approach and catering to the international market could also be key to their success.

site_title: High hopes for new Range Rover as chip shortage zaps profits
summary: Jaguar Land Rover unveiled the fifth-generation Range Rover, aiming to boost profits, but the company reported a £302 million loss due to a semiconductor shortage. The shortage affected the new model's production, and the company's profits for the quarter ending September 30. Despite the setback, the new Range Rover is expected to put Jaguar Land Rover on a path to profitability. The company's financial struggles highlight the impact of global supply chain disruptions on the automotive industry.

site_title: NY Governor unveils plan to revamp Pennsylvania Station
summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul unveiled a revised plan to modernize Pennsylvania Station, scaling back previous plans championed by her predecessor Andrew Cuomo. The single-level, $6-7 billion upgrade will increase circulation space, accessibility, and escalators, and is expected to be completed within four to five years. The surrounding area will see reduced building heights and increased green and sustainable features, with up to 1,800 residential units. The overhaul aims to revamp the "depressing" train hub and improve commuters' experience.

site_title: Zillow's flipping halt marks major collapse in housing push
summary: Zillow Group has halted its home-flipping operation, a major collapse in the company's housing push, after struggling to read the pandemic housing market. The decision, made by the board of directors, resulted in a 19.7% drop in shares and a write-down of over $500 million on the real estate it purchased. The company had invested over $1 billion in its iBuying service, but found it only appealed to a small portion of the market, with only 10% of serious sellers accepting its offers. Zillow will now reduce its workforce by 25% and reposition itself as it winds down the flipping business.

site_title: Working the live-work-play plan
summary: Singapore property developers are exploring the live-work-play concept to revitalize sleepy regions. This mixed-use development combines housing, retail, and offices, potentially offering premium values and recurrent income. However, it carries significant risks for developers. The concept's success depends on various factors, including the local market and the ability to balance different uses. Experts emphasize the importance of careful planning and execution to avoid toxic office environments and promote a healthy work-life balance. The live-work-play plan is gaining attention as a key strategy for transforming underutilized areas.

site_title: DBS plans 'broader retail offering' on crypto exchange; Q3 profit up 31%
summary: DBS Bank plans to expand its members-only crypto exchange to the broader retail market, pending regulatory approvals. The bank's CEO Piyush Gupta said the DBS Digital Exchange has seen "very encouraging" performance since its launch in August, with S$600 million in assets under custody. DBS reported a 31% increase in Q3 net profit to S$1.7 billion, beating analyst estimates, and a 1% growth in net interest income. Gupta expects loan growth for 2021 to top out at 9-10% and 6-7% in 2022, driven by growth in India and China.

site_title: The 2 Series Coupe and 4 Series Gran Coupe are not for the usual BMW buyer
summary: BMW has introduced a new 4 Series Gran Coupe in Singapore, targeting drivers seeking a fun driving experience. The three versions available range in price from S$273,888 to S$409,888. This addition complements the existing 4 Series lineup, which includes a Coupe and Convertible. The Gran Coupe offers a four-door design with a low roofline and tailgate, catering to practical buyers.

images.alt_text:
bmw5 - BMW M440i xDrive Gran Coupe in Singapore (1)

source: BMW Group
put in project float##########bmw2##########BMW Group
A crab-sorting facility in the Tunisian city of Zarzis; in the first 7 months of this year, Tunisia produced 1,450 tonnes of blue crab.

To be sure, drivers are not simply passive victims of algorithms. Uber drivers figured out the upfront pricing scheme by sharing pictures of passengers' receipts alongside their own pay stubs in online driver forums. Their experiences serve as a useful warning about the algorithms that are closely integrated into our daily lives.
In Singapore, the four-door is the only version of the 4 Series to come with the option of a six-cylinder engine.
In Singapore, the four-door is the only version of the 4 Series to come with the option of a six-cylinder engine.
BMW also unveiled a full redesign of its 2 Series Coupe in its home market last week.

site_title: Longines pilot watch goes titanium
summary: Longines has released a new variant of its Spirit family watch, encased in Grade 5 titanium, which is lighter and stronger than stainless steel. The titanium case gives a contemporary look, with a satin-polished finish and sand-blasted anthracite and satin black flange. This new model joins the existing Longines Spirit family, which is known for its aviation-inspired design and high-quality execution. The titanium case also reduces the overall weight of the watch, making it a desirable option for those seeking a lightweight yet durable timepiece.

site_title: Turning ideas into reality
summary: A Romanian design team has developed a virtual reality headset called .Lumen, which can provide navigation assistance to the 40 million blind people worldwide, mimicking the characteristics of a guide dog without the high cost of training. The device uses haptic and auditory impulses to detect objects and transmit information to the user. The design team received the Red Dot Luminary award for their innovative idea.

site_title: Asia tourism reopens with big-spending Chinese stuck at home
summary: Asia's tourism sector is slowly reopening with international travel curbs easing, but China remains a significant obstacle due to its zero-tolerance COVID-19 policy. The world's largest outbound tourism market is expected to take until 2025 to recover to pre-pandemic levels, leaving a $255 billion annual spending hole for operators. As a result, destinations are shifting marketing focus to other regions, with Thailand's Laguna Phuket resorting to Europe and the US. Experts predict a shift towards domestic holidays and independent travel, with a focus on natural scenery and outdoor activities.

site_title: Opec+ set for geopolitical clash as US demands more oil
summary: US President Joe Biden is pressuring Saudi Arabia and its allies to increase oil production, warning that high energy prices could derail his economic agenda. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) cartel is expected to rebuff the request, potentially leading to a geopolitical clash between top producers and consumers. If Opec+ does bow to American demands, the group's ability to follow through is uncertain, and the oil market may be in for a volatile few weeks. The US has various tools at its disposal, including a potential release from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to influence oil prices.

site_title: As Turkey and Singapore emerge from Covid-19, exciting prospects ahead to carry relations to new heights
summary: Turkey and Singapore are celebrating the 120th anniversary of the appointment of the first Turkish Consul General in Singapore, marking the beginning of their formal diplomatic relations in 1969. The two countries have strengthened their ties through a strategic partnership since 2014, a free trade agreement in 2017, and cooperation in areas such as trade, finance, and tourism. With Turkey emerging from the Covid-19 pandemic, the prospects for carrying relations to new heights are exciting, with plans to enhance connectivity, innovation, and digitalization, and to fight climate change.

site_title: 2021 Volvo XC60 review: Phoning it in
summary: Volvo Cars has successfully listed on the Stockholm exchange, valuing the company at 158 billion kronor. This comes after the Chinese company Zhejiang Geely Holding Group purchased Volvo from Ford for US$1.8 billion 11 years ago. The listing is seen as a significant success, contrasting with the poor outcomes of Saab under General Motors' ownership and Rover under BMW's ownership. The listing is a testament to the Chinese company's ability to manage a car manufacturer.

site_title: Oil prices sink, reversing gains as Saudi TV reports looming output rise
summary: Oil prices dropped, reversing earlier gains, after Saudi Arabia's oil output is expected to surpass 10 million barrels per day for the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic. Brent crude fell 1.8% to $80.54 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2.5% to $78.81 a barrel. The drop comes despite a previously agreed production increase by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies.

site_title: Powell gambles on inflation easing as Fed waits for more jobs
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said he won't consider interest-rate increases until the labor market heals further, despite inflation running above the Fed's 2% target. The Fed will slow its $120 billion monthly asset purchases, aiming to finish the process by mid-2022. Powell cited the need to balance inflation with the labor market, with the employment-population ratio still millions of jobs short of pre-pandemic levels. The Fed's policy framework aims to avoid premature rate hikes and instead focus on maximum employment.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's biggest developer seeking large real estate investment deals
summary: Abu Dhabi's largest developer, ALDAR Properties, is actively seeking large real estate investment deals with a war chest of 6.8 billion dirhams (S$2.5 billion). The company aims to scale its management business and expand into new markets, including Egypt and Saudi Arabia. ALDAR is targeting acquisitions of retail, commercial, logistics, and residential assets, with a focus on government-zoned properties. The company is competing with Dubai's Emaar Properties for the most valuable listed developer in the UAE.

site_title: Covid drives workload for restructuring, insolvency lawyers
summary: Singapore's restructuring and insolvency lawyers are in high demand due to the ongoing pandemic, which has strained companies worldwide. Law firms report an increase in foreign companies seeking to implement cross-border restructuring in Singapore, citing the country's favorable laws and moratorium options. This has led to a growing need for specialists in this field, with firms recruiting new partners and staff to meet the demand. The industry expects the trend to continue unless the pandemic subsides.

site_title: European regulators slowly turn up heat on greenwashing
summary: European regulators are cracking down on greenwashing by asset managers, who have been accused of exaggerating their environmental, social, and governance (ESG) credentials. Despite trillions of dollars invested in sustainable finance, regulators face challenges in proving deliberate mis-selling due to a lack of agreement on ESG definitions. Several European regulators, including France, Britain, and Switzerland, have found cases of greenwashing, forcing asset managers to provide more information or drop sustainability labels. Regulators are shifting their approach from guidance to enforcement, with some warning that asset managers must meet investor protection and market integrity standards.

site_title: Europe: Shares close at record high after Federal Reserve, Bank of England announcements
summary: European shares closed at a record high, rising 0.4% to the Stoxx 600 index, after the US Federal Reserve signaled it would scale back its bond purchases in November and end them next year. The Bank of England maintained its benchmark rate at an all-time low. Market strategist Hugh Gimber said the Fed's move suggests central banks will ease off the accelerator but won't hit the brakes. This positive news boosted investor confidence, leading to a fifth consecutive day of gains.

images.alt_text: European shares rose for a fifth straight session on Thursday to hit record highs as investors took comfort from the US Federal Reserve signalling it was in no hurry to hike interest rates, while the Bank of England left its benchmark rate at an all-time low.

site_title: NFTs in Singapore: hotter than ever
summary: Singapore is set to host its first significant NFT exhibition, "Right Click + Save," from November 7 to 14, featuring prominent figures like Beeple and Andy Warhol. The event aims to showcase the value and legitimacy of NFT art, attracting both traditional and crypto collectors. Major companies, including Singapore-listed Hatten Land, are also venturing into the NFT space, while some artists are producing eco-friendly NFTs on energy-efficient blockchain networks like Tezos. The exhibition and market growth suggest NFTs are becoming a permanent feature of the art market, with players expecting a shift towards decentralization and financial independence.

site_title: Transforming leaders for the future of work
summary: A global transformation in the future of work is underway, driven by the pace of digital transformation and the need for leaders to prioritize workforce well-being, relevance, and resilience. Emerging forces require a different spirit of leadership, focusing on human and organisational transformation. Key attributes of transformational leadership include psychological safety, growth mindset, feedback culture, courageous conversations, and a culture of collaboration. To drive change, leaders must foster an environment of trust, mutual understanding, and positive intent, and lead by example. This requires a multi-year journey of transformation, starting from the top and engaging managerial teams to sustain progress.

site_title: The money is here: COP26 banks on boosting climate finance
summary: Climate change efforts at COP26 received a boost as financiers and governments believe they have found the necessary funds to limit global warming and decarbonize the economy within 30 years. The Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ) represents assets worth $130 trillion, which could be mobilized to pay for the world's transition to carbon neutrality. However, critics argue that the initiative leaves room for investments in fossil fuels and does not impose sufficient targets on indirect emissions. The alliance aims to cut emissions by 50% by 2030 and report on progress annually.

site_title: The case for proper remuneration governance
summary: A Singaporean construction company, Lian Beng Group, has faced scrutiny over its remuneration practices, with concerns raised about a significant increase in executive directors' remuneration despite reporting falls in revenue and profit. The issue highlights structural difficulties in remuneration governance, including outdated service contracts and lack of transparency. To address these concerns, regulators and listed companies should prioritize greater disclosure and transparency, strengthen regulations on remuneration disclosure, and implement limited fixed terms for service contracts. By doing so, they can ensure better remuneration governance and align executive remuneration with corporate culture and strategic priorities.

site_title: Moderna cuts 2021 sales forecast for Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Moderna cuts its 2021 sales forecast for its Covid-19 vaccine by up to $5 billion, citing production challenges and a prioritization of deliveries to low-income countries. The company now expects sales of $15-18 billion, down from its previous estimate of $20 billion. This comes as the company expands bottling capacity and faces longer lead times for international shipments, which will delay some deliveries to early 2022. Despite this, Moderna still expects sales of $17-22 billion in 2022 as it signs deals with more countries for its vaccines and booster doses.

site_title: Tokyo craftsmanship on show
summary: An ongoing local exhibition at Supermama The Museum Store in Singapore showcases works from lesser-known artisans in Adachi Ward, Tokyo's industrial hub. The exhibition, titled Adachi Tide, features 11 manufacturers and brands producing lifestyle products using their tools and equipment. Items on display include gold-plated brass sake cups, stainless steel tea trainers, and leather tote bags, highlighting the ward's transformation from industrial to artisanal production. The exhibition runs until November 25.

site_title: Firms out of the red, but mood gets gloomier in Q3: survey
summary: Singapore businesses have narrowly exited the red, but their optimism has dimmed in the third quarter, according to the BT-SUSS survey. The survey found a mixed picture for business performance, with decreasing net balances for sales and new business, but an improvement in profits net balance to 0% for the first time since 2010. Predicted Q4 growth is 7.1-8.3% by the survey consultants, but private-sector economists are less upbeat, predicting 5% growth.

site_title: Japanese shippers reap quarterly profit bonanza amid supply chain chaos
summary: Japanese shipping companies Nippon Yusen, Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, and Mitsui OSK reported record quarterly profits due to higher freight rates amid global supply chain chaos. Freight rates soared to the highest since 2008, with Nippon Yusen's profit increasing 25 times from last year to 260 billion yen. The companies attribute the surge to port and inland congestion caused by a shortage of drivers for inland haulage. The problems are expected to continue into 2022, threatening Christmas shopping and global trade recovery.

site_title: Credit Suisse to trim investment banking, sharpen focus on rich
summary: Credit Suisse will significantly reduce its investment banking operations and focus on serving its wealthy client base, investing an additional 3 billion Swiss francs (S$4.4 billion) into its private bank. The bank will also centralize its operations into four divisions and four geographic regions. This move comes after a series of scandals, including a fraudulent loan to Mozambique, losses due to Archegos collapse, and spying on executives. The bank expects a net loss in the fourth quarter and aims to hire 500 more private bankers to reach 1.1 trillion Swiss francs of assets under management by 2024.

site_title: Toyota boosts profit outlook on weaker yen, but warns of production risks with chip shortage
summary: Toyota Motor Corp raised its full-year operating profit forecast 12% to 2.8 trillion yen (S$33 billion), driven by a weaker yen. The company has already cut its production target to 9 million vehicles and warned that the global semiconductor shortage poses risks to its production plans. Despite this, Toyota reported a 48% jump in second-quarter operating profit to 750 billion yen and announced a share buyback and dividend hike. The company plans to invest heavily in electric vehicles, aiming to have 15 battery electric vehicle models on the market by 2025.

site_title: Vibrant Italian fun fare at Osteria BBR
summary: Osteria BBR, a revamped Alain Ducasse eatery in Raffles Hotel Singapore, has reopened with a smart-casual Italian identity and a one-size-fits-all menu. The restaurant offers pleasing, well-executed cooking that hits the middle ground between flavors and price. Highlights include the Instagrammed Italian red prawn and caviar tartare, char-broiled octopus, and a signature Baba cake. While the tasting menu may be pricey, the a la carte options offer flexibility and equal enjoyment. With a fun and convivial atmosphere, Osteria BBR is a promising dining option despite its limited seating capacity. Rating: 6.5.

site_title: Tokyo: Japanese shares track Wall Street higher as Fed affirms taper plan
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.93% to close at 29,794.37, tracking US Wall Street gains after the Federal Reserve announced plans to taper bond purchases. Despite record quarterly profits from shipping firms Kawasaki Kisen and Nippon Yusen, the shipping sector fell 6.25% due to heavy losses. Toyota Motor and Fujifilm Holdings also rose, with Toyota increasing its earnings outlook and Fujifilm raising its annual net profit forecast.

site_title: Evergrande vehicle unit selling Protean to EV maker Bedeo
summary: China Evergrande Group's automotive unit is selling UK-based Protean Electric to e-mobility company Bedeo for an undisclosed amount. Protean, which makes in-wheel motor technology, has been acquired by Evergrande since 2019. The deal is expected to help Bedeo expand into Asia and the US, and will allow the company to further develop its technology. Evergrande, which has struggled financially, is seeking to shed assets to avoid default, following a series of costly acquisitions. The sale is part of the company's efforts to restructure and cut liabilities, estimated at over $300 billion.

site_title: OCBC customers buy over S$1m of gold, silver digitally in first week
summary: OCBC customers have bought over S$1 million worth of gold and silver digitally in the first week since the bank's mobile app made these safe-haven assets available. Over 3,698 troy ounces of gold and silver have been purchased, with a preference for gold, amid market uncertainty and volatility. This move aims to democratize access to these assets for a wider range of customers and diversify their portfolios digitally.

site_title: Manulife Q3 core profit misses estimates on weather charges
summary: Manulife Financial reported Q3 core profit of C$1.5 billion (76 Canadian cents a share), beating analyst estimates but missing expectations due to higher-than-expected charges from weather events. Reported net income declined to C$1.6 billion from C$2.1 billion a year earlier. The miss was attributed to increased assets under management and new business, offset by higher weather-related charges.

site_title: Reversing the 'she-cession'
summary: Women's employment has rebounded from the pandemic, but the "she-cession" has left a lasting impact. Women lost jobs at a rate 1.8 times greater than men and experienced extreme burnout. As the pandemic recedes, "The Great Resignation" has led to higher resignation rates among women, while men are more likely to move to new jobs. C-suite leaders say the pandemic has negatively impacted women's progress in the workplace, with 76% believing women are juggling more responsibilities. To address this, leaders must take personal responsibility and create more inclusive workplaces, including flexible work models and career paths.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slips to 6-month low in Oct as price pressures soar
summary: Eurozone business growth has slipped to a 6-month low in October, with a Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 54.2, down from 56.2 in September. Supply chain bottlenecks and logistical issues related to the Covid-19 pandemic have pushed input prices to rise at the fastest rate in over 2 decades, despite lifted restrictions. The slowdown in growth is expected to continue, with forecasters predicting a 1.1% expansion in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia: Markets closed on Thursday for holiday
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's financial markets are closed on November 4 for a public holiday, resuming trading on November 5. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have rallied for a 5-day stretch ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China's Lenovo beats chip shortage to post 65% rise in Q2 profit
summary: Lenovo reported a 65% increase in Q2 profit to $512 million, outpacing the market despite a global chip shortage. Revenue rose 23% to $17.9 billion, driven by strong sales growth in China and America. The company secured more components to overcome supply chain challenges and remains on track to double profitability in three years. Despite a slowdown in worldwide PC shipments, Lenovo retained its title as the largest worldwide PC vendor by shipments.

site_title: Greenback rebounds as investors buy post-Fed dip
summary: The US dollar rebounded on Thursday after the Federal Reserve's announcement of a $15 billion monthly cut to its Treasury and mortgage-backed securities purchases, citing high inflation as transitory. The dollar index rose to 94.25 points, its highest since Nov 1, as investors took a more balanced view of the Fed's monetary policy update. The euro fell 0.5% against the dollar, while sterling and the yen remained relatively stable. The Bank of England is expected to announce a possible interest rate hike, but economists are divided on the outcome.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, extending US gains, with investors focusing on earnings from top companies, including Toyota. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1% or 305.73 points to 29,826.63, while the Topix index increased 0.7% or 14.39 points to 2,046.06. The gains come ahead of key earnings releases from major companies.

site_title: Seoul: South Korean stocks gain as Fed unveils tapering as expected
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.25% on November 4, driven by the US Federal Reserve's expected stimulus tapering and patient stance on interest rates. The Kospi index gained 7.51 points to 2,983.22, with technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also seeing gains. The benchmark bond yield fell, and the Korean won weakened. Despite a 3.82% year-to-date gain, the Kospi has lost 5.6% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: Japanese shippers reap quarterly profit bonanza amid supply chain chaos
summary: Japan's largest shipping companies, Nippon Yusen and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, reported record quarterly profits due to higher freight rates amidst global supply chain chaos. Nippon Yusen's quarterly profit reached 260 billion yen, nearly 25 times last year's amount, while Kawasaki Kisen's profit increased nearly 14-fold to 144 billion yen. This surge in profits is attributed to the shortage of drivers for inland haulage and port congestion, despite efforts to improve the situation.

site_title: Resale HDB flat prices up in Oct, but fewer units sold during the month
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 0.9% in October, marking the 16th consecutive month of increases, despite a 0.6% decline in transactions to 2,505 units. The majority of units sold were four-room flats, with 20 units selling for over S$1 million, including a five-room DBSS unit at S$1.26 million. Analysts attribute the resilience of demand to Covid-19 restrictions and a cap on visitor numbers, with some buyers seeking to secure housing before prices rise further.

images.alt_text: There were 2,505 HDB resale transactions last month, down 0.6% from the 2,518 units sold in September, according to real estate portal SRX.

site_title: Beyond COP26: An action plan for CEOs
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The 26th UN Conference of the Parties (COP26) has marked a milestone in global efforts to address climate change. CEOs are now expected to take action beyond setting targets, with a focus on delivering results. Key actions include making carbon transition a strategic pillar, getting more bang for net-zero buck, embedding carbon transition into business practices, and avoiding the "hourglass effect" where top management is enthusiastic but middle management lacks experience. Companies must also be prepared to report on climate risks, set ambitious decarbonisation targets, and be scrutinised by investors for their sustainability and climate change commitments.

site_title: Lithuania says its rocky ties with China are a 'wake up call' for Europe
summary: Lithuania's deputy foreign minister, Arnoldas Pranckevicius, calls China's treatment of Lithuania a "wake-up call" for Europe, urging the EU to be united in dealings with Beijing. Tensions arose after Lithuania withdrew its ambassador in Beijing and ended participation in a "17+1" dialogue mechanism with China. China demanded Lithuania withdraw its office in Vilnius, which is called the Taiwanese Representative Office. Trade disruptions have posed a risk to Lithuania's economic growth, and Pranckevicius says Europe must defend democracy by standing up to China.

site_title: Toyota lifts annual profit forecast despite production cut
summary: Toyota upgraded its annual profit forecast to 2.49 trillion yen, up from 2.3 trillion yen, despite production cuts due to the global chip shortage and supply chain issues. The company's net profit for the July-September quarter increased 33.2% to 626.7 billion yen. Toyota's annual sales forecast remains unchanged at 30 trillion yen. The company cut output by 550,000 units in the July-September quarter and will continue reducing production during the current quarter. Toyota bounced back from the pandemic's impact on its sales, reclaiming the top spot last year.

site_title: Singapore to phase out unabated coal power by 2050
summary: Singapore plans to phase out unabated coal power by 2050, joining the Powering Past Coal Alliance, a global alliance aiming to end coal power generation. The city-state will also restrict direct government finance of unabated coal power internationally. Singapore's reliance on coal is currently marginal, but its membership in the alliance reflects its commitment to accelerating a low-carbon future. The move is seen as a significant step towards reducing the country's carbon footprint and aligning with international efforts to transition away from unabated coal power.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as tech, bank stocks gain
summary: Australian shares ended higher on Thursday, rising 0.5% to 7,428 points, driven by gains in tech and bank stocks. The US Federal Reserve's plan to taper its bond purchases boosted sentiment, with tech stocks rising 1.2% and Appen gaining 3.2%. Energy stocks fell 2% due to a slump in oil prices. Australia's "Big Four" banks advanced, while insurer NIB Holdings led gains with a 5.8% increase. Despite data showing a 4.4% decline in retail sales, investors remained optimistic due to high vaccination rates and economic reopening.

site_title: Oil extends decline after Iran, world powers set date for nuclear talks
summary: Oil prices declined for a third day, with US West Texas Intermediate crude falling to $79.94 a barrel and Brent crude futures for January falling to $81.19 a barrel. The decline was attributed to a rise in US oil stockpiles and Iran's announcement that the US and Iran will resume nuclear talks on November 29, potentially leading to the removal of US sanctions on Iranian oil and increased global supplies.

site_title: Latin America's monster movie
summary: Latin America is expected to be the world's slowest-growing region in 2022, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The region's economic failure is attributed to a combination of factors, including slow growth in productivity and income, longstanding problems with export-oriented manufacturing, and the impact of the pandemic, which has exacerbated income inequality. The IMF projects that Latin America will fall further behind the rest of the world in terms of per capita income, with some countries facing a debt crisis and higher interest rates. However, the region has opportunities to catch up, such as re-shoring and investing in green infrastructure.

site_title: China's junk bond slump resumes; onshore bond halts
summary: China's junk-rated dollar bonds slumped amid signs of contagion spreading to the onshore market. Trading was halted in two yuan bonds after they plunged, with Shimao Group Holdings' 4.75% dollar bond poised for its biggest drop on record. At least four property firms defaulted last month, while credit assessors downgraded the industry's companies at the fastest pace on record. The looming deadline for upcoming payments may add further strain on the market, with China Evergrande Group unit Scenery Journey facing a US$82.5 million coupon payment on November 6.

site_title: Businesses in Bangkok tourist hotspot anxiously waiting for visitors' return
summary: Bangkok's Khaosan Road, a popular tourist destination, remains quiet despite Thailand's reopening to vaccinated travelers from over 60 countries. Only a few people visited restaurants and bars, and around 90% of shops are closed. Businesses are hopeful for a return to normal, but some restrictions remain, such as bars being closed until further notice. The street's economy has been on pause for 18 months, with only 10% of businesses able to remain open.

site_title: Republicans jolt Biden with Virginia win, but fall short in New Jersey
summary: Republicans made gains in the US, with Glenn Youngkin winning the Virginia governorship and narrowly losing the New Jersey governorship to incumbent Phil Murphy. Youngkin's campaign focused on parents' concerns over schools and critical race theory, while Murphy ran as a liberal and emphasized unity. The wins signal trouble for President Biden's party ahead of the 2022 congressional elections, which could potentially give Republicans control of both chambers of Congress.

site_title: UN's Beasley says he will show Elon Musk global food aid plan in days
summary: UN's Beasley vows to unveil a global food aid plan in days, promising to show how $6.6 billion can alleviate hunger for 42 million people in 43 countries. The plan, which will be posted soon, aims to "scale up" existing systems to prevent crises. This comes after Tesla CEO Elon Musk offered to donate $6.6 billion to the World Food Programme (WFP) if the organization could demonstrate the plan's effectiveness.

site_title: The future of work is about thriving in unpredictability
summary: Singapore businesses are set to return to the office after 18 months, with the new normal presenting an opportunity to reimagine work models for the future of work. To thrive in uncertainty, companies should adopt three pillars: creating a learning tribe, fostering a hybrid work culture, and building a healthy and sustainable workplace. This involves investing in employee development, promoting flexibility and autonomy, and prioritizing ESG priorities to drive business resilience and growth. By embracing agility and people-first mindsets, businesses can position themselves as great places to work and navigate the challenges of the "fragile planet" in which we live.

images.alt_text: In reality, keeping employees engaged and motivated will not be straightforward in the new world of work. Companies will need to find opportunities to create structures and initiatives that help break down silos and foster trusting relationships to create the foundations for an accountable workforce.

site_title: Democratic New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy wins re-election
summary: Democratic New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy won a second term, narrowly defeating Republican challenger Jack Ciattarelli, with the Associated Press reporting on Wednesday. Murphy, 64, is the first Democratic governor in four decades to win re-election in New Jersey, despite Democrats outnumbering Republicans by over 1 million registered voters. Murphy's victory is seen as a testament to his shift to the left, including new taxes and stricter gun restrictions, which have been key issues during his campaign.

site_title: Qualcomm's rosy outlook adds to signs that chip crunch is easing
summary: Qualcomm reported an upbeat forecast for the latest quarter, with shares rising 7.1% as the company expects earnings of $2.90-$3.10 per share and revenue of $10 billion-$10.8 billion. Despite chip shortages persisting, Qualcomm's diversified suppliers and focus on new markets, such as 5G and the internet of things, are contributing to its growth. The company's CEO, Cristiano Amon, stated that Qualcomm is no longer defined by a single market, with growth vectors including mobile, automotive, and IoT.

site_title: BTS agency to sell NFT photo cards, developing video game
summary: Hybe, the agency managing K-pop sensation BTS, will sell non-fungible tokens (NFTs) of photo cards featuring the band members through its partnership with South Korea's largest crypto exchange operator, Upbit. The company also plans to issue 700 billion won of new shares to Upbit and release a video game co-produced by BTS in the first half of 2022.
