The NFTs will allow fans to securely own and trade digital versions of the photo cards, which will also feature moving images and sound.

site_title: China's property developers struggle to find buyers for billions in assets
summary: China's property developers face difficulties in selling assets due to potential buyers hoarding funds amid plummeting home sales and Beijing's tightened borrowing crackdown. China Evergrande Group, Modern Land China Co, and Oceanwide Holdings have all struggled to find buyers, with Evergrande ending talks on a US$2.6 billion stake sale and Modern Land China Co defaulting on a US$250 million bond. The situation is expected to test demand for Chinese prime projects, particularly those priced above S$3,000 psf.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at record high on strong earnings
summary: European shares ended at a record high on November 3, driven by strong quarterly earnings and commodity price rises. The Stoxx 600 rose 0.4% to 481.22 points, with basic resources stocks leading gains. Notable earnings beats included TeamViewer, Lufthansa, and Raiffeisen Bank International. Despite anticipation of US Federal Reserve stimulus tapering, hopes for a growth reacceleration and supportive earnings season contributed to the market rally.

site_title: Powell gambles on inflation easing as Fed waits for more jobs
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the US central bank won't consider interest-rate increases until the labor market heals further, despite inflation running above the Fed's 2% target. Powell cited the need to balance the risk of not reaching maximum employment with the risk of overshooting inflation. The Fed's policy framework, led by Powell, aims to slow asset purchases and prepare for a potential rate hike in the future, assuming the labor market and inflation trends improve in 2022.

site_title: The dangerous power of insecure billionaires
summary: Billionaires' opposition to taxation has significant implications for society. Despite the claim that taxing them would deprive society of their unique contributions, history suggests that this is not the case. In fact, the post-war years saw unprecedented prosperity despite high corporate taxes and a top personal tax rate of 91%. Billionaires' concerns about taxes likely stem from their insecure ego, seeking recognition and acknowledgment of their greatness. This insecurity drives their pettiness and vast power, ultimately affecting all of us who pay a steep price for their behavior.

site_title: Rising interest rates expected to cool UK housing market
summary: The UK housing market is expected to cool due to rising interest rates, which are anticipated to increase as early as Thursday. Despite a 0.7% rise in average house prices in October, the Nationwide Building Society warns that a squeeze on living standards and inflation will have a significant impact. The average price of a UK home has surpassed £250,000, with rising mortgage costs expected to affect borrowers, particularly those on variable interest rates. Economists predict a 1% benchmark rate by the middle of next year, which would lead to higher mortgage payments.

site_title: CBA offers crypto trading, breaks ranks with industry
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has become the country's first main-street bank to offer a platform for retail customers to trade cryptocurrencies, partnering with Gemini Trust Company to offer a "crypto exchange and custody service" through its mobile app. The move breaks ranks with industry peers and is seen as a response to growing client demand. CBA's decision is expected to validate the US$2.6 trillion crypto trading industry, with cryptocurrency executives and supporters hailing it as a significant development.

site_title: Asia tourism reopens with big-spending Chinese stuck at home
summary: Asia's tourism industry is slowly reopening with countries like Thailand gradually easing international travel curbs. However, China, the world's largest outbound tourism market, remains closed, leaving a $255 billion annual spending hole for operators. China's strict COVID-19 measures are expected to last until at least the second quarter of 2022, with many experts predicting a reluctance to travel internationally due to fears. This shift may lead to a focus on domestic holidays and a rise in independent travel and smaller customised tours.

site_title: Iran nuclear talks to resume amid growing doubts about a deal
summary: The US and Iran will resume nuclear talks on November 29 in Vienna after a five-month delay, with the goal of reviving the 2015 agreement limiting Tehran's nuclear program. The talks, facilitated by European and Russian intermediaries, come amid growing doubts about a deal due to sticking points on sanctions relief and the permanence of the agreement. US officials say substantial progress was made in the first six rounds, but Iran seeks a guarantee from the Biden administration that future US presidents won't back out.

site_title: Gold rebounds as dollar dips after Fed unveils taper plan
summary: Gold prices rebounded 0.3% to $1,774.11 per ounce after the US Federal Reserve announced plans to unwind its stimulus program this month while retaining low interest rates. The dollar weakened, contributing to the gold price increase. This move is expected to reduce the attractiveness of holding US assets, causing investors to seek safer alternatives like gold. The Fed's decision is seen as a positive development for gold prices, which had touched a three-week low earlier.

site_title: US: Stocks end at records after Fed tapering decision
summary: US stocks finished at fresh records on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% to 36,157.58, the S&P 500 gaining 0.7% to 4,660.57, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1% to 15,811.58. The Federal Reserve announced it will scale back its stimulus program, citing a solid US economy recovery. Despite initial negative trading, the market rebounded after the announcement, with major indices ending at all-time highs for the fourth straight day.

site_title: ADB launches plan to retire coal-fired power plants in the Philippines, Indonesia
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has launched a plan to retire coal-fired power plants in Indonesia and the Philippines within 15 years, significantly reducing carbon emissions. The proposal, called Energy Transition Mechanism (ETM), involves public-private partnerships to buy out and wind down the plants. Japan has committed a $25 million grant to support the plan, which aims to cut 200 million tons of CO2 emissions annually. If scaled up, the plan could make Indonesia and the Philippines pioneers in removing coal from the region's energy mix, contributing to global greenhouse gas emissions reduction.

site_title: Christmas may be difficult as Covid not over, UK's deputy medical officer says
summary: UK's deputy chief medical officer warns that Christmas may be difficult due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, with 293 reported deaths and an average of 40,000 new cases per day. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson's plan to rely on vaccinations, the situation is still concerning, and booster shots are necessary to prevent further spread. The Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage) advises taking action now to reduce the need for tougher measures later. Experts warn that the crisis is not over, and the UK faces a potentially tough winter.

site_title: Hybrid cars' green credentials under scrutiny
summary: Hybrid cars are gaining popularity in the European Union as eco-conscious drivers opt for them, but environmentalists question their green credentials. In the EU, 20.7% of new cars sold in the third quarter were hybrids, with 9.1% being plug-in hybrids. However, Greenpeace and Transport & Environment argue that hybrids slow down the transition to fully electric vehicles, citing that they are not as clean as claimed. Experts, like IFP Energies Nouvelles, argue that hybrids can be more environmentally friendly, especially when used correctly, and provide a bridge to fully electric vehicles.

site_title: Stepping up in a pandemic
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore and FoodXervices Inc were recognized for their efforts to support migrant workers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The agency converted floating accommodations into "makeshift homes" for migrant workers, providing medical care, food, and recreation activities. The operation, which began in April 2020, was successful despite initial challenges. The agency's efforts were recognized with the President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards 2021, highlighting the organization's commitment to supporting the safety and well-being of migrant workers.

site_title: Facebook ends facial recognition system over privacy fears
summary: Facebook is shutting down its facial recognition system, deleting data on over 1 billion people, amid growing privacy concerns. The move comes after internal documents were leaked, fueling calls for government regulation. The system, which automatically identified people in photos, was a key feature that drew controversy. Facebook's parent company, Meta, is winding down the system over the coming weeks, with vice-president Jerome Pesenti citing concerns about facial recognition technology in society. Privacy advocates welcomed the news, while some expressed concerns it may be a PR stunt.

site_title: Britain offers warning of what happens when a country ignores Covid-19
summary: Britain is facing a surge in Covid-19 cases, with a three-month high of around 52,000 infections on October 21. Despite this, the government continues to oppose measures that could reduce cases. Experts say Britain is making three main mistakes: not enough vaccinations, waning immunity, and a "live and let live" approach that ignores the need for restrictions. The country's high vaccination rate has prevented severe illness, but the lack of boosters and mask mandates has contributed to the surge. Britain's Covid-19 policy has led to deaths and overwhelmed hospitals, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to mitigate the pandemic's impact.

site_title: US dollar hovers near peaks as Fed heads for taper
summary: The US dollar remained near recent peaks against the euro and yen on November 3, 2021, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's decision to unwind pandemic-era stimulus and assess inflationary pressures. The Bank of England is set to meet on November 4, adding to the central banks' busy week.

site_title: Oil tumbles as US piles pressure on Opec+ for more barrels
summary: US pressure on Opec+ to boost oil supplies led to a 1.7% drop in West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices, with Brent also falling. President Biden blamed Opec+ for fueling inflation, while Secretary of State Antony Blinken urged the UAE for increased supply. The Federal Reserve is expected to announce the end of its bond-buying program, causing the US dollar to rise and making commodities more expensive for overseas consumers. Despite Opec+ plans to raise output by 400,000 barrels, the market remains cautious due to shifts in risk appetite and potential data releases.

site_title: The NFT phenomenon is here to stay
summary: Singapore hosts its first major exhibition of NFTs, featuring works by Beeple, Refik Anadol, and Tyler Hobbs, aiming to bring non-fungible tokens into the mainstream. The phenomenon is expanding into various fields, including property, martial arts, and charity auctions. Meanwhile, an exhibition on Japanese design and craft is being showcased, and the Red Dot awards highlight innovative designs from around the world.

site_title: Rate-hike bets are escalating across Asia's emerging markets
summary: Rate-hike bets are escalating across Asia's emerging markets, particularly in South Korea and India, where traders now anticipate at least a quarter-point increase in the next three months. Markets are also building in Malaysia and Thailand over a two-year horizon. This hawkish shift reflects growing concerns about inflation and economic growth, with China's GDP growth expected to slow. The shift in expectations comes as central banks in the region prepare to normalize policy and respond to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: South Korea's Kakao Pay more than doubles on debut
summary: South Korea's Kakao Pay, a financial services app, made its debut and more than doubled in value, surpassing traditional finance companies. This comes as investors seek growth prospects amidst heightened regulatory scrutiny. The IPO's success could indicate room for further growth in South Korea's market, providing relief to investors.

site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon returns with hybrid finale events
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon will return with a hybrid format, featuring in-person races on Dec 4-5 at The Float @ Marina Bay, and a virtual race grand finale from Dec 1-12. This year's event marks the marathon's return after a pause due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The hybrid format allows participants to choose between in-person or virtual participation, offering more flexibility for runners. The event aims to promote running and community engagement while also promoting a zero-waste future.

site_title: Asean needs unified vaccine protocols to revive tourism: panel
summary: A unified vaccine passport is needed for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to revive its tourism sector, which declined by 53% in 2020 and 77% in international visitor spending. Indonesia's Minister for Tourism and Creative Economy Sandiaga Uno called for a digital vaccine certificate to speed up the recovery, while Philippines and Indonesia's Transportation Minister Budi Karya Sumadi echoed the need for harmonized border measures. The World Travel & Tourism Council emphasized the importance of coordinated travel protocols to restart travel in the region.

site_title: Finance firms managing US$130 trillion join net-zero pledge at COP26
summary: Finance firms managing $130 trillion in capital have joined the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, pledging to assume a "fair share" of decarbonization. The alliance aims to channel private money into investment that advances the UN-backed goal of 'net-zero' greenhouse emissions by 2050. However, US climate envoy John Kerry said the world has only a 60% chance of capping warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius due to insufficient emission reduction goals. The UK has committed £100 million to increasing climate finance for developing countries and promoting green bonds.

site_title: Venture Corp chalks up Q3 net profit of S$77m
summary: Venture Corp reported a Q3 net profit of S$77 million, up sequentially from S$75.1 million, with earnings per share reaching S$0.264. Revenue rose to S$769.9 million, but was lower than the year-ago period. The company attributed the decline to global components shortages and the Extended Movement Control Order in Malaysia. Despite this, demand for its services and products remained healthy, and the company expects this trend to continue.

site_title: Netflix launches mobile games for members worldwide
summary: Netflix has launched mobile games for its members worldwide, offering two Stranger Things-based games and three basic card or skill games. The games are accessible through Netflix accounts on Android-powered smartphones or tablets and are available globally, excluding iPhone and iPad versions. This move aims to expand Netflix's entertainment empire into the gaming sector, with the goal of competing with hit games like Fortnite and attracting new subscribers. The global gaming market exceeds $300 billion, presenting a lucrative opportunity for Netflix to diversify its offerings.

site_title: Aukus may send Asian countries a huge bill for services provided
summary: The formation of the Australia-UK-US (Aukus) security and technology alliance has raised concerns among Asian countries, particularly Asean, as it may reshape Indo-Pacific geopolitics. The alliance, which includes a nuclear-powered submarine program with Britain and the US, has been criticized for being an "all-white club" aimed at confronting China. Aukus countries, particularly the US, will seek a return on investment from Asian countries, including greater investment, trade access, and diplomatic support. Asian powers must weigh the risks and benefits of aligning with the Aukus, which may undermine Asean's neutrality and centrality in the region.

site_title: The risk of Democrats becoming minority party
summary: US election results suggest voters are turning against a party at risk of being hijacked by its progressive wing. A hypothetical six-party system, including a centre-left and centre-right party, and the Progressive Party, which includes figures like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders, may struggle to gain significant support. The Progressive Party could potentially participate in a European-style parliamentary system as a junior member in a coalition government, but its best-case scenario is around 14% of the electorate. This outcome could lead to a minority party struggling to influence policy in a two-party system.

site_title: Sowing the seeds of green finance to realise Singapore's Green Plan
summary: Singapore's government aims to promote green finance through various initiatives, including establishing a Green Bonds Programme Office to catalyse efforts. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong reiterated the importance of green finance in a recent conference, highlighting its role in enabling sustainable development. The government has also set policies on climate-related financial disclosures, focused on ESG data, and supported high-quality carbon credit markets. These efforts aim to support green investments and contribute to the country's Green Plan, emphasizing the crucial role of finance in achieving a greener and more sustainable environment and society.

site_title: World Economic Forum postpones China event due to Covid-19
summary: The World Economic Forum postponed its Annual Meeting of the New Champions in Tianjin, China, due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, with new locally transmitted cases in major cities and provinces reaching a near three-month high.

site_title: American democracy and soft power
summary: A recent meeting of trans-Atlantic foreign policy experts raised concerns about the US's internal issues affecting its soft power, which underlies American foreign policy. Former President Donald Trump's term was damaging to US soft power, partly due to his nativist foreign policy and incompetent response to the Covid-19 pandemic. However, US soft power can recover from setbacks, as seen in the past with the country's capacity for resilience and reform. Key sources of US soft power include its diverse civil society, free press, charitable work, and universities, which can attract others despite politics.

site_title: AirAsia eyes potential Airbus A321neo freighter
summary: AirAsia is in talks with Airbus to develop a freighter version of its A321neo passenger plane. The airline's logistics division, Teleport, plans to convert a "meaningful chunk" of its 362 A321neo orders to a dedicated freighter. CEO Pete Chareonwongsak stated that the move would allow AirAsia to capitalize on the growing demand for freighter services. This conversion could potentially increase AirAsia's revenue and expand its logistics capabilities. The exact details of the partnership are still being discussed between AirAsia and Airbus.

site_title: Tencent unveils first chips in push beyond online entertainment content
summary: Tencent, a Chinese tech giant, unveiled its first chips, marking a year-long push into silicon design. The company introduced an AI chip for search and recommendation, a video compression chip, and a networking chip for cloud servers. The move is part of Tencent's efforts to grow beyond digital entertainment and align with Chinese President Xi Jinping's goals of tech self-sufficiency. The company has pledged $3 billion in resources to support its cloud business partners, and its shares rose 1.3% on the news. This move follows similar efforts by other Chinese tech companies, including Alibaba and ByteDance.

site_title: Focus should be on productive use of workers - regardless of age
summary: Singapore aims to raise retirement and re-employment ages to 65 and 70 by the end of the decade. Starting in 2022, the retirement age will be 63, and re-employment will be 68. The government also plans to raise Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for workers above 55, with those aged 60-65 to enjoy a 26% rate. However, older workers face age discrimination in the workplace, with many facing discouragement in new employment terms and benefit cuts. To address this, the government and employers must strike a balance between flexibility and business stability, and encourage age-inclusive workplace practices.

site_title: US services sector index jumps to record high
summary: The US services sector index jumped to a record high in October, reaching 66.7, driven by declining Covid-19 cases and boosted demand. This surge follows an acceleration in private payrolls growth and suggests the economy is regaining momentum in the fourth quarter. Despite supply-chain disruptions and labor difficulties, economists expect labor supply to improve in the months ahead, but supply chains will take months to return to normal. This marks the highest reading since the series began in 1997.

site_title: Credit Suisse to tighten reins after scandals cost bank billions of dollars
summary: Credit Suisse is set to unveil a new centralized structure on November 4 to address scandals that have cost the bank billions of dollars. The bank has been fined for a fraudulent loan to Mozambique, suffered losses with Archegos collapse, and been rebuked for spying on executives. This move aims to bring its far-flung divisions under control and draw a line under the scandals.

site_title: The women guarding India's rainforest 'refugees'
summary: In India's Western Ghats mountain range, a 27-member all-female team is fighting to protect biodiversity amidst deforestation and climate change. The Gurukula Botanical Sanctuary, created 50 years ago, is home to over 325 globally threatened species and serves as a refuge for native flora struggling to survive. The women, known as "rainforest gardeners," work tirelessly to replant, care for, and protect the sanctuary's diverse ecosystem, which faces threats from rising temperatures, habitat loss, and human encroachment. Their efforts are crucial in preserving the region's ecological balance.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund weighs deal to form largest cellular towers company
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund is considering a deal to merge the mobile phone infrastructure of Saudi Telecom and Zain Saudi Arabia, creating the kingdom's largest cellular towers company. The proposed merger would combine 23,000 towers, potentially listing the firm on the local bourse. The talks are at an early stage, and the PIF may decide against the transaction. This move follows global telecom operators seeking to derive more value from their tower portfolios amid rising investor appetite.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post longest losing streak since July
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, posting the longest losing streak in nearly four months, as investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The Hang Seng index fell 0.3% to 25,024.75, marking the seventh straight day of losses. Analysts expect the Fed to announce the tapering of its US$120 billion-a-month asset purchase programme, shifting market attention away from Hong Kong.

site_title: US factory orders unexpectedly rise in September
summary: US factory orders unexpectedly rose 0.2% in September, despite manufacturing being constrained by input shortages. This growth was driven by strong demand for goods, with machinery, primary metals, and fabricated metal products leading the way. However, orders for computers, electronics, and transportation equipment fell due to a global chip shortage. Shipments increased 0.6% and inventories at factories rose 0.8%. The rise in factory goods orders suggests businesses are rebuilding depleted inventories, but labor and raw material shortages remain a challenge.

site_title: Prince Andrew could face US civil trial in woman's sex abuse case in late 2022
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan has set a target trial date for Prince Andrew in a civil case brought by Virginia Giuffre, alleging sexual abuse by the late financier Jeffrey Epstein. The trial is expected to begin between September and December 2022, pending a safe jury arrangement amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Giuffre, 38, claims Andrew forced her to have sex at various locations, including Epstein's mansion and private island. Prince Andrew has denied the allegations, calling them "false accusations" and suggesting Giuffre is seeking a "payday."

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as focus shifts to Fed's taper decision
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Wednesday, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on tapering its pandemic-era support. The Dow Jones rose 6.46 points, the S&P 500 remained flat, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 8.91 points. Investors are cautious ahead of the Fed's conclusion, despite expectations of a signal to withdraw pandemic-era support.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q3 DPU up 0.8% to S$0.0356
summary: Parkway Life Reit reported a 0.8% increase in its third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0356, driven by higher rent from Singapore properties and revenue from Japan acquisitions. Despite a 2.9% decline in net property income due to a one-off allowance for doubtful debts, the Reit's year-to-date DPU rose 2.9% to S$0.1051. The company has also secured master leases for its Singapore hospitals and executed a 3-year committed loan facility to term out remaining loans, reducing its long-term debt refinancing needs.

site_title: Lufthansa posts surprise return to profit as bookings surge
summary: Lufthansa reported a surprise profit of 17 million euros in the third quarter, its first profit since the start of the Covid pandemic, driven by a surge in cargo demand. The airline's cargo arm posted a record 301 million-euro profit, while its full-service airlines reported a 304 million-euro loss. Passenger demand is increasing, with bookings reaching four-fifths of pre-crisis levels, and the airline plans to offer over 70% of its usual capacity in 2022. This marks a significant improvement from its previous prediction of a narrower loss.

site_title: US private payrolls rise strongly in October
summary: US private payrolls rose strongly in October, increasing by 571,000 jobs, according to the ADP National Employment Report. Economists had forecast 400,000 jobs added. Labor market indicators improved, with initial claims for unemployment benefits below 300,000 for the first time since the pandemic, and the Conference Board's labor market differential hitting a 21-year high. Despite worker shortages, hiring pace remained solid, and the economy is expected to create 450,000 jobs overall in October.

site_title: Retail Reits need to pivot to omnichannel options, de-emphasise F&B
summary: Singapore-listed retail real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) are showing signs of improvement, with several reporting higher gross revenue and net property income. However, their recovery is contingent upon a more definitive lifting of restrictions, and they may need to adapt to a new normal. Retail S-Reits are de-emphasizing food and beverage (F&B) tenants, which are typically seen as crowd pullers, and are instead focusing on omnichannel retailing initiatives to drive organic growth. The industry is shifting towards a more purposeful and online shopping experience, with some S-Reits seeing success with apps and e-commerce platforms.

images.alt_text: Among the retail S-Reits that unveiled their results last week were Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Mapletree Commercial Trust and Starhill Global Reit, which have significant exposure to malls in Singapore.

site_title: US 'absolutely' has ability to defend Taiwan, says top Pentagon general
summary: US Joint Chiefs Chairman Mark Milley stated that the US military "absolutely" has the ability to defend Taiwan from an attack by China, if called upon to do so. Milley warned that China's rapid technological advancements, including its recent hypersonic missile test, pose a significant threat to global stability. Despite this, he does not expect China to take military action against Taiwan within the next 24 months. The US maintains a policy of "strategic ambiguity" regarding its response to a potential Chinese attack on Taiwan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, down 6.3 points to 1531.33, with a 647-322 loss-gain ratio. Volume reached 3.419 billion lots worth RM2.353 billion.

site_title: China ministry orders 38 apps to rectify excessive collection of personal data
summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology ordered 38 apps, including social media giant Tencent's news and music streaming apps, to rectify excessive personal data collection. The move comes after China's Personal Information Protection Law went into effect, which dictates online privacy practices. The apps have until November 9 to comply or face administrative penalties. This is part of a broader regulatory crackdown in China, following the implementation of the Data Security Law.

site_title: Winding-up petition filed against Gold Mart, unit that Hatten Land is divesting
summary: A winding-up petition has been filed against Gold Mart Sdn Bhd, a Hatten Land unit being divested to Singapore-based Tayrona Capital Group Corp, for RM1.38 million (S$449,000). Gold Mart claims it is indebted to the petitioners, who have consented to stay the application pending an appeal. Hatten Land does not expect the petition to significantly impact its business operations and advises shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in the company's shares.

site_title: Lagarde says ECB is 'very unlikely' to hike rates next year
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that the ECB is "very unlikely" to hike interest rates next year, citing subdued medium-term inflation outlook and three conditions that need to be satisfied before rates will rise.

site_title: Singapore reports 3,635 new Covid-19 cases; weekly infection growth rate down to 0.96
summary: Singapore reported 3,635 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 207,975. The weekly infection growth rate decreased to 0.96, down from 1.09 the previous day. Twelve people aged 59-99 died from complications linked to Covid-19, increasing the death toll to 442. Local cases included 535 people above 60 years old, with 3,223 in the community, 409 in migrant worker dormitories, and three imported cases.

site_title: Babies wanted: Chinese province may offer a year of maternity leave
summary: China's Shaanxi province is considering a significant increase in paid maternity leave to nearly one full year, aiming to encourage couples to have children. The proposed 168 days of additional maternity leave would put the province in line with some European nations. Shaanxi is also considering doubling paternity leave to 30 days for couples with three children. This move comes after China's recent decision to allow married couples to have up to three children, following a decline in births.

site_title: COP26 coalition worth US$130t vows to put climate at heart of finance
summary: Banks, insurers, and investors with $130 trillion in capital pledged to prioritize limiting climate change, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 1.5 degrees Celsius. The Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ) was launched to raise private funds for climate-friendly projects. The alliance's goal is to secure $100 trillion in investment over three decades, with a focus on transparency and standardization. The move aims to prevent "greenwashing" and ensure that financial institutions account for climate risks, with key players including BlackRock and the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: China targets 1.8% cut in average coal use at power plants by 2025
summary: China has set a target to reduce the average coal use for electricity generation at power plants by 1.8% by 2025, aiming to lower greenhouse gas emissions. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) aims to adjust the consumption rate to 300 grams of standard coal per kilowatt-hour, down from 305.5 grams in 2020. This move is part of China's efforts to peak carbon emissions before 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS seeks views on classification of complex investment products, including perps, through a consultation paper. The MAS report highlights emerging trends in corporate governance, with more independent directors but shrinking board sizes. The government is prepared to address inflation concerns with a multi-pronged approach. New businesses outnumber closures, with over 5,000 firms registered monthly. The MAS is assessing controls on illicit financial flows, while Singapore's defence investments arm backs a decade-old university project with a 7-digit seed funding round. Corporate earnings show mixed results, with UOB and OCBC reporting increases in profit.

site_title: WHO approves emergency listing of India's first homegrown Covid-19 shot
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has approved India's first homegrown Covid-19 vaccine, Covaxin, for emergency use. The vaccine, developed by Bharat Biotech, meets WHO standards for protection against Covid-19 and has been recommended for use in all age groups 18 and above. The approval paves the way for Covaxin to be accepted as a valid vaccine in many poor countries and will allow Bharat to ship the vaccine to countries that rely on WHO guidance for their regulatory decisions.

site_title: Hong Kong-based insurer FWD adds to warnings in New York IPO push
summary: Hong Kong-based insurer FWD Group has warned US regulators that Beijing may intervene or influence its operations, adding to its list of risk factors as it tries to list in New York. FWD, controlled by billionaire Richard Li, aims to raise $2-3 billion in its US IPO, valued at $13-15 billion. The insurer has a business presence in 10 Asian markets but no China operations. FWD has expanded its risk factors section to highlight the potential for Chinese government intervention, which could impact its business.

site_title: Singapore's outward-facing sectors make productivity gains while others struggled
summary: Singapore's labour productivity rose in outward-oriented sectors such as manufacturing, wholesale trade, and finance in 2020, with growth rates of 18.6% and 3.1%, respectively. In contrast, sectors severely disrupted by Covid-19 restrictions, including construction, transportation, and food and beverage services, experienced declines in productivity. Productivity growth in 2021 is expected to follow a similar pattern, with most outward-oriented sectors remaining positive. Productivity in disrupted sectors is likely to remain below pre-Covid-19 levels.

site_title: China's latest Delta outbreak its most widespread since Wuhan
summary: China is experiencing its most widespread Delta Covid-19 outbreak since Wuhan in 2019, with over 600 local infections reported in 19 provinces. The highly-infectious Delta variant continues to spread despite aggressive measures taken by local officials. As of Wednesday, China reported 93 new local cases and 11 asymptomatic infections, with three additional provinces detecting cases in central Chongqing, Henan, and Jiangsu.

site_title: US factory orders unexpectedly rise in September
summary: US factory orders unexpectedly rose 0.2% in September, driven by strong demand for goods despite manufacturing constraints due to input shortages. This marks a year-over-year increase of 17.6%. Manufacturing accounts for 12% of the economy, with businesses rebuilding depleted inventories. Shipments and unfilled orders rose, but orders for certain products, such as computers and electronics, fell due to a global chip shortage. The increase suggests a potential rebound in business spending on equipment, but inflation could cut into gains.

site_title: Singapore shares falter despite Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.39% on Wednesday, November 3, 2021, despite Wall Street's third consecutive day of record highs. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,219.69 points. The decline was attributed to weak growth momentum in China and concerns about the US Federal Reserve meeting. The Jakarta Composite Index was the only exception, rising 0.91%.

site_title: Public transport fares to rise by 3 to 4 cents for adults from Dec 26
summary: Singapore's public transport fares will increase by 2.2% starting December 26, translating to a 3-4 cent hike for adults paying by card. Concessionary fares for seniors, students, and low-wage workers will rise by 1 cent. The fare hike aims to offset rising operating costs, including energy and wages, despite reduced ridership due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The 2.2% increase is the result of a fare review exercise, with the Public Transport Council (PTC) considering factors such as ridership, cost pressures, and fare affordability.

site_title: Europe: Equity markets flat before Fed meeting
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained flat on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, where plans to begin tapering stimulus are expected. London's FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices remained unchanged. Analysts predict a gradual start to the tapering of bond purchases, with the Bank of England expected to raise interest rates on Thursday to combat inflation.

site_title: ESR Cayman shareholders approve acquisition of ARA Asset Management, paving way for ESR-Reit, ARA Logos merger
summary: ESR Cayman shareholders have approved the acquisition of ARA Asset Management, creating the largest real asset manager in the Asia-Pacific. The acquisition, expected to close by end-2021 or Q1 2022, paves the way for a merger of ESR-Reit and ARA Logos Logistics Trust. The enlarged group will have $131 billion of assets under management, making it the third-largest listed real estate investment manager globally. The transaction has received 91.81% of votes in favor, with three non-executive directors elected to the board.

site_title: Henderson to pay record US$6.5b for Hong Kong land site
summary: Henderson Land Development won a record-breaking US$6.5 billion bid for a prime land plot in Hong Kong's Central business district, surpassing the previous record set by Sun Hung Kai Properties. The 47,967 square meter site, located near Victoria Harbour, will yield a maximum floor area of 150,000 square meters. The developer plans to build three buildings, including a multifunctional block closest to the harbor, with a focus on office space and sustainable design. The sale is a vote of confidence in Hong Kong's commercial real estate market, but may pose challenges in attracting tenants due to weakening demand and increasing office supply.

site_title: With US leasing recovery in full swing, Manulife US Reit eyes acquisitions
summary: Manulife US Reit is seeking acquisitions to boost growth amid a surge in US office property transactions. The Reit manager, Jill Smith, aims for accretive deals with 6.5-7.5% capitalization rates, focusing on tech and healthcare sectors in cities like Austin, San Diego, and Denver. The Reit's leasing volume increased to 39.2 million sq ft in Q3 FY2021, with 7.7-year tenures, reflecting growing corporate confidence in the US economy's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (REITs) reported strong quarterly earnings. Prime US Reit posted a 11.3% increase in distribution income to US$20 million, driven by leasing activity. NetLink NBN Trust's distribution per unit rose 1.2% to 2.56 Singapore cents, despite a 9.4% decline in Ebitda. ARA US Hospitality Trust reported a 31.6% increase in gross operating profit to US$15 million. Cromwell European Reit posted a 8.4% year-on-year gain in net property income, driven by newly-acquired assets and positive performances of its light industrial and logistics properties.

site_title: India's largest bank SBI reports record US$1b Q4 profit
summary: State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest lender, reported a record quarterly profit of $1.02 billion, a 66.7% increase from the previous year, beating analyst expectations. The bank's provisions for bad loans declined 52% to $26.99 billion, and its gross bad loan ratio fell to 4.90%. SBI shares rose 1% following the results, outperforming the NSE Nifty 50 index this year. The bank's strong performance is attributed to a rebound in credit demand as the economy reopened fully and low interest rates boosted spending.

site_title: COE prices end higher in latest tender as supply shrinks
summary: COE prices in Singapore ended higher across the board in the latest tender due to a double-digit drop in supply of certificates. The COE premium for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp rose to S$53,709, while the premium for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp increased to S$82,801. The open COE price rose to S$88,000, and the commercial vehicle COE price closed at S$42,001. Bidding remained subdued until the open COE price breached S$70,000, leading to a surge in bids.

site_title: Hong Kong, BIS develop platforms for green bond investing
summary: Hong Kong's de facto central bank and the Bank of International Settlements have developed two platforms to facilitate retail investors' access to government green bonds. The platforms utilize blockchain technology, enabling real-time tracking of environmental impact and interest accrued. This initiative aims to help Hong Kong fulfill its climate obligations under the Paris agreement, with the city setting ambitious carbon emission reduction goals. The move follows Hong Kong's release of its Climate Action Plan 2050 and the sale of US$2.5 billion of green bonds this year.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark best day in a month as banks, miners rebound
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to 7,392.7, their best day in a month, as investors reacted to the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision not to hike interest rates anytime soon. Financials and miners led gains, with Commonwealth Bank rising to its highest close since August 11 after announcing crypto services. Asian shares were cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's announcement on tapering pandemic-era monetary stimulus.

site_title: Venture Corp net profit up sequentially to S$77m in Q3, though down year-on-year
summary: Venture Corp reported a sequential increase in net profit to S$77 million in Q3, driven by rising revenue to S$769.9 million. However, year-on-year revenue fell due to global component shortages and the Extended Movement Control Order in Malaysia. The company expects demand for its services to remain healthy, with new products to be launched globally. Investments will be made to secure parts and expand science and technology talent. Net profit for the first nine months is S$217.4 million, up 3.2% from the year-ago period.

site_title: Lufthansa jumps back to profit as travel restrictions ease
summary: Lufthansa has returned to operating profit in the third quarter, posting an adjusted Ebit of 17 million euros, its first profit since the pandemic began. The airline's revenue nearly doubled to 5.2 billion euros, driven by the easing of Covid-19 travel restrictions and strong demand in the summer season. This surpasses analyst expectations of an adjusted Ebit loss of 33 million euros.

site_title: More businesses were set up than shut down in last 2 years, despite Covid-19
summary: In the last two years, more businesses were established than dissolved in Singapore, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. On average, over 5,000 new firms were registered each month, exceeding the 3,840 firms deregistered monthly. The retail sector saw a net growth of 6,970 firms, while tourism businesses remained stable, with licensed hotels and tourist guides remaining largely intact. Government support measures helped businesses recover, and the government is working to strengthen Singapore's physical and digital connectivity to prepare for the post-COVID-19 recovery.

images.alt_text: An average of more than 5,000 new firms were registered each month over the last two years, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling. This exceeded the average number of firms that were deregistered each month, which, at 3,840, is comparable to the period from 2017 to 2019.

site_title: UOB to launch 'buy now, pay later' feature in Indonesia; banks watching space
summary: UOB will launch a "buy now, pay later" feature in Indonesia called TMRW Pay, in partnership with an unnamed local company. This move comes as the Singapore BNPL market experiences changes, with Standard Chartered partnering with Atome and ShopBack acquiring its peer hoolah. The service aims to capitalize on Indonesia's growing demand for such services, which are expected to expand in the country.

site_title: Ether scales US$4,600 to record high, Bitcoin trails
summary: Ether, the world's second-largest cryptocurrency, reached an all-time high of US$4,643 on November 3, surpassing the previous day's US$4,600. The token's value has surged 10% for the week, with bitcoin trading around US$63,078 and up 117% this year. Ethereum's strength has been moving in stride with bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies, driven by news of blockchain adoption, NFT growth, and the need for diversification among investors.

site_title: Global credit conditions to stabilise in 2022, but Covid-linked challenges remain: Report
summary: Global credit conditions are expected to stabilize in 2022, but Covid-linked challenges remain. Moody's report notes that inflation risks are high, and elevated inflation could strain household budgets and weigh on growth. The global economic recovery is expected to solidify, with most G-20 economies surpassing pre-pandemic real GDP levels by the end of 2022. However, low-income countries and those heavily reliant on tourism will face challenges, and supply-chain disruptions will persist into 2022, although their effects will lessen in the second half of the year.

site_title: Units at CanningHill Piers along Singapore River priced at S$1.16m and above; more VTLs may spur demand
summary: Singapore's CanningHill Piers luxury residence, set to be completed in 2025, has units priced from S$1.16 million for a one-bedroom apartment, with indicative prices ranging from S$8.1 million for a five-bedroom unit and S$50 million for a penthouse. The development, developed by CapitaLand Development and City Developments Limited, is expected to drive more foreign investment and attract buyers seeking separate living spaces due to the work-from-home trend. The 696-unit development will be part of the Liang Court site redevelopment, offering scenic views of the city, river, and hill.

site_title: Malaysia holds rates on recovery, 'benign' inflation outlook
summary: Malaysia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 1.75% to support a nascent economic recovery as virus restrictions ease and inflation remains under control. The central bank expects core inflation to edge up but remain "benign" and average below 1% this year. The rate decision follows the government's unveiling of a record $80 billion budget for 2022 aimed at boosting its recovery from the pandemic. The central bank will continue to keep monetary policy accommodative to aid economic recovery.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's SPH is facing a rival offer for its assets from a consortium led by HPL and Ong Beng Seng's Temasek units, CLA and Mapletree, with a full cash offer of S$2.10 per share. Employers can now terminate unvaccinated workers as a last resort, according to a new MOM advisory. Keppel Offshore & Marine has been sued for over US$800 million in the US over investment loss. Unvaccinated individuals will be barred from workplaces starting January 1, 2022, with a negative test required for return.

site_title: Taiwan welcomes first official European Parliament delegation
summary: Taiwan welcomed its first official European Parliament delegation, a significant move towards strengthening ties with the European Union. The visit comes amid heightened tensions between Taipei and Beijing. Taiwan, which has not ruled out taking Beijing by force, seeks to deepen ties with EU democracies. This marks a crucial step for Taiwan in expanding its diplomatic presence in Europe. The visit is seen as a major development in Taiwan's efforts to strengthen its international relationships and counterbalance China's influence.

site_title: Hong Kong in talks with China to open border
summary: Hong Kong is in advanced discussions with China to reopen their shared border, potentially reviving travel crucial to the city's economy. Experts from both sides are set to meet to discuss a mainland-style health code system and a quota for quarantine-free travel. A "circuit-breaker" to immediately suspend the system in an emergency is also being considered. The resumption of travel could be a major economic boost for Hong Kong, which has sought to kickstart cross-border travel for months. A final decision is expected soon, with officials considering conditions and quotas for travel to the mainland.

site_title: Developer Evergrande says 57,400 properties handed to buyers
summary: Evergrande, a Chinese property developer, reported delivering over 57,400 units to buyers between July and October, aiming to calm concerns over its liquidity crisis. The move comes as the company tries to shore up confidence after making overdue interest payments and resuming work on stalled projects. The completed properties are across 184 different projects, with shares rising over 2.5% in Hong Kong. Evergrande's debt mountain is estimated at over $300 billion, but the company has averted default twice in October. China's central bank appears to be easing regulations, potentially easing the crisis.

site_title: 24/7 multiple CBDC network could save global corporates US$100b yearly: whitepaper
summary: A whitepaper by JPMorgan and Oliver Wyman estimates that a 24/7 multi-currency central bank digital currency (mCBDC) network could save global corporations $100 billion annually in transaction costs. This is achieved through an 80% reduction in transaction costs, from $120 billion to $27. The current correspondent banking system, which facilitates cross-border payments, is outdated and inefficient, resulting in long settlement times and high costs. An mCBDC model, featuring simultaneous settlements and 24/7 infrastructure, is proposed as a solution to achieve seamless and scalable cross-border payments.

site_title: Indonesia's GDP growth set to slow in Q3 as Covid-19 curbs bite
summary: Indonesia's economic growth is expected to slow significantly in Q3 due to COVID-19 curbs, with forecasts ranging from 1.6% to 5.2% growth, below the government's forecast of 4.5%. The country's GDP growth in the July-September period is expected to be 3.76%, a decline from the 7.07% growth in the second quarter. The economic slowdown is attributed to the services sector being hit hard by the pandemic, with higher debt and impaired balance sheets expected to leave a lasting impact.

site_title: AirAsia interested in potential Airbus A321neo freighter
summary: AirAsia Group is in talks with Airbus to develop a factory-built freighter version of the A321neo passenger plane. The cargo arm of AirAsia, Teleport, is interested in converting some of its 362 passenger orders to a dedicated freighter. The potential freighter would cater to markets requiring both range and capacity, and AirAsia is uncertain if it would be the launch customer. Airbus is reportedly in talks with customers about the new build freighter version, but no decision has been announced.

site_title: More independent directors, but board sizes shrinking in Singapore: SID report
summary: In Singapore, the 2021 Directorship Report by the Singapore Institute of Directors (SID) found that 54.4% of boards now have independent directors, up from 47.5% in 2014. Average board size has decreased to 5, with 25.8% of companies having 5-member boards. The report also noted an increase in firms refreshing their boards, with 24.6% of independent directors having served for more than 9 years. However, women directors still make up only 12.7% of board seats, and diversity remains a challenge.

site_title: US Republican Youngkin's win in Virginia plots party's path for 2022 elections
summary: US Republican Glenn Youngkin's victory in the Virginia governor's election may serve as a blueprint for the party's strategy to retake majorities in Congress in 2022. Youngkin's approach of appealing to suburban moderates and avoiding alienating Donald Trump's supporters, while also focusing on issues like school safety and racism, could be a model for Republicans across the country. The win comes ahead of next year's midterm elections, which will determine control of the US Congress.

site_title: MAS seeks views on classification of complex products, including perps
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking public comments on classifying complex investment products, including perpetual securities and collective investment schemes, as specified investment products (SIPs). This reclassification would provide enhanced safeguards for retail investors. MAS is also looking to classify debentures and preference shares under the same category. The move aims to improve the distribution of these products to retail investors and enhance regulatory oversight.

images.alt_text: The consultation seeks to enhance MAS's existing complex products regime introduced in 2012.

site_title: Crypto exchange becomes unicorn; Bitkub's coin surges 200% after banking giant buys stake
summary: Bitkub Online Co, Thailand's largest crypto exchange, has reached a valuation of over $1 billion after selling a majority stake to Siam Commercial Bank (SCB). The deal valued Bitkub at approximately 35 billion baht. As a result, Bitkub's coin surged 200% to a record $2.85, while SCB shares rose 3.5%. The acquisition is part of SCB's expansion into digital assets, aiming to create new growth value and meet consumer needs.

site_title: E-commerce roll-up company Una Brands raises US$15m in Series A funds
summary: Una Brands, a Singapore-based e-commerce acquirer, has raised US$15 million in Series A equity funding led by White Star Capital and Alpha JWC Ventures. The company aims to invest in acquiring great brands, expanding into new markets, and supporting brands' growth. Since its founding last year, Una Brands has acquired over 15 brands, with some seeing a 50% increase in sales and profits since acquisition. The company believes there is a US$20 billion opportunity for e-commerce brand acquirers in Asia-Pacific, driven by the growth of digitally native brands.

site_title: New Zealand warns of economic vulnerabilities in the Pacific
summary: New Zealand's Foreign Minister Nanaia Mahuta has warned of economic vulnerabilities in the Pacific region due to China's growing investment, which she believes creates significant economic vulnerability and debt. Mahuta emphasized the need for partnerships that bolster resilience as the world recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic. New Zealand offers partnerships to strengthen the region's resilience, while acknowledging the respectful but inconsistent relationship with China, particularly in the human rights space. The country's "Pacific Reset" aims to link New Zealand's future to a safe, secure, and prosperous Pacific.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks dip ahead of Fed decision
summary: South Korean stocks dropped 1.25% on Wednesday as traders awaited a potential US Federal Reserve decision to taper pandemic-era stimulus. The Kospi benchmark fell 37.78 points to 2,975.71, while the Korean won weakened and bond yields fell. The spread of Covid-19 in China also contributed to the decline in sentiment, according to analyst Kim Seok-hwan of Mirae Asset Securities.

site_title: MAS mulls over need to tighten controls on illicit financial flows following Pandora Papers
summary: Singapore's financial regulator is considering tightening controls on illicit financial flows amid the Pandora Papers scandal, despite the documents not raising significant concerns about the country's anti-money laundering and combating financing of terrorism controls. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that 336 prominent individuals had established offshore structures in at least 38 jurisdictions, but Singapore's controls have been deemed sufficient. The regulator will engage financial institutions to assess the need for tighter controls.

images.alt_text: The two licensed trust companies in Singapore mentioned in the Pandora Papers were already under "intensified scrutiny" by MAS before they were named in the leaked documents, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Thai economy may not grow much this year: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's deputy prime minister, Supattanapong Punmeechaow, stated that the country's economic growth is expected to be subdued this year due to the impacts of the coronavirus outbreak. However, the country has passed the worst of the pandemic and fiscal and financial stability remains sound. This assessment comes as Thailand navigates the ongoing economic challenges, but the deputy prime minister expressed optimism about the country's economic prospects.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment books 33% growth in fees related earnings in Q3, establishes 2 new funds
summary: CapitaLand Investment reported a 33% growth in fee-related earnings to S$94.6 million in Q3 FY21, driven by a 9% rise in funds under management and capital recycling. The company established two new funds in Japan and South Korea, with a combined target of S$688 million, to increase funds under management. The lodging management business also reported 33% year-on-year revenue growth, with occupancy of around 60% for Q3 FY21. The company aims to reach S$100 billion in funds under management by 2024.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment booked a 33 per cent growth in fee-related earnings for Q3 FY21 to S$94.6 million from S$71.1 million a year ago in its first business update since listing on the bourse in September.

site_title: SGX-backed private market exchange ADDX lists its first cryptocurrency product
summary: SGX-backed private market exchange ADDX has listed its first cryptocurrency product, the TCM Digital Asset Fund, for accredited investors. The fund, managed by Trovio Capital Management, takes core positions in Bitcoin and Ethereum and invests in 8 other top-performing cryptocurrencies. The fund has a 60% core position in Bitcoin and Ethereum and recorded a 215% return in 2020. It charges a 1.5% management fee and a 15% performance fee on net returns. The fund's minimum investment size is US$10,000, and it is custodied by Nasdaq-listed Coinbase.

site_title: Indonesia could phase out coal by 2040 with financial help: finance minister
summary: Indonesia may phase out coal-fired power plants by 2040 with international financial aid, according to Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati. The Southeast Asian country is the world's fourth-most populous and eighth-largest greenhouse gas emitter, with coal making up 65% of its energy mix. Indonesia aims to move to cleaner energy sources, with the coal phase-out being a key issue, as it is the world's biggest coal exporter.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Wednesday
summary: Financial markets in Tokyo are closed on Wednesday due to a holiday. In contrast, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, a mandatory offer was made by Sam Goi for the rest of Popiah king PSC at S$0.40 per share. Traders in Asia are brushing off new Trump threats, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reached new highs.

site_title: Gold edges down as investors cautiously eye Fed verdict
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,784.04 per ounce on Wednesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's verdict on its stimulus tapering timeline. The Fed is expected to announce its plan to pare monthly asset purchases by $15 billion each month, with purchases to end by mid-2022. Investors are cautious about the Fed's decision, which could impact gold prices.

site_title: UOB Q3 profit up 57%; watching digital asset space but 'not 100% convinced' about cryptocurrencies
summary: UOB's third-quarter profit rose 57% to S$1.05 billion, driven by healthy loan growth and sustained fee income. The bank is cautious on cryptocurrencies, but sees potential in central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) and digital asset tokenisation. UOB is partnering with digital asset platforms and focusing on CBDCs, particularly in China, where it expects to benefit from cross-border flows. The bank's annualised earnings per share increased 58.7% to S$2.46, beating analyst estimates. UOB's net interest income and net fee income also rose, while non-performing loans and allowances decreased.

site_title: Some 450 firms representing US$130t of assets join net-zero emissions coalition
summary: Over 450 firms, representing $130 trillion in assets, have joined the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ), nearly doubling the initial $70 trillion in assets. The alliance, chaired by former central banker Mark Carney, aims to meet the Paris climate agreement's net-zero emissions goal by mid-century. However, critics question the alliance's commitment to stopping fossil fuel financing, with some firms still investing in oil, gas, and coal. The UK has pledged to become a net-zero aligned financial center, with plans to establish clear standards for measuring and analyzing net zero commitments.

site_title: China opposes US revocation of licence for China Telecom
summary: China has strongly opposed the US revocation of China Telecom Corp's license to operate in the US, calling it an "unreasonable suppression" of Chinese enterprises by abuse of state power. The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) cited national security concerns for the decision, which China claims lacks justification. China Telecom has vowed to comply with US regulations, while the US government had previously alleged the company targeted over 4 million Chinese Americans, 2 million Chinese tourists, 300,000 Chinese students, and 1,500 Chinese businesses in the US.

site_title: Parliament: Inflation 'a clear and present issue', but Singapore ready to tweak policies
summary: Singapore's government acknowledges inflation as a "clear and present issue" but remains committed to a multi-pronged approach to tackle it. Despite projected inflation rates of 2% in 2021 and 1.5-2.5% in 2022, the country's economic recovery is on track, with GDP growth expected to range from 6-7% for the year. The government will monitor inflation closely and adjust policies where necessary, while implementing measures to mitigate the impact of rising costs on households and businesses.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan told the House on Wednesday that Singapore could see business and consumer costs go up on factors such as increases in global energy and food commodity prices.

site_title: EDP Renewables buys stake in Sunseap; valuing company at S$1.1b
summary: EDP Renewables (EDPR), the world's fourth-largest renewable energy producer, has acquired a significant stake in Singapore-based renewable energy firm Sunseap Group for S$1.1 billion. The deal will expand EDPR's renewables platform in Asia and enhance the deployment of its US$22 billion investment plan through 2025. Sunseap will become a major shareholder under EDPR's ownership, marking a significant investment in the Asian renewable energy market.

site_title: British woman wins court battle against Australia 'backpacker tax'
summary: A British woman, Catherine Addy, won a court battle against Australia's "backpacker tax", which unfairly discriminated against foreigners on working holiday visas. The levy, applied since 2017, charged 15% on earnings for specific visas linked to seasonal labor. The Australian High Court unanimously ruled in her favor, potentially benefiting thousands of other backpackers who may be eligible for a tax refund. The ruling reverses a levy that targeted foreign workers, including Addy, who worked in Sydney in 2017.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of Federal Reserve meeting as China concerns weigh
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, with investors cautious about inflation and interest rate hikes. Despite strong earnings and record-breaking Wall Street indexes, concerns about China's economy and rising prices continue to weigh on markets. Hong Kong and Shanghai retreated again due to Covid-19 concerns, while the Bank of England is expected to announce a rate rise. The Fed's decision on tapering its bond-buying program and signaling rate hikes will be closely watched.

site_title: Myanmar says no Suu Kyi visit for envoy, would be unlawful
summary: Myanmar's ruling junta says it won't allow a special Asean envoy to meet with detained former leader Aung San Suu Kyi, citing domestic laws and the fact she's facing trial. The decision comes despite an agreement between Myanmar and Asean that a visit would depend on internal stability. No other country would allow such a move, according to Vice-Senior General Soe Win.

images.alt_text: Myanmar will not allow a special Asean envoy to meet with detained former leader Aung San Suu Kyi, a top official in the ruling junta said, because it is beyond the country's domestic laws.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB raises target price for Hongkong Land on companies returning to offices
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB is raising its target price for Hongkong Land to US$6.30, from US$5.48, due to companies returning to offices in Hong Kong. Office rents in key business districts have fallen 5-13% year-over-year but leasing demand has improved, leading to "officerecentralisation". This trend benefits large office landlords like Hongkong Land, according to CGS-CIMB analyst Raymond Cheng. The analyst believes the company's valuation is attractive and maintains an "add" call.

site_title: Singapore defence investments arm backs decade-old university project
summary: Singapore's Defence Science and Technology Agency-backed investment arm, Cap Vista, has provided a 7-digit seed funding round to autonomous underwater robot startup BeeX. Founded by National University of Singapore students nearly a decade ago, BeeX aims to keep marine infrastructure safe without risking human lives. The funding will support the expansion of its software team and development of autonomous capabilities for diverse environments, including ports and vessels. This investment highlights the growing trend of private sector involvement in research and innovation, particularly in areas like defence and sustainability.

site_title: Federal Reserve starts deliberations with US stimulus pullback expected
summary: The US Federal Reserve began its two-day policy meeting, expected to announce a pullback of its stimulus program, which has been in place since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. The Fed aims to slow its massive bond buying program amid rising inflation, now above the 2% goal. A policy statement on Wednesday is expected to set the date for tapering asset purchases and may signal an interest rate hike in 2022.

site_title: SingPost H1 profit rises 13.3% to S$35m on growth in domestic businesses
summary: SingPost's net profit for the first half of the fiscal year ended September 2021 rose 13.3% to S$35 million, driven by growth in domestic businesses, particularly logistics and property segments. Revenue increased to S$731.4 million, while operating profit rose 28.4% to S$51.1 million. The company attributed the growth to increased e-commerce delivery revenue and investments in Australia. Despite a decline in international post and parcel revenue, the company maintained an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per ordinary share and announced promotions for its CEOs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.18 points or 0.14% to 1,539.81, opening higher on Wednesday. The index saw 368.45 million lots traded worth RM155.39 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 205 to 178.

site_title: Transforming patient care in Asia with intelligent automation
summary: Advanced technologies like artificial intelligence (AI) and robots are transforming patient care in Asia Pacific (APAC) by addressing challenges such as patient safety, worker retention, and workflow processes. Hospitals are deploying AI and robots to automate administrative duties, minimally invasive surgeries, and supply chain management. A recent study found that 94% of hospitals in Singapore, 84% in Australia, and 89% in China are exploring and trialing digital health solutions. However, it's essential to balance technology with human touch to ensure deep expertise and complex interactions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day slightly lower, easing 0.15% to 25,060.93, as investors await the Federal Reserve's conclusion on monetary policy. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.13%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.09%. The decline comes ahead of the Fed meeting's expected impact on global markets.

site_title: Oil mixed in choppy trade before US inventories, Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices fell below $85 a barrel on Tuesday amidst a rise in US crude inventories and anticipation of a potential increase in production at the Opec+ meeting. Industry analysts expect a 1.6 million barrel rise in US crude inventories, set to be released on Wednesday. The meeting, scheduled for Thursday, may impact oil prices as it could determine production levels. Oil prices have been volatile, with the recent increase in US inventories and the looming Opec+ meeting contributing to the choppy trade.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners drive shares 1% higher
summary: Australia's shares rose 1% on Wednesday, driven by strong overnight gains on Wall Street and a rebound from losses recorded the previous day. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,395.8, with miners and heavyweight financials leading the gains. Fortescue Metals Group and the "Big Four" banks advanced, while AMP shares surged 7% after agreeing to sell its remaining stake in Resolution Life's Australia business.

site_title: StanChart Q3 profit doubles as bad loans shrink, trade finance booms
summary: Standard Chartered posted a stronger-than-expected pre-tax profit for the third quarter, with statutory pre-tax profit reaching $996 million, doubling from $435 million in the same period last year. The bank's growth in trade finance and lower credit charges contributed to the increase. This marks a recovery for the bank in pandemic-hit markets.

site_title: US: Dow ends above 36,000 points for first time, extending rally
summary: US stocks closed at records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% at 36,052.63, its first close above 36,000 points. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also finished at records, driven by strong corporate earnings and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's decision to begin trimming its stimulus package. The market is awaiting key labor data and the outcome of President Biden's infrastructure and social spending agenda.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) declining 0.03 points to 3,232.34. Losers outpaced gainers 72 to 62, with 47.8 million securities worth S$61.2 million changing hands. Key movers included Genting Singapore, Sembcorp Marine, and Singapore Press Holdings, which fell 0.5% and 1.3% respectively. In contrast, DBS rose 0.6% and UOB 0.04% on the back of strong quarterly results.

site_title: Shares in South Korea fintech firm Kakao Pay jump in debut
summary: Shares in South Korea's fintech firm Kakao Pay Corp doubled in value from their initial public offering (IPO) price, opening at 180,000 won on debut on KOSPI. The company raised 1.5 trillion won (S$1.71 billion) from its IPO, exceeding its initial target. This marks a successful debut for the financial technology firm, with its shares more than doubling in value from the IPO price of 90,000 won.

site_title: Chip shortage to last through 2022: Arm CEO
summary: The head of Arm Holdings, Simon Segars, predicts that the global chip shortage will last until the end of 2022, despite a planned 50% increase in production. The semiconductor industry is currently investing $2 billion per week, but supply will remain tight in the near term. Segars expressed caution, stating that supply chain constraints will not be completely fixed by next Christmas.

site_title: New Zealand unemployment rate drops to record low in Q3
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate has dropped to a record low of 3.4% in the third quarter, beating expectations. The rate matches the record low set in December 2007. The seasonally adjusted employment increased by 2.0%, while the participation rate rose to 71.2%. Strong wage growth and a rising New Zealand dollar also contributed to the data, with markets forecasting a further interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand this month.

site_title: Facebook ends facial recognition over privacy fears
summary: Facebook is shutting down its facial recognition system, which automatically identified people in digital photos, due to privacy concerns. The system, launched in 2010, was central to a lawsuit and regulatory scrutiny, and the company agreed to a $650 million payout in 2020. The decision comes amid a crisis for the tech giant, following the leak of internal documents and calls for government regulation. Over a billion people's facial recognition templates will be deleted, and the company will wind down the system over the coming weeks.

site_title: Cryptocurrency plays off Squid Game and buyers lose big
summary: A cryptocurrency called Squid Game, launched on October 21 without Netflix's permission, saw its value plummet after its release. The digital asset played off the hit Netflix series, which has been touted as the streaming service's most-watched program. As a result, buyers lost big, highlighting the risks of unregulated and unauthorized cryptocurrency releases.

site_title: UK to unveil plan for first 'net zero' financial centre
summary: UK Finance Minister Rishi Sunak is set to unveil plans to make Britain the world's first 'net zero' financial services centre by 2050. The proposal will require financial institutions and listed companies to publish net-zero transition plans. The announcement is expected to be made at the COP26 climate change conference in Glasgow. The goal aims to reduce carbon emissions and align the UK's financial sector with the country's net-zero target.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB says Raffles Medical price weakness a chance to accumulate
summary: RHB has issued a "buy" call on Raffles Medical, citing the share price weakness as an opportunity to accumulate. The research team sees near-term revenue drivers from Covid-19 testing and facility management. The target price is set at S$1.65, representing a 21.3% upside. The share price has dropped 11% amid concerns over revised on-arrival test requirements for travellers. Raffles Medical's share price fell 0.7% to S$1.36 at the time of the report.

images.alt_text: RHB on Wednesday said Raffles Medical's recent share price weakness is an opportunity to accumulate. It maintains Covid-19 testing and Covid-19 treatment facility management to be a near-term revenue driver.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 90.9% occupancy rate, surge in new leases for Q3 FY2021
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 90.9% occupancy rate for Q3 FY2021, rising to 91.6% after the period, with a 9-fold surge in new leases. New leases made up 32.3% of leased property from Jul 1 to Oct 25, 2021. The Reit also reported a 1.3% rental reversion and increased leasing volume to 39.2 million sq ft, with tenures growing to 7.7 years. The Reit is targeting accretive deals with 6.5-7.5% cap rates in growth segments like technology and healthcare.

site_title: Dubai developer says he's shocked by property rebound
summary: Dubai developer Damac Properties chairman Hussain Sajwani expressed shock at the city's real estate sector rebounding after predicting a disaster from oversupply. Average home prices have risen at the fastest pace since 2015, and transaction volumes surged 77% in August. The city's decision to avoid lockdowns has made it an attractive destination, with coronavirus cases falling sharply amid a fast vaccination drive. Sajwani expects a "surprising" rebound to extend into 2022, and may look to make investments overseas after taking his company private.

site_title: UK parliament tightens Covid rules after surge in infections
summary: The UK Parliament tightened COVID-19 rules amid a surge in cases, with face coverings made compulsory for staff and contractors, but MPs not ordered to wear them. Tours and banquets were cancelled for two weeks, and chairs of committees were asked to ensure mask-wearing and better social distancing. Health Secretary Sajid Javid urged people to get vaccine booster shots as the pandemic is not over, and daily cases reached 40,077.

site_title: Ho Bee Land acquires residential site in Melbourne for A$142m
summary: Singaporean real estate developer Ho Bee Land has acquired a 68.52-hectare residential development site in Melbourne, Australia for A$142 million (S$142.3 million). The site, located 22 km north of Melbourne's central business district, is expected to deliver approximately 1,150 residential lots, parks, and wetlands. The acquisition will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with no significant impact on Ho Bee Land's earnings and net tangible assets.

site_title: US poised for final approval of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5-11
summary: US health authorities are poised for final approval of Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5-11, following a unanimous recommendation by an expert panel. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is expected to endorse the recommendation, allowing injections in young children to begin this week. The vaccine has been distributed and shipments are underway, with White House pandemic coordinator Jeff Zients stating that vaccinations will start towards the end of this week and gain momentum by November 8.

site_title: Brandon Lee's sister says actors need gun safety training
