summary: Brandon Lee's sister, Shannon Lee, advocates for mandatory gun safety training for actors working on Hollywood sets, citing her brother's accidental shooting death in 1993. She believes such training could be a matter of life and death for those in the film industry. Shannon Lee's comments come after her brother's tragic death, highlighting the need for increased safety protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TLV Holdings is changing its trading counter name to "Taka Jewellery" on the Singapore exchange, effective November 8. The company has also changed its name to Taka Jewellery Holdings to increase shareholder awareness of its jewellery businesses. Meanwhile, SingHaiyi Group is selling a two-storey shopping mall in Ohio for $29 million. CDW Holding's subsidiary Tomoike Bio is conducting pre-clinical trials for its anti-Cripto-1 antibody in cancer treatment, with plans to seek pharmaceutical partners for further development.

site_title: Biden says China 'walked away' on climate summit
summary: US President Joe Biden accused China's leader Xi Jinping of walking away from global leadership aspirations by skipping the COP26 climate summit, calling it a "gigantic issue" and questioning China's ability to lead. This move was also seen as a missed opportunity for China to assert its role as a global leader. Biden also criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin for not attending the summit. The Chinese government has not commented on Biden's remarks.

site_title: OCBC's Q3 profit up 19%, debt holidays rise in Malaysia
summary: OCBC Bank's Q3 profit rose 19% to S$1.22 billion, driven by resilient business growth and lower allowances. The bank's loans under moratorium in Malaysia increased to S$6.3 billion, but at a lower rate than last year. Non-performing assets rose 4% to S$4.24 billion, with total credit costs decreasing to 21 basis points. The bank expects a 3-6% gross domestic product growth for its key markets in 2022 and aims to double its relationship managers servicing Chinese clients to 500 by 2023.

images.alt_text: OCBC's net profit for its third quarter rose due to resilient business growth and lower allowances as the credit outlook continued to improve, it said on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia's CBA leads industry to offer in-app crypto trading
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has become the first major Australian bank to offer retail clients cryptocurrency trading services through its banking app, in partnership with Gemini Trust Company LLC. The service will initially offer trading in about ten cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum, starting with a pilot this year. CBA aims to address customer concerns over the lack of trust and security in cryptocurrency services, and will work with Chainalysis to monitor and mitigate cybercrime risks. This move contrasts with CBA's smaller peers, which had refused to do business with cryptocurrency providers.

site_title: Straits Trading showing plenty of value despite strong rise this year
summary: Straits Trading shares have gained 75.1% this year, outperforming the Straits Times Index's 13.7% gain. Despite the strong rise, the stock remains undervalued relative to its book value, suggesting potential for further growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, OCBC, CapitaLand Investment, SingPost, OUE C-Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments affecting their trading on November 3. UOB's net profit jumped 57% to S$1.05 billion, while OCBC's net profit rose 19% to S$1.22 billion. CapitaLand Investment's fee-related earnings increased 34% to S$94.6 million. SingPost posted a 13.3% increase in net profit to S$35 million, while OUE C-Reit's available distribution decreased 7.5% to S$30.2 million. Manulife US Reit reported a 90.9% occupancy rate and a 9 times surge in new leases. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) ended 0.4% higher, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Taiwan to woo backers at Apec Summit for bid to join CPTPP trade pact
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen plans to seek support for the island's bid to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Forum (Apec) Summit. Taiwan and China both applied to join the 11-member pact in September, with China opposing Taiwan's membership due to its claims of sovereignty. Taiwan's representative, Morris Chang, will present the island's case for joining the pact, emphasizing its high trade contribution and adherence to its high standards.

site_title: Companies must put equality at the heart of the race to zero
summary: Companies pursuing net-zero emissions must prioritize equality and inclusivity to avoid exacerbating inequality and undermining progress towards a climate-resilient future. A singular focus on emissions reduction can lead to regressive policies that disproportionately affect low-income households. To mitigate this, companies must engage in smart policymaking, protect the poorest and most vulnerable, and consider the impact of their decisions on employees, communities, and society. By taking a more equitable approach, companies can contribute to a fair transition to a net-zero economy and ensure that no one is left behind.

site_title: Zillow seeks to sell 7,000 homes for US$2.8b after flipping halt
summary: Zillow is selling approximately 7,000 homes worth $2.8 billion to institutional investors, aiming to recover from an operational stumble in its high-tech home-flipping business. The company bought too many houses, resulting in many being listed for less than the initial purchase price. This move comes after Zillow halted new offers in its home-flipping operation for the remainder of 2021, citing a cooling home-price appreciation. The sale effort is larger than usual, with the company likely to sell the homes to multiple buyers rather than a single transaction.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch up to record high on healthcare gains, miners weigh
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% to a record high on Tuesday, driven by healthcare stocks, including Demant's 1.3% gain after hiking its annual profit outlook. Mining stocks fell 2.9% due to a slump in iron ore and copper prices. The market remains volatile, with central bank meetings and inflation concerns to watch. About 65.7% of Stoxx 600 companies have topped profit estimates, according to Refinitiv IBES data.

images.alt_text: European shares crept up to a record high on Tuesday as a strong outlook from hearing aid maker Demant supported healthcare stocks, although broader gains were stifled by losses in miners and the prospect of major central bank meetings.

site_title: Amid China's regulatory crackdowns, sectors that could benefit from policy tailwinds
summary: China's regulatory crackdowns on its tech sector have negatively impacted investor sentiment, leading to massive sell-offs. However, sectors benefiting from policy tailwinds include semiconductors, renewables, and electric vehicles (EVs), which align with the government's long-term strategic priorities. China aims to produce 70% of its semiconductors by 2025, increase renewable energy to 20% of primary energy consumption by 2025, and transition to all-electric or hybrid cars by 2035. These sectors offer opportunities for investors, with ETFs such as the Global X China Semiconductor ETF, Global X China Clean Energy ETF, and Global X China Electric Vehicle and Battery ETF.

site_title: Bright, new horizons: Central Asian startups beckon
summary: Central Asian startups are gaining traction, despite being under-explored by investors. The region's high-quality tech human capital and lower valuations present opportunities for investors. Venture capital firms like Quest Ventures and QazTech Ventures are partnering to support startups, with success stories including Kaspi, a Kazakhstani unicorn, and Smart Satu, a B2B inventory and logistics management platform. The region's digital trade services, e-commerce, and fintech startups are also attracting interest from South-east Asian investors. A partnership between Quest Ventures and QazTech Ventures has fostered a new generation of startup founders, propelling them to succeed in their respective Central Asia markets and eventually scale to South-east Asia.

site_title: Can carbon capture save the day?
summary: Carbon capture technology may play a significant role in reducing emissions in the shipping industry. Unlike alternative fuels, carbon capture can enable ships to continue burning heavy fuel oil or liquefied natural gas (LNG) while achieving zero carbon emissions. Industry leaders such as K Line and AET have successfully tested and invested in carbon capture technology, which can capture up to 99.9% of CO2 emissions. This approach could provide a pragmatic solution to the shipping industry's decarbonization challenges, allowing for a more gradual transition to net-zero emissions.

site_title: Pandemic-linked collapses, distressed asset sales to rise: observers
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has taken a toll on Singaporean businesses, with industries like retail, F&B, and construction suffering due to "vacillating rules" and caps on foreign workers. Market watchers predict an increase in pandemic-linked collapses and distressed asset sales as the government adjusts to an endemic state and withdraws support measures. This could lead to more insolvencies and troubled companies looking to sell off assets, exacerbating economic challenges.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 earnings fall 26% to S$213.3m on market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 26% fall in net profit to S$213.3 million for Q3 2021 due to unfavorable market conditions, resulting in mark-to-market losses. Operating profit rose 46% to S$248.7 million, while non-operating profit declined to a loss of S$4.6 million. Despite negative impacts from COVID-19, the company achieved a 29% growth in total weighted new sales to S$555.2 million. CEO Khor Hock Seng emphasized building resiliency and delivering solutions to meet customer needs amid the pandemic.

site_title: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia excavate forgotten kingdoms
summary: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia's Al Ula region are excavating remnants of the ancient kingdoms of Dadan and Lihyan, which flourished 2,000 years ago. The kingdoms, mentioned in the Old Testament, controlled vital trade routes but little is known about them. The team aims to uncover their worship rituals, social life, and economy. The excavation is part of Saudi Arabia's push to transform its economy and society, with Al Ula serving as a tourist destination to attract non-Muslim visitors and strengthen national identity. The project seeks to provide a comprehensive overview of the sites.

site_title: October a damp squib
summary: October's market activity proved to be a "damp squib" as feared, but a head-and-shoulder reversal pattern in the S&P 500 poses a significant threat. The pattern, observed on a weekly chart, indicates a trend reversal, with a potential downside target set by projecting the distance between the neckline and the head downwards. Oil's uptrend, driven by high prices, may continue to fuel inflation, potentially disrupting the S&P's uptrend. Smart traders should watch for early signs of the pattern's development, which can take weeks to months to confirm.

site_title: Tourism 2025: The future of tourism and hospitality for a tiny city-state
summary: Singapore's tourism industry is poised for growth as the country establishes new Vaccinated Travel Lanes with over 10 countries, bringing hope for the hospitality sector. However, the industry must evolve to offer unique experiences, leveraging cutting-edge technology and sustainable practices to compete with global metropolises. This includes preserving local art and culture, attracting world-class talent, and redefining luxury through narratives and experiences. By doing so, Singapore aims to become a "uniquely me" tourism proposition and attract high-end markets willing to pay for premium experiences.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.22% to 25,099.67, amid concerns over a fresh Covid outbreak in China that led to containment measures. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. Investors are increasingly worried about the impact of the outbreak on global markets.

site_title: Evergrande crisis, China property curbs pose near-term challenges for Singapore developers
summary: China's property sector is facing significant challenges due to the Evergrande crisis and government-imposed curbs, with several developers defaulting on bond payments and ratings agencies downgrading firms. This has led to a slowdown in new home sales, with China's leading developers experiencing a 32% decline in October. However, analysts suggest that Singapore-listed property counters with exposure to China may not be overly leveraged, and the slowdown could ultimately benefit Singapore developers by allowing them to acquire assets at lower prices.

site_title: Denmark, US and 12 other nations back tougher climate goal for shipping
summary: Denmark, the US, and 12 other countries have backed a goal to reduce global maritime sector emissions to zero by 2050. The initiative, led by Denmark, aims to build support for the goal at the International Maritime Organization (IMO) by 2023. Countries such as Belgium, Britain, and Norway also signed the declaration, while Japan and Greece did not. The move aims to decarbonize the sector, which accounts for nearly 3% of global CO2 emissions, and requires significant investments in green fuels and clean ships.

site_title: Singapore reports 3,496 new Covid-19 cases, 9 deaths; weekly infection growth rate 1.09
summary: Singapore reported 3,496 new Covid-19 cases, with 3,352 in the community, on November 2, 2021. The weekly infection growth rate increased to 1.09, up from 1.05 on Monday. Nine deaths were reported, bringing the total to 430, with 538 local cases above 60 years old. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 204,340.

site_title: Aussie dollar drops as RBA sounds dovish tone
summary: The Australian dollar dropped after the Reserve Bank of Australia sounded a more dovish tone, contradicting expectations. This comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, where markets expect the start of tapering asset purchases and a potential interest rate rise. The Bank of England's meeting is also anticipated to result in an interest rate increase.

site_title: Eurozone manufacturing activity crimped by supply-chain bottlenecks
summary: Eurozone manufacturing activity declined to an 8-month low of 58.3 in October due to supply-chain bottlenecks and logistical issues, despite strong demand. Input costs soared, with the input prices index reaching 89.5, its highest since 1997. Despite this, the sector remains strong, and the demand side continues to be robust. The European Central Bank's Christine Lagarde has warned that inflation will remain high for longer, and the sector's growth may be constrained by ongoing shortages and transportation problems.

site_title: BlackRock raises US$673m for climate-focused infrastructure fund
summary: BlackRock has raised US$673 million for a climate-focused infrastructure fund, exceeding its target, with backing from French, German, and Japanese governments. The fund aims to invest in renewable energy projects in emerging markets, aiming to mobilise private capital to tackle climate change. The fund's backers include state-owned development banks and philanthropic institutions, and has agreed to take losses before other investors. The fund is part of BlackRock's efforts to support emerging economies' transition to a low-carbon economy, with the need for around US$1 trillion per year by 2050.

site_title: Unresolved dilemmas from sustainability-linked finance
summary: Sustainability-linked finance, which incentivizes issuers to achieve environmental or social targets while reducing financing costs, has grown in popularity. However, two unresolved dilemmas persist: the omission of the "additionality principle," which ensures the impact is additional, and the risk of moral hazard, where investors and lenders benefit financially from companies' failures to meet sustainability targets. To address these dilemmas, industry stakeholders must establish a "business-as-planned" baseline, design robust metrics and targets, and explore the creation of concessionary funds to ensure the public good is prioritized.

site_title: GST on imports of low-value goods will level playing field for local businesses: Indranee
summary: Singapore's GST will be extended to low-value goods worth S$400 or less imported by air or post, and imported B2C non-digital services, starting Jan 1, 2023. This move aims to level the playing field for local businesses, defending the country's GST revenue base. The change is part of the GST (Amendment) Bill, which was passed by Parliament. Singapore is not the first jurisdiction to implement such measures, with other countries such as Australia and the European Union already doing so.

site_title: US unveils crackdown on methane from oil and gas industry
summary: The US has unveiled a plan to slash methane emissions from oil and gas operations by 74% by 2035, as part of its broader strategy to combat climate change. The proposal, set to take effect in 2023, requires oil and gas operators to monitor 300,000 well sites every 3 months and upgrade equipment to reduce leaks. About 100 nations have pledged to cut methane emissions, with US President Biden setting a target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030. Environmental groups have welcomed the proposal, but industry groups have expressed concerns about the costs and complexity of the regulations.

site_title: DBS says: reimagining wealth management for the digital age
summary: DBS Treasures introduces "smart wealth management" to help clients grow their wealth confidently in less time. The digital platform, DBS digibank, offers a Wealth Management Account, intelligent banking features, and curated insights from DBS's Chief Investment Office. Users can track investments, receive smart alerts, and access tailored investment ideas. DBS empowers relationship managers with digital intelligence to provide a unique, in-depth view of clients' needs. The platform is available to Accredited Investors with investible assets of S$350,000.

site_title: China's property crackdown helps reduce emissions - for now
summary: China's property crackdown has led to a slowdown in the country's housing production, resulting in reduced emissions. The economy slowed over the past three months due to a state-directed squeeze on real estate companies, which slowed construction. Economists agree that the period of rapid growth in housing production has ended, but differ on when and how fast the activity will decline. The country's commitment to cutting carbon emissions will depend on the extent of the reduction in housing construction. This temporary reduction in emissions may provide a short-term benefit, but long-term effects are still uncertain.

site_title: Reshuffle the Fed board now to signal policy continuity
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering reappointing Jerome Powell as chair, despite concerns about his hawkish stance on inflation. Powell's leadership has led to speculation about premature tightening of monetary policy, which could slow the economy and lead to fewer jobs. Replacing him with Lael Brainard, a Democrat and experienced Fed governor, is seen as a way to signal policy continuity and align with President Joe Biden's values. Brainard's expertise in macroeconomic policymaking and her commitment to worker outcomes and financial regulation make her a better fit for the role.

site_title: Singapore nears key metric tied to easing Covid curbs
summary: Singapore has reported its lowest number of Covid-19 cases since October 18, bringing the country close to a key metric tied to easing measures. The weekly infection growth rate, a comparison of seven-day averages of new cases, fell to 1.05 on Monday, below the government's target of 1. The ratio is critical for reopening plans, which could include allowing group dining and team sports, but hospitals remain stressed due to staffing shortages and a medical system under strain.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed ahead of Federal Reserve meeting
summary: US stock indexes opened mixed on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, where policymakers are expected to scale back bond purchases. The Dow Jones rose 0.06%, the S&P 500 fell 0.01%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.08%. The mixed opening was due to cautious investors amid uncertainty over the Fed's future actions.

site_title: Smart money on the go
summary: DBS Treasures, a wealth management arm of DBS Bank, has seen a significant increase in digital transactions among its clients, with a threefold jump in equity transactions and a 1.5 times year-on-year growth in forex transactions in 2020. This trend has continued into 2021, with the total value of unit trust transactions exceeding that of the previous year. Clients are becoming more proactive in wealth management, taking a self-directed approach, and leveraging digital tools to make investment decisions, such as the DBS digibank mobile app, which provides personalized investment prompts and real-time market updates.

site_title: Australia's central bank opens door to earlier rate rise, but pledges patience
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has abandoned its ultra-low target for bond yields, opening the door for an earlier hike in cash rates. However, Governor Philip Lowe emphasized the need for patience, rejecting market speculation of a potential rate hike as early as May 2022. This move is seen as a step towards unwinding extraordinary pandemic stimulus policies, but Lowe stressed the RBA will monitor economic conditions before making any decisions.

site_title: Why G20 may represent the future of global affairs
summary: The G20 summit has secured a landmark global corporate minimum tax deal, but its failure to strengthen climate change positions has frustrated many. Despite this, the G20 may represent the future of global affairs as a "multilateralism-lite" approach, where forums like the G20, G7, and Brics become increasingly important. This shift away from mass institutionalization of international relations is seen as a return to concert diplomacy, where key powers collaborate on long-term joint management of international relations, a concept that originated in the 19th century.

site_title: Japan Airlines narrows H1 loss on cost cuts, flags annual loss
summary: Japan Airlines reported a narrower first-half loss of 151.8 billion yen due to cost cuts during the pandemic, but flagged a wider-than-expected annual loss of 198 billion yen. The airline expects domestic passenger numbers to reach 92% of pre-Covid levels by March and international traffic to remain at 23% of pre-Covid levels. Japan's state of emergency during the second quarter and ongoing Covid-19 border restrictions have impacted the airline industry. Japan Airlines aims to stop burning cash by the fourth quarter of the financial year as travel demand improves.

site_title: Global energy transition spending to grow; Bank of Singapore sees opportunities in disruption
summary: Bank of Singapore expects energy-transition spending to accelerate further, driven by declining renewable energy costs and growing demand for clean technologies. Global energy-transition spending reached a record $501 billion in 2021, with renewables accounting for 70% of new-generation capacity investment. The bank sees opportunities in clean energy, green technologies, and enabling infrastructure, and believes the transition will create a virtuous circle that accelerates the energy transition. Despite disruptions to global energy markets, policymakers are expected to implement policies that encourage an even more rapid transition to clean energy over the next decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.71 points to 1537.63 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of 629 stocks over 404 losers. The index saw 3.654 billion lots worth RM2.705 billion.

site_title: Leaders at global climate talks pledge to cut methane and save forests
summary: Leaders at the COP26 global climate conference in Glasgow have pledged to cut methane emissions by 2030 and stop deforestation by the end of the decade. Nearly 90 countries, including Brazil and India, have joined a US- and EU-led effort to slash methane emissions, while over 100 national leaders have committed to halting and reversing deforestation and land degradation. The agreement aims to slow climate change and avert greater damage from intensified heatwaves, droughts, and storms.

site_title: Yahoo leaves China for good, cites 'challenging' environment
summary: Yahoo has stopped allowing its services to be accessible from mainland China, citing a "challenging business and legal environment". The move, effective November 1, follows Microsoft's decision to pull LinkedIn from China. Yahoo had previously scaled back its presence in China, operating a weather app and some foreign-language news pages. The company's departure comes amid Beijing's fresh curbs on internet companies and new laws protecting online user data privacy. Yahoo's decision is seen as a response to the increasingly restrictive business environment in China.

site_title: Dubai to launch US$545m market-maker fund, eyes 10 IPOs
summary: Dubai plans to launch a $545 million market-maker fund to boost trading on its stock market, aiming to list 10 state-backed companies, including utility Dubai Electricity & Water Authority, on the Dubai Financial Market. The move aims to make Dubai a more competitive market against Saudi Arabia and Abu Dhabi. The fund is expected to double the financial market's size to $3 trillion, with a committee overseeing the stock market's development and specialized courts for capital markets to be formed.

site_title: TLV Holdings has changed its name to Taka Jewellery Holdings
summary: TLV Holdings has changed its name to Taka Jewellery Holdings, effective from November 2, with its trading counter name on the Singapore Exchange changing to "Taka Jewellery" from November 8. The name change aims to increase shareholder awareness of the company's jewellery businesses, which the company plans to diversify into the moneylending business.

site_title: Liquidation plan for Eagle Hospitality Trust units is 'convoluted, complex and confoundingly dense': US Trustee
summary: The US Trustee has objected to Eagle Hospitality Trust's liquidation plan, citing its complexity and lack of clarity. The plan, filed by units linked to the beleaguered trust, has raised concerns that creditors cannot reasonably determine the feasibility of the plan and the proposed distribution of claims. The US Trustee has urged the Delaware bankruptcy court judge to deny the motion and relief sought by the debtors, citing insufficient disclosure and overly broad provisions.

site_title: ADB donors pledge US$665m to support South-east Asia's green recovery
summary: ADB donors pledge $665 million to support Southeast Asia's green recovery, bringing total pledges to $2 billion. The funding will go to the Asean Green Recovery Platform to mobilize $7 billion for low-carbon and climate-resilient infrastructure in the region of over 600 million people. The platform aims to accelerate investments in climate-resilient, environmentally sustainable projects and support sustainable development. Southeast Asia is vulnerable to climate change due to its long coastlines and heavy dependence on agriculture and natural resources.

site_title: Malaysia's Carsome seeking US$200m in pre-IPO funding round: sources
summary: Malaysia's online used-car marketplace Carsome is seeking US$200 million in pre-IPO funding, according to sources. The company, valued at US$1.3 billion, aims to complete the funding round in the coming weeks. Carsome, founded in 2015, has expanded into Indonesia, Thailand, and Singapore, working with over 8,000 dealers. The funding round is part of the company's plans for a potential US listing next year.

site_title: Taking stock of Bitcoin's merits and risks as a long-term portfolio asset
summary: Bitcoin's market capitalization briefly reached $1 trillion in April, then fell by half in three months before rebounding with a 40% gain in October. The article discusses the merits and risks of holding Bitcoin as a long-term portfolio asset, citing its unique opportunities and risks as a store of value. Bitcoin's limited supply, resilience of the core network, and self-custody features make it a viable store of value, but regulatory and institutional risks exist. Investors should consider diversification and be aware of the potential for losses, but also acknowledge the potential for significant gains.

site_title: BP to buy back an additional US$1.25b of shares
summary: BP plans to buy back an additional $1.25 billion of shares, using the proceeds of surging energy prices to attract investors. The company's third-quarter earnings rose to $3.32 billion, beating analyst estimates. BP has already completed a $1.4 billion share buyback and plans to increase the dividend by 4% annually if Brent crude remains above $60 a barrel. The company remains committed to its capital expenditure budget of $13 billion this year, with plans to increase investment to $14-16 billion from 2022 to 2025.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened mixed on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX index up 0.3%. Paris' CAC 40 remained flat. The US Federal Reserve is expected to announce plans to taper its stimulus, while the Bank of England is likely to raise interest rates amid soaring inflation.

site_title: Singapore has grand ambitions to become a global crypto hub
summary: Singapore aims to become a global crypto hub by implementing "strong regulation" for cryptocurrency-related businesses, according to Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The country seeks to balance risks with benefits, recognizing the potential for crypto to create jobs and value-add beyond the financial sector. Singapore has attracted crypto firms, including Binance Holdings and Gemini, and has issued licenses to a few companies, with the regulator assessing applicants to ensure they meet high standards.

site_title: Team Europe mobilises 783m euros for green infrastructure to boost economic recovery in Asean
summary: The European Union is contributing 783 million euros, including 50 million euros, to the Asean Catalytic Green Finance Facility to boost economic recovery in Asean through green infrastructure development. Team Europe, comprising the EU, its member states, and financial institutions, aims to help Asean countries build greener, fairer, and more sustainable economies. This contribution is part of a broader effort to address climate change and promote sustainable development in the region.

site_title: Singapore Business Federation leads 45 firms to China International Import Expo in Shanghai
summary: The Singapore Business Federation is leading a delegation of 45 Singaporean companies to the 4th China International Import Expo in Shanghai, showcasing products and services in various sectors. The SBF aims to connect businesses with new customers and suppliers, building on the success of previous expos where Singapore businesses secured over 21,000 leads and achieved S$1.7 million in confirmed sales. This year's expo features both physical and virtual elements, including a Singapore Virtual Pavilion, to expand business opportunities.

site_title: Singapore PMI stays flat at 50.8 in Oct following 2 months of slowdown
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sentiment remained flat in October at 50.8, unchanged from the previous month, marking its 16th consecutive month of expansion. This pause in slowdown follows recent trends since August.

images.alt_text: The purchasing manager's index (PMI) stood at 50.8 in October, unchanged from the previous month, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management (SIPMM).

site_title: South Korea firms plan US$5.4b investment to create vaccine hub
summary: South Korea's private sector plans to invest US$5.4 billion by 2024 in vaccine production and distribution, aiming to become a global vaccine powerhouse. The investment includes US$4.85 billion from Samsung BioLogics and US$1.5 billion from Celltrion. The government has selected 14 companies for state financial support, and President Moon Jae-in has designated Covid-19 vaccines as a national strategic technology to boost investment and localisation. This move follows a partnership with the US to combine expertise and production capacity, and comes after a plan was unveiled in May to create a global vaccine production hub.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend Monday's gains, STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,232.37, with Jardine Matheson Holdings and UOB among top gainers. The US stock market indices closed at record highs on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.6%. Analysts attribute investor optimism to the US corporate earnings season and tariff deal between the US and Europe, but warn of potential pullbacks in the near-term.

site_title: France pulls back in Brexit fish row, gives talks more time
summary: France has backed down from its threat to punish the UK for restricting access to British waters, giving talks more time. President Emmanuel Macron said the UK will come back with further proposals, and France won't impose sanctions while negotiations continue. The UK-France fishing spat, which had threatened to overshadow COP26 climate talks, is now being de-escalated, with Downing Street welcoming the move. Brexit Minister David Frost will travel to Paris on Thursday to hold in-depth discussions with France's junior minister.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales rise for 8th month
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 7.3% in September, its eighth consecutive month of growth, driven by a stabilizing Covid-19 situation, improved labor market, and economic recovery. Retail sales in value terms increased 8% for the first nine months of 2021, while online sales jumped 30.5% in September. However, tourist arrivals remained constrained, with visitor arrivals from January to September dropping 98.2% year-over-year. The economy's momentum has largely run its course, with longer-term prospects tied to the city's zero-Covid policy.

site_title: Japan opposition leader resigns after dismal election results
summary: Japan's opposition leader Yukio Edano resigned on Tuesday after his party, the Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan, lost 14 seats in the election, bringing its total to 96. Edano apologized for the poor showing, citing his inability to capitalize on public dissatisfaction with the ruling party's pandemic response. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party won a strong majority under new leader Fumio Kishida, with the party and its coalition projected to hold 293 of the 435 seats in the lower house.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retirement age remains crucial for older workers, with Tan See Leng emphasizing its importance as a safeguard against progressive employers. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) will have the option to step in and provide infrastructure for the energy sector. DBS is investing S$300m in 2022 to boost 'intelligent banking' capabilities. The Sandbox secured US$93m in Series B funding, while Temasek's offer for Sembmarine turned unconditional. Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,232.37.

site_title: China developer debt slump is engulfing even high-rated issuers
summary: China's high-rated property developer debt is experiencing a slump, with spreads on investment-grade bonds widening about 15 basis points from a 18-month low. Yield premiums on top builders like Country Garden Holdings and Shimao Group Holdings have surged, injecting volatility into the industry. Despite expectations that high-rated firms will weather the turmoil, tumbling home sales and cash crunches may exacerbate the issue. The concerns are linked to the liquidity crisis at junk bond giant China Evergrande Group and spillover from junk-rated Kaisa Group Holdings, which has seen high-yield dollar bond yields exceed 20%.

site_title: Maersk triples quarterly profit despite lower container volumes
summary: Maersk triples its quarterly profit to $6.9 billion, driven by record-high freight rates despite lower container volumes due to port congestion. The company expects its Ocean business to grow below global container demand, and will buy freight-forwarder Senator International for $644 million. Maersk also extends its share buy-back program by $5 billion. The company's transformation into an integrated logistics company has accelerated during the pandemic.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower after RBA decision; miners, banks drag
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, November 2, 2021, after the Reserve Bank of Australia abandoned its ultra-low target for bond yields and opened the door for an earlier interest rate hike. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,324.3, with miners and banks dragging the market down. The RBA left cash rates untouched, but dropped a commitment to keep yields on the April 2024 government bond at 0.1%.

site_title: Diageo to make whisky in China to woo premium drinkers
summary: Diageo, the owner of Johnnie Walker and Singleton, plans to invest $75 million to build its first whisky distillery in China, targeting premium drinkers. The distillery in Yunnan province will produce Diageo's first Chinese-origin single malt whisky, expected to be completed in 2023. The company aims to tap into China's growing middle class and increasing demand for premium products, with whisky sales growing by high-single digits annually over the past five years.

site_title: Businesses could face rising costs, cash crunch amid supply-chain snafus: Gan
summary: Singapore businesses face rising costs and cash flow challenges due to global supply-chain disruptions, Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong stated. Smaller and medium-sized enterprises may need to hold higher inventory buffers or provide favorable payment terms, requiring higher working capital. Construction companies also face higher costs for materials due to a global supply crunch. The government will continue to support small businesses through the Enterprise Financing Scheme and closely monitor essential goods prices.

site_title: OUE C-Reit's amount available for distribution slips 7.5% in Q3 to S$30.2m
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's (OUE C-Reit) amount available for distribution dropped 7.5% to S$30.2 million in Q3, driven by a 17.5% decline in revenue and 17.1% decrease in net property income. Despite slower leasing momentum, the commercial segment's committed occupancy edged up to 92% as of Sep 30. The Reit secured a S$540 million sustainability-linked loan and was included in the FTSE EPRA Nareit Global Real Estate Index, enhancing its visibility among global investors.

site_title: Shareholders concerned that SPH still undervalued, says Sias
summary: Shareholders of Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) are concerned that current offers to take the company private undervalue it, citing a net asset value (NAV) of S$2.18 per share. The media business has been separated from the main company, and shareholders question whether SPH should continue its operations independently. The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) will meet with SPH's senior management to discuss concerns and inform shareholders of the board's decision.

site_title: Digital Currency Group, parent of cryptocurrency exchange Luno, secures over US$700m investment round
summary: Digital Currency Group (DCG), parent of cryptocurrency exchange Luno, secured a US$700 million investment round led by SoftBank's Vision Fund II and Latin American Fund, valuing the company at US$10 billion. The investment round, alongside other equity investors including Google's Capital G and Ribbit Capital, adds to the US$25 million raised since DCG's formation in 2015. The company claims revenues will exceed US$1 billion in 2021 and is expanding its investment focus, including seed investments into new markets, public equity investing, and lending in the crypto currency industry.

site_title: Can a CBDC become a global currency?
summary: A central bank digital currency (CBDC) could become a global currency, offering a more secure, efficient, and energy-efficient alternative to private cryptocurrencies. CBDCs can streamline trading via smart contracts and enable settlements between individuals and businesses without the need for correspondent banking relationships. They can also reduce volatility and facilitate trade by enabling faster transactions at lower cost. However, implementation would require a political will among central banks and global commercial banks to reach a consensus, and addressing issues of dominance and control would be crucial.

site_title: DBS to invest S$300m in 2022 to boost 'intelligent banking' capabilities
summary: DBS Bank plans to invest S$300 million in 2022 to enhance its digital-banking capabilities, focusing on "intelligent banking" that integrates and analyzes data to provide personalized recommendations. The investment will bolster tech talent and infrastructure, and scale online and offline capabilities across the region. The bank's new platform, DBS Client Connect, enables frontline staff to provide hyper-personalized advisory to customers, with plans to roll out similar capabilities on digital platforms and mobile apps. DBS aims to measure the value of its intelligent banking capabilities through growth rates, with CEO Sim S. Lim suggesting a 20% growth rate could translate to a 5 percentage point higher return than the market median.

site_title: StanChart Q3 profit doubles as bad loans shrink, trade finance booms
summary: Standard Chartered reported a stronger-than-expected pre-tax profit for Q3, with a statutory pretax profit of US$996 million, doubling from the previous year. The bank's credit impairment charges decreased to US$107 million, and trade finance income rose 13% to its highest since 2018. Despite this, the bank's London-listed shares underperformed rivals, and CEO Bill Winters faces a challenge to convince investors of StanChart's prospects. The bank has US$18.5 billion in exposure to China's real estate sector and expects low credit impairment charges in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered rode a recovery in pandemic-hit markets to post a stronger-than-expected pre-tax profit for the third quarter on Tuesday (Nov 2), aided by lower credit charges and growth in trade finance.

site_title: South Korea to seek inclusion into MSCI's developed markets index
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Hong Nam-ki, announced the country's intention to seek inclusion into MSCI's developed markets index, citing its international economic status and foreign investor perception. This move is seen as a strategic step to increase foreign investment and boost the country's economy. The consultation with MSCI will be conducted to determine the feasibility of South Korea's inclusion. The announcement comes amid global economic shifts and trade tensions.

site_title: Apple cuts iPad production to feed chips to iPhone 13: Nikkei
summary: Apple has cut back on iPad production to allocate more components to the iPhone 13, citing multiple sources. The production of the iPad was reduced by half from the original plans for the past two months. Parts intended for older iPhones are being redirected to the iPhone 13.

site_title: SGX licenses its iEdge Bitcoin Index to MAS-licensed Propine
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has licensed its iEdge Bitcoin Index to Propine, a MAS-licensed digital asset custodian and Bitcoin exchange-traded fund service provider. The index, developed with CryptoCompare, tracks 165 global spot exchanges and was launched in September 2021. This partnership aims to provide low-cost and efficient access to emerging digital asset themes for investors. The move is seen as a major step for the region's asset managers and institutional investors interested in Bitcoin.

site_title: Retirement age still a crucial safeguard for older workers, Tan See Leng says, while not ruling out 'future changes' to road map
summary: Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the importance of statutory retirement and re-employment ages, stating they serve as a safeguard against unprogressive employers. He noted that proposed changes to raise the retirement age to 65 and re-employment age to 70 by 2030 are ambitious but achievable, reflecting the tripartite consensus. Tan also acknowledged that future changes may be necessary, while maintaining that a one-off Employment Assistance Payment for older workers will be increased in line with wage growth.

site_title: Some 8 in 10 Singaporeans still underestimate retirement amount by 31%: OCBC
summary: In Singapore, nearly 8 in 10 people underestimate the amount needed for retirement by 31%, according to OCBC's annual Financial Wellness Index. Despite this, 40% of Singaporeans have chosen a more prudent retirement lifestyle, with 66% having made retirement plans, but less than half are on track to meet their goals. The survey also found that digitally savvy individuals are more likely to manage their finances and investments effectively, but still need professional advice to plan for retirement.

site_title: Elon Musk goes viral on Chinese social media with ancient poem post
summary: Elon Musk posted an ancient Chinese poem, "Seven Steps Verse," on his Weibo and Twitter accounts, sparking a debate among Chinese internet users about its meaning. The poem, which describes the importance of getting along, was seen as a departure from Musk's typical cryptic tweets. Some interpreted the post as a reference to dog-themed cryptocurrencies, while others suggested it was related to a heated exchange with the UN World Food Programme's executive director. Musk's post gained over 100 million views on Weibo, with many praising his knowledge of the text and his departure from his usual messages.

site_title: Metaverse platform The Sandbox secures US$93m in Series B round led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2
summary: The Sandbox, a metaverse platform, has secured US$93 million in its Series B round led by SoftBank Vision Fund 2. Other investors include True Global Ventures 4 Plus, Animoca Brands, and Samsung Next. The funding will be used to scale the platform's growth as an entertainment destination for brands and creators. The Sandbox has generated over US$144 million in gross merchandise value and has over 500,000 users with a connected wallet. This investment marks SoftBank Vision Fund 2's first investment in crypto assets.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip as investors cautious ahead of RBA meeting
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with banks and miners contributing to the decline, as investors awaited the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,355.1. Investors are cautious about the potential for a sooner-than-expected interest rate hike. This cautious sentiment also affected US markets, with S&P 500 E-minis futures down 0.02%. The decline follows a 0.6% gain on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump most in 3 weeks on chip boost, finance minister remarks
summary: South Korean stocks surged the most in nearly 3 weeks on Tuesday, driven by chip heavyweights and positive remarks from the finance minister. The country's benchmark shares jumped, while the Korean won rose and the bond yield fell ahead of key central bank meetings. Investors also cheered the government's plan to seek inclusion into MSCI's developed markets index. The focus now shifts to the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England policy decisions later in the week.

site_title: ByteDance to reorganise, Singaporean CFO Chew steps down to focus on TikTok
summary: ByteDance's CFO Shou Zi Chew steps down to focus on running TikTok full-time, effective immediately. Chew will be replaced by an interim CFO. The company also plans a major reorganisation into 6 business units: TikTok, Douyin, Lark, BytePlus, Nuverse, and Dali. ByteDance's parent company, ByteDance, has shelved its IPO plans and will focus on its short video business. The reorganisation aims to create a more streamlined structure and improve efficiency.

site_title: EMA to be given option to step in and provide infrastructure, services for energy sector
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) in Singapore may be given the option to step in and provide critical infrastructure and services for the energy sector, ensuring its security and reliability. The proposed updates to the EMA Act, Electricity Act, and Gas Act will empower EMA to acquire, build, own, or operate critical infrastructure. This move aims to navigate the energy transition while maintaining Singapore's energy supply. The amendments are necessary to ensure the sector's resilience and sustainability.

site_title: Malaysia's auto, plantation and tech sectors to gain from 2022 Budget: Maybank KE
summary: Malaysia's 2022 federal budget is expected to benefit the automotive, plantation, and tech sectors, according to Maybank Kim Eng. The automotive sector is seen as a "clear winner" due to tax exemptions for electric vehicles, while plantation stocks such as Boustead Plantations and KLK are expected to benefit from an increased threshold for the crude palm oil windfall profit tax. The tech sector is also expected to gain, with a 2.7 billion ringgit investment outlay for the electronics and engineering ecosystem.

site_title: Shopback to acquire BNPL player hoolah
summary: ShopBack acquires 100% of BNPL platform hoolah for an undisclosed amount. The deal will expand hoolah's offerings to over 8,000 merchants across nine markets in Asia Pacific. ShopBack's recent $40 million funding round, led by Temasek, valued the startup at $539.4 million. The acquisition comes after reports of layoffs at hoolah and co-founder Stuart Thornton's departure. The combined entity will provide a broader platform for shoppers and merchants, with ShopBack CEO Henry Chan citing significant synergies between the two companies.

site_title: China property firms' shares, bonds take hit after Yango debt exchange
summary: China's top 20 property developers saw shares and bonds take a hit after Yango Group Co offered to exchange US dollar bonds for new notes personally guaranteed by its chairman to avoid defaulting on debt payments. Fitch Ratings and Moody's Investors Service downgraded Yango's ratings, citing liquidity risk and exposure to joint ventures. The downgrades led to a 4% drop in Hong Kong's mainland properties sub-index and a 3% drop in the CSI300 real estate index, with Yango's shares falling as much as 9% and its bonds falling almost 58% in value.

site_title: Japan eases Covid-19 border curbs, trails major partners
summary: Japan plans to gradually ease Covid-19 border restrictions, with quarantine for business travelers potentially cut from 10 days to 3, and daily border entrants raised from 3,500 to 5,000. The move is in line with major trading partners such as the US and EU, which allow entry to vaccinated travelers. However, long-term visas remain a concern for businesses, with the European Business Council calling for the easing of restrictions. The decision comes as Covid-19 cases have fallen in Japan, with a vaccination rate over 70% of the population.

site_title: Taiwan to woo backers at Apec for bid to join Pacific trade pact
summary: Taiwan is set to attend an APEC meeting to seek support for its bid to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a trade pact that excludes China. President Tsai Ing-wen asked Taiwan's representative to gather support from APEC members for Taiwan's membership. China opposes Taiwan's membership and has increased military activities near the island, raising tensions between the two. Taiwan's bid to join CPTPP has become a point of contention between Beijing and Taipei, with Taiwan arguing for its qualification to meet the pact's high standards.

site_title: A record year for Singapore fintech
summary: Singaporean fintechs raised a record S$3.1 billion in equity funding in 2021, more than doubling the global total of S$137 billion. Fintechs in the payments space attracted the most investment, with cross-border payment platforms like Nium and Thunes raising S$1 billion. Trading and investments fintechs also saw significant growth, with notable investments in cryptocurrencies and blockchain-powered uses cases. The sector's growth is attributed to government initiatives and a supportive ecosystem, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore announcing plans to link the country's national real-time payment system to Malaysia's infrastructure.

site_title: An Affinidi for secure technology
summary: Temasek-founded Affinidi aims to help individuals reclaim ownership of their digital identities by providing secure technology that allows personal credentials to be verifiable and cryptographically secure. The company has launched a product to verify Covid-19 digital credentials from over 2,000 healthcare labs worldwide and is running pilot programmes with airlines across the Asia-Pacific. Affinidi also sees potential in making financial services more efficient and inclusive through verifiable credentials, which can help small businesses access loans and reduce the time required to assess potential customers.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise on Tuesday, with central bank meetings in focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with key central bank meetings this week expected to see officials begin withdrawing pandemic-era financial support. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed 1.5% and Seoul also advanced, while Tokyo dipped. Analysts remain optimistic about market outlook, citing strong earnings season and seasonal strength. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, will meet this week, with a focus on inflation and interest rates.

site_title: China pledges boost in policy support for consumer services sector
summary: China's cabinet has issued guidelines to boost policy support for the consumer services sector, including increased financial support for small firms and individual businesses. The government will use monetary policy tools to guide commercial banks to boost loans, and local governments will offer tax incentives and public services infrastructure projects. The aim is to narrow gaps in social well-being between rural and urban areas under President Xi Jinping's "common prosperity" banner. By 2025, the number of college graduates in key sectors is expected to increase by 100,000.

site_title: Covid-19 restrictions in Sydney to ease weeks ahead of schedule
summary: Australia's largest city, Sydney, will ease COVID-19 restrictions for vaccinated residents ahead of schedule. Starting November 8, vaccinated residents can have unlimited guests at home, and pubs and clubs can reopen with more guests and dance floors. Initially set for December 1, these changes were accelerated to boost inoculation rates. The restrictions for unvaccinated Sydneysiders remain unchanged.

site_title: Getting certified on Web 3.0
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival (SFF) has introduced a Web 3.0 Knowledge Certificate in Financial Services, issued by The Asian Institute of Digital Finance (AIDF) at the National University of Singapore (NUS). The certification program features 45 sessions over three days, covering four modules: Inspirational Openings, Basics, Deep Dives, and Global Trends. Participants must pass a test for each module to receive an online Knowledge Certificate. The program aims to build a foundation for understanding the impact of Web 3.0 in financial services, addressing topics such as designing, building, and sustainable financial services.

site_title: Singapore taps potential in crypto, green economy
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) sees significant economic possibilities in a crypto or tokenised economy, which can facilitate cheaper cross-border payments and transform asset trading. This development comes as the country liberalises its financial sector. MAS managing director Ravi Menon noted the potential of this digital infrastructure.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Indian logistics startup Delhivery files for 74.6b rupee IPO
summary: SoftBank-backed Indian logistics startup Delhivery has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) of up to 74.6 billion rupees (S$1.3 billion), joining a surge of startups tapping the capital market in India. This year, 157 Indian startups have raised US$17.2 billion via IPOs, compared to US$8.5 billion last year, according to Refinitiv data. The IPO will consist of a fresh issue of shares worth 50 billion rupees and an offer for sale of shares worth 24.6 billion rupees.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 down 0.51% and the Topix index down 0.24%. This follows a strong rally in the previous session. The decline is attributed to profit-taking.

site_title: Temasek's offer for Sembmarine turns unconditional
summary: Temasek's mandatory general offer for Sembcorp Marine has turned unconditional after reaching 50.6% ownership. The offer, initially set at S$0.08, was accepted by 4% of Sembcorp Marine's total shares. Remaining shareholders have until Nov 3 to accept the offer, after which it will be closed. The move comes after Sembcorp Marine's shares closed flat at S$0.079 on Monday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise sharply at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.81% to 25,609.01, driven by gains in tech firms. The move followed another record on Wall Street. Investors are monitoring a key Federal Reserve policy meeting this week.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: Japanese shares ended lower on Tuesday, Nov 2, ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, which could reveal plans to taper stimulus measures and hike rates. The Nikkei fell 0.43% to 29,520.90 and the Topix lost 0.64% to 2,031.67. Earnings disappointment from Pola Orbis, Hitachi Zosen, and Kyowa Kirin weighed on markets. Despite some gains from TDK, Kyocera, and Dexerials, decliners outnumbered gainers 3 to 1, with all but 4 industry subindices in the red, ahead of a market holiday on Nov 3.

site_title: The next global lift for SFF
summary: Singapore's Singapore FinTech Festival (SFF) marks its sixth edition, coinciding with the 50th anniversary of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The festival explores the impact of Web 3.0 on financial services, with a focus on fostering dialogue between the public and private sectors. Elevandi, a non-profit organization, was established to promote this dialogue, and it now runs SFF, as well as other fintech events. Elevandi aims to create a global knowledge platform to drive business activity and address real economic challenges, with a focus on inclusivity, collaboration, and knowledge sharing.

site_title: Ant Group vies for a slice of SE-Asia's SME fintech market
summary: Chinese tech giant Ant Group has expanded its presence in South-east Asia's SME fintech market with a digital wholesale bank licence in Singapore and investments in e-wallet operators such as Ascend Money and GCash. Ant aims to be the go-to fintech partner for SMEs in the region, leveraging its experience in building Alipay to develop e-wallet solutions and provide cross-border mobile payments and marketing solutions. The company has also introduced blockchain-based solutions, such as Trusple, to help SMEs obtain financial services from partner financial institutions.

site_title: Tapping the network effect for a sustainable future
summary: Mastercard is implementing the "network effect" to tackle shared sustainability challenges, leveraging its global network of 3 billion cardholders, 70 million merchants, and 20,000 customers to bring environmental solutions to market. The company's Priceless Planet Coalition aims to restore 100 million trees by 2025, while its sustainability innovation lab develops eco-conscious digital solutions, such as a carbon calculator. Mastercard aims to bring 1 billion people and 50 million micro and small businesses into the digital economy by 2025, focusing on financial security, small business growth, and data science for social impact.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.47 points or 0.55% to 1,539.39 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of 285 to 145 stocks. The market saw a high volume of 286.25 million lots worth RM122.21 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open, tracking global gains; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Tuesday's open, tracking global gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,224.18. The mainboard-listed shipbuilder Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 5.7% despite a 25% rise in revenue due to higher raw material costs. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB advancing 0.9% each, while OCBC lost 0.2%. This follows overnight gains on Wall Street and in the European market, where stocks finished at fresh records.

site_title: Challenges remain even as Thailand moves to open border amid pandemic: report
summary: Thailand is set to open its borders in November, but challenges remain despite this move. The Phuket Sandbox programme has seen limited success, with only 1% of pre-pandemic tourist arrivals. The country has also detected its first case of the Delta-plus Covid variant, which could strain tourist arrivals. According to UOB economist Barnabas Gan, the economy will depend on further vaccination take-up, supporting domestic spending and foreign tourist figures.

site_title: South Korea's Oct inflation accelerates to near decade-high
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation accelerated to a near 10-year peak in October, rising 3.2% from a year earlier, driven by increases in oil products, fresh foods, and housing rentals. This marked the seventh consecutive month inflation exceeded the central bank's 2% target. Core inflation, excluding food and energy prices, rose 2.4% year-on-year, the fastest growth since December 2015.

site_title: California judge rules for drugmakers in major opioid lawsuit
summary: A California judge has ruled against several large counties in a major opioid lawsuit against four drugmakers, finding they failed to prove a US$50 billion case. Orange County Superior Court Judge Peter Wilson said Johnson & Johnson, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Endo International PLC, and AbbVie Inc's Allergan unit are not liable for creating a public nuisance. The ruling is a significant setback for the counties, which accused the companies of fueling the opioid epidemic.

site_title: Bank of England eyes first rate rise since 2018 as inflation surges
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise its main interest rate for the first time in over three years to combat surging inflation, which is at its highest level since 2018. Analysts predict a 0.1% to 0.25% hike in borrowing costs, following similar moves by other central banks worldwide. This decision aims to curb inflation and mitigate the impact of economies reopening from pandemic lockdowns.

site_title: Strategic reforms key to Indonesian MSMEs' greater contribution to the economy
summary: Indonesian micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) employ 97.2% of the workforce but contribute only 60% to the US$1.2 trillion economy. To increase their economic output, strategic reforms are needed in three areas: digitalisation, access to credit, and collaboration with larger corporations. This will enable MSMEs to reach their full potential and contribute more to the economy.

site_title: Philippine Fintech Mynt hits US$2b valuation with US$300m funding round
summary: Philippine fintech company Mynt has reached a valuation of US$2 billion after securing US$300 million in funding led by Warburg Pincus and Insight Partners. This funding round joins existing investors Globe Telecom, Ayala Corporation, and Bow Wave Capital. Mynt plans to accelerate its consumer lending business and introduce "buy now, pay later" products by the end of the year, capitalizing on the online shopping boom. This milestone comes after the collapse of the Philippines' first billion-dollar startup, Revolution Precrafted, more than a year ago.

site_title: Climate change main cause of fires in US west: study
summary: A study published by the US National Academy of Sciences found that climate change, primarily caused by human activity, is the main cause of unprecedented forest fires in the US western region. The study analyzed the "vapour pressure deficit" and found that global warming, largely due to human activities, is responsible for 68% of the increase in atmospheric water deficit over the past 20 years, contributing to conditions conducive to fires.

site_title: White House says 15 million Covid-19 shots will roll out to children by next week
summary: The US is rolling out Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccines for children aged 5-11, with 15 million shots expected to be shipped by the end of the week, but most will arrive next week. The FDA has authorized the vaccine, and the CDC will advise on administration. Parents can visit vaccines.gov to find locations offering the vaccine. The rollout follows a decline in coronavirus cases, hospitalizations, and deaths.

site_title: Nasa, SpaceX delay ISS mission again for medical issue
summary: NASA and SpaceX have delayed the ISS mission for the second time due to a "minor medical issue" with a crew member. The Crew-3 astronauts, including US astronauts Raja Chari and Tom Marshburn, will remain in quarantine at the Kennedy Space Center until their launch on November 6. The mission was originally set for October 31, but was postponed to avoid a large storm system. The crew will spend six months on the ISS, conducting research and spacewalks, and will replace four Crew-2 astronauts who have been on the station since April.

site_title: Art-house cinemas try movie subscription passes to bring audiences back
summary: Art-house cinemas are trying a new approach to attract audiences back after the pandemic and venue closures. Mubi, a streaming service catering to cinephiles, has launched Mubi Go, a membership program that offers a streaming service and a weekly ticket to see a hand-picked film at a local theatre. The program aims to provide curated content and support small, independently owned film venues. Mubi Go is initially available in New York and plans to expand to Los Angeles and other cities in 2022, with the goal of boosting attendance at art-house cinemas.

site_title: Hot stocks: Yangzijiang and Jiutian Chemical down more than 5% over latest news
summary: Shares of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Jiutian Chemical plummeted 5.7% and 5.8% respectively on the Singapore Exchange, with Yangzijiang reaching a low of S$1.30 and Jiutian Chemical hitting a low of S$0.079. The decline follows recent news, with Jiutian Chemical being the top traded counter and Yangzijiang as the third most traded counter by volume. The losses are attributed to the latest news, with no further details provided.

site_title: Barclays CEO Jes Staley resigns after Epstein probe
summary: Barclays CEO Jes Staley has resigned following a probe into his ties with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The Financial Conduct Authority and Prudential Regulatory Authority investigation found no evidence that Staley was aware of Epstein's alleged crimes, but Staley intended to contest the conclusions. Staley will step down as CEO and director, replacing CS Venkatakrishnan, who pledged to continue Staley's strategy. Barclays shares fell 2% after the announcement. The investigation was launched after Staley's relationship with Epstein was questioned by regulators.

images.alt_text: Staley (above) has previously said his relationship with Epstein, which he now regrets, ended in late 2015.

site_title: Amazon-backed electric vehicle startup aims for valuation above US$50b
summary: Rivian Automotive, an Amazon-backed electric vehicle startup, is targeting a valuation of over $50 billion. The company will price shares between $57 and $62, raising up to $9.1 billion at the midpoint. Rivian has raised over $10 billion in funding since its founding in 2009, including a $3.8 billion stake from Amazon. The startup is also producing electric trucks and SUVs for consumers, with prices starting from around $70,000. The news comes as governments prioritize electric car development and the global auto sector accelerates EV production.

site_title: Gold prices dip as US dollar firms ahead of Fed decision
summary: Gold prices declined 0.2% to $1,789.58 per ounce amid a firmer US dollar, as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The dollar index edged up 0.1% ahead of the meeting, which may challenge the Fed's balance between containing inflation and supporting the economy. Goldman Sachs now expects the first post-pandemic US interest rate hike in July 2022, citing elevated inflation. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also fell, while the Bank of England is set to make an unpredictable interest rate decision.

site_title: Livingstone Health H1 net profit rises 56% on strong demand for Sinovac vaccines
summary: Livingstone Health Holdings reported a 56% rise in net profit to S$2.1 million for its first half, driven by improved contributions from existing business segments and the sale and administration of Sinovac vaccines. Revenue jumped 97% to S$16 million, with growth propelled by the addition of doctors and new medical practices. The company expects its performance to improve in FY2022, driven by vaccine procurement and distribution, growth strategies, and lower RTO-related costs.

site_title: Biden, Indonesia's Widodo tell Myanmar junta to release prisoners
summary: US President Joe Biden and Indonesian President Joko Widodo called on the Myanmar military junta to release political prisoners and cease violence, amid a coup in Burma. They also expressed support for ASEAN's position on Myanmar and Indonesia's leadership in the Indo-Pacific region. The leaders agreed that a swift return to democracy is necessary, and Biden expressed support for ASEAN's stance on the issue.

site_title: WP's Jamus Lim proposes wealth tax of 0.5% to 2% on the richest
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party MP Jamus Lim has proposed a wealth tax of 0.5% to 2% on the country's richest individuals, with the goal of reducing income and wealth inequality. The tax would apply to net wealth exceeding $10 million, with rates increasing to 1% and 2% for wealth above $50 million and $1 billion, respectively. Lim argues that the tax could help diversify Singapore's revenue sources and minimize regressive components in the overall tax regime.

site_title: Over 100 global leaders pledge to end deforestation by 2030
summary: Over 100 global leaders have pledged to end deforestation and land degradation by 2030, backed by $19 billion in funding. The agreement, made at COP26 climate talks, aims to protect and restore over 13 million square miles of forests. The move is seen as a significant step towards reducing carbon emissions, with forests absorbing 30% of global carbon dioxide emissions. The commitment is part of a broader effort to combat climate change, with leaders also pledging to stop investing in deforestation-linked activities and support indigenous communities in forest conservation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Great Eastern, Livingstone, SPH, SPH Reit, Yangzijiang, PropNex, Ascendas Reit
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments on Nov 2. Sembcorp Marine accepted a mandatory general offer from Temasek, while Great Eastern posted a 26% decline in net profit. Livingstone Health rose 56% in net profit, driven by improved business segments. SPH and SPH Reit saw increased activity, with Cuscaden making a rival offer for SPH Reit units. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 20.8% decline in gross profit, while PropNex terminated its master franchise agreement in Vietnam. Ascendas Reit issued HKD 950 million notes with a fixed interest rate of 2.63% per annum.

site_title: Dune stays atop North American box office
summary: Dune maintained its lead at the North American box office, earning $15.5 million in its second weekend, while Halloween Kills took the second spot with $8.5 million. No Time to Die remained in third place with $7.8 million. Last Night in Soho, a new release, debuted in sixth place with $4.16 million. The Halloween weekend saw a slow start, but October became the best month for North American theaters since the pandemic, with $638 million in sales, and November may continue the trend with upcoming releases.

images.alt_text: Timothee Chalamet of Dune (above); Jamie Lee Curtis and Judy Greer in Halloween Kills; and Daniel Craig of No Time to Die.
Timothee Chalamet of Dune; Jamie Lee Curtis and Judy Greer in Halloween Kills (above); and Daniel Craig of No Time to Die.
Timothee Chalamet of Dune; Jamie Lee Curtis and Judy Greer in Halloween Kills; and Daniel Craig (above) of No Time to Die.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 earnings fall 26% to S$213.3m on market conditions
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 26% decline in net profit to S$213.3 million in Q3 2021 due to unfavorable market conditions, resulting in mark-to-market losses. Operating profit rose 46% to S$248.7 million, while non-operating profit was a loss of S$4.6 million. Despite the decline, the company saw strong momentum in Singapore, with a 29% growth in total weighted new sales to S$555.2 million. CEO Khor Hock Seng attributed the growth to the successful execution of distribution, product, and digital strategies.

site_title: Big consumers mostly insulated from attrition of electricity retailers
summary: Singapore's major industrial users of electricity remain relatively shielded from the risk of their retailers exiting the open electricity market due to their long-term contracts with gentailers, power generation companies. Despite rising power costs, industrial players such as Evonik and BASF have alternative pricing mechanisms and energy-efficient measures in place to manage their energy needs. Meanwhile, some retailers, which buy power from the wholesale market, have exited the market amid tight supply and strong demand.

site_title: WP MP Raeesah admits she lied to Parliament about sexual assault case
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party MP Raeesah Khan has admitted to lying in Parliament about a sexual assault case, retracting an anecdote she shared about a victim's experience with the police. Khan, 27, claimed she was a victim of sexual assault at 18, but later revealed she had not accompanied a rape victim to a police station as she claimed. She apologized to the police force, Parliament, and others, and faces a referral to the Committee of Privileges for breaching parliamentary privilege.

site_title: US dollar cements gains in big week for central banks
summary: The US dollar consolidated gains against its rivals, posting its biggest daily rise in over 4 months, as hedge funds cut back bearish bets ahead of a US Federal Reserve policy meeting. The dollar index hovered close to a 4-month high, driven by expectations of a potential rate hike by the Fed. Markets now assign a 50% probability of a 25 basis point rate hike by next June, up from 15% previously.

site_title: Oil rises on demand outlook despite China fuel reserves release
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as strong demand expectations outweighed concerns over China's fuel reserve release. Brent crude futures gained 1.1% to $84.71 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 0.6% to $84.05. The price increase was driven by a belief that OPEC will not rapidly cut production, despite China's release of 8 million barrels of oil from strategic reserves. The move is seen as a sign of confidence in the market's ability to absorb the additional supply.

site_title: Ryanair posts first quarterly profit since 2019 but sees annual loss
summary: Ryanair posted its first quarterly profit since 2019, with a 225m euros profit in Q2, but downgraded its annual forecast to a loss of 100-200m euros due to selling discounted tickets to fill planes over winter. The airline expects to return to profitability in 2023 and forecasts empty seats per plane will shrink from 20% to under 10% by next summer.

site_title: US: Stock indices end at fresh records, extending rally
summary: US stocks ended at fresh records on Monday, extending a recent rally ahead of key economic data and central bank announcements. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively. Investors are optimistic about corporate earnings, which have largely surpassed expectations, and await the Federal Reserve's announcement on pulling back pandemic monetary stimulus. The week's calendar includes earnings reports and the October US jobs report, which is expected to show a hiring surge.

site_title: Lenders fuel higher consumer spending in India with easy credit
summary: India's top lenders are fueling higher consumer spending by offering easy credit, with outstanding consumer durable loans reaching their highest in over three years. Financiers are eager to lend amid record low interest rates and an improving labor market. Businesses expect sales during Diwali to pick up, with some lenders, such as HDFC Bank and Axis Bank, reporting double-digit growth in retail loans. Economists attribute the expected recovery to government spending and vaccination efforts, which are crucial for lifting growth and incomes.

site_title: Europe: Banks power stocks to record highs after stellar October
summary: European stocks reached record highs on Monday, driven by strong earnings and expectations of interest rate hikes supporting bank stocks. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.7% to a record high of 478.87 points, with banks contributing a 1.4% jump. Euro zone bond yields surged, fueling the bank sector's best performance in over two years.

site_title: Britain tells France: Back down in 48 hours or we get tough
summary: Britain has given France 48 hours to back down in a fishing row that threatens to escalate into a wider trade dispute between the two European economies. The dispute began when France seized a British scallop dredger in French waters, prompting Britain to threaten tortuous legal action under the Brexit trade deal.
